div2.head: CHAPTER I
div2.p: tou= d' e)pigignome/nou qe/rous—the opening words introduced by de/ complete the sentence which ends the preceding book, tau=ta me\n kata\ to\n xeimw=na tou=ton e)ge/neto k.t.l. The third and fifth books begin in the same way. qe/rous—‘in the summer’; the genitive denotes the time within the limits of which a thing occurs, and is partitive in character (Madvig, § 66). Thucydides divides his history into summers and winters, thus reckoning more accurately, as he points out (v. 20), than by the names of the archons or other officials of the year in different states.

peri\ si/tou e)kbolh/n—lit. ‘putting forth (ears)’. Some time in April is probably denoted: see Arnold's note on tou= si/tou a)kma/zontos, ii. 19; and Jowett on ii. 1. The latter holds that the terms a)kma/zein and e)n a)kmh=| ei)=nai refer to the time when the corn was in full ear, though not ready for harvest. In Attica this would be about May 10—June 10, harvest beginning about June 15.
pleu/sasai—the order of the sentence shews that this word belongs to *surakosi/wn de/ka nh=es: the Syracusans put to sea, and after being joined by the Locrians went to Messene.

*lokri/des—Locri Epizephyrii, a colony founded by the Locrians of Greece, was in the S.E. of what is now Calabria. It was in alliance with Syracuse (iii. 86). Messene (now Messina) had been forced to join the Athenian confederacy the year before (iii. 90). A summary of its history is given vi. 4. i)/sai—‘an equal number’: iii. 75, i)/sas plhrw/santes.

kate/labon—‘occupied’, especially used of taking up a military position: cf. katalamba/nwn, ch. 3, 18: iii. 31, tw=n po/lewn katalabei=n tina/: so Plato, Gorg. 455 B, speaks of xwri/wn kata/. lhyis as a subject for military debate.
au)tw=n e)pagagome/nwn—‘the people themselves having invited them’; the preceding *messhnhn shews to what au)tw=n refers: cf. i. 136, feu/gei e/s *ke/rkuran, w)\n au)tw=n eu)erge/ths.

e)/pracan de)—the verb being placed first, the subject is divided into two parts, oi\ me\n *surako/sioi . . . oi( de\ *lokroi/, the respective motives of the allies being thus distinguished: cf. line 17.

o(rw=ntes prosbolh
 e)/xon—‘seeing that the place commanded, or afforded (lit. contained), an approach, or point of landing and attack’, i.e. it was the key of Sicily. So the Messenians are said e/n prosbolh=| ei)=nai th=s *sikeli/as, vi. 48; and an Athenian squadron despatched to the straits of Messene is said peri\ th
 prosbolh
 th=s *sikeli/as nauloxei=n, vii. 4. e)/xw is used in the same way in ch. 8, 40, a)po/basin ou)k e)/xousan, ‘not admitting of a landing’. From the idea of ‘containing in itself’ it is often used in the sense of ‘bringing with itself’, and therefore of involving or implying, the equivalent English depending on the context; e.g. i. 97, a)po/deicin e)/xei, ‘affords a proof’: ii. 41, a)gana/kthsin e)/xei, ‘gives ground of complaint’: ii. 61, ai)/sqhsin e)/xei, ‘causes perception’.
th=s *sikeli/as—objective gen. after prosbolh/n: so ch. 83, 6, e/pi\ th=| e)sbolh=| th=s *lu/gkou, ‘at the pass into Lyncus’.

e)c au)tou= o(rmw/menoi—‘making it a base of operations’ against Syracuse, lit. ‘starting from it’: so ch. 3, 22. pote/ —‘sooner or later, some day’: so ch. 60, 16. If the Athenians had possession of Messene, their command of the sea would enable them to collect forces and supplies there, so as to attack Syracuse at their own time.

Rhegium was on the Italian side of the straits of Messene. It was in alliance with the Athenians and Leontines (iii. 86). The Athenian ships under Pythodorus were apparently stationed there at the present time, but made no effort to save Messene. Pythodorus may have been crippled by a defeat he had lately sustained in an attack on a Locrian fortress (iii. 115).
a)mfote/rwqen—by land and sea: so ch. 11, 9: iii. 18.
e\s th\n *(rhgi/nwn—sc. gh=n: i. 44, th=| a:llh/lwn bohqei=n.

e)pibohqw=si—the subjunctive is more graphic than the optative, which according to rule should follow the pluperfect. ‘The historians, especially Thucydides, seem often to have
thrown themselves so completely into the past events which they recorded that those events became as present to them, and hence a form of the subjunctive group follows a historic tense. Sometimes indeed forms from both groups occur in a clause dependent on the same historical tense, as iii. 22, o(/pws a)safh= tense by the best Attic ta\ shmei=a toi=s polemi/ois h)=|, kai\ mh\ bohqoi=en. In such examples the subjunctive form often expresses the more immediate or more certain contingency, and the optative form the more remote or more uncertain contingency’ (Clyde's Greek Syntax, § 40, obs. 2). Apart from cases which can be thus explained, the subjunctive is constantly used after a historic tense by the best Attic writers, and in later Greek tends to supplant the optative altogether (Clyde, loc. cit.: Madvig, § 131 b).

cunepago/ntwn—‘joining in promoting the invasion’. ch. 84, 6. cunepa/gontes: ch. 79, 11, ai\ plhsio/xwroi po/leis cuneph=gon: so ib. line 7, e)ch/gagon to\n strato/n: i. 107, e)ph=gon. In such instances the active differs from the middle, the latter meaning ‘to invite’, i.e. bring in to one's self. The reasons of the Locrian invasion are given in two clauses of different construction, a final clause, i(/na mh/..., and a genitive absolute introduced by a(/ma de/.

e)stasi/aze—‘had been for a long while in a state of faction’. The imperfect shews that the state of faction still continued: this corresponds to the well-known use of the present to denote what is still going on, as nosei= pa/lai, ‘he has been long sick’.
a)du/nata h)=n—‘it was impossible’: so i. 59: ii. 72: iii. 86, ei) dunata\ ei)/h. Such neuter plurals are very common; see Shilleto on i. 7.

h(=| kai\ ma=llon e)peti/qento—‘wherefore they attacked them the more’, this was a further reason for choosing this time for their attack: cf. i. 11, h(=| kai\ ma=llon oi( *trw=es a)ntei=xon: iii. 13, h(=| kai\ ma=llon xrh/. With this may be compared the Homeric tw=|, e.g. Il. i. 418, tw=| se kakh=| ai)/sh| te/kon. e)peti/qento—lit. ‘set on them’: cf. iii. 72, e)piti/qentai tw=| dh/mw|, ‘they attack the democracy’.

a)/llai ai( plhrou/menai—lit. ‘others. viz. those which were being manned’, the definite article implying that such ships were in preparation, and contrasting them with those already afloat. Possibly ai( has got into the text from the end of a)/llai.

e(/mellon au)to/se e)gkaqormisa/menai—‘were intended to take up their position in the harbour of Messene’, etc. au)to/se implies the idea of motion to the harbour: so iii. 76, o(rmisa/menoi e)s lime/na: ch. 8, 26, e)formi/sasqai e)s. The place meant is
here determined by the preceding *messh/nhn: cf. the use of au)to/se, ch. 2, 13. o(rmi/zw and its compounds mean to bring (ships) to anchor, and in the middle to come to anchor. e/gkaqormi/zomai, ‘to come to anchor in’ a certain station, is not found elsewhere in Thucydides.

div2.head: CHAPTER II
div2.p: *peloponnh/sioi...e)se/balon—The Peloponnesian forces had invaded Attica every year since the outbreak of the war, with the exception of 429 and 426. Their ravages caused much suffering to the Athenians, who were driven from the country and crowded within the city walls. The distress was especially great in 430, the year remarkable for the outbreak of the great plague. The Athenians usually retaliated by ravaging the coasts of Laconia with their fleet. The phrase *peloponnh/sioi kai\ oi\ cu/mmaxoi is commonly employed for the allied forces, e.g. ii. 47, iii. 1, in which passages the invasion is described in almost the same words which are here used. The article is omitted before *peloponnh/sioi, as is not uncommon with proper names. Sometimes the omission has no particular force: at other times, as in ch. 10, 25, ‘I call on you, who are Athenians’, it calls attention to the particular characteristics of the people spoken of as bearing on the point in question. So we say, ‘Is this worthy of Englishmen?’ i.e. of men who, as being Englishmen, profess to be brave, humane, etc.
e)gkaqezo/menoi—‘taking up their position in’ the country.

ta\s tessara/konta nau=s—‘the forty ships which (as we have related) they were getting ready’; see iii. 115. The use of the definite article and of the imperfect tense has reference to presupposed knowledge in the reader.

*kerkurai/wn...e)pimelhqh=nai—‘to see to the Corcyreans in the city’. Two years ago the popular party in Corcyra had overcome the aristocratical party and massacred most of them. Five hundred who had escaped established themselves with a few auxiliaries on Mount Istone, and carried on a plundering warfare against the democracy (iii. 70—85). paraple/ontas is put in the accusative before e)pimelhqh=nai, though tou/tois to which it refers closely precedes it: cf. i. 53, e)/docen au)toi=s e/mbiba/. santas prospe/myai. Such a violation of strict grammatical principle is very common in Greek writers, who study above all things to avoid stiffness of expression.

timwroi/—‘to help those in the mountain, and because they thought’. timwroi/ is feminine, being a predicate in agreement with nh=es: so iii. 36, nh=es bohqoi/. After this nomi/zontes is introduced, in accordance with the sense of the passage, as if *peloponnh/sioi had preceded and not *peloponnhsi/wn nh=es: so i. 110, trih/reis e)s *ai)/gupton e)/sxon, ou/k ei)do/tes tw=n gegenhme/nwn ou/de/n.

katasxh/sein ta\ pra/gmata—‘would get the control of affairs’: cf. iii. 72, oi( e)/xontes ta\ pra/gmata, ‘those in power’. katalamba/nw ‘to get hold of’ is used in the passive with ta\ pra/gmata, iii. 30: and ta\ pra/gmata e)fai/neto katalhpta/ is found iii. 11.

o)/nti i)diw/th|—‘who had held no command’, lit. ‘who had been (and was now) in a private position’. i)diw/ths in reference to any profession or business means a layman or non-professional person. Demosthenes had been sent round Peloponnesus with an Athenian force the year before. He met with a severe defeat in Aetolia, but was more successful in Acarnania, where he headed the natives against the Peloponnesians and Ambraciots (iii. 94—98, 100—102, 105—114). au)tw=| dehqe/nti—‘at his own request’.

div2.head: CHAPTER III
div2.p: w(s e)ge/nonto ple/ontes—‘when they came in their voyage off the coast of Laconia’. The aorist gives the ‘end-view’ (Clyde) of their arrival off the coast, regarded as a single concluded fact, the imperfect e)punqa/nonto denotes the information which they went on to receive; it is followed by ei\si/, more graphic than ei)=en: see note on ch. 1, 13. For the somewhat uncommon combination of verb and participle e)ge/nonto ple/ontes, cf. viii. 86, 9: Ar, Ran. 36, h)/dh badi/zwn ei)mi/: Hdt. ix. 2, 1.
h)pei/gonto—‘were for pushing on’, the proper course considering the news which they received. For the imperf. see Goodwin, § 11, n. 2.

o( de\ *dhmosqe/nhs—‘but Demosthenes urged them to put in first at Pylos and carry out what was needful before continuing their voyage’: cf. ch. 17, 10, to\ de/on pra/ssein. sxo/ntas—so ch. 25, 44, sxou=sai: cf. iii. 34, e)/sxe kai\ e)s *no/tion: also with dative, iii. 33, gh=| sxh/swn: so iii. 32, prossxw\n *muonnh/sw|.

a)ntilego/ntwn de/—sc. tw=n strathgw=n, genitive absolute with subject not expressed: so e)lqo/ntwn de/, ch. 16, 22: 21, 14. This construction is not uncommon when the subject is easily supplied from the context.

kath/negke—‘drove the ships into Pylos’. The passive is more common; e.g. ch. 26, 26, a)ne/mw| katafe/resqai: i. 137, katafe/retai xeimw=ni: kata/ thus used in composition implies an approach to the coast from the sea or from inland; so iii. 49, e)pikata/getai, ‘comes into port after’.
teixi/zesqai—probably mid.: so (aor.) i. 11: iii. 105.

e)pi\ tou=to ga\r cune/pleuse—‘for he had joined the expedition for this purpose’, a statement on the part of the historian. e)pi\ tou=to is the reading of the best manuscripts, and the accusative is supported by e)f' a(\ a)figme/noi, ch. 18, 5: e)f' a(\ e)ch=lqon, iii. 111: e)pi\ tou=to, v. 87. e)pi\ tou/tw|, ‘with this object’, is however read by many. Most editors adopt the reading cunekpleu=sai, making the clause a statement by Demosthenes, expressed in oratio obliqua, e)/fh or a similar word being supplied from h)ci/ou: such a construction is common and presents no difficulty; cune/pleuse however has the best manuscript authority, and gives an excellent sense.

kai\ a)pe/faine—‘and pointed out (the existence of) good store both of timber and of stone, and (the fact) that the place was strong and uninhabited, as was also a great extent of the district’, lit. ‘both itself and (to) a great extent’. a)pofai/nw is found in this sense with a participle in vi. 54. e)pi\ polu/ is constructed as if it formed one word, and is followed by the genitive: cf. i. 50, (new=n) e)pi\ polu\ th=s qala/sshs e)pexousw=n, ‘covering a great extent of the sea’: ii. 76, tou= oi)kodomh/matos e)pi\ me/ga kate/seise, ‘it (a military engine) shattered a large portion of the work’: ch. 100, 14, e)sesidh/rwto e)pi\ me/ga tou= cu/lou, ‘a great part of the wood was plated with iron’.

a)pe/xei ga/r—the ancient territory of Messenia had been subdued by the Lacedaemonians, and the people driven from their country or reduced to serfdom. On the suppression of the final struggle for freedom in 455, the Athenians gave the Messenians a settlement at Naupactus on the Corinthian Gulf (i. 101—3). Demosthenes had acted with the Messenians of Naupactus in his last year's campaign (iii. 94, etc.). He proposed now to employ them in the occupation of some post in Peloponnesus, where their hatred of the Spartans, and knowledge of the country and the dialect might best be turned to account. For such a purpose Pylos seemed especially fit. It was far from Sparta, the district was uninhabited, the position was easy to defend, and it commanded an excellent harbour. The harbour of Pylos is identified with the modern Bay of Navarino; but the description given by Thucydides in ch. 8 of the narrowness of the two entrances is not in accordance with their present state. The southern channel is now some 1400 yards in width, and the northern not less than 150.
See Grote, vol. iv. ch. 52, and Arnold: also Jowett on the present passage.
*korufa/sion—diminutive of korufh/ = a little top or headland.

oi( de\ e)/fasan—‘they said that there were many desert capes in Peloponnesus, if he should wish to waste the city's resources by occupying them’. h)\n bou/lhtai represents in oratio obliqua h)\n bou/lh|, ‘if you (shall) wish’; not ei) bou/lei, which would become ei) bou/letai, as in ch. 2, 11: so ch. 2, 18. The generals wished Demosthenes not to insist on occupying Pylos, as he would find plenty of places equally useless. Their object was to reach Corcyra, without being delayed by Demosthenes' schemes.

dapana=n—commonly taken as governing th
 po/lin, in the sense ‘to use up, impoverish by expenditure’. In favour of this rendering a passage is quoted from Antiphon, de caede Her. 719, a)/ndra o(
 e)dapa/nhsan, ‘whom they had exhausted with torture’ (where however e)basa/nisan is also read), and the meaning is said to be common in late Greek. On the other hand it is simpler to retain the usual sense of dapana=n, ‘to spend’, and to make th
 po/lin the subject before the infinitive, katalamba/nwn, by a slight irregularity, being taken closely with bou/lhtai. The sense will then be, ‘if he wished, by occupying them, that the city should incur expense’. This view is supported by the fact that Thucydides uses dapana=n in other passages without an accusative following; i. 141, a)po\ tw=n au)tw=n dapanw=ntes: iii. 46, pw=s ou) bla/bh dapana=n; vii. 29, ou) boulo/menoi dapana=n. Rutherford rejects th
 poli/n. The suggested construction has some support from Ar. Vesp. 720, bo/skein e)qe/lwn kai\ mh\ tou/tous e)gxa/skein soi.
dia/foro/n ti—strengthened by the addition of e(te/rou ma=llon, ‘more than (any) other’: so i. 138, diafero/ntws ti ma=llon e(te/rou. ti is accusative ‘of respect’.

kai\ tou\s *messhni/ous—‘while the Messenians (he thought) would, etc.’ The construction is slightly altered in the course of the sentence. After the genitive absolute lime/nos te proso/ntos, which gives one reason for the importance of Pylos to Demosthenes, the next reason would be given regularly in a corresponding clause with kai/. Instead of this we have the accusative with the infinitive, dependent on the sense supplied from e)do/kei au)tw=|, as if ‘he considered’ or a similar verb had gone before. So v. 53, e)do/kei *)epi/dauron proslabei=n, th=s te *kori/nqou e(/neka h(suxi/as, kai\ e)k th=s *ai/gi/nhs braxute/ran e)/sesqai th\n boh/qeian, ‘it was determined to acquire Epidaurus both in order to keep Corinth quiet, and (because it was thought) that the voyage from Aegina would be shorter’.

oi)kei/ous o)/ntas au)tw=| to\ a)rxai=on: v. 80, 2, h)=n de\ kai\ au)to\s to\ a)rxai=on e)c *)/argous. o(mofw/nous—i.e. speaking Dorian Greek: for the same reason Demosthenes when he surprised the Ambraciots at Idomene placed the Messenians in front of his force as *dwri/da glw=ssan i(e/ntas (iii. 112). We are not told that Demosthenes had any Messenians at Pylos as yet: the arrival of some is related in ch. 9.

plei_st' a)\n bla/ptein...e)/sesqai—there is a difference of meaning between the infinitive with a)/n, and the future infinitive: ‘they would (be likely to) do the greatest injury to the Lacedaemonians, and would (be sure to) prove, etc.’

div2.head: CHAPTER IV
div2.p: u(/steron kai\ toi=s tacia/rxois koinw/sas—‘when he had afterwards communicated his plan to the taxiarchs also’, kai/, i.e. as well as to the strathgoi/. This is in close connexion with ou)/te tou\s stratiw/tas, and explanatory. Demosthenes, finding that he could not convince Eurymedon and Sophocles, afterwards appealed to the army at large by the agency of the taci/arxoi (regimental officers, see Arnold), to whom he imparted his views. koinw/sas—‘having communicated (the matter)’, without an accusative expressed: so v. 60: cf. viii. 48, tw=| plh/qei e)koi/nwsan.

h(su/xazen—‘he was detained in inactivity by stress of weather’. The plural has been suggested as giving a better sense than the usual reading, which would apply to Demosthenes alone. Some editors, reading h(su/xazen, place a comma after it and connect u(po\ a)ploi/as with sxola/zousi in the following clause; but this is an awkward arrangement of the words.

e)se/pese—this reading has the best manuscript authority, but has been commonly altered into e)pe/pese, on the ground that e)spi/ptw is not used by Thucydides with the dative or to denote emotions of the mind. e)pipi/ptw also is open to the objection that it is used by Thucydides not of mental emotions or ideas but of the attacks of disease or calamity. If an alteration be necessary, e)ne/pese would seem preferable: cf. ch. 34, 15, e)/kplhcis e)ne/pesen a)nqrw/pois: vii. 80, au)toi=s e)mpi/ptei taraxh/: cf. ch. 28, 25, e)ne/pese/ ti kai\ ge/lwtos.

perista=si—‘taking their stand round’, stationing themselves at different points round the works: Hdt. i. 43, perista/ntes to\ qhri/on, of hunters surrounding a wild boar. e)kteixi/sai to\ xwri/on—‘to complete the defences of the place’: ch 45, 13, e)cetei/xisan to\ xwri/on.

loga/dhn—‘picking out’, again used with li/qoi, ch. 31, 15; vi. 66, e)/ruma li/qois loga/dhn w)/rqwsan. It is an adverb derived from le/gw in the sense of picking out and setting in order; Hom. Od. xviii. 359, ai\masia\s le/gwn, ‘picking (stones for) walls’: so also loga/des (in Thuc. etc. of picked men) is used by Pausanias of picked (unhewn) stones: hence liqolo/gos (vi. 44 etc.) means a mason generally.

kai\ cuneti/qesan—‘and they put them together as each piece happened to fit in’: ti gives indefiniteness to e)/kaston, ‘each bit as it came, whatever it was’; the neuter seems to shew that other materials were used with the picked stones to fill in the interstices. Thucydides says of the walls of the Piraeus, i. 93, e)nto\s ou)/te xa/lic ou)/te phlo\s h)=n, ‘inside was neither clay (or mortar) nor rubble’, but all was built of squared stones. cumbai/noi is the optative of indefinite frequency (Farrar, § 177.6; Madvig, § 133), ‘as each (from time to time) fitted in’. ei)/ pou de/oi, in the next sentence, comes under the same rule, ei)/ pou being equivalent to wherever; and me/lloi in line 11 is to be similarly explained, ‘as (in each different case) it was likely to stay best on their backs’. Thucydides seems to have derived these minute details from an eye-witness, possibly from Demosthenes himself.

tw\ xei=re—so tw\ po/lee is found twice, v. 23. According to Cobet there is in the dual only one form for all genders of the article, pronouns, adjectives, and participles, viz. tw\, toi=n, tou/tw, a)llh/loin, le/gonte, etc.; ta\, tau/tain, paqou/sa, and the like, being the ill-advised corrections of grammarians and copyists (Var. lect. p. 69; Nov. lect. p. 695). Dual nouns are often found with plural predicates and verbs.

panti/ te tro/pw|—‘and so in every way they were eager to anticipate the Lacedaemonians by having completed the most assailable parts before they could attack the place’. te sums up what has gone before and continues the account. ‘bohqe/w and its compounds’, as Arnold points out, ‘never lose their proper notion of defensive movement, even when the particular operation is offensive. Thus the Lacedaemonian attack on Pylos was in order to recover possession of their own country’. e)pi/maxos, ‘open to attack’, occurs ch. 31, 14.

au)to\ kartero\n u(ph=rxe—‘was strong of itself to begin with’. Verbs thus compounded with u(po\ denote the ground or foundation on which is based what follows: e.g. u(poti/qhmi (more frequent in mid.), ‘to lay down as a premiss or basis of argument’: Eur. El. 1036, tou=d u(po/ntos, ‘with this condition to start with’; Ar. Vesp. 55, o)li/ga u(peipw/n, ‘after some prefatory words’; Dem. Pantaen. 973, u(pogra/yas e)piboulei=sai/ me
au)tw=|, ‘after starting with the statement that I plotted against him’. ou)de\n e)/dei tei/xous—‘there was no need of a wall’: the impersonal dei=, ‘there is need of’, must be distinguished from the personal de/omai, ‘I am in need of’.

div2.head: CHAPTER V
div2.p: oi( de\ e(orth/n—‘but the Lacedaemonians chanced to be keeping a certain feast, and withal when they heard the news accounted but lightly of it, thinking that when they had once marched forth either the Athenians would not stand their attack or they would easily take them by force’. So we find the Lacedaemonians remaining inactive during the Carneian festival (v. 54), and during the Gymnopaediae (v. 82). Herodotus (ix. 7) relates that in 479 they were prevented by the Hyacinthia from marching into Boeotia to aid the Athenians against Mardonius. ‘They considered it of the greatest importance’ he adds ‘to perform their duties to the god; and meanwhile their wall across the isthmus was in progress, and the battlements were getting fixed’. Jowett also cites Hdt. vi. 106 (before Marathon), and vii. 206 (before Thermopylae).

e)n o)ligwri/a| e)poiou=nto—cf. vii. 3: Hdt. ix. 42, e)n a)dei/h| poiei=sqai, ‘to account as safe’: so peri\ pollou= poiei=sqai and many like expressions; the verb meaning to make for oneself, and therefore to account, reckon, etc.

h)\ ou)x u(pomenou=ntas—this is the accusative absolute with w(s in the sense of thinking, ‘in the belief that’ (Madvig, § 182); with it is joined h)\ lhyo/menoi, in agreement with the subject of the sentence: cf. Dem. de Sym. 182, a)peble/yate pro\s a)llh/lous w(s au)to\s me\n e(/kastos ou) poih/swn, to\n de\ plhsi/on pra/conta.

kai/ ti kai\ au)tou/s—‘and in some part too their army being still before Athens detained them’, i.e. the fact that a portion of their forces was still away with king Agis. e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais—‘in the neighbourhood of Athens’: so ch. 25, 8, e)n tw=| *(rhgi/w|: ii. 2, h( e\n *potidai/a| ma/xh, ‘the battle at (as we say of) Potidaea’: Dem. Lept. 479, u(ma=s e)/xwn pareta)cato e)n *qh/bais, ‘at Thebes’: Plat. Rep. 522 D, e)n *)ili/w|, of the Greeks before Troy. e)pe/sxe—‘checked, held back’: i. 129, kai/ se mh/te nu\c mh/q' h\me)ra e)pisxe/tw: more often intrans. as ch. 31, 2.

to
 plou=n...h)pei/gonto—‘pushed on with their voyage to Corcyra and Sicily’: so viii. 9, e)peigome/nwn to
 plou=n: iii. 2, th
 paraskeuh
 e)pei/gontai: usually intransitive, ‘to hasten on’, as in ch. 3, 4. Note the position of kai\ *sikeli/an, two words which are part of the epithet of plou=n. When the epithet of a
substantive consists of several words, a portion of these words may be placed otherwise than between the article and substantive; e.g. iii. 56, kata\ to
 pa=si no/mon kaqestw=ta: vi. 31, th
 th=s po/lews a)na/lwsin dhmosi/an. In ch. 24, 18, we have a similar order: see also note on ch. 90, 7.

div2.head: CHAPTER VI
div2.p: w(s e)pu/qonto th=s *pu/lou kateilhmme/nhs—‘when they heard of the occupation of Pylos’. Thucydides more commonly uses the accusative participial construction with punqa/nomai: ch. 50, 17, puqo/menoi *)artace)rchn teqnhko/ta, etc.; in accordance with the principle that verbs of hearing take the accusative of the sound heard, and the genitive of that which produces it. As this however is not an invariable rule, so with punqa/nomai the genitive of the thing heard of is not unfrequent, especially in poetry; ou)d ei)/ ken tou= patro\s a)pofqime/noio puqoi/mhn, Hom. Il. xix. 322.

nomi/zontes me/n—the order of words is to be carefully observed. The reasons for the Peloponnesians leaving Attica at once are given in three clauses, nomi/zontes me/n..., a(/ma de/... e)spa/nizon..., xeimw/n te k.t.l. The first of these clauses is limited in its application by the introduction of the words oi( *lakedai/monioi kai\ *)/agis, ‘thinking, that is, Agis and the Lacedaemonians thinking’; the Lacedaemonians alone having a vital interest in Pylos. This is a construction of partial apposition, like ch. 38, 1, oi( de\ a)kou/santes parh=kan ta\s a)spi/das oi( plei=stoi, ‘dropped their shields, that is, most of them did so’: cf. i. 49, where dedio/tes oi( strathgoi/ is placed in apposition with ai( *attikai\ nh=es. In the next clause the construction is changed after the participle e)sbalo/ntes, the finite verbs e)spa/nizon and e)pi/ese giving the second and third reasons for retreat.

oi)kei=on sfi/si—‘thinking that the matter of Pylos touched them nearly’. oi)kei=os, ‘concerning one's self’, is the opposite of a)llo/trios: iii. 13, a)llotri/as gh=s pe/ri oi)kei=on ki/ndunon e(/cein.

toi=s polloi=s—according to Classen ‘for their large numbers’; but there is no reason to suppose that the expression has not its usual meaning ‘for the greater part’. No doubt the want of supplies would be felt throughout the army; but the chiefs and officers would not suffer like the rest of the troops (oi( polloi/): see also vii. 84 fin.

xeimw/n te—‘stormy, wintry weather’: so iii. 21, xeimw\n notero/s, ‘stormy and rainy weather’. mei/zwn para/—‘with greater violence than was to be looked for at the time of the year then
present’; lit. ‘greater, going beyond’; nearly = mei/zwn h)\ kata/: so i. 23, pukno/terai para/. th\n kaqesthkui=an w(/ran—lit. ‘the (then) settled season’, i. e. the spring, when finer weather might be expected to set in.
pollaxo/qen—‘from many causes’: Dem. Con. 1261, pollaxo/qen dh=lon: so i. 17, pantaxo/qen, ‘from all causes’, etc.

div2.head: CHAPTER VII
div2.p: *)hio/na—where this place was is disputed: it was not Eion on the Strymon, which had been held by the Athenians since its capture by Cimon in 476 (i. 98). The mothercity Mende was on Pallene, the most westerly of the three Chalcidian peninsulas, and Eion may have been in the same district, which is also indicated by the proximity of the Chalcidians and Bottiaeans. The name means ‘shore’. th\n e)pi\ *qra/|khs—so ta\ e)pi\ *qra/|khs, the usual form by which Thucydides denotes the ‘Thrace-ward regions’.

polemi/an de/—‘but hostile’, thus differing from Mende, which was now in alliance with Athens, though it revolted two years after, ch. 123: cf. vi. 62, po/lisma *sikaniko\n me\n *)egestai/ois de\ pole/mion.
e)k tw=n frouri/wn—from the various points on the coast which were occupied by the Athenians during the war.

prodidome/nhn—the present, or rather, imperfect participle gives the meaning ‘which was to be betrayed’ in accordance with a previous understanding: so iii. 18, e)pi\ *mh/qumnan w(s prodidome/nhn e)stra/teusan.
e)cekrou/sqh—‘was driven out and lost many of his men’: e)kkrou/w is used to denote dislodging an enemy, iv. 102, 128, etc.

div2.head: CHAPTER VIII
div2.p: a)naxwrhsa/ntwn de\ tw=n e)k th=s *)attikh=s—this is called a pregnant construction, containing the two ideas ‘when the Peloponnesians in Attica had retired from it’: so ch. 16, 20: 19, 5, a)ntaitou=ntes tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou a)/ndras.

oi( *spartia=tai—the fully-privileged citizens of Sparta itself, who alone were eligible to public offices: the peri/oikoi were the inhabitants of the townships of Laconia, who though free had no voice in the government.

perih/ggellon...bohqei=n—‘and they sent round word also over Peloponnesus to march’: so ii. 10, perih/ggellon stratia\n paraskeua/zesqai: also with an accusative of the thing demanded, vii. 18, si/dhron perih/ggellon, ‘they sent round orders for iron’: this corresponds to the use of impero with frumentum, pecuniam, obsides, etc.; and the English ‘to order’ supplies, etc.

u(perenexqei=sai—‘after being carried over the Leucadian isthmus’: so iii. 81, u(perenegko/ntes to\n *leukadi/wn i/sqmo\n ta\s nau=s: the same construction, viii. 7. Leucas (now Sauta Maura) was afterwards turned into an island by cutting through the isthmus which connected it with the mainland. In 428 we find the Lacedaemonians preparing machines (o(lkoi/) to transport (w(s u(peroi/sontes) a fleet over the isthmus of Corinth (iii. 15): and in 412 twenty-one ships were conveyed across it (viii. 7, 8).

ta\s e)n *zaku/nqw|—so far had the Athenian fleet advanced on the way to Corcyra. Zacynthus (now Zante) was much nearer than Leucas to Pylos. It was faithful to the Athenians throughout the war, and was an important link in the chain of naval stations which enabled the Athenians to command the coast of Peloponnesus (ii. 7, 80).

w(s tou= xwri/ou—‘since the place was in danger’; w(s with the genitive absolute gives the ground on which Demosthenes called for speedy succour, stated as a fact; thus differing from the accusative construction, which expresses belief or opinion: see note on ch. 5, 3.

kai\ ai( me\n nh=es. oi) de/—note the force of the imperfect tenses: the Athenian ships ‘were on their way’ to obtain help, the Lacedaemonians on their side ‘were engaged in’ preparations for the attack. Classen takes ai( men nh=es to mean the Athenian ships at Zacynthus, which ‘were getting ready for the voyage’ to help Pylos. This perhaps gives a greater force to kata\ ta\ e)pestalme/na, ‘in accordance with the orders of Demosthenes’, i.e. his urgent demand for speedy aid.

dia\ taxe/wn ei)rgasme/non—‘a work hastily constructed and occupied by a small force’: after the passive participle agreeing with oi)kodo/mhma comes the genitive absolute with an active participle. For other variations of participial construction see the opening clauses of chs. 28, 29, and 32.

e)n nw=| ei)=xon—‘they purposed’: ch. 22, 7, e)n nw=| e)/xontas, ‘intending’: so Hdt. i. 27, e)/xontes e)n nw=| strateu/esqai, ‘intending to march’: so in Latin, Liv. vi. 19, nobis in animo est. On
the other hand nw=| e)/xein without e)n means to remember: Plat. Gorg. 490 A, ei) nw=| e)/xeis, ‘if you bear in mind’: so Hdt. v. 92 (7), no/w| i)/sxwn.
h)\n a)/ra mh/—‘if they should fail to take it’: a)/ra with ei) and h)/n has the force of if after all, if, which I do not expect.

o(/pws mh\ h)=|—‘that it might not be possible for the Athenians to enter and take up a position against them’: e)/sti ‘it is possible’ is most commonly found with a negative: ch. 9, 8, ou)k h)=n o(/pla pori/sasqai. For the meaning of o(rmi/zomai, and its construction with e)s, see note on ch. 1, 19: the compound with e)pi/ is only found here in Thucydides; it corresponds to the neuter verb e)forme/w, ‘to lie at anchor over against, to blockade’, and to the substantives e)fo/rmhsis and e)/formos.

h( ga\r nh=sos h( *sfakthri/a—the fortress of Pylos was at the northern extremity of the bay, the harbour being the bay itself, which was rendered secure by the island of Sphacteria. The island lay north and south across the bay, leaving two narrow entrances which the Lacedaemonians now proposed to block up. Sphacteria is almost certainly the Sphagia of ancient writers and of modern days: cf. Plat. Menex. 242 c, labo/ntes au)tw=n tou\s h(ge/monas *lakedaimoni/ous e)n th=| *sfagi/a|. The description given by Thucydides is however not free from topographical difficulties: see note on ch. 3, 14.

paratei/nousa—‘stretching along’: tei/nw and its compounds are sometimes used intransitively of geographical position. e)ggu\s e)pikeime/nh—‘lying close off’: so ch. 44, 28, e)s ta\s e)pikeime/nas nh/sous.

th=| me/n...th=| de/—‘at one point...at the other’. dia/ploun—‘a passage for two ships (abreast)’; the accusative is in apposition to the preceding e)/splous. h( a)/llh h)/peiros is the main land on the south of the harbour, which was now occupied by the Lacedaemonians.

kai\ me/geqos—‘and in length was about 15 stades pretty nearly’; both peri/ and ma/lista are used in the sense of ‘about’ to give dimensions roughly. Fifteen stades would be about 3000 yards, whereas the modern Sphagia is said to be upwards of 2 1/2 miles in length.

a)ntiprw/rois—‘with the prows facing the enemy’: so ch. 14, 4, a)ntiprw/rous: vii. 34, nh=es a)nti)prwroi e)mballo/menai, ‘ships struck bow to bow’: vii. 36, to\ a)nti/prwron cugkrou=sai, ‘ramming stem-on’: Tac. Hist. ii. 14, conversa et minaci fronte. bu/zhn—‘closely’ from bu/w ‘to stuff full’. The entrances were
so narrow that it was possible to close them by placing the ships side by side with their beaks pointing outwards. On the other hand in 413 the Syracusans closed the mouth of their harbour by anchoring their ships cross-ways (plagi/ais), having a much wider entrance to secure (vii. 59).

ou(/tw ga/r—‘for so, they considered, both the island would be hostile to the Athenians and the main land, which did not admit of landing’. e)/sesqai, like the subsequent e(/cein and e)kpoliorkh/sein, depends on the sense ‘they hoped, they expected’ supplied from the preceding sentence: see note on e)pi\ tou=to ga\r cunekpleu=sai, ch. 3, 10. For e)/xousan see note on prosbolh\n e)/xon ch. 1, 7: similarly ou)x e(/cein o(/qen, line 42, means ‘would not present a point from which’.

ta\ ga\r au)th=s th=s *pu/lou—the coast to the north of the bay, facing the main sea. This offered no harbour where the Athenians could establish a naval station, such as was occupied by the English at Balaclava. The island of Sphacteria was held by the enemy's troops, as was also the mainland to the south forming the shore of the bay. Thus the Athenian fleet would be unable to succour their countrymen in Pylos, and the garrison being unprovided must shortly surrender.
w)felh/sousi tou\s au(tw=n—indic. fut. after o(/qen: so i. 107, ske/yasqai o(/tw| tro/pw| diaporeu/sontai, ‘in what way they should cross’.

si/tou te ou)k e)no/ntos—‘as there was no provision in the place, and it had been occupied with slender preparation’; the gen. abs. is here followed by the participle agreeing with xwri/on; see note on line 21. I follow Classen in reading kateilhmme/non for the MSS. kateilhmme/nou, which would be gen. abs. agreeing with xwri/ou understood. di' o)li/ghs paraskeuh=s is one of the many adverbial expressions with dia/, like dia\ profulakh=s, ch. 30, 5.

w(s d' e)do/kei...kai\ diebi/bazon—‘as they determined, so they sent the men across, selecting them by lot from all the lochi’, lit. ‘went on to send’. The lochus was one of the larger divisions of the Spartan army: see Arnold's note on v. 68, where a calculation is made of the Lacedaemonian force present at the field of Mantinea in 418, when seven lo/xoi were engaged: see also Grote, vol. ii. ch. 8, on the military divisions of Sparta.

oi( de\ teleutai=oi—‘those who crossed last and were caught in the island’, i.e. whose retreat was cut off by the Athenians; or those who were ‘taken in it’ on its capture, in
which case the slain are included, cf. ch. 38, 30. e)gkatalhfqe/ntes —ch. 116, 5, o)/sous e)gkate/labe, ‘all that he captured in the city’: so iii. 33, (nh=es) e)gkatalhfqei=sai, ‘caught in a place’.

kai\ *ei(/lwtes oi( peri\ au)tou/s—‘besides the Helots attached to their service’, called qera/pontes ch. 16, 11; their number is not stated, possibly each Lacedaemonian had one in attendance on him. The Helots, or country serfs, the main body of whom were Messenian Dorians, were often employed in military service. Thus in 424 they furnished seven hundred heavy-armed men for the expedition led by Brasidas into Thrace (ch. 80).

div2.head: CHAPTER IX
div2.p: ta\s trih/reis—three in number, five having been left at first with Demosthenes, two of which he had despatched to Zacynthus. Classen suggests ai(\ perih=san au(tw=|, ‘which he had remaining’, instead of ai(/per h)=san, there being no obvious reason for the use of o(/sper in the passage.

a)naspa/sas u(po\ to\ tei/xisma—‘having dragged up under the fortifications and secured with a stockade’. prosestau/rwsen—either ‘put a stockade to’ the ships, or ‘added them by a stockade to’ the line of defence, i.e. included them in an outwork of palisading. Thus the Greeks intrenched their fleet at Troy, and the Persians at Mycale (Hdt. ix. 96, 7). proestau/rwse, ‘put palisades before’, has been proposed as a correction: the word is used vi. 75, th\n qa/lassan proestau/rwsan, of the Syracusans who fringed their shores with stakes, to prevent the Athenians from landing near the city.

a)spi/si te fau/lais—‘with poor shields and for the most part wicker’. Here we must either regard te as out of place, te and kai\ coupling fau/lais and oi)sui+/nais, or we must consider that the sentence is irregular in construction, beginning as if a second substantive were to be connected with a)spi/si. Similar irregularities in the position of te are common, e.g. ch. 10, 9, h)\n e)qe/lwme/n te mei=nai kai\ mh\...kataprodou=nai.

For a full discussion of the usage of te see Jowett on i. 9, kai\ nautikw=| te a(/ma: also Shilleto on the same passage. Both authorities consider that the word sometimes bears in Thucydides the sense of too, which is found in lyric and dramatic poetry and in Herodotus.

e)k lh|strikh=s—‘from a piratical thirty-oared boat and a pinnace belonging to certain Messenians who happened to have arrived’; doubtless Messenians from Naupactus, who
were plundering the Laconian coast. Both lh|strikh=s and triakonto/rou are adjectives agreeing with new/s understood. A ke/lhs or kelh/tion is mentioned as accompanying a trireme, ch. 120, 10.

o(pli=tai/ te—‘of these Messenians was made up a force of about forty heavy-armed men’: gi/gnomai is very commonly used of numbers in the sense of amounting to: ch. 23, 18, ai pa=sai e(bdomh/konta e)ge/nonto: cf. ch. 39, 1.

tou\s me\n ou)=n pollou/s—‘the greater part both of those without (full) arms and of those who were armed’. By o(/pla is denoted especially the full equipment of a heavy-armed soldier (o)pli/ths): so o(/pla e)/xontes, ch. 33, 17.

We are not told the total number of the men under Demosthenes, but we can make an approximate calculation. He had forty Messenians, and the crews of three triremes. A trireme was manned by about 170 rowers (nau=tai), some half-dozen officers, and a certain number of e)piba/tai, heavy-armed men serving as marines. Of these last there were at this time 10 to each ship, according to Arnold's note on iii. 95: Classen says 20: see also Grots, vol. iv. ch. 49. When the two ships were sent to Zacynthus their e)piba/tai may have been left at Pylos. Thus the whole Athenian force amounted to about 600 men, the greater part hastily and imperfectly armed.
a)poleca/menos—‘having picked out for himself’: the middle participle is similarly used with au)to/s, v. 8.
e)/cw tou= tei/xous—Demosthenes expected that the descent of the enemy would be made on the point beneath the walls of Pylos, outside the bay on the north and looking toward the main sea.

e)s xwri/a me/n...sfi/si de/—the two clauses with me/n and de/ give the pros and cons for attacking at the point in question; on the one hand (me/n) landing was difficult, on the other (de/) the works were here incomplete: the clauses do not however correspond in construction, e)s xwri/a me/n being connected with a)pobai/nein, while in the second clause the finite verb h(gei=to is introduced.

sfi/si de\ tou= tei/xous—‘as their wall was weakest at this point’: sfi/si corresponds to h(mi=n in oratio directa, and includes both Demosthenes and his men; sfei=s and sfe/teros being often thus used in reference to the thought or words of a single person. ‘Our wall is here the weakest’ says Demosthenes: so v. 72, keleu/santos au)tou= sfi/si prosmi/cai, ‘when (Agis) had given the order—close up to us’ see note on ch. 36, 3, a)/llws e)/fh ponei=n sfa=s.

e)pispa/sasqai au)tou/s—these words present considerable difficulty. We have, dependent on h(gei=to, the aorist middle e)pispa/sasqai, followed by the future proqumhqh/sesqai. e)pispa/sasqai is transitive in sense, meaning ‘to draw to oneself, induce’ with inf., as in v. 111: so e)pispa=sqai with inf. Xen. Cyr. v. 5. 10. The natural meaning of the construction is, ‘he thought that he had drawn them on so that they would be eager’; but this is not satisfactory in sense. The meaning required is, ‘he considered that it (the weakness of the works) would draw them on to be eager’. Besides the awkwardness thus involved in supplying the subject to e)pispa/sasqai from the genitive absolute tou= tei/xous o)/ntos, this necessitates giving a future meaning to the aor. inf. following h)gei=to. Whether it will bear such a meaning is by no means clear. The same question arises on ii. 3, e)no/misan krath=sai: and perhaps on iii. 24, nomi/zontes u(potoph=sai.

There is no doubt that the aor. inf. is used in reference to future things after phrases denoting expectation, such as e)lpi/zein, e)lpi/s e)stin, ei)ko/s e)stin etc.: but it does not follow that words which express merely a thought or statement, like h(gei=to in this passage, can be used in the same way. Madvig (§ 172 R.) considers that instances of such construction ‘undoubtedly rest upon a false reading, either a)/n having been accidentally omitted, or the aorist written by mistake for the future’. Goodwin however (Greek Moods and Tenses § 32) points out that ‘unless we decide to correct a large number of passages against the authority of the MSS, we must admit even this anomalous construction; although it is to be considered strictly exceptional’.

In the passage before us it is perhaps best to cut the knot by reading the fut. e)pispa/sesqai, passive in sense, with au)tou/s as its subject—‘he considered that they would be led on to be eager’, or possibly ‘would be ready to be led on’. It may be that proqumh/sesqai is only an explanation of e)pispa/sesqai, which has found its way into the text: on the other hand a redundancy of almost synonymous infinitives is by no means foreign to the style of Thucydides; while the future inf. is often found after words of thinking, wishing, etc. e.g. i. 27, e)deh/qhsan nausi\ sfa=s cumprope/myein.

ou)/te ga\r au)toi/—‘for as they themselves never expected to be overmastered at sea, and therefore had not been building the works with any strength, so if the enemy could force the landing, the place, he felt, was at once within their grasp’. ou)/te...te—lit. ‘neither...and’: so neque...et. e)lpi/zontes—‘looking for, expecting’: ii. 11, e)lpi/zein dia maxhs i)enai au)tou/s.—i)sxuro/n—predicate agreeing with tei=xos: after the
preceding ou)/te the negative ou)k is of course redundant. The imperfect e)tei/xizon means either ‘had been building’, or ‘had been for building’, i.e. thought fit or purposed to do so.

e)kei/nois te—dativus commodi after a(lw/simon gi/gnesqai. bia/zesqai with accusative, meaning ‘to carry by force’ occurs again ch. 11, 23 and ch. 36, 6: Thucydides uses it also without a case, meaning ‘to act by force, force one's way’, and as a passive. gi/gnesqai, ‘to come to be’, here denotes what would follow as an immediate and necessary consequence: so ch. 10, 13, cu/mmaxon gi/gnetai. The infinitive depends on the sense continued from h)gei=to in the previous sentence.

kata\ tou=to—‘at this point’: so iii. 89, where it is the antecedent to h(=|: or possibly ‘on this plan’, i.e. with this view and purpose: like v. 7, kata\ qe/an tou= xwri/ou, = ‘to reconnoitre the place’.

parekeleu/sato toia/de—‘exhorted them to the following effect’: toia/de, ‘of this sort’, in relating speeches, means as follows: corresponding to which we have tosau=ta ‘so much’ (as in ch. 11, 1) or toiau=ta, both equivalent to as aforesaid.

div2.head: CHAPTER X
div2.p: Speech of Demosthenes to the garrison. His address is brief and soldierlike. We must fight, he says, and fight at once. Nor is there any need for despairing of success, if only we hold our ground. The place is difficult of approach, and the enemy can only bring a small part of his numbers into action at once. Besides, he is at a disadvantage, having to force the landing from his ships. There is therefore no need to fear an overwhelming onslaught, and a vigorous resistance will make us victorious.

cunara/menoi—‘having taken part in’: v. 28, cunara/menoi tou= pole/mou: the genitive is partitive, as with proscumba/llomai, iii. 36: cullamba/nomai, ch. 47, 4: so Eur. Ion, 331, po/nou cullabei=n. On the other hand we have, ii. 71, cuna/rasqai to\n ki/ndunon, ‘to join in undertaking the danger’.

mhdei\s cuneto\s boule/sqw dokei=n—‘let no one desire to be esteemed a man of intelligence’. cuneto/s and cune/sis denote especially natural sagacity and quickness of apprehension, qualities which eminently distinguished the Athenians. Now however what was needed was rather stolid determination. Demosthenes therefore calls on his men to repel their enemy first and argue afterwards.

e)klogizo/menos—‘reasoning out, calculating thoroughly’: i. 80 with acc. to\ periesto\s h(mo=s deino/n—‘the danger that surrounds us’: so ch. 34, 27: iii. 54, fo/bos perie/sth th\n *spa/rthn. The neuter form kaqesto/s occurs, iii. 9: elsewhere kaqesthko/s, ch. 97, 7, etc.

ma=llon h)\...xwrh=sai—ma=llon d' is read by nearly all modern editors, the best manuscripts omitting h)/ and several giving de/. The sense is then ‘but rather (let each one resolve) to close with the enemy, etc.’, e)/kastos or pa=s tis being supplied from mhdei/s, and xwrh=sai of course being governed by boule/sqw. Classen however urges that not only is such an elliptic construction doubtful in the present sentence, but that a parallel can scarcely be quoted from Thucydides to this usage of ma=llon de/. On the other hand ma=llon h)/ is a frequent expression, and is more than once found in sentences which closely resemble the one before us: e.g. viii. 48, ou) ga\r boulh/sesqai (e)/fh) au)tou\s. douleu/ein ma=llon h)\...e)leuqe/rous ei)=nai: cf. ii. 62: iii. 46. a)periske/ptws eu)/elpis—‘with sanguine hope which casts aside reflection’: so ch. 108, 25, e)lpi\s a)peri/skeptos.

kai\ e)k tou/twn a)\n perigeno/menos—‘confident that he will come out successful from this danger too’: so i. 141, e)k tw=n kindu/nwn perigene/sqai: ii. 49, e)k tw=n megi/stwn perigene/sqai, ‘to escape the worst consequences (of the plague)’.

o(/sa ga\r e)s a)na/gkhn—‘whenever matters have reached a point of necessity, as they have now with us, they least of all admit of calculation, etc.’: so i. 124, nomi/santes e)s a)na/gkhn a\fi=xqai, ‘convinced that you have no choice left’.

e)gw\ de\ kai/—‘but I see that most things too are in our favour’. kai/ couples the two ideas, that not only is it a time for action rather than consideration, but also consideration is encouraging rather than the reverse. pro\s h(mw=n—so ch. 29, 13, pro\s tw=n polemi/wn, ‘in favour of the enemy’.

h)\n e)qe/lwme/n te mei=nai—e)qe/lw seems especially used of the alacrity and determination of a soldier: so Brasidas says to his men, when on the point of gaining his final victory, v. 9, nomi/sate ei)=nai tou= kalw=s polemei=n to\ e)qe/lein kai\ ai)sxu/nesqai kai\ toi=s a)/rxousi pei/qesqai. The sentence is slightly irregular, te following e)qe/lwmen as if to couple it to another finite verb, while kai/ introduces instead a second infinitive mh\ kataprodou=nai. See note on ch. 9, 7.

ta\ u/pa/rxonta h(mi=n krei/ssw kataprodou=nai—‘to sacrifice the advantages we have already’. kataprodou=nai, ‘to betray utterly’ implies a disgraceful and cowardly abandonment: i. 86, uh/te tou\s cumma/xous kataprodi/dwmen.

tou= te ga\r xwri/ou—followed by to/ te plh=qos, line 18, the words from d meno/ntwn to i)/sw| h)/dh being explanatory and parenthetical. Demosthenes points out that two things are in favour of the Athenians, the difficulty of effecting a lodgement (to\ duse/mbaton), and the fact that only a few ships can attack them at once. h(me/teron = pro\s h(mw=n.

o(\ meno/ntwn h(mw=n—o(/ is absent from nearly all manuscripts, but is considered necessary by Poppo. If it be omitted, and a stop placed at nomi/zw, we have an abrupt, though not impossible sentence. The same question, under the same conditions, arises on iii. 37, a)rxome/nous (oi(\)...a)krow=ntai u(mw=n. Classen in both cases follows the manuscripts and omits the relative.

u(poxwrh/sasi de/—‘though if we once give way we shall find that, hard though it be, it is easy enough if there is no one to bar the road’. u(poxwrh/sasi, sc. h(mi=n, is an ethical dative (dativus incommodi); the aorist = ‘when we have once yielded’. Case and tense are similarly used in ii. 62, a)/llwn d' u)pakou/sasi kai\ ta\ proskekthme/na filei=n e)lassou=sqai, ‘when men have once submitted to others (know that) they soon find that what they have gained diminishes’. eu)/poron—‘affording an easy path (to the enemy)’: ch. 78, 12, eu)/poron diie/nai ‘easy to traverse’.

mh\ r(a|di/ws ou)/shs—the adverb has better manuscript authority than r(a|di/as: cf. ch. 13, 6. a)poba/sews ma/lista ou)/shs: so vii. 4, r(a=|on e)fai/neto h) e)skomidh\ e)/sesqai. Göller's note, quoted by Arnold, gives several instances of adverbs with sum in Latin. bia/zhtai—passive; this verb is passive or deponent indifferently, except in two tenses e)biasa/mhn (dep.) and e)bia/sqhn (pass.).

e)pi\ ga\r tai=s nausi/—‘for while on board their ships they are easiest to repel’ = r(a=|sto/n e)stin a)mu/nesqai au)tou/s: so Hom. Il. xii. 54, ta/fros r(h|idi/h perh=sai, ‘easy to cross’: ib. xxiv. 243, r(h|i/teroi e)naire/men: Plat. Rep. 283B lo/gos prosh/kwn r(hqh=nai.

kat' o)li/gon ga\r maxei=tai—‘it will fight in small divisions’; distributive use of kata/, of a whole divided into parts: v. 9, to\ kat' o)li/gon kai\ mh\ a)pa/ntas kinduneu/ein: vi. 34, kat' o)li/gon prospi/ptousa: Hdt. vii. 104, oi( *lakedaimo/nioi kat' e(/na maxeo/menoi, ‘man by man’.

kai\ ou)k e)n gh=|—‘and it is not an army on land on equal terms with superiority of force, but an army fighting from ships, which require the concurrence of many fortunate circumstances (for success)’. e)k tou= o(moi/ou—i.e. with equal advantages of ground, facility of approach, etc. polla/ is of course predicative in construction, lit. ‘the kairi/a occurring must be many’. kai/rios means ‘seasonable, suitable’: here ta\ kai/ria
are the favourable conditions of wind, sea-room, good landing and the like, which must be combined if the ships were to act with effect. Similarly Nicias says that in the expedition to Sicily ‘there is need of good counsel, and still more of good fortune’ (vi. 23). Some take kai/ria here to mean accidents, on the analogy of kairi/a plhgh/, which means a mortal wound, as striking a vital part (kairo/s or kai/rion). The clause would then be rendered ‘to which many accidents must needs occur’: but this does not give so good a sense; and we should expect ei)ko/s or a)na/gkh rather than dei=. cumbh=nai—‘to happen together’.

a)ntipa/lous tw=| h(mete/rw| plh/qei—‘I consider their difficulties a counterpoise to our (small) numbers’: so v. 6, u(perido/nta sfw=n to\ plh=qos, ‘despising their (small) force: Hdt. i. 77, *kroi=sos memfqei\s kata\ to\ plh=qos to\ e(wutou= stra/teuma, ‘having misgivings about his army in respect of numbers’.

kai\ e)pista/menous—‘and knowing from practical experience what landing from ships against others is, viz. that it could never be effected by force, if etc.’ a)po/basis is the subject of the following bia/zoito, the construction being similar to e)pi/stamai *ku=ron o(/ti te/qnhke, ‘I know that Cyrus is dead’.

ei)/ tis u(pome/noi—u(pome/nw is especially used of standing one's ground in danger or alarm: it takes an accusative of the thing or person: vi. 68, u(perfronou=si me\n h(ma=s u(pomenou=si de\ ou)/, ‘they despise us but will not endure our attack’.

fo/bw|—the order of construction is fo/bw|...deino/thtos kata/plou new=n, but Thucydides commonly places the most important and general word first in position, and then the words which particularize what is said about it: so ii. 60, tou= koinou= th=s swthri/as a)fi/esqe, ‘ye loose your hold on the safety of the state’. Analogous to this is the usage by which the name of a country is often put first and followed by the name of a particular place therein.

The omission of any article seems intended to give a somewhat contemptuous emphasis to the words; as in the speech of Hermocrates describing the motives of the Athenians in invading Sicily, vi. 33, pro/fasin me\n *)egestai/wn cummaxi/a| kai\ *leonti/nwn katoiki/sei, ‘ostensibly by way of alliance with Egesteans and settling of Leontines’. So Demosthenes, in Nicostr. 1255, speaking of the artifices by which a criminal tries to beg himself off, says h)\ ga\r o)rfanou\s h)\ e)piklh/rous kataskeua/santes, a)ciw/sousi e)leei=sqai, h)\ gh=ras kai\ a)pori/as kai\ trofa\s mhtri\ le/gontes, ‘they will try to excite pity by getting up tales about orphans and heiresses, and destitute mothers that they have to keep’.

kai\ au)tou/s—‘now that your turn has come’ (Jowett). r(axi/a—Ion. r(hxi/h (r(a/ssw, r(h/gnumi), ‘the place where the waves break’: Aesch. Prom. 713, a(listo/nois po/das xri/mptousi r(axi/aisi. In Hdt. = the flood tide breaking on on the shore. para/—with acc. ‘along the line of’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XI
div2.p: e)pikataba/ntes—‘marching down to the sea to face the enemy’: vii. 23, pro\s th\n qa/lassan e)pikataba/ntwn.

a)rantes—‘having set out’: with acc., i. 52, a)/rantes tas nau=s, ‘having got the fleet under way’: more commonly intransitive, of land or sea forces; ii. 12, a)/ras tw=| stratw=|: i. 29, a)/rantes e(bdomh/konta nausi/.

tessara/konta kai\ trisi/—if the reading is right, the Lacedaemonians did not make the attack with their full force, as the fleet which had come from Corcyra numbered 60 sail, ch. 8, 10. The article with nausi/ seems to show that they used all their available ships. Some may perhaps have been disabled. Poppo suggests e\ch/konta kai\ trisi/.

e)pe/plei—‘was on board’; applied to the commander or any persons not belonging to the regular crew: as in ii. 66 to a force of 1000 heavy-armed men. In ch. 12, 15 e)piple/w means ‘to sail up, sail against’: so i. 51, iii. 79 etc.

kat' o)li/gas nau=s—‘in detachments of a few ships’. kata/, distributive: ch. 10, 19. dielo/menoi—‘apportioning the work’: sometimes used as in the present passage without a case, v. 114, dielo/menoi kata\ po/leis: sometimes with an accusative, ii. 78, dielo/menoi kata\ po/leis to\ xwri/on, ‘apportioning (the operations against) the place to the several contingent cities’.

ou)k h)=n plei/osi prossxei=n—‘it was not possible to approach the shore with more’. The place where the Athenians were posted was of no great extent, and triremes rowing to the shore would require 50 feet or so to clear each other. plei/osi is the dat. of the force with which the attempt was made.

a)napau/ontes e)n tw=| me(rei—‘relieving (each other) in turn’: Arnold quotes Xen. Hel. vi. 2. 29, kata\ me/ros tou\s nau/tas a)ne/pauen: so id. Cyr. vii. 1. 4, a)napau/ein stra/teuma, ‘to halt an army’: cf. vii. 79, a)napauome/nwn au)tw=n, ‘while they were resting’: ii. 75, dih|rhme/noi kat' a)napau/las, ‘in relieving parties’.
ei)/ pws w)sa/menoi—‘if by any means they might force their way etc.’: so ch. 35, 13, w)/sasqai e)peirw=nto: also with acc., vi. 70, w)same/nwn to\ ke/ras. ei)/ pws—so ch. 37, 5.

pa/ntwn ..*brasi/das—The first mention of Brasidas by Thucydides is in the year 431, when his promptitude and energy in saving a fortress gained him public thanks at Sparta (ii. 25). We next find him in 427, as ‘adviser’ (cu/mboulos) to Alcidas, whom the Lacedaemonians were about to send with a fleet to Corcyra (iii. 69). This expedition effected little, not from the fault of Brasidas, who had not an equal voice in its direction; *brasi/dou parainou=ntos, i)soyh/fou de\ ou)k o)/ntos (iii. 79).
ei)/ ph| kai\ dokoi/h—‘if at any point it did seem possible to land’; opt. of frequency, as in ch. 4, 9, ei)/ pou de/oi.

fulassome/nous tw=n new=n—‘being careful of their ships’: verbs which denote caring for take the genitive, so fula/ssomai ‘to beware, be on one's guard’ here takes the genitive of the thing about which the care is shown. There is however no other instance of the gen. with fula/ssesqai. Krüger therefore takes new=n as partitive gen.: while R. omits tw=n...cuntri/ywsi.

cu/lwn feidome/nous—‘sparing planks’; speaking contemptuously. So Mardonius called the defeat at Salamis cu/lwn a)gw/n, Hdt. viii. 100. ‘It is not timber’, he said, ‘which will give us success, but horses and men’.

perii+dei=n pepoihme/nous—‘to allow the enemy to have made’. The perfect participle points to the fact that the work had been actually constructed, and Brasidas calls on his soldiers to avenge the wrong: so ii. 18, perii+dei=n th\n gh=n tmhqei=san, ‘to allow the ravaging of the land to be unavenged’: ii. 20, perio/yesqai ta\ sfe/tera diafqare/nta, (Clyde, § 46). pepoihme/nous— perf. partcp. middle, ‘having made for themselves, or caused to be made’: Dem. Androt. 596, ta\s trih/reis ou) pepoi/hsai; of the officials responsible for ship-building.

ta\s sfete/ras nau=s—see note on sfi/si, ch. 9, 21. ‘Smash our ships’, cries Brasidas, ‘and force the landing’. The sense is of course ‘force the entrance, even if we destroy our ships’: cf. Shilleto on i. 20, dra/sante/s ti kai\ kinduneu=sai. kai\ tou\s cumma/xous—sc. e)ke/leue.

e)pidou=nai—‘to give freely’, especially used of voluntary offerings for purposes of state or war: so e)pi/dosis. This sense is common in Demosthenes. In Thucydides e)pidi/dwmi is elsewhere intransitive, meaning ‘to advance, increase’, o)kei/lantas —‘running (their ships) aground’: so ch. 26, 29, e)pw/kellon ta\ ploi=a: in ii. 91 o)ke/llw is intransitive, ai\ de\ (tw=n new=n) e)s bra/xea w)/keilan, ‘grounded on shoals’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XII
div2.p: kai\ o( me/n—to this corresponds oi( de\ a)/lloi, line 10. toiau=ta e)pe/sperxe—‘thus urged on’; cognate accusative, carrying on the idea of the verb, like traumatisqei\s polla/, line 5, ‘with many wounds’. e)pispe/rxw is a poetical word, used in Aesch. Sept. 689 and in Homer.

th\n a)poba/qran—‘the gangway’ for landing from the ship. The Greeks when preparing to attack the Persian fleet drawn up on the shore at Mycale provided a)poba/qras kai\ ta\ a)/lla o)/swn e)/dee (Hdt. ix. 98).

th\n pareceiresi/an—the part ‘clear of the rowing’, at the bows or stern. The word occurs vii. 34 and 40, in both of which passages it means the bows, which are described as shattered by the beaks of the enemy's triremes. perierru/h— ‘slipped off his arm’; see Arnold's note. Xenophon, when his troops were in a difficulty, dreamed that he was in fetters, but that ‘they slipped off him of themselves’, au)to/matai perirruh=nai (Anab. iv. 3). So ch. 51, 1 and 133, 1, tei=xos periei=lon: cf. Plat. Rep. 519 A, perieko/ph with acc. ‘was clipped of its surroundings’.

o(\ e)/sthsan...tau/ths—‘which they set up for (their success in repelling) this attack’: so ii. 92, e)/sthsan tropai=on th=s troph=s. For tropai=on see Liddell and Scott. Sometimes when both sides claimed a victory both set up a trophy (ch. 134, 7). Thucydides however only records a single instance (viii. 24) in which a trophy was removed by the enemy as being erected on insufficient grounds.
perie/sth—‘changed, came round’: i. 78, e)s tu/xas perii/stasqai, ‘to change in respect of fortune’: i. 120, e)s tou)nanti/on perie/sth, ‘changed to the opposite’.
kai\ tau/ths *lakwnikh=s—‘and that too Laconian land’: ch. 55, 17, kai\ tou/tw|: like kai\ tau=ta ‘and that too’, a very common phrase, usually with a participle.

e)pi\ polu\...proe/xein—‘it formed at this time a great part of the glory of the Lacedaemonians that they were chiefly mainlandsmen and most excellent in military matters, and of the Athenians that they were seamen and most eminent with their ships’. e)pi\ polu/—‘(to) a great extent’ (see note on ch. 3, 13), is the object of e)poi/ei, the subject of which is formed by the following infinitive clauses. e)n tw=| to/te—i.e. at the time of which Thuc. is writing: so ch. 35, 18, e)n tw=| pri/n: i. 32, e)n tw=| pro\ tou=, ‘in former time’.

qalassi/ois—sc. ei)=nai. The word implies seafaring habits and skill. In i. 7 we read of pirates assailing o(/soi o)/ntes ou) qala/ssioi katw w)/|koun, ‘all who, though not seamen, had their dwelling on the coast’: so Aristotle Eth. Nic. iii. 6 (9), 11, says, on the subject of bravery, e)n qala/tth| a)deh\s o( a)ndrei=os, ou)x ou)/tw de\ w(s oi) qala/ttioi, i.e. he has not the confidence which sailors have from experience.

div2.head: CHAPTER XIII
div2.p:
prosbola\s poihsa/menoi—‘after attacking’: poiei=sqai with substantives is very commonly used by Thucydides instead of the simple verb; as fugh
 poiei=sqai = ‘to fly’. The article is often added to give further definiteness: ch. 11, 13, tou\s e)pi/plous e)poiou=nto, ‘they made their attack’: i. 6, th
 di/aitan e)poih/santo, ‘they passed their lives’: i. 8, ma=llon th
 kth=sin tw=n xrhma/twn poiou/menoi, ‘increasing their wealth’, etc.

e)pe/paunto—the pluperfect shows that the Lacedaemonians had already given up the attempt to force a landing when they sent to Asine. Arnold has a good note on a similar pluperfect, ch. 47, 3, parede/donto. This construction occurs, he says, ‘when the writer wishes to describe the first in time of two events, as not only preceding the other, but as preparing the way for it; so that in describing the second event he may place the prior event before the reader's mind at the same time, as that without which the notion of the second event would be incomplete’.

e)pi\ cu/la e)s mhxana/s—meaning especially scalingladders (Poppo). pare/pemyan—‘sent along the coast’. Asine appears to have been round the promontory of Acritas (cape Gallo) on the shore of the Messenian bay. It is mentioned again as a Peloponnesian port, vi. 93.

e)lpi/zontes...e(lei=n mhxanai=s—‘expecting that though the wall over against the harbour was of some height, yet as landing was here most practicable they could take it by means of engines’. In construction e)lpi/zontes governs both e)/xein and e(lei=n, though in sense the idea of hoping refers only to e(lei=n. So far as the connecting particles are concerned this is one of the sentences in which the clause with me/n is subordinate in sense to that with de\: see note on ch. 80, 18. There is however a further difficulty, that tei=xos is the subject of e)/xein and the object of e(lei=n. Classen adopts the reading e)/xon in agreement with tei=xos, giving two antithetical clauses, the second a gen.
absolute. There are no doubt instances of similar construction, but the run of the sentence is decidedly against the proposed change in the present passage.

e)lpi/zontes e(lei=n—‘hoping to take’: for the aorist infinitive see note on ch. 9, 22. ma/lista ou)/shs—so ch. 10, 15, mh\ r(a|di/ws ou)/shs. to\ kata\ to\n li/mena tei=xos—that part of the fortress which faced south, inside the entrance to the harbour.

paragi/gnontai penth/konta—‘arrive, to the number of fifty’. tessara/konta has the best manuscript authority, but fifty is the number required, for we find that the arrival of twenty ships made the fleet amount to seventy, ch. 23, 18. Thirty-five ships had sailed to Zacynthus (ch. 5) and two had been despatched thither by Demosthenes. Naupactus had been an Athenian naval station since its capture thirty years back, i. 103.

a)porh/santes o)/ph| kaqormi/swntai—‘finding no place in which to come to anchor’: so i. 107, nomi/santes a)porei=n o)/ph| die/lqwsi. kaqormi/swntai is the subj. of doubt or deliberation. It is not uncommon after a past tense, as well as after a present: see note on ch. 1, 13.
hu)li/santo—‘took up their quarters’; the Greeks if possible landing from their ships not only at night, but even to take their meals: see ch. 26, 11; 30, 4.

h)
 me
...e)pespleusou/menoi—‘in case the enemy should be willing to sail out against them into the open sea, but if not, intending themselves to sail in to attack them’. After eu)ruxwri/an is implied ‘ready to fight there’; the former of the two alternatives not being expressed: so iii. 3, h)
 me
 cumbh=| h( pei=ra, ei) de\ mh\ k.t.l., if the attempt succeed (well and good), but if not, etc.’

ou)/te a(\ dienoh/qhsan—‘nor as it happened had they carried out what they proposed, viz. to block the entrances’; see ch. 8, 34 The Lacedaemonians seem to have been disheartened by the failure of their sea attacks; nor indeed were they ever much at home in naval operation, or ready to encounter an equal Athenian force. Moreover Brasidas, the soul of their enterprise, was now probably disabled by his wounds.
h)\n e)sple/h| tis—so ei)/ tis u)pome/noi, ch. 10, 27.

o)/nti ou) smikrw=|—‘which was of considerable size’, being in fact much the largest harbour in Greece. ou) smikro\s = me/gas, by the figure called by grammarians lito/ths ‘plainness’ or mei/wsis ‘lessening’: so ch. 25, 23, ou)k e)/lasson e)/xontes, ‘having the advantage’. The form smikro/s has good authority in vii. 75 and viii. 81, in both instances with ou).

div2.head: CHAPTER XIV
div2.p: gno/ntes—‘seeing this’: so ch. 38, 1, a)kou/santes: i. 91, a)kou/ontes: gnou/s, ib.: i. 95, ai)sqo/menoi, etc. The sense in such cases is supplied from the context.
ta\s me\n plei/ous—to this is opposed ai( de\ kai\ plhrou/menai e)/ti, line 8; tai=s de\ loipai=s, line 7, being ‘the rest’ of the ships that were mete/wroi.
metew/rous h)/dh—‘already under way’: mete/wros, lit. ‘raised from the ground’, when applied to a ship means ‘separated from the shore,’ i.e. at sea.

e)pidiw/kontes—‘pursuing them hotly, following them up closely’: so ii. 79: in. 33 etc. w(s dia\ braxe/os—‘as (they could) being but a short way off’. dia\ braxe/os, ‘separated by a short interval’: so iii. 94, dia\ pollou=, ‘far apart’ etc. The short distance between the Athenians and their foes enabled them to follow up the Lacedaemonians with effect; so Krüger and Classen. Poppo and others however take w(s dia\ braxe/os to mean ‘as (well as they could) considering the short distance from the land’. The meaning would then be that the Lacedaemonians would have suffered still more had not the shore with the protection of its friendly troops been close at hand. (For such uses of w(s see note on ch. 84, 10.) e)/trwsan—‘damaged’: so Hdt. viii. 18, tetrwme/nai, of ships. Thucydides also uses katatraumati/zw of ships, vii. 41: viii. 10, 42.

e)n th=| gh=| katapefeugui/ais—‘which had taken refuge on the land’, i.e. by running themselves ashore. The present katafeu/gw ‘to fly for refuge’ would require e)s, implying motion to; while the perfect, implying arrival and rest in the place of refuge, may be constructed with e)n. So iii. 71, oi( e)kei= katapefeugo/tes, ‘those who were in a place of refuge there’: Plat. Sophist. 260 C, e)n tou/tw| tw=| to/pw| katapefeuge/nai: cf. Rep. 519 C, e)n maka/rwn nh/sois zw=ntes e)/ti a)pw|ki/sqai. Thus be/bhka, ‘I have gone’ sometimes = ‘I stand’, e.g. Soph. Ant. 67, oi( e)n te/lei bebw=tes, ‘those who stand in authority’.
Other instances of perfect participles so constructed in Thucydides are vii. 71, oi( e)n th=| nh/sw| diabebhko/tes: ib. 87, e)n tw=| toiou/tw| xwri/w| e)mpeptwko/tas.

It is possible of course in the present instance, to take e)n th=| gh=| with e)ne/ballon only, or to understand e)s th\n gh=n with katapefeugui/ais, and the other passages quoted might be similarly explained: there is however no need for this expedient.

e)ne/ballon—‘dashed into’, often used of ships: so in the account of a sea fight in vii. 36 e)mbolh/ is used of the act of ramming or charging the enemy's ship, while e)/mbolos means the actual beak or ram. In the present chapter the different tenses give a vivid picture of the scene. First we have the instantaneous rush of the Athenians and flight of the enemy— w(/rmhsan..., kate/sthsan..., e)/trwsan... Then the changes of a protracted struggle are represented by the imperfects, e)ne/ballon...e)ko/ptonto, etc. which depict not only the progress of the fight, but the details which occurred again and again at different points (see note on ch. 3, 1). Finally the description closes with the aorist diekri/qhsan.
kai\ plhrou/menai e)/ti—‘still getting their crews on board’. e)ko/ptonto—so viii. 105, e)/kopton: ib. 13, nh=es kopei=sai, ‘shattered, crippled’.

a)nadou/menoi—‘taking in tow’: so ii. 90, tw=n new=n tina\s a)nadou/menoi ei(=lkon kena/s. The expression occurs commonly in accounts of naval actions; as does keno/s, ‘without the crew’, opposed to au/toi=s a)ndra/si, ‘men and all’.
perialgou=ntes—‘sore distressed’: so vi. 54, perialgh/sas: cf. peride/s (iii. 28), peridei/dw, periorgh/s (ch. 130, 19), perialgh/s, perixarh/s etc.

o(/ti per—‘because as a matter of fact’: like o(/per kai\ e)ge/neto, ‘which in fact came to pass’: viii. 92, dio/per (di' o(/ per), ‘for which reason in truth’: per thus used emphasizing the word with which it is connected. Classen says that the combination of o(/ti and per is not elsewhere found in Attic Greek.

au)tw=n—from its prominent position, the gen. has an emphatic force, like that of the ethical dative = ‘they saw they should lose their men’: so i. 30, e)pei\ sfw=n oi( cu/mmaxoi e)po/noun: cf. Buttmann on Dem. Meid. 520, tou\s stefa/nous tou\s xrusou=s e)pebou/leuse diafqei=rai/ mou. a)pelamba/nonto—lit. ‘were being cut off’, i.e. this was evidently a necessary concomitant of the success of the Athenians.

pareboh/qoun—this compound is especially used of the movements of troops along the shore: so i. 47: ii. 90 etc. Here it refers to the land army of the Lacedaemonians, which came to save the ships. In ii. 90 the Peloponnesians are described in nearly the same words as rushing into the sea with their arms and rescuing some triremes which the victorious Athenians were already dragging off.

kai\ e)n tou/tw| kekwlu=sqai—‘and in this struggle each man thought things at a standstill, wherever he himself was not on the spot’. This shows at once the spirit and alacrity
of the Lacedaemonians, and their confusion and want of order. In similar words Thucydides describes the enthusiasm with which the Lacedaemonian allies were animated at the beginning of the war, ii. 8, e)n tou/tw| te kekwlu=sqai e)do/kei e)ka/stw|ta\ pra/gmata w)=| mh/ tis au)to/s pare/stai. e)n tou/tw|—‘meanwhile, while this was going on’. kekwlu=sqai—perf. = ‘to be stopped’, with e)/rgon as subject, or perhaps impersonal. w)=| mh/ tini ..parh=n—lit. ‘at whatsoever struggle he himself also (besides any others) was not present’. In the general conflict the fight at each point and for each particular ship was itself an e)/rgon or ‘action’.
qo/rubos—also in i. 49 and viii. 10 of the ‘confusion and tumult’ of a hotly contested sea fight.

a)nthllagme/nos—‘a complete reversal of’ lit. ‘interchanged for’, agreeing with qo/rubos and governing tro/pou: cf. iii. 82, toi=s ei)/desi dihllagme/na, ‘varying in their phenomena’ (Arn.). Classen reads a(nthllagme/nou, gen. abs. with tro/pou, ‘the fashion of the two sides being counterchanged’; on the ground that it is not easy to speak of qo/rubos as being itself ‘taken in exchange’ for the combatants' usual way of fighting. peri\ ta\s nau=s—either with tro/pou, ‘in respect of their ships’, i.e. in naval contests generally, or with e)ge/neto o( qo/rubos, for the possession of these particular ships.
oi)/ te ga\r. oi(/ te—‘on the one hand......on the other’ etc. te—te comparing and contrasting the two sides.
e)kplh/cews—‘dismay’; here it means the excitement of the Lacedaemonians in their alarm at the prospect of losing their men.

w(s ei)pei=n—like w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, used to modify a statement which is too general or extensive, especially with pa=s or ou)dei/s. Here it modifies ou)de\n a)/llo, ‘nothing else, so to put it’: cf. vi. 30, o( a)/llos o)/milos a(/pas, w(s ei)pei=n, ‘the general multitude without exception, we may say’. The infinitive with w(s in such expressions is one of limitation, denoting a certain manner of regarding the thing in question; in this case = so far as making a statement goes: Plat. Rep. 475 D, w(s g' e)n filoso/fois tiqe)nai = ‘so far as the classing them among philosophers is to be considered’: id. Euthyph. 3 B, w(/s g' ou(twsi\ a)kou=sai, ‘just to listen to’ (Madv. § 151). a)/llo ou)de\n h)/— ‘simply, absolutely’: ii. 16: so iii. 39, ti/ a)/llo h)\ e)pebou/leusan;

e)nauma/xoun e)pezoma/xoun—the Lacedaemonian soldiers were rushing into the water, grappling the ships, and fighting against the crews of vessels which were actually afloat, while the Athenian sailors were pushing their advantage and assailing their enemies hand to hand on the shore.

th=| parou/sh| tu/xh| e)pecelqei=n—‘to prosecute their present good fortune’: so Krüger, Poppo, etc. When however this verb governs the dat. it is used of a person, meaning to proceed against, e.g. iii 38, tw=| dra/santi e)pece/rxetai, ‘retaliates on the wrongdoer’. When it means to go through with a thing, it either takes the accus., as v. 100, pa=n e)pecelqei=n, or more commonly is used without governing a case, as i. 62, e)pech=lqon diw/kontes, ‘they pushed the pursuit’. Classen therefore seems right in taking <*>h=| parou/sh| tu/xh| separately, and rendering e)pecelqei=n, ‘to carry out (their success), follow up (their victory)’. The clause thus means ‘wishing, with their present fortune, to pursue their advantage as far as possible’: v. 14, 1 confirms this view.
polu/n te—‘so after etc.’, summing up and concluding the account of the battle.

kai\ a)po\ pa/ntwn—‘who were now present in full force’: kai/ goes with pa/ntwn, i.e. besides those from Sparta and its neighbourhood; see ch. 8, 3. kata\ xw/ran—‘in their place’, i.e. making no further movement: very common literally and metaphorically: Dem. Tim. 701, kata\ xw/ran de\ me/nein tou\s a)/llous (no/mous) e)a=n. e)pi\ th=| *pu/lw|—‘over against, watching’: v. 7, e)pi\ th=| *qra|kh|, ‘commanding Thrace’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XV
div2.p: e)/docen. ta\ te/lh kataba/ntas—‘it was determined that the authorities should go down etc.’ ta\ te/lh, being equivalent to tou\s e/n te/lei, has the masculine plural kataba/ntas: we have also the neuter construction, i. 58, ta\ te/lh u)pe/sxeto au)toi=s: and a neuter participle in combination with a plural verb, ch. 88, 7, ta\ te/lh o)mo/santa au)to\n e)ce/pemyan. a)rxh/ is similarly used for ‘a proper authority’ (h) a)rxh/ = oi( or o( e)n th=| a)rxh=|: ai( a)rxai/ = oi( e)n tai=s a)rxai=s): i. 90, ou) prosh/|ei pro\s ta\s a)rxa/s: so v. 47, ai( e)/ndhmoi a)rxai/, ‘the (several) home authorities’: cf. ch. 53, 10. By a similar usage we say the government, the church, the board, the great powers, etc. from a natural tendency to regard the office more than its incumbent in speaking of things which have an official rather than a personal bearing.
w(s e)pi/—‘on the strength of, in circumstances of’.

bouleu/ein—‘to deliberate’, so often: in aor. ‘to resolve’. In iii. 42, however, tw=| plei=sta eu)= bouleu/onti means ‘to him who advises best’. According to the general use of such words the active would mean to ‘give counsel’, the middle to ‘take counsel’, or deliberate; but Thuc. uses several verbs in the active in
senses for which other writers employ the middle. paraxrh=ma— ‘at once, seeing (the actual state of things)’: pro\s to\ xrh=ma is also read, but on worse authority.

ti paqei=n—‘that anything should befall them’, i.e. that they should die: cf. ch. 38, 11. Many manuscripts read h)/ before krathqh=nai, giving the sense ‘that they should run the risk either of death from famine or in battle, or of being taken prisoners’.
ta\ peri\ *pu/lon—‘as concerns Pylos’: an adverbial expression, cf. note on ta\ pro\s to\ pe/lagos, ch. 23, 15.

div2.head: CHAPTER XVI
div2.p: to\n lo/gon—‘the proposition’: v. 37, dexome/nous to\n lo/gon. The plural ‘propositions, terms’ in general, is more commonly used. e)gi/gnonto—‘was made’; impf. because the writer now gives the terms which the contracting parties went on to arrange, a matter taking some little time; on the conclusion of which he uses the aor. e)ge/nonto, line 25.

toiai/de—‘on the following terms’. The conditions are given in the acc. and infin. construction, ‘The Lacedaemonians to give up, etc.’, ‘it is agreed’ being understood. The same construction is followed in citing laws, decrees of the assembly, etc.
makrai/—i.e. ships of war, opp. to nau=s stroggulh (ii. 97), ‘a round ship’, i.e. with a capacious hull, fit for conveying cargo, o)lka/s and ploi=on are also terms applied to merchant ships.
o(/pla mh\ e)pife/rein—with dat.: ch. 78, 26, *)aqhnai/ois o(/pla e)pife/rein: v. 18, e)p' *)aqhnai/ous.

takto/n—‘fixed in quantity’: ch. 65, 6, takto\n a)rgu/rion, ‘a fixed sum’. memagme/non—‘kneaded’, i.e. prepared and probably ready baked. The amount specified is a day's allowance. xoi=nic = 1/48 me/dimnos, about a quart; kotu/lh, about half a pint. Two xoi/nikes of meal and one kotu/lh of wine was the portion sent to the houses of the Spartan kings when they did not dine at the public table (Hdt. vi. 57): one xoi=nic of meal a day, according to commentators, was considered a slave's proper allowance. kre/as—‘meat’; no particular quantity is specified. It may be conjectured that some words giving the measure have been omitted, or that kre/as means a portion of meat of definite size. Krüger quotes Xen. Cyr. ii. 2. 2, e)ge/neto e(ka/stw| h(mw=n tri/a kre/a: cf. also Ar. Ran. 553, kre/a a)na/brast' ei)/kosin.

o(/sa mh\ a)pobai/nontas—‘provided only they do not land’, lit. ‘in all (that they can do) not landing’: i. 111, th=s gh=s e)kra/toun o(/sa mh\ proi+o/ntes polu\ e)k tw=n o(/plwn, ‘they were masters of the country except in so much as they could not advance any great distance from their headquarters’.

o(/ ti d' a)/n—‘and whatsoever of these provisions (either of) the two contracting parties shall transgress in what respect soever, the truce be then and there at an end’. o(/ ti and o(tiou=n are both acc. after parabai/nwsin, kai/ not meaning ‘and’ but emphasizing o(tiou=n. Either the construction is a species of apposition, or o(tiou=n is a determinant accusative denoting the part of the object to which the action of the verb extends (Madvig, § 31).
