Similarly we have in 123, 5, e)/stin a(\ parabai/nein ta\s sponda/s, ‘to transgress the truce in certain particulars’.

The construction of to/te lelu/sqai is slightly irregular, as if h)/n ti had gone before instead of o(/ ti a)/n. Such irregularities with o(/stis are common: cf. Plat. Euthyph. 3 D, where we have a)/n tina oi)/wntai followed by d\n d' a)\n oi)/wntai with no other change of constr.: also notes on Soph. Trach. 96, klai=e d' o)rga/nwn o(/tou yausei=en. lelu/sqai gives the sense that on any violation of the terms the truce is to be considered as thereby terminated, the perfect inf. denoting the complete accomplishment of a thing, and the state produced by such complete accomplishment: ch. 46, 17, w(/ste a(/pasi lelu/sqai ta\s sponda/s: so e)spei=sqai, line 19, ‘the truce be (now considered as) concluded’. e)spei=sqai (pf. pass. spe/ndomai) and e)/speisto occur iii. 111.

me/xri ou(=—‘until they shall have returned’. The subj. without a)\n after relatives and conjunctions of time, denoting present or future contingency, is usually regarded as a poetical construction. It is however far from uncommon in Thucydides: iii. 28, me/xri ou(= ti do/ch|, ‘till something shall have been determined’: i. 13, me/xri (conj.) plou=s ge/nhtai, ‘till the ship shall have put to sea’, etc.

Speech of the Lacedaemonian envoys before the public assembly on their arrival at Athens. It is marked by a tone of somewhat arrogant superiority. They invite the Athenians to secure peace by restoring the captives, and enlarge upon the uncertainty of fortune and the folly of trusting to it. They do not however suggest any concessions on their own part, but rather imply that an end of the war is a boon which the Athenians would gladly secure on any terms.

div2.head: CHAPTER XVII
div2.p: pra/contas o(/ ti...oi)/sein—‘to effect such an arrangement as may at the same time prove acceptable to you from the advantages which it offers, and may be most conducive to our honour in the circumstances of our present misfortune’. The construction after o)/ ti a)/n is slightly varied, u(mi=n te w)fe/limon o)\n pei/qwmen corresponding to kai\ h(mi=n me/llh| oi)/sein. This modification is adapted to the sense of the passage. The first clause relates to the Athenians, who require to be convinced that the terms were good for them; the second concerns Lacedaemonian interests, which need not be pressed upon the audience. As the sentence stands o(/ ti is acc. after pei/qwmen, while it supplies the nom. to me/llh|: so ii. 84, pneu=ma o(/per a)name/nwn te perie/plei kai\ ei)/wqei gi/gnesqai, ‘which he was waiting for and (which) usually sprang up’: cf. Madv. § 104; and see note on ch. 67, 6.

o(/ ti a)
...pei/qwmen—‘whatsoever we may persuade you of’: ch. 22, 4, o(/ ti a)
 pei/qwsi. u(mi=n te w)fe/limon o)
 to\ au)to/ forms the predicate to o(/ ti, ‘(as) being at the same time (to\ au)to/) advantageous to you’. For to\ au)to/ cf. iii. 47, to\ *kle/wnos to\ au)to\ di/kaion kai\ cu/mforon, ‘Cleon's coincidence of justice and interest’: so Cic. de Off. i. 19, 63, viros fortes et magnanimos, eosdem bonos et simplices esse volumus, ‘at the same time’.

e)s th\n cumfora/n—‘in respect of, in relation to’. w(s e)k tw=n paro/ntwn, ‘as far as present circumstances will admit’: vi. 70, w/s e)k tw=n paro/ntwn suntaca/menoi, ‘forming their ranks as well as they could’: ii. 3, w\s e)k tw=n duna/twn. In such expressions e)k gives the origin from which the result spoken of arises, and in accordance with which it is characterised. ko/smon—‘honour, credit’: i. 5, ko/smos kalw=s tou=to dra=n: Hdt. viii. 60, e)/fere/ oi( ko/smon.

makrote/rous—pred., with mhkunou=men, ‘prolong to greater length (than is our wont)’. ou) negatives para\ to\ ei)wqo/s only, and does not affect the rest of the sentence; the sense of which is, ‘our speaking at length will not be contrary to our custom’. Grote (vol. iv. ch. 52) misunderstands the sentence, saying that the envoys ‘prefaced their address with some apologies for the brevity of speech which belonged to their country’, whereas in fact they give reasons for departing from it. The laconic style of speech was proverbial. It was in accordance with the character of reserved and self-contained strength which the Spartans were careful to keep up.

a)ll' e)pixw/rion o)/n—lit. ‘but (we shall do so) it being our country's custom etc.’, i.e. we shall be carrying out our principles by speaking at length on a due occasion. e)pixw/rion o)/n stands in opposition to para\ to\ ei(wqo/s. The construction is
accus. abs., like e)co/n, ‘it being lawful’, ei)rhme/non ‘it having been ordered’, etc.; which construction is admissible in impersonal expressions with o)/n and an adjective: so vii. 44, a)du/naton o)/n, ‘it being impossible’.
ou(= a)rkw=si—subj. without a)/n: see note on ch. 16, 19.

plei/osi de/—with this is probably to be supplied lo/gois xrh=sqai, ‘but (to employ) more (words)’; the relative clause with e)n w(=| lasting to the end of the sentence, and pra/ssein being dependent on kairo/s, ‘whenever it is a proper time to effect our object etc.’ It is however possible to make the relative clause consist simply of e)n w)=| a)\n kairo\s h)=|, in which case plei/osi agrees with lo/gois in line 10, and pra/ssein, like xrh=sqai in line 8, depends on e)pixw/rion o)/n.
kairo/s—‘due occasion, opportunity’, without art.: ch. 27, 23, kairo\n parie/ntas: iii. 13, kairo\s de\ w(s ou)/pw pro/teron.
prou)/rgou—‘of importance’, contracted for pro\ e)/rgou. A declinable comparative form is found iii. 109, prou)rgiai/teron e)poih/santo, ‘they considered of more importance’.

lo/gois—‘by the use of words’, may be governed either by dida/skontas or by pra/ssein. The run of the words seems slightly in favour of connecting it with pra/ssein, but it may perhaps be affected by both: see note on ch. 40, 13.

la/bete de/—‘and listen to them, not in a hostile spirit, but etc.’ mh/ deprecates polemi/ws, and must not be taken with la/bete, the aor. imperat. not being used in prohibition, for which mh\ la/bhte would be required.

u(po/mnhsin—‘a reminder’, with gen.: i. 72, u(po/mnhsin w(=n h)/|desan. pro\s ei)do/tas—‘to men who know (what good counsel is)’: Pericles says he will not makrhgorei=n e)n ei/do/sin, ii. 36: so ch. 59, 7, ti/ a)/n tis e)n ei/do/si makrhgoroi/h; v. 89, e)pistame/nous pro\s ei/do/tas: Dem. Androt. 613, w(s ei)do/si me\n i)/sws, o(mw=s de\ e)rw=.

kalw=s qe/sqai—‘to make a good use of’, lit. ‘to order, arrange, dispose for yourselves’; used especially of good or bad fortune, and its resulting circumstances, sometimes with an idea of securing or investing: cf. ch. 18, 14: i. 25, e)n a)po/rw| ei)/xonto qe/sqai to\ paro/n, ‘they were at a loss how to settle the question’ (see Classen's full note).

e)/xousi...proslabou=si—agreeing with umi=n: note the difference of tense in these participles. mh\ paqei=n—after e)/cesti, = ‘to avoid’, lit. ‘not to have that happen to you’; in sense but little different from ‘not to do’, but less harsh and direct. A Greek speaker avoids suggesting that his audience
will do what is injudicious or foolish. He warns them lest an error should befall them. o(/per—sc. pa/sxousi: cf. vii. 61, ou)de\ pa/sxein o(/per oi( a)peiro/tatoi tw=n a)nqrwpwn.

tou= ple/onos—‘more’, gov. by o)re/gontai: ch. 21, 8, tou= de\ ple/onos w)re/gonto: ch. 92, 13, tou= plei/onos o)rego/menos: cf. ch. 30, 23, peri\ tou= ple/onos. In these cases the definite article probably denotes the larger remaining part of a whole amount contemplated as attainable, the smaller portion of which is already attained. e)lpi/di—with o)re/gontai, ‘they grasp at in hope’.
ta\ paro/nta—cognate accusative with eu)tuxh=sai: vi. 23, plei/w eu(tuxh=sai, ‘to be fortunate in’.
e)p' a)mfo/tera—i.e. for the better or the worse: so i. 83; ii. 11: Dem. Lept. 471, mete/pipte ta\ pra/gmata e)p' a)mfo/ tera.

di/kaioi/ ei)si—‘have just reason to be most distrustful’: so Hdt. ix. 60, di/kaioi/ e)ste i)e/nai, ‘you are bound in justice to come’: see the note on ch. 10, 17, r(a=|stoi/ ei)sin a)mu/nesqai. o)/pistos, ‘distrustful’, is used with the dative, Plat. Apol. 26 E, a)/pistos ei)= sautw=|: Dem. Fals. Leg. 349, a)/pistos pro\s *fi/lippon.

div2.head: CHAPTER XVIII
div2.p: gnw=te de/—‘and see (the truth of this)’. a)pido/ntes— lit. ‘looking away at’: a)po/ compounded with ble/pw etc. is especially used of looking at a standard or authority, e.g. of a painter looking at his model. oi(/tines—‘we who’, with h(mete/ras.

pro/teron au)toi\ kuriw/teroi—‘though we formerly thought ourselves more able to grant that for which we are now come, making our request to you’: cf. ch. 20, 12, u(ma=s ai)tiwte/rous h(gh/sontai: ib. 15, h)=s nu=n u(mei=s to\ ple/on ku/rioi/ e)ste, ‘which now rests with you in the greater measure’. nomi/zontes is imperfect in sense, ‘we had been thinking’ (till this happened).

ou(/te duna/mews e)ndei/a|...ou(/te u(bri/santes—‘neither from deficiency of strength,...nor because we became arrogant’. e)pa/qomen au)to/—‘it befell us’, i.e. that we should be thus obliged to sue for terms. au)to/ and au)ta/ are not uncommonly used in this way, to denote the circumstances, or state of things spoken of in the context: e.g. i. 69, ou)x o( doulwsa)menos a)ll' o( duna/menos me\n pau=sai periorw=n de\ a)lhqe/steron au)to\ dra=|, i.e. is the
true cause of the allies being enslaved. mei/zonos—sc. duna/mews. prosgenome/nhs—‘being added’, opposed to e)ndei/a|, ‘falling short’.

a)po/ de\ tw=n a)ei u(parxo/ntwn—sc. e)pa/qomen au)to/, ‘going upon, starting from our regular resources’: ii. 91, a)po\ a)ntipa/lou paraskeuh=s. gnw/mh| sfale/ntes—‘failing in our calculations’. gnw/mh, denoting generally ‘what one has in one's mind’, is used in various shades of meaning implying resolution, judgment, opinion, etc. Here it means the calculation which the Spartans had formed that they could easily recover Pylos; cf. ch. 5. For the dat. gnw/mh| Poppo compares vi. 78, gnw/mh| a\martei=n: on the other hand we have sfalei=si gnw/mhs, ch. 28, 30: so sfale/ntes do/chs, ch. 85, 6. Similarly we say disappointed in, or disappointed of, our expectations.
e)n w(=|—‘in which matter’, i.e. in the liability to fail. pa=si...u(pa/rxei—‘the same (chance) awaits all alike’.

po/lew/s te kai\ tw=n prosgegenhme/nwn—‘of your city and its acquisitions’, that is of the dominion which Athens had gained during late years, perhaps referring also to the recent success at Pylos. The omission of the article with po/lews is noticeable, especially with th/n preceding. We have, i. 10, cunoikisqei/shs po/lews: ii. 72, po/lin kai\ oi/ki/as para/dote, in each instance of a definite city. The explanation seems to be that words like po/lis acquire in such cases a definiteness like that of a proper name, and therefore do not need the article to define them further. So we often have pai=des kai\ gunai=kes without an article, as in i. 89: so iii. 50, *mutilhnai/wn tei/xh kaqei=lon kai\ nau=s pare/labon: so ch. 31, 9, me/son k.t.l. In the present sentence po/lews kai\ tw=n prosgegenhme/nwn taken together make up the idea ‘of your present empire’.
to\ th=s tu/xhs—‘what belongs to fortune’: also found vii. 61: ch. 55, 19, ta\ th=s tu/xhs: ii. 60. ta\ th=s o)rgh=s.

swfro/nwn de\...h(gh/swntai—‘Now they are wise men who secure their advantages against a day of danger, (and these same men would show more sense in dealing with misfortunes), and as to war, are convinced that it can not be engaged in just so far as a man may wish to take it in hand, but (must go on) as its vicissitudes may determine’. The general sense of the passage is clear, that prudent men will not presume on a continuance of good fortune, especially in war. The grammatical form of the sentence has however given rise to much discussion, and requires close attention. Following oi(/tines we have three clauses, ta)gaqa\...e)/qento,—kai\...prosfe/rointo,—to/n te...h(lh/swntai. Each of these clauses varies in construction, and will require to be examined in detail.

swfro/nwn de\.. oi(/tines—=‘they are prudent men who’. This construction is probably a confusion between sw/frones a)/ndres ei/si\n oi(/tines e)/qento and swfro/nwn de\ a)ndrw=n e)sti\ to\ qe/sqai, ‘it is the part of prudent men to secure’: so iii. 45, pollh=s eu)hqei/as, o(/stis oi)/etai, ‘it shows great simplicity when a man thinks’: vi. 14, to\ kalw=s a)/rcai tou=t' ei)=nai, o(\s a)/n, ‘this is a proper discharge of official duty, when’: Xen. Anab. ii. 5. 21, a)po/rwn e)sti\..., oi(/tines. The genitive in these phrases gives the characteristic which belongs to the persons spoken of (Madvig, § 54). This explanation of the passage, for which there seems fully sufficient support, is adopted by the majority of editors; Classen however considers that the gen. is partitive, and that ou(=toi/ ei/sin is understood; the sense would thus be, ‘they are of the class of prudent men who, etc.’

ta)laqa\...e)/qento—aor. denoting what is wont to happen (having happened in other supposed instances), to be translated by our present (Madvig, § 111, R. 3). It is a question whether e)/qento is to be taken in close connexion with a)sfalw=s or e)s a)mfi/bolon. In the former case, a)sfalw=s e)/qento is a phrase like kalw=s qe/sqai, ch. 17, 14, and means ‘to order safely’, i.e. to secure, by making good terms; while e)s a)mfi/bolon is ‘in reference to, with a view to (a time of) doubt’. In the latter case, e)s a)mfi/bolon qe/sqai means ‘to reckon as doubtful’, tiqe/nai e)s meaning ‘to put down to, count among’, while the middle gives the sense ‘in their own case’: so Hdt. iii. 3, e)n timh=| ti/qetai, ‘holds in honour’. The clause then means ‘who safely reckon their gains as doubtful’, i.e. know they may lose them again, and so run no needless risks.

kai\...prosfe/rointo—by most editors taken as a parenthesis, ‘now these same men would, etc.’ Others take it as a second clause with oi(/tines, ‘and who would also, etc.’ making oi( au)toi\ a predicate like to\ au)to/, ch. 17, 3. This however merely gives the somewhat feeble sense that prudent men would be more likely to act with prudence; and the former view is preferable. prosfe/resqai—‘to behave oneself towards, deal with’: vi. 44, pro\s ta\ pra/gmata prosoi/sontai: more commonly used of dealing with persons, either with dat., as v. 111, or with a prep., as v. 105, etc.

to/n te po/lemon—‘and as regards war, are convinced, etc.’ Instead of the aor. indic. to correspond to e)/qento, we have vomi/swsi, as if oi(/tines a)/n had gone before. Such a subj. with a)/n is equivalent to the Latin 2nd future, ‘shall have taken the view’, i.e. once for all. The position of po/lemon is in favour of regarding it as the subject to cunei=nai: in which case tou/tw| must refer either to tis or to me/ros, the meaning being either ‘that it abides with this man’, or ‘that it restricts
itself to this part’. The former gives the better sense, that po/lemos is a potent thing, which when once called up, can not be got rid of at pleasure. So war is as it were personified in such expressions as i. 78, mhkuno/menos (po/lemos) filei= e)s tu/xas ta\ polla\ perii/stasqai: i. 122, po/lemos h(/kista e/pi\ r(htoi=s xwrei=, ‘proceeds least of all on fixed conditions’: ii. 36, po/lemon e)pio/nta a)mu/nesqai. Some editors take tis as the subject of cunei=nai and tou/tw| as referring to po/lemos or me/ros, ‘that a man can deal with this’, viz. with war, or a particular part of it: but this is more than doubtful in construction, though it gives a reasonable sense.

a)ll' w(s a)/n—‘but (that it abides with him, tou/tw| cu/nesti) just as, etc.’ ai( tu/xai—‘the phases of fortune’; as in the passage from i. 78 cited above. au)tw=n—neut. governed by tu/xai, referring either to the different stages of the war (me/rh) or generally to ta\ tou= pole/mou: cf. note on line 6. h(lh/swntai— ‘may have led the way’. By some au)tw=n is taken as masculine, governed by h(lh/swntai, ‘may have led them (those engaged in war) on’, the sense of au)tw=n being supplied from tis.

kai\ e)la/xist' a)/n—in this sentence we have metaphors derived from stumbling (ptai/ontes), standing upright (tw=| o)rqoume(nw|), and being lifted up (e)pai/resqai). a)/n, which in construction goes with katalu/ointo, is placed, as is often the case, at the beginning of the sentence, to show its contingent character, and repeated later on; so i. 36, braxuta/tw| d' a)\n kefalai/w|...tw=|d' a)\n ma/qoite, etc. e)la/xista ptai/ontes—‘making the fewest trips’. katalu/ointo a)/n—‘would make terms’: so i. 81, etc.: we have also katalu/ein po/lemon, ‘to give up fighting’, vii. 31, and kataluein without a case (in the words of a treaty), v. 23, viii. 23.
o(/—viz. to make terms while successful. kai\ mh\ .. nomisqh=nai—dependent on kalw=s e)/xei, ‘and (so) to avoid being thought, etc.’

h)\n a)/ra—‘if, after all, you reject our terms and meet with failure’: for a)/ra cf. note on ch. 8, 24. a(\ polla\ e)nde/xetai— a(\ is cognate acc. after sfallesqai, which is understood after e)nde/xetai: polla/ is predicative, ‘failure which is possible in many ways’.

kai\ ta\ nu=n proxwrh/santa krath=sai—‘to have won even your present successes’; krath=sai governed by nomisqh=nai. Such words often take a neut. acc. carrying on the idea of the verb: so ch. 19, 10, e)pikrath/sas ta\ ple/w. proxwrh/santa—cf. i. 109, w(s au)tw=| ou) prou)xw/rei, ‘when his design did not succeed’: v. 37, tou/tou proxwrh/santos, ‘when this was secured’. do/khsis —‘credit, reputation’: ii. 35, h( do/khsis th=s a)lhqei/as.

div2.head: CHAPTER XIX
div2.p: *lakedaimo/nioi de/—‘now the Lacedaemonians invite you’; de/ introduces the terms actually proposed, after the general observations with which the speakers had begun. So, in other speeches of envoys, after some preliminary words, we have the question at issue brought in with de/: i. 32, *kerkurai=oi de\...a)pe/steilan h(ma=s: iii. 10, h(mi=n de\...cummaxi/a e)ge/neto.
dia/lusin pole/mou—cf. line 10, dialu/esqai: iii. 114, dialu/ein po/lemon. kata/lusis pole/mou is found ch. 118, 60 and viii. 18 (in the words of treaties).

dido/ntes—‘offering’: so ch. 21, 4, didome/nhs: i. 85, e)pi\ to\n dido/nta (di/kas), ‘against him who is ready to give satisfaction’. The inf. u(pa/rxein is added to define the result looked for, ‘for this to subsist between us’: Xen. Anab. i. 6. 6. 6, tou=ton e)/dwken u(ph/koon ei)=nai e)moi/. a)/llhn—‘in general, in other respects’: i. 2, ou)/te mege)qei po/lewn i)/sxuon ou)/te th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=|. oi)keio/thta— ‘friendly understanding’.
tou\s e)k—cf. ch. 8, 1. diakinduneu/esqai—‘that the hazard should be risked to the utmost’, lit. risked out (dia/), passive impersonal: so i. 73, e)p' w)feli/a| e)kinduneu/eto, etc. (mid. Cobet).

ei)/te bi/a| diafu/goien—dependent on diakinduneu/esqai, ‘whether they might escape’, the optative of deliberation after a past tense; like i. 25, e)ph/ronto ei) paradoi=en, ‘asked if they were to give up’. It carries back the idea of h(gou/menoi to the time when the Lacedaemonians decided to send their envoys.
paratuxou/shs—cf. pare/tuxen o( kairo/s, ch. 103, 14: viii. 11, e(/ws o)/n tis paratu/xh| diafugh/, ‘till some means of escape offer’: so parape/soi, ch. 23, 21.

ma=llon a)\n xeirwqei=en—‘they might be likely to be still more reduced within your power’. The construction is slightly changed by the introduction of a)/n with the optative; the Lacedaemonians not choosing to speak of the capture of their countrymen except as a matter of contingent possibility.
a)ntamuno/menos—cf. line 17: iii. 84.

e)pikrath/sas ta\ ple/w—‘having proved victorious in most points of the war’. For ta\ ple/w, cf. ch. 18, 24: so vii. 63, ta\ plei/w e)pikratei=n. Instead of pole/mou Classen reads polemi/ou, ‘having got the better of his enemy’, thus supplying an object to e)gkatalamba/nwn and defining au)to/n in line 15.

e)gkatalamba/nwn—‘binding his foe down in (an agreement)’, with kat' a)na/gkhn and o(/rkois: so ch. 86, 3, o(/rkois katalabw/n: i. 9, o(/rkois kateilhmme/nous. mh\ a)po\ tou= i)/sou cumbh=|— ‘shall make peace on unequal terms’: iii. 11, a)po\ tou= i)/sou o(milou=ntes, etc.

paro\n to\ au)to\ dra=sai—‘though it is in his power to do the same’. i.e. to impose harsh conditions: pro\s to\ e)pieike/s, etc. going with what follows. Classen however connects pro\s to\ e)pieike/s with dra=sai, and renders ‘when he can effect the same end (i.e. secure peace) in the way of moderation’. Krüger takes the same view, but connects kai\ a)reth=| also with dra=sai. pro\s to\ e)pieike/s—‘having regard to what is moderate and equitable’: i. 76, e)k tou= e)pieikou=s, ‘from our moderation’: iii. 4. o(mologi/a| e)pieikei=, ‘on fair terms’. In the philosophical language of Aristotle e)piei/keia is equity, as opposed to strict justice.

kai\ a)reth=| au)to
 nikh/sas—‘having also conquered him in generosity’. Arnold quotes Eur. Herc. Fur. 339, a)reth=| se nikw=, qnhto\s w)/n, qeo
 me/gan. au(to/n—his adversary; even if we do not read polemi/ou with Classen, there seems no difficulty in supplying this sense, as the enemy is certainly to be understood as the object of e)gkat. Krüger reads au(to
 nikh/sas, ‘having subdued himself’. The reading of most manuscripts is au)to\ nikh/sas, which would give the sense, ‘having got the better of it’, i.e. of his wish to insist upon severe terms.

para\ a(\ prosede/xeto—‘contrary to what (his enemy) looked for’. Poppo regards prosede/xeto as passive, but admits that there is no similar example in good Greek; Kruger suggests the plpf. prosede/dekto in pass. sense. metri/ws cunallagh=|—‘shall agree upon moderate terms’: viii. 90, cunallagh=nai pro\s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous: in act., v. 45, ‘to settle differences’.

o)fei/lwn—‘being bound, being under obligation’. a)ntapodou=nai a)reth/n—‘to show generosity in return’: cf. ii. 40, e)s o)fei/lhma th\n a)reth\n a)podw/swn, ‘as an obligation’. ai)sxu/nh|—the ‘sense of shame’ which makes a man shrink from doing what would be dishonourable: it may sometimes be rendered honour or self-respect.

pro\s tou\s meizo/nws e)xqrou/s—‘in dealing with those who are more deeply their enemies’. tou\s to\ me/tria dienexqe/ntas—‘those who quarrelled with them in small things’, a construction like ta\ ple)w, line 12. diafe/resqai—‘to be at variance with’: v. 31, diafero/menoi toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois.

a)nqhssa=sqai—‘to make counter-concessions’, a rare word, which here, like other verbs of giving way to, takes the dative of the person in whose favour the concessions are made.
In the same sense we have in ch. 64, 8, o(/son ei)ko\s h(ssa=sqai: so i. 77, e)lassou/menoi, ‘a bating our strict rights’. h(ssa/omai usually means ‘to be worsted’, or with gen. ‘to yield to’: cf. ch. 37, 7. The dat. iii. 38, a)koh=s h\donh=| h(ssw/menoi, is ‘overcome by your delight in listening’.

pro\s ta\ u(perauxou=nta—‘against overweening arrogance’, neuter instead of masculine: so ii. 45, fqo/nos toi=s zw=si pro\s to\ a(nti/palon, ‘jealousy is felt by living men against rival claims’, etc. kai\ para\ gnw/mhn—‘even against their better judgment’: i. 70, para\ gnw/mhn kinduneutai/: vi. 9, ei)=pon para\ gnwmhn.

div2.head: CHAPTER XX
div2.p: h( cunallagh/—‘the (proposed) agreement’.

ti a(nh/keston—‘some irremediable thing’, a euphemistic expression for the death of their countrymen. So the Lacedaemonians hesitated in the case of Pausanias bouleu=sai ti a(nh/keston, i.e. to decree his death (i. 132), where also we have another euphemism, new/tero/n ti poiei=n e)s au)to/n, i.e. to slay him. dia\ me/sou geno/menon—‘intervening’; v. 26, h( dia\ me/sou cu/mbasis. katalabei=n—‘befall us’, with acc., a common constr. in Herod.; e.g. ii. 66, qei=a prh/gmata katalamba/nei tou\s ai/elou/rous, ‘wondrous things befall the cats’: in Thuc. it is elsewhere found without a case, as in ii. 18, o(po/te po/lemos katala/boi, ‘whenever war befell’.
e)n w(=|—‘in which case’. u(mi=n—‘against you’, after e)/xqran e)/xein: Classen reads h(mi=n, ‘it would be necessary for us to have’.

pro\s th=| koinh=| kai\ i)di/an—the ‘private hatred’ which would thus be caused is usually understood as the feud which the individual families of Sparta would cherish against the Athenians for the death of their relations, in addition to the national (koinh/) hostility already felt. Grote however considers the i)di/a e)/xqra to be ‘a new and inexpiable ground of quarrel, peculiar to Sparta herself’, while the koinh e)/xqra is that of the Peloponnesian confederacy, the whole war having been begun in consequence of the complaints of the allies, and to redress their wrongs, not those of Sparta individually (Grote, vol. iv. ch. 52).
Jowett observes that the speaker is attracted by a connexion of sound, and perhaps by a fancied connexion of sense or etymology between a)i+/dion and i)di/an: so ch. 63, 9: 87. 28.

e)/ti d' o)/ntwn a)kri/twn—‘while matters are still undecided’, neut. gen. abs.: so i. 7, plwimwte/rwn o(/ntwn, ‘when navigation was advanced’: Hdt. vii. 37, e)pinefe/lwn e)o/ntwn, ‘the sky being cloudy’. The number and variety of instances of the gen. abs. in this chapter is remarkable.

cumfora=s metri/ws katatiqeme/nhs—‘our disaster being settled on tolerable terms’ (Arn.): so i. 121, kataqhso/meqa po/lemon, ‘we will settle or conclude the war’, opposed to e)gei/romen: Dem. Fals. Leg. 425, to\n po/lemon kate/qento. We have vi. 11, to\ sfe/teron a)prepe\s eu)= qh/sontai=‘they will retrieve their honour’: see also note on ch. 17, 14, kalw=s qe/sqai. katati/qesqai commonly means to ‘lay up in store for oneself’, e g. ch. 57, 22, and iii. 72, of depositing hostages in a place of safety: i. 128, of bestowing a favour or benefit, etc.
diallagw=men—‘let us be reconciled’: in act. vi. 47, *selinounti/ous dialla/cai au)toi=s, ‘to reconcile the men of Selinus to them’.

polemou=ntai—according to Classen from polemo/w, ‘they are made enemies’: i. 36, oi)keiou=tai/ te kai\ polemou=tai, ‘becomes your friend or your enemy’: i. 57, *perdi/kkas e)pepole/mwto, etc. So far as form goes it might equally well come from poleme/w, which is often used in the passive: e.g i. 37, polemou=ntai, ‘they are attacked’.

a)safw=s o(pote/rwn a)rca/ntwn—‘without knowing clearly which of us began’, lit. ‘from which of the two sides having begun (they are thus at war)’. With the adverb a)safw=s, which is used emphatically as is common in Thuc., is connected an indirect question expressed by the gen. absolute with a verb implied, the phrase being equivalent to a)/dhlon o)\n o(pote/rwn a)rca/ntwn (sc. polemou=ntai). The following is a somewhat similar construction with gen. abs., Dem. Aph. i. 829, a)\n e)/xein me fh=|, ti/nos parado/ntos e)rwta=te au)to/n, ‘if he says I have it, ask him who paid it me’, lit. ‘by whose payment (I have it)’. The statement of the envoys seems somewhat at variance with facts, as it could hardly be supposed by any that the Athenians had begun the war.
th\n xa/rin—‘the gratitude which they will feel for peace’. prosqh/sousi—‘they will put down, ascribe, pay’.

h)/n te gnw=te—‘so if you decide to accept our proposals’; te sums up and resumes the argument. *lakedaimoni/ois e)/cestin—‘it is in your power to become friends to the Lacedaemonians’; fi/lous refers to u(mi=n; see note on ch. 2, 11; here this construction avoids confusion. In the following clauses au)tw=n te prokalesame/nwn (gen. abs.) refers to the Lacedaemonians, while xarisame/nois and biasame/nois belong to u(mi=n.

ta\ e)no/nta a)gaqa/—‘the advantages involved’. Note the position of ta\ e)no/nta a)gaqa/, and to\ a)/llo *(ellhniko/n: the most important words being put early in the clauses for the sake of emphasis.

tau)ta\ lego/ntwn—‘holding the same language’, i.e. pursuing the same policy: so v. 31, to\ au)to\ le/gontes. ‘That the jealousy of the other Hellenes was speedily aroused by a temporary combination of the Lacedaemonians and Athenians, which they regarded as a conspiracy against their liberties, we learn from v 59: cf. Ar. Pax, 1082, e)co\n speisame/nois koinh=| th=s *(ella/dos a)/rxein’ (Jowett).

div2.head: CHAPTER XXI
div2.p: e)piqumei=n—imperfect, ‘had been desiring’. In construction all the infinitives in this sentence depend on nomi/zontes, but in sense the idea of thinking belongs particularly to de/cesqai and a)podw/sein. The meaning is ‘the Lacedaemonians thought that, as the Athenians had all along been desirous of peace, they would now be glad to make it’: cf. note on ch. 13, 5, e)lpi/zontes to\ tei=xos u(/yos me\n e)/xein, a)poba/sews de\ ou)/shs e(lei=n. sfw=n de\ e)nantioume/nwn—so in vii. 18 we find the Lacedaemonians admitting that they had forced on the war, and incurred the guilt of refusing negotiations. In 430, the second year of the war, the Athenians had made fruitless proposals for peace (ii. 59).

e(toi/mous—according to Poppo, Classen, etc. fem. agreeing with sponda/s, ‘ready for them’. There is good authority in viii. 26 for nh=es e(toi=moi, and e(toi=mos fem. is found in Hdt. and Dem. Elsewhere however Thuc. has e(toi/mh; for which reason Krüger takes e(toi/mous as agreeing with *lakedaimoni/ous understood. In this view poiei=sqai is to be taken after e(toi/mous, ‘thinking that the Lacedaemonians were ready to make the truce etc.’ Besides the difficulty of thus supplying an object to e)no/mizon, this involves the further awkwardness that pro\s au)tou/s (as well as sfi/si) must then be taken as referring to the Athenians.

e)nh=ge—‘urged on’: ch. 24, 5, note. *kle/wn o( *kleaine/tou —Cleon is first mentioned by Thucydides in iii. 36, where he urges the necessity of putting to death the whole of the revolted Mytileneans (B.C. 427). He is then described in very similar words as w)\n kai\ e)s ta\ a)/lla biaio/tatos tw=n politw=n tw=| te dhmw| para\ polu\ e)n tw=| tote piqanw/tatos. It appears from Plutarch (Nicias ch. 2) that he had already come into notice during
the lifetime of Pericles. It is difficult to form a just estimate of the character of Cleon. He is known to us almost entirely through Thucydides and Aristophanes, the former certainly not his friend, the latter his bitter enemy. There can be little doubt that he was loud, overbearing, and violent; but he seems to have been by no means without patriotism and political ability. At the present time he was undeniably right in insisting upon substantial concessions before giving up the advantage which the Athenians had gained; though his conduct was such as to render successful negotiation almost hopeless.

dhmagwgo/s—‘leader of the people’, a word not used elsewhere by Thucydides. It is not necessarily used in a bad sense, but merely implies that ascendancy in the popular assembly which Cleon had acquired by his confidence, readiness, and power of speaking. In the same sense Pithias tou= dh/mou proei/sthkei at Corcyra (ii. 70); and Athenagoras is called dh/mou prosta/ths at Syracuse (vi. 35). Such influence being readily open to abuse, the word demagogue has not unnaturally come to mean, as defined by Johnson, ‘a ringleader of the rabble; a popular and factious orator’.

tw=| plh/qei piqanw/tatos—‘most influential with the people’; so iii. 36, tw=| dh/mw| piqanw/tatos. Similarly Athenagoras is called piqanwtatos toi=s polloi=s, vi. 35. piqanos—‘persuasive’, is also applied to arguments: Dem. Lacr. 928, lo/gous qaumasi/ws w(s piqanou\s e(/legen.

*)aqh/naze—According to Liddell and Scott the forms *)aqh/naze, *)aqh/nhqen, *)aqh/nh|sin ‘are more Attic than ei)s *)aqh/nas, etc.’ Thucydides sometimes uses *)aqh/naze, as in ch. 46, 15, me/xri ou(= *)aqh/naze pemfqw=sin: v. 32 (twice). *)aqh/nh|si occurs v. 25: v. 47, in the words of a treaty. On the other hand we have e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas (ch. 16, 27): e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n (ch. 16, 20: 22, 17): e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais (ch. 5, 5: 27, 1) repeatedly occurring.

e)lqo/ntwn de/—for gen. abs. see note on a)ntilego/ntwn de/, ch. 3, 8. a)podo/ntas—‘let the Lacedaemonians restore Nisaea etc., and then receive back their men’. In construction *lakedaimoni/ous is subject to komi/sasqai, line 18.

a)podo/ntas...*)axai+/an—these places were given up by the Athenians in accordance with the terms of the thirty years' truce concluded in the year 445 (i. 115). Nisaea and Pegae were the chief ports of the territory of Megara. Troezen was the capital of a district in the E. of Argolis. What is meant by ‘restoring Achaia’, is however not so clear. The country of Achaia was an independent state, which in no intelligible sense belonged to the Lacedaemonians or Athenians, or could
be ‘given up’ by the one to the other. In i. 111 we find certain Achaeans accompanying an Athenian force as allies: and possibly alliance and influence with Achaea may have been the point at issue. Otherwise either *)axai+/an is corrupt, which is improbable, as it occurs in two similar passages; or some particular town is meant, the situation of which we do not know.
a)po\ th=s prote/ras—‘from the previous convention’, i.e. the thirty years' truce of 445. a)po/ gives the origin, from which a result follows: cf. ch 30, 1: vii. 21, a)p' au)tou=, ‘therefrom’.

cugxwrhsa/ntwn—‘having agreed to these concessions’. kata/—‘in accordance with, on the strength of’. deome/nwn ti ma=llon—‘being in considerably greater need’: ch. 30, 1, me/ros ti, ‘in great part’. The thirty years' truce was concluded after hostilities had gone on for three or four years (i. 103—115).
o(po/son a)/n—‘for so long a time as may seem good to both parties’: v. 18, e)/th d' ei)=nai ta\s sponda\s penth/konta, ‘to be for fifty years’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXII
div2.p: cune/drous e(le/sqai—‘but requested that commissioners might be chosen to confer with them’. e(le/sqai—trans., the usual construction with words like keleu/w. sfi/si—governed by cune/drous, cf. ch. 23, 5: ch. 93, 21, oi( cu/mmoroi au)toi=s. When the Athenians invaded Melos their envoys were not brought before the general assembly (pro\s to\ plh=qos), but heard before the authorities and officials (e)n tai=s a)rxai=s kai\ toi=s o)li/gois), who are afterwards called oi( tw=n *mhli/wn cu/nedroi (v. 85).

oi(/tines cumbh/sontai—future in final sense: iii. 16, nautiko\n pareskeu/azon o(/ ti pe/myousin. kata\ h(suxi/an—as opposed to the tumult and hurry of the assembly: i. 85, mhd' e)peixqe/ntes e)n braxei= mori/w| h(me/ras bouleu/swmen a)lla\ kaq' h(suxi/an.

polu\s e)ne/keito—‘fell on them vehemently’, like a mighty tempest or torrent: Hdt. vii. 158, *ge/lwn pollo)s e)ne/keito. Eur. Hip. 443, *ku/pris ga\r ou) forhto/n, h)\n pollh\ r(uh=|: so Sal. Iug. 84, multus atque ferox instare. e)/gkeimai=incumbo, used of pressing an enemy hard, or pursuing an object, with dat. or without a ease: ii. 59, e)ne/keinto tw=| *periklei=, ‘assailed Pericles’: v. 43, eu)qu\s e)ne/keinto, ‘at once urged on their purpose strenuously’.

e\n nw=| e)/xontas—‘intending’: ch. 8, 23, note. oi(/tines— ‘seeing that they’;=qui, quippe qui, with subj. o(/stis as rel. denotes the class, the characteristics of which are found in the antecedent: iii. 64, ti/nes a)\n u(mw=n dikaio/teron misoi=nto, oi(/tines k.t.l., ‘inasmuch as you’.
ei)/ ti u(gie\s dianoou=ntai—‘if they have any honest purpose’: iii. 75, ou)de\n u(gie\s dianooume/nwn.

sfi/sin oi(=o/n te o)/n—‘possible for them’, i.e. consistently with their interest, as is explained afterwards. e)n plh/qei—‘in a public assembly’. ei)/ ti kai\...cugxwrei=n—‘even if they were ready to make any concession’, ti acc. with cugxwrei=n, the two words forming the subject of e)do/kei ‘seemed good’. It does not appear what the Lacedaemonians were willing to concede, as they did not get a hearing.

mh\...diablhqw=sin—‘lest they should be represented injuriously to their allies’. diaba/llw, to set cross or wrong, means to slander or represent prejudicially: iii. 109, *peloponnhsi/ous diabalei=n e)s tou\s *(/ellhnas, ‘to raise a prejudice against the Peloponnesians in the eyes of the Greeks’, e)s denoting those to whom the report reaches and among whom it spreads: ii. 18, h( sxolaio/ths die/balen au)to/n, ‘his slowness did him injury’: also with dat., viii. 88, boulo/menos au)to/n toi=s *peloponnhsi/ois diaba/llein. We have too the passive with dat. meaning lit. ‘to be set wrong with’: viii. 81, i(/na tw=| *tissafe/rnei diaba/llointo, ‘that they might be set against Tissapheines’: Plat. Phaed. 67 E, diabe/blhntai tw=| sw/mati: common in Dem. with pro/s.
ei)po/ntes kai\ ou) tuxo/ntes—‘having made proposals and failed’: ii. 74, prokalesa/menoi polla\ kai\ ei)ko/ta ou) tugxa/nomen.

a)nexw/rhsan a)/praktoi—‘withdrew without effecting anything’. Little else could be expected from the temper of both sides, and the way in which matters were managed. Cleon and the democracy are scarcely to be blamed for demanding more than the Lacedaemonians seemed prepared to grant, while on the other hand a delicate negotiation could not be carried on before the popular assembly. The conduct of affairs at this time seems to have rested chiefly with Nicias and his adherents, but they were powerless to force their views against the will of the people. According to Plutarch (Nicias ch. 7) it was from personal enmity to Nicias that Cleon persuaded the assembly to reject the truce, proqu/mws o(rw=n au)to\n sumpra/ttonta toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois. Thucydides says nothing of the efforts of Nicias on this occasion, but he relates that in
422 he was most eager for peace, from his anxiety to preserve his own good fortune and name as a safe and successful general (v. 16). The impression which we form of his character is that he was a brave and careful commander when actually in the field, but disposed to magnify dangers and difficulties, and deficient in confidence and in a spirit of enterprise. He was also rich and prosperous, and ‘had given hostages to fortune’. It is therefore probable that if he had been one of the proposed cu/nedroi he would willingly have agreed to one-sided terms; and Cleon showed both courage and statemanship in opposing such an arrangement.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXIII
div2.p: dielu/onto—the imperfect refers to the going on of the arrangements for ending the truce, or else the meaning is ‘was to come to an end’, i.e. according to the agreement. Cobet proposes diele/lunto ‘was at an end’ that is, was terminated there and then by the arrival of the ship from Athens. This agrees with the words in ch. 16, 22, e)lqo/ntwn de\ ta/s te sponda\s lelu/sqai, k.t.l.

cune/keito—‘had been agreed’: ch. 68, 20, cune/keito au)toi=s: iii. 70, kata\ ta\ cugkei/mena, ‘in accordance with the terms’: viii. 94, a)po\ cugkeime/nou lo/gou. kei=mai is virtually the perfect passive of ti/qhmi: oi( no/moi kei=ntai, ‘the laws have been enacted’: cf. vi. 62, e)se/keito pa/nta, ‘had been put on board’. cu/gkeimai therefore = the perf. pass. of cunti/qhmi. So Thucydides says of his history, i. 22, cu/gkeitai, ‘it has been composed’. Here cune/keito is pass. of cunti/qesqai, ‘to make a compact, agree to terms’, as in ch. 19, 19: vi. 65, cune/qento h(/cein, ‘they agreed to come’.

e)gklh/mata—‘as grounds of complaint’, in apposition with the following accusatives. e)pidromh/n—‘a sudden attack’, probably made with a small body: ch. 56, 8, e)fo/bhsen e)pidromg=|. tw=| teixi/smati—dat. after verbal subst. e/pidromh/n: cf. notes on Plat. Euthyph. 14 C, e)pisth/mh do/sews qeoi=s: so Rep. 439 D, po/lei diakoni/an. dokou=nta—sc. to the Lacedaemonians, who were therefore indignant.

i)sxurizo/menoi—‘insisting, maintaining’: iii. 44, tou=to o(\ *kle/wn i)sxuri/zetai. dh/, a particle giving emphasis to the particular words to which it is attached, gives the reason urged by the Athenians: iii. 108, kata\ xrhsmo\n dh/ tina, ‘in accordance, as they alleged, with a certain oracle’. Thus used it often conveys the idea that the alleged reason is a mere pretence.

a)di/khma e)pikale/santes—‘expostulating against the (detention) of the ships as an act of injustice’: v. 59, ei)/ ti e)pikalou=sin *)argei/ois, ‘if they have any ground of complaint against the Argives’; the full construction being with dat. of person, while the thing complained of is expressed by the acc. or an inf. clause.
ta\ peri\ *pu/lon—nom. to e/polemei=to: iii. 6, ta\ peri\ *mutilh/nhn e)polemei=to: v. 26, ta\ e)/peita e)polemh/qh. We must render ‘hostilities went on at Pylos’.

*)aqhnai=oi me/n—construction in accordance with the sense, as if a)mfo/teroi e)pole/moun had gone before: see note on ch. 2, 15: cf. v. 70, h( cu/nodos h)=n, *)argei=oi me\n...xwrou=ntes, *lakedaimo/nioi de/ k.t.l., ‘the encounter took place, the Argives etc.’, an exact parallel to the sentence before us. e)nanti/ain—‘in opposite directions’, so used of two waggons, i. 93. If Cobet's rule, given in the note on ch. 4, 11, is universally applicable to adjectives, this should be e)nanti/oin, but no editor that I know of reads it. neoi=n is absent from the best MSS, but is inserted by modern editors, as there is an awkwardness in understanding it from periple/ontes.

kai\ a(/pasai—‘all without exception’, kai/ emphasizing a(/pasai: v. 71, ta\ strato/peo(\a poiei= kai\ a)/panta tou=to: vii. 28, kai\ cu/mpantes, opposed to kata\ diadoxh/n. periw/rmoun, ‘lay at anchor around’. ta\ pro\s to\ pe/lagos—either, ‘on the side of the open sea’, accusative of reference used adverbially: cf. iii. 96, ta\ pro\s *pai/onas: ch 108, 7, ta\ pro\s *)hio/na: or acc. governed by periw/rmoun. ei)/h—opt. of indefinite frequency with o\po/te.

skopou=mtes kairo/n—a similar construction to ch. 8, 35: ch. 10, 25,=skopou=ntes ei)/ tis kairo\s parape/soi. parapi/ptw, ‘to occur’, is used with kairo/s by Xenophon and Polybius (Krüg.): cf. ch. 19, 8, paratuxou/shs.
The account of the operations in Sicily is now resumed from ch. 1; some of the statements there given being recapitulated here.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXIV
div2.p: e)n th=| *sikeli/a|—in construction the epithet of *surako/sioi, but belonging in sense to the whole passage, marking the change of scene from Greece to Sicily: cf. iii. 88, oi( e)n th=| *sikeli/a| *)aqhnai=oi, etc.
pareskeua/zonto—‘were (as we have told) getting ready’: see ch. 1, 19. proskomi/santes—‘having taken to (Messene)’.

e)nh=gon—‘urged on’ the intruders, or the invasion. Sometimes of persons, as in ch. 21, 9, au)tou\s e/nh=ge: sometimes of things, i. 67, e)nh=gon to)n po/lemon: sometimes as here, with no object expressed: so vi. 61, e)nago/ntwn tw=n e)xqrw=n.

kai\ au)toi\ de/—‘and they themselves too’: i. 132, kai\ h=n o(\e\ ou(/tws, ‘and so too was the case’: ii. 36, kai\ pre/pon de\ a(/ma. kai\ de/=and also (Madv. § 229 a). This seems to be the same invasion as that related in ch. 1.
a)popeira=sqai—elsewhere Thuc. uses the active: e.g. vii. 17, with naumaxi/as.

ta\s me\n parou/sas—‘seeing that the ships they had were few’; the emphasis falling upon o)li/gas, which in its construction is the predicate. For a similar order of words cf. v. 10, oi( d' au(tou= custrafe/ntes o(pli=tai e)pi\ to\n lo/fon: v. 41, oi( pre/sbeis a)fiko/menoi au)tw=n: Ar. Rhet. 1. 5. 17, oi( a(/lloi ai)sxroi\ a)delfoi/, o( de\ kalo/s: Ar. Vesp. 839, tou=t' a)/ra prw=ton ta)di/khma ei)sakte/on: the spaced words being predicative.
e)formou=ntes—‘blockading’: the word belongs more especially to nausi/n; the sense of invading or attacking being supplied with pezh=|.

xeirw/sasqai—‘they hoped to subdue’, aor. inf. after h)/lpizon, referring to the result immediately looked for. The following gi/gnesqai either depends directly on h)/lpizon, the present inf. indicating a lasting result, or its construction, like that of ei)=nai, line 17, corresponds to the general sense of the sentence—‘we hope to take Rhegium, and (we think) our position thereby becomes (gi/gnetai) strong’. gi/gnesqai=was sure to be: ch. 9, 26, a(lw/simon gi/gnesqai.

a)krwthri/ou—in apposition with *(rhgi/ou, ‘a projecting point on the Italian coast’. It seems plain that the passage refers to the advantageous position of Rhegium itself, not to some promontory near the city.

*)aqhnai/ois te ou)k—Classen omits te, which however is found in the best manuscripts. If we retain it, we must either consider that it is out of place, and in sense follows e)formei=n, coupling it to tou= porqmou= kratei=n; or we must suppose that Thuc. was going to speak of the Syracusans in the second part of the sentence, but altered its construction.

e)/sti de/—‘consists of, is formed by’: so, in a similar topographical description, iii. 112, e)sto\n de\ du/o lo/fw h) *)idome/nh. tou=to—‘this channel’. braxu/taton a)pe/xei—so iii. 104, a)pe/xei o)li/gon. The strait is not narrowest between Rhegium and Messene, nor are these places exactly opposite each other.
Thucydides is speaking of the strait generally, which at its narrowest point is not much more than two miles across, and would be entirely commanded by Rhegium and Messene.

h(=| *odusseu/s—the passage of Ulysses is related in the twelfth book of the Odyssey. Charybdis, the whirlpool monster, was more terrible than Scylla, the monster of the rock, and Ulysses escaped with the loss of some of his men by keeping nearer to the side on which Scylla dwelt.

dia\ steno/thta de\ kai/—‘owing to the narrowness of the passage, and as it rushes in, etc.’; two reasons given with different verbal construction. e)s au)to/—into this channel,=tou=to, line 20. Note that in this passage qa/lassa is used of the sea generally, pe/lagos of a particular ‘sea’, as a geographical description. The ‘Tyrsenian (Tyrrhenian) sea’ is that on the W. coast of Italy, the ‘Sicilian’ E. and S.E. of Sicily.
ei)ko/tws xaleph\ e)nomi/sqh—‘naturally got a dangerous name’. The way in which Thuc. speaks shows that the terrors of the strait were entirely a thing of the past.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXV
div2.p: h)nagka/sqhsan—though they wished to fight (ch. 24, 8), the action, late in the day and in the narrow strait, was forced upon them by the danger of a friendly ship. a)ntepanago/menoi— ‘putting out to sea against’, e)pi/ implying that the Syracusans made the attack.

e)n tw=| *(rhgi/w|—‘in the territory of Rhegium’, i.e. at some point on the coast where the Locrians had established themselves, Rhegium itself being the headquarters of the Athenians. The Syracusans and allies had thus two naval stations, to which they now fled, w(s e(/kastoi e)/tuxon, i.e. each ship made for the nearer point. Classen however points out that there is no mention of any such naval station friendly to Syracuse near Rhegium, and thinks it possible that Thucydides means that the Syracusans returned to Messene, and the Athenians to Rhegium, the sentence to which oi( *surako/sioi is the nominative expanding in meaning at this point, and applying to the combatants on both sides: ‘they departed, each combatant making for his own headquarters at Messene and Rhegium respectively’. For similar cases of what may be called expanded apposition see note on ch. 80, 18, kai\ prokri/nantes e)s disxili/ous..., oi( me\n ta\ i(era\ perih=lqon, oi( de\ k.t.l. In the sentence before us however
w(s e(/kastoi seems more applicable to the beaten Syracusans only, who fled as they best could in different ways. Moreover a)pole/santes certainly refers to the Syracusan side alone.

e)pege/neto tw=| e)/r gw|—‘closed upon the action’: so ch. 48, 20, nu\c e)p. tw=| paqh/mati: iii. 112, nukto\s e/pigenome/nhs, etc. e)/rgon— ‘action’, i.e. fight: v. 67, e/n th=| e)kei/nwn to\ e)/rgon e)gi/gneto, ‘the action was to be fought in their country’.

oi( me\n *lo/kroi—in ch. 1 we are told that the Locrian army withdrew from Rhegium. They may not have finally evacuated the territory till now, or possibly there may have been two invasions. The land and sea forces were now concentrated at Peloris, the N. E. promontory of Sicily.

xeiri\ sidhra=|—‘a grappling iron’: vii. 62, xeirw=n sidhrw=n e)pibolai/. au)toi\ a)pw/lesan—‘they themselves (the Athenians) lost’. This is plainly right, because of e)te/ran nau=n a)pollu/ousin, line 21, and ou)k e)/lasson e)/xontes, line 23. Otherwise au)toi=s, which has the better authority, might stand, meaning ‘they destroyed for the enemy’. Jowett suggests that au)toi=s may mean ‘they lost at the hands of the enemy’=dat. commodi.
a)po\ ka/lw—‘with a rope’, i.e. being towed. They kept as near to the shore as possible to have the support of the land forces.

a)posimwsa/ntwn—‘got their ships into the open sea’, according to the scholiast. simo/s means ‘snub-nosed’, and when applied to ground signifies sloping up hill, as in Xen. Hell. iv. 3, 23: see Lidd. and Scott. Hence the meaning seems to be that the Syracusans cast off their tow-ropes, and made an oblique movement at an obtuse angle to their former course, thus getting into the open and attacking the Athenians first. The Athenian fleet seems to have been in very incompetent hands since the arrival of Pythodorus (iii. 115).
prodi/dosqai—‘news being brought that Camarina was to be betrayed’; impf. like prodidome/nhn, ch. 7, 5. Camarina was a Syracusan colony, but friendly to the Athenian allies (iii. 86).
*na/con th\n *xalkidikh/n—colonized by the Chalcidians from Euboea, and the first Greek settlement in Sicily (vi. 3).
teixh/reis poih/santes—‘having confined them within their walls’: so ii. 101: Hdt, i. 162.

peripleu/santes—round a headland which lies to the s. of Naxos. kata\ to
 *)akesi/nhn—‘by way of’: iii. 7, kata\ to
 *)axelw=|on e)/pleuse (opp. to kata\ gh=n): ch. 14, 1, kaq' e(ka/teron to
 e)/|sploun. For the order cf. ch. 43. 3, e/pi\ th
 *solu/geian kw/mhn

pro\s th\n po/lin e)seba/llon—if the reading be right, this probably means ‘made an inroad in the direction of the city’, e)sba/llw being used of invading a country, not of attacking a place. (When used with e/s of cavalry attacking a body of troops, as ii. 100: vi. 70, it possibly means ‘shooting darts into’ though the meaning of charging seems more appropriate in the former of these passages.) Poppo and others would here read prose/ballon, ‘made an attack’: in viii. 31 e)sbolh\n poihsa/menos th=| po/lei is the manuscript reading, for which also prosbolh/n is proposed as a correction.

*sikeloi/—the non-Greek inhabitants, called ba/rbaroi, line 42. *sikeliw=tai was the general name for the Greek colonists. In vi. 2 we are told that the *sikeloi/ crossed originally from Italy, and being numerous and powerful they gave their name to the island, of which they still possessed the centre and northern portions. u(pe\r tw=n a)/krwn—with kate/bainon, ‘came down in numbers over the heights’. Possibly oi( u(pe/r, who dwell beyond the heights', should be read. bohqou=ntes <*>ti/—to attack the Messenians: iii. 110, bohqei=n e)p' au)tou/s.
e)p' oi)/kou—‘homewards’ (with e(/kastai). The allied fleet was broken up, and the contingents returned to their several ports.

kekakwme/nhn—‘having received a severe blow’: ch. 87, 7, kakou/menoi, ‘sustaining injury’. prosba/llontes applies to the whole allied force, which is divided into oi( me\n *)aqhnai=oi..., o( de\ pezo/s. e\pei/rwn—‘made their attempt’: ch. 43, 24, e)pi\ kw/mhn peira/oein: vii. 72, a)/llh| peira/sein: usually with gen., i. 61, peira/santes tou= xwri/ou. For kata/ and pro/s see note on line 32. o( pezo/s—(adj.) sc. strato/s, ‘the land army’: i. 47, etc.
e)pekdromh\n poihsa/menoi—‘having sallied out against them’; a similar compound to e)pekqei=n, ch. 34, 3.

tou= *dhmote/lous—there seems no reason for the article, which as a rule is used only with names which are well known, or have been mentioned before. The rule however is not invariably observed. meta\ to\ pa/qos—i.e. after their disastrous attempt on Naxos. e)gkatelei/fqhsan frouroi/—‘had been left behind in the city as a garrison’, on the separation of the combined forces.

tropai=on sth/santes—the infinitesimal success thus commemorated seems to have satisfied Pythodorus, who now returned to his headquarters at Rhegium, the Athenians having this year lost Messene and gained no compensating advantage.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXVI
div2.p: e)/ti e)polio/rkoun...e)/menen—the imperf. denotes the continuance of the state of things described at the end of ch. 23.
o(/ti mh/—also written o(/ ti mh/, ‘except’: ch. 94, 10, ou) parege/nonto o)/ti mh\ o)li/goi: cf. ch. 16, 15, o(/sa mh/.

diamw/menoi to\n ka/xlhka—‘scraping away the shingle’; see Arnold's note. Eur. Bacch. 709, describes the Bacchae as finding milk, a)/kroisi daktu/loisi diamw=sai xqo/na. oi(=on ei)ko/s—sc. pi/nein au)tou/s, such water as could be thus procured.

stenoxwri/a—cf. ch. 8, 35—9. The Athenians held only Pylos itself, the mainland and the island being occupied by their enemies. There was therefore no anchorage or harbour (o)/rmos) where the ships could lie, nor could the men land with safety except under the walls of the fort. The trireme was plainly a vessel for fighting only, with but little accommodation for the crew.

si=ton h(|rou=nto—‘took their food’, ai( me/n in this clause implying the crews. Cobet (Var. Lect. p. 451) would read oi( me/n: but cf. i. 110, where trih/reis is followed by ou)k ei)do/tes. kata\ me/ros—‘in turn, in divisions’: iii. 49, oi( me\n u(/pnon h(|rou=nto kata\ me/ros oi( de\ h)/launon.

para\ lo/gon—‘contrary to reasonable expectation or reckoning’: vi. 33, tou= *mhdou para\ lo/gon polla\ sfale/ntos. e)pigigno/menos—lit. ‘coming after, or coming upon them’, i. e. lasting longer than they had calculated: i. 126, xro(nou e)pigignome(nou, of a siege: iii. 77, e)pigene/sqai, of a reserve force which was to fall on the enemy when already engaged.

ou(\s w)/|onto—‘for they thought they should reduce them’. ou(/s means the enemy, as the sense shows, though the antecedent is not expressed. Such a sentence is elliptical, and would be completed by inserting ‘as they were besieging men, whom’ etc. So ii. 44, xalepo\n oi)=da pei/qein o)/n, w(=n kai\ polla/kis e(/cete u(pomnh/mata, ‘I know it is hard to persuade you, when you will often be reminded of them’, i.e. of the sons slain in war, of whom Pericles is speaking.

h(merw=n o)li/gwn-‘within a few days’: Ar. Vesp. 260, ou)k e)/sq' o(/pws ou)x h(merw=n tetta/rwn u(/dwr a)nagkai/ws e)/xei to\n qeo\n poih=sai, ‘it can not be but rain must needs fall within four days’: cf. note on qe/rous, ch. 1, 1.
ai)/tion de\ h)=n oi(—‘the cause was the Lacedaemonians having given notice’, i.e. the fact that they had done so: so viii. 9, ai)/tion d' e)ge/neto oi( me\n polloi\ ou)k ei)do/tes k.t.l.

to
 boulo/menon—‘any who wished’, subj. to e)sa/gein: i. 26, oi)kh/tora to
 boulo/menon i)e/nai keleu/ontes, ‘directing that all who chose should go as settlers’, o\ boulo/menos is the usual phrase employed when a duty or privilege is open to all: Dem. Tim. 720 (quoting a law), kathgorei=n *)aqhnai/wn to
 boulo/menon oi)=s e)/cesti, ‘any duly qualified Athenian may be accuser’.

a)lhlesme/non—‘ground’: Hdt. vii. 23, si=tos pollo\s e)foi/ta e)k th=s *)asi/hs a)lhlesme/nos. For the form see Veitch's Greek Verbs. Cobet would read a)lhleme/non. ei)/ ti—‘any’, lit. ‘if (they could send in) any’: i. 14, *)aqhnai=oi kai\ ei)/ tines a)/lloi.

oi)=on a)n...cumfe/rh|—‘of whatever kind might (lit, may) be useful for a siege’, i.e. for besieged men. The rel. with a)/n is commonly used in thus defining quality or character. The subj. construction is not unusual after a past tense, e.g. ii. 74, e)bouleu/santo...a)ne/xesqai...o)/ ti a)\n cumbai/nh|.

oi(=on a)\n cumfe/roi is also read, and gives a good but different sense, ‘such as might be likely to prove serviceable’, a)/n being then connected with the verb and not with oi(=os: cf. vi. 36, e)c w)=n a)\n a)/nqrwpoi dra/seian, ‘from what men would be likely to do’: so vii. 48, e)c w)=n a)/n tis eu)= le/gwn diaba/lloi. This construction is common, and requires notice. It is often liable to be misunderstood, from a)/n standing next the relative, though not belonging to it.
ta/cantes a)rguri/ou—‘having rated’ the service or the provisions ‘at a high price’: so line 30, tetimhme/na xrhma/twn, gen. of price.

a)pai/rontes—‘putting off’: ch. 46, 2, e)k th=s *pu/lou a)ph=ran. The converse of this is katai/rw, ‘to put in’: viii. 39, e)s *kau=non kath=ran: cf. kata/rseis, ‘landing-places’, line 31. o(po/qen tu/xoien—‘from any point they chanced’, opt. of indefinite frequency: cf. ch. 25, 7, w(s e(/kastoi e)/tuxon, ‘as each happened’. e)/ti nukto/s—‘while it was still night’: so ch. 31, 2, nukto/s, lit. at a time of or within the night.

e)th/roun. katafe/resqai—‘looked out for (a chance of) making the land’; usually with subst. as ch. 27, 11: i. 65, a)/nemon thrh/sasi, etc.; or partic. i. 134, e)/ndon o)/nta thrh/santes au)to/n, etc. For katafe/rw see note on ch. 3, 9: in the present chapter we have various compounds with kata/ in the sense of coming to the coast.

toi=s de\ a)feidh/s—lit. ‘the landing was made unsparing’, i e. they ran to shore at the risk of wrecking their boats. a)feidh/s—‘unsparing, reckless’: Eur. Iph. T. 1354, h(mei=s d' a)feidh/santes, ‘made reckless’. kaqesth/kei—‘was made or
established’ the word implies a more or less permanent state of things; i.e. this reckless landing was secured by the Lacedaemonian arrangements: cf. ch. 78, 14: ch. 34, 21, kaqi/stato.

e)pw/kellon—cf. note on o)kei/lantas ch. 11, 26. This sentence gives the two reasons for risking the landing—the government paid for the boats, and the troops on the island were watching (e(fu/lasson) to save the provisions. ka/tarsis— a rare word, except in late Greek.

galh/nh|—‘in calm weather’: most probably a dat. of the point of time: ii. 20, e)kei/nh| th=| e)sbolh=| katabh=nai, ‘to descend in that invasion’, where see Poppo's note: cf. Dem. Meid. 570, o)xei=sqai dia\ th=s a)go/ras tai=s pompai=s ou) duna/menon. Rutherford inserts e)n. kinduneu/seian, h(li/skonto—indefinite frequency.
kata\ to\n lime/na—as opposed to pro\s to\ pe/lagos: cf. ch. 25, 32, kata\ to\n *)akesi/nhn.

mh/kwna memelitwme/nhn—‘poppy seed mixed with honey and pounded linseed’. Krüger quotes a scholiast to the effect that poppy seed mixed with honey was a preventive of hunger, while linseed kept off thirst. The commentators cite Athenaeus and other authorities to show that such substances were sometimes smeared on bread or mixed with it.
w(=n lanqano/ntwn—objective gen. after fulakai/. oi( de\ mh\ lanqa/nein sfa=s—‘and the others to detect them’, mh\ lanqa/nein after e)texnw=nto, lit. ‘that it should not escape them’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXVII
div2.p: e)n de\ tai=s *)aqh/nais...e)kpleu/sesqai—the subject of this sentence is the people at Athens, there are two principal verbs, h)po/roun and e(dedoi/kesan, and the participle o(rw=ntes is in agreement with the subject of those verbs; a(/ma...peripe/mpein being parenthetical. A difficulty is however caused by the words e)n xwri/w| e)rh/mw|. The troops at Pylos were those who were e)n xwri/w| e)rh/mw|, while oi(=oi/ te o(/ntes peripe/mpein certainly refers to the people at Athens. In order therefore to complete the sense we must understand either ou)=si governed by komidh/n (or metape/mpein), ‘for men who were’, or o)/ntwn, gen. abs., ‘the troops being’ in a desolate position. Poppo gives a different explanation, that there is a confusion between the Athenians at Athens and those at Pylos, or that they are as it were identified, in which case o)/ntes is understood with e)n xwri/w e)rh/mw.

talaipwrei=tai—‘suffers hardships’, mid.: ch. 35, 15, talaipwrou/menoi; so iii. 3, tetalaipwrhme/noi, etc. kai\ si=tos— nom. to e)splei= placed emphatically. e)splei=—cf. ch. 39, 6, e)sple/ousi, note.

mh\ sfw=n—‘lest they should have winter stopping their blockade’; see note on au)tw=n ch. 14, 12. xeimw/n—here ‘the winter season’, in line 11 it means stormy weather. e)pila/boi,— ‘come upon’ and stop: ch. 96, 37, nukto\s e)pilabou/shs to\ e)/rgon: in ii. 51 it is used of the attack of disease.

o(rw=ntes—governs the two clauses tw=n te...e)some/nhn, to/n te...e)so/menon. a)/ma...peripe/mpein is parenthetical, see note on line 1. The meaning is clear—‘the soldiers withal were in a desert place, and not even in summer could the Athenians send them adequate supplies’. ou)k e)so/menon—‘would not be practicable’: see note on ch. 8, 25, o(/pws mh\ h)=|.

a)ll' h)\...e)kpleu/sesqai—the infinitives are governed by o)rw=ntes, or by the idea supplied therefrom, ‘they expected, they feared’. a)ne/ntwn—‘having given up, slackened’: Eur. Suppl. 1042, fulaka\s a)nh=ka. perigenh/sesqai—‘would pull through’, i.e. would escape being reduced by hunger.

e)fobou=nto tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous—‘they feared with regard to the Lacedaemonians’; an extension of the common construction by which the subject of a subordinate sentence is made the object of the principal verb, as ch. 1, 8, fobou/menoi tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, mh/. o(/ti e)/xontas—‘because they thought they must have some strong point in their favour, as they made no further overtures to them’. ti i)sxuro/n—a source or point of strength: iii. 6, o(rw=ntes ou)de\n i)sxuro\n a)po\ tw=n *lesbi/wn. e)pikhrukeu/esqai is used especially of making conciliatory overtures, in which sense it is common.
katasko/pous—‘commissioners of inspection’, Grote: so vi. 41. e)s kataskoph/n, of a commission sent by Syracuse to the towns in Sicily.

fanh/sesqai—grammatically dependent on a)nagkasqh/setai: in sense however it seems rather connected with the notion of knowing or thinking which is the main idea of the sentence. We might in fact have expected h)\ a)nagkasqh/setai ..., h)\ fanh/setai. Poppo indeed suggests that fanh/sesqai may follow gnou/s directly, o(/ti only affecting the first clause (as in i. 87, etc.), and h)/ being out of place, as in vi. 24 init.
w(rmhme/nous ti to\ ple/on—‘somewhat the more eager’: so ch. 21, 18, ti ma=llon, note. th=| gnw/mh|—‘in mind’, with w(rmhme/nous.

a)pesh/mainen—‘pointed at’; a)po/, as in a)pido/ntes, ch. 18, 1, implying that he glanced aside from the immediate question to attack his enemy. e)pitimw=n—‘reproaching him’; possibly ‘saying to his reproach’, with r(a/|dion ei)=nai, which otherwise depends on apesh)mainen.
paraskeuh=|—‘with a (proper) force’, with pleu/santas labei=n: cf. vi. 21, au)to/qen paraskeuh=| a)cioxre(w| e)pie/nai, ‘to invade them with an adequate force from our own country’.

kai\ au)to/s g' a)/n—‘and he himself, he said, would have done this had he been in office’, i.e. had he been strathgo/s. From this passage it is plain that Cleon had no official standing, but derived his power merely from his personal influence in the assembly. The conduct of the war rested with the board of strategi, of whom Nicias was the most prominent. Here again Cleon was undeniably right in urging an energetic attempt on the Spartan position.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXVIII
div2.p: u(poqorubhsa/ntwn—‘having raised some clamour’, u(po/ thus compounded having, like sub, the sense of somewhat. The word is not elsewhere found in classical Greek, on which account Cobet suggests u(po/ ti qorubhsa/ntwn. e)s to\n *kle/wna— ‘at Cleon’: e)s is very generally used by Thucydides in phrases denoting relation, such as i. 38, e)s h(ma=s toioi/de, ‘of such character towards us’: iii. 14, ta\s tw=n *)ellh/nwn e)s u(ma=s e)lpi/das, ‘the hopes of the Greeks in regard to you’: cf. note on ch. 22. 14, diaba/llein e)s: so i. 128, eu)ergesi/an e)s basile/a kate/qeto=‘he began to bestow services on, or win favour with, the king of Persia’: ii. 60, ta\ th=s o)rgh=s u(mw=n e)s e)me\ gege/nhtai.

o(/tiou)—‘because he did not sail even now’. o(/ ti is read by Krüger and Classen and explained as ‘why’, an indirect question corresponding to ti/ direct; Jowett also approves of this: cf. i. 90, o(po/te tis e)/roito o(/ ti ou)=k e)pe/rxetai.

plei=—Krüger takes this to refer to Nicias, and makes e)s to\n *kle/wna mean ‘on hearing Cleon’. It seems however plain that the Athenians called out to ask why Cleon did not sail, if he thought it an easy task. Plutarch (Nic. ch. 7) says that the Athenians called out, ti/ de\ ou)xi\ kai\ nu=n au)to\s su\ plei=s e/pi\ tou\s u)/ndras;

to\ e)pi\ sfa=s ei)=nai—Nicias says ‘so far as concerns us’, sfa=s meaning himself and his colleagues: ch. 9, 21. For ei(=nai cf. i. 21, w\s palaia\ ei)=nai, ‘so far as their ancient date allows’: ii. 89, e\kw\n ei(=nai, ‘so far as my will goes’: see also note on ch. 14, 20, w(s ei\pei=n.

lo/gw| mo/non a)fie/nai—‘only pretended to give up’. lo/gw| is opposed to e)/rgw| or tw=| o)/nti; i. 128, tw=| de\ lo/gw| ape/drasan au)to/n, ‘he pretended that they had escaped from him’: ii. 65, lo/gw| me\n dhmokrati/a, e)/rgw| de\ u\po\ tou= prw/tou a)ndro\s arxh/, of Athens under Pericles.

paradwsei/onta—‘wished to hand over the command’. The termination ei/w is a desiderative formed from the future: i. 33, polemhsei/w, ‘I wish for war’, from the future of polemw=: i. 95, a)pallacei/w, from fut. of a)palla/ssw: viii. 79, naumaxhsei/ontes, from fut. of naumaxw=, etc.: Ar. Vesp. 168, Pax 62, drasei/w. The Latin termination urio has the same force, e.g. esurio, formed from esum supine of edo. a)nexw/rei—‘he began to draw back’. kai\ ou)k e)/fh—‘and said Nicias was general, not he’; au)to/s subj. to strathgei=n, nom. because referring to the subject of e)/*fh.

ou(k a)\n oi)o/menos—‘and never supposing that Nicias could have brought himself to withdraw in his favour’. tolmw=, used according to the context, of audacity, fortitude, hardness of heart, condescension, etc. implies in every case an overcoming of natural weakness or inclination. It may often be rendered ‘to have the heart’ to do something. oi(, sibi, means Cleon, au)to/n Nicias. a)/n—with tolmh=sai.

e)ci/stato—‘renounced’: ii. 63, h(=s (a)rxh=s) ou)de\ e)ksth=nai e)/ti u(mi=n e)/stin, ‘which moreover you can not now give up’. Notice the force of the imperfects in this passage: Nicias ‘was ready to renounce’ the command, Cleon ‘tried to back out’ of it, the people ‘kept calling upon’ Nicias to hand it over, etc.

u(pe/feuge—‘shrunk from’. e)canexw/rei ta\ ei)rhme/na— ‘backed out of what he had said’. Though the verb is compounded with e)c it governs the accusative, since it represents the active idea ‘to evade’: cf. iii. 34, u(pecelqo/ntes tou/tous, ‘withdrawing from these’; i. 128, a)pe/drasan au)to/n: so Dem. Lept. 460, ou\de/na pw/pote ki/ndunon e)ce/sthsan, ‘they never shrank from any danger’, ete. Similarly in Latin we have, Tac. Ann. xii. 35, evadere ‘to pass’ with acc.: so ib. ii. 38, egredi relationem, ‘to go beyond the question’: ib. xi. 36, evecta insulas.
to/sw|—‘so much (the more)’: viii. 24, o(/sw|—to/sw|: so i. 37, tosw=|de. The more usual prose form is tosou/tw|.

kai\ e)kei/nw| e)pebo/wn plei=n—‘and shouted at Cleon to sail’: so v. 65, *)/agidi e)pebo/hsen: vi. 16, ta\ i)/dia e)pibow/menos, ‘cried out at in respect of my private life’. The shouts in the assembly seem to have come from supporters of Cleon, who hoped that he would succeed.

e)capallagh=|—‘get out of’. u(fi/statai—‘undertakes’, with acc.: iii. 57, a)gw=nas u(pe/sthmen, ‘underwent’: ch. 59, 11, kindu/nous u(fi/stasqai: the constr. with dat. ii. 61, cumforai=s tai=s megi/stais u(fi/stasqai, seems to mean ‘to endure even in the greatest misfortunes’. See also note on ch. 39, 14.

parelqw/n—the usual expression for ‘coming forward’ to address the assembly: iii. 41, parelqw\n kai\ to/te. Note ou)/te ...te. *lhmni/ous kai\ *)imbri/ous—usually mentioned together as in iii. 5, where they remain faithful to Athens on the occasion of the revolt of Lesbos: v. 8, where they form a part of the force with which Cleon attempted to recover Amphipolis.

oi(\ h)=san e)/k te *ai)/nou—for peltasta/s te oi(\ h)=san e)c *ai)/nou... kai/ k.t.l. te, which is grammatically out of place, connects in sense e)/k te *ai)/nou and a)/lloqen, as the two sources from which the auxiliaries came.

tau=ta—‘this force’. e)ne/pese—see note on ch. 4, 5. ti kai\ ge/lwtos—‘something even of laughter’: i. 5, fe/ronto/s ti kai\ do/chs, of piracy, ‘even bringing some honour’. th=| koufologi/a| —‘at his vain and boastful speaking’, an unusual word.

This is the first mention of laughter on this occasion, and it was excited simply by Cleon's boastful manner. There is no warrant whatever for the idea that the Athenians committed the incredible folly of forcing the command upon him by way of a joke. Plutarch (Nic. ch. 7) says toi=s de\ *)aqhnai/ois e)ph=lqe gela/sai me/ga ma=llon h)\ pisteu=sai, when Cleon ‘added his limit’ (prosdiwri/sato) of twenty days. Still the majority of the assembly seem to have believed that the attempt ought to be made, and that Cleon would succeed in it. Nicias and his colleagues are however open to grave censure for entrusting the conduct of an expedition, from which they appear to have shrunk themselves, to a man of no military experience or capacity. If this was done merely in the hope of discrediting a political opponent, it would not be easy to find a more disgraceful party manœuvre. Possibly they may have considered the enterprise feasible, but were not unwilling that its risks should fall upon Cleon, while they knew that Demosthenes would be at hand to advise and direct.
a)sme/nois e)gi/gneto—‘sober-minded men were not ill pleased’: so ii. 3, tw=| plh/qei ou) boulome/nw| h)=n a)fi/stasqai, ‘the multitude did not wish to revolt’: ch. 85, 15, boulome/nois e)/sesqai.

tou= e(te/rou teu/cesqai—‘would gain one of two blessings’. a)pallagh/sesqai and xeirw/sasqai are dependent on this clause. The former of these is in the future, implying a state of subsequent continuance, ‘being rid for the future of Cleon’; while xeirw/sasqai refers to one definite point, ‘subduing the Lacedaemonians’. There is no difficulty in the aor. following an expression which denotes expectation: see notes on ch. 9, 21 and 24, 12. The subject to xeirw/sasqai is *kle/wna: cf. v. 63, *)/agin e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon ou) xeirwsa/menon sfi/si *)/argos, ‘blamed Agis for not subduing Argos for them’.
There is no doubt an awkwardness in this change of subject: Cobet, who says of the passage misere laborat, proposes the passive fut. perfect kexeirw/sesqai.

h)/lpizon—‘expected’; as is plain from the following sfalei=si gnw/mhs: cf. 18, 9, gnw/mh| sfale/ntes. Jowett's rendering, ‘which they would have greatly preferred’, is unnecessarily hard on the sw/frones.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXIX
div2.p: kai\ pa/nta diapraca/menos—‘having had all arrangements made’. Note the construction; the gen. abs. is placed between two participles in agreement with the nom. to the verb: see Goodwin, § 111. yhfisame/nwn—so vi. 25, h)/ntina au)tw=| paraskeuh\n yhfi/swntai, ‘what force they are to vote him’.

a)nagwgh/n—‘putting to sea’, a reading adopted by Krüger, Classen, etc., here and in vi. 29 for a)gwgh/n, which has the better manuscript authority. a)gwgh/ means ‘bringing’, as v. 85, h( e)s tou\s o)li/gous a)gwgh/, and might possibly mean the conveyance of Cleon's forces and supplies, and therefore his voyage in general: so Xen. Cyr. vi. 1, 24, e)n tai=s a)gwgai=s, ‘on marches’.

th\n a)po/basin dianoei=sqai—‘to contemplate the descent’. This is the only instance in Thuc. of dianoei/sqai being followed by a substantive. Usually it takes the infinitive, or an adverb, as w(/sper dienoou=nto. We have however, ch. 22, 10, ei)/ ti u)gie\s dianoou=ntai, and iii. 75, ou)de\n u)gie\s dianooume)nwn: cf. 13, 19, a(\ dienoh/qhsan. It does not therefore seem necessary to adopt Cobet's view that poiei=sqai has been accidentally omitted.

It has been suggested that some secret communications had already passed between Demosthenes and Cleon, which made the latter ready to undertake the expedition. It is at any rate clear that he did not take a leap in the dark, but had full information as to the state of things at Pylos. Thus he took with him a force of suitable character, and secured the help of Demosthenes, a brave and competent officer.

r(w/mhn—‘confidence’: vii. 18, toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois e)gege/nhto r(w/mh: so ii. 8, e)/rrwnto e)s to\n po/lemon, ‘were confident and eager for the war’. h( nh/sos e)mprhsqei=sa—‘the island having caught fire’: cf. ch. 26, 16, oi( *lakedaimo/nioi proeipo/ntes: so iii. 20, tw=| si/tw| e)pilipo/nti e)pie/zonto, etc.

pro/teron me/n—corresponding to this is tw=n de\ stratiwtw=n, ch. 30, 3, a long parenthetical passage being inserted, which gives the reasons of the previous hesitation on the part of Demosthenes. The island is described in similar words in ch. 8.

pollw=| ga\r a)/n—either ‘if he landed with a large army’, or stratope/dw| agreeing with a)poba/nti. prosba/llontas—‘they could fall on him from an unseen position and do him injury’; a)/n goes with bla/ptein. The acc. and inf. depend on e)no/mize, or the sense supplied from it, the same construction lasting to the end of the chapter.

ta/s—note one article with two nouns of different number: so i. 143, th\n me\n gh=n kai\ oi)ki/as a)fei=nai. Note also neut. plural dh=la in agreement with the general idea of ‘the enemy's situation’.

h(=| bou/lointo—‘wherever they chose’, represents after a past tense h(=| a)\n bou/lwntai; ‘wherever they may choose’. e)p' e)kei/nois ga/r—‘for the initiative would rest with them’: ii. 84, th\n e)pixei/rhsin e)f' e(autw=| e)no/mizen ei)=nai.
lanqa/nein te—‘and so their force though numerous would get cut to pieces unawares’, lit. ‘would find itself being cut to pieces’: so i. 141, w(/ste lanqa/nein to\ koino\n fqeiro/menon.

ou)k ou)/shs—‘it being impossible to see at what point they ought to help each other’: so ii. 89, mh\ e)/xwn th\n pro/soyin tw=n polemi/wn e)k pollou=, ‘not being able to sight the enemy at any distance’. Some editors in both passages write pro/oyis in the sense of ‘seeing in front’: the word occurs v. 8, where it means ‘seeing beforehand’.

xrh=n—the general sense of the passage deals with what Demosthenes had been thinking up to the time of the fire, the imperfect infinitives with a)/n throughout the passage representing what in his view would have been happening if the attack had been made. We have therefore the imperf. xrh=n corresponding to e)no/mize in line 23: so ii. 51, e(\n d' ou)de\ e(\n kate/sth i(/ama o(/ ti xrh=n prosfe/rontas w)felei=n, ‘there was no one single remedy, the application of which could be serviceable’: v. 35, xro/nous de\ prou)/qento e)n oi)=s xrh=n (The present xrh/ is often used in a similar way. as in ch. 34, 28.)

div2.head: CHAPTER XXX
div2.p: a)po\ de\ tou= *ai)twlikou=—the disaster which Demosthenes sustained the year before, as related iii. 97, 98. The Athenians were deficient in light-armed troops, and after holding out for some time against an enemy who could not be brought to close quarters, but harassed them at every point, they finally took to flight. Many lost their way in a wood, and were destroyed by fire. The Athenians lost many of their allies, and 120 of their best heavy-armed men. It is not a little remarkable that Cleon (ch. 28) at once announced his intention to bring troops of the very kind which Demosthenes had lacked in Aetolia, and which had operated against him with fatal effect. This certainly suggests the probability of some understanding between the two commanders.
me/ros ti—‘in a great measure’, an adverbial use of the determinant accusative: cf. ch. 16, 17, note. ou)x h(/kista— ‘mainly’. These are instances of mei/wsis: cf. ch. 13, 22.
e)sh/|ei—‘occurred to him’: vi. 30, ma=llon au)tou\s e)sh/|ei ta\ deina/.
th=s nh/sou toi=s e)sxa/tois—‘on the edges of the island after prosi/sxontas.
dia\ profulakh=s—‘with a guard posted in advance’: ii. 81, dia\ fulakh=s e)/xontes.
kata\ mikro\n th=s u(/lhs—these words are the object of e)mprh/santos, kata\ mikro/n forming as it were a single word: cf. note on ch. 3, 13, e)pi\ polu/.

a)/kontos—‘unintentionally’, a)/kwn implying sometimes the absence of will, sometimes its contravention: Plat. Rep. 520 B, of philosophers, au)to/matoi e)mfu/ontai a)kou/shs th=s politei/as. a)po\ tou/tou, if the text be right, goes with e)pigenome/nou, meaning ‘after this’ or ‘thereupon’. It usually means ‘from this cause’. Classen therefore omits kai/, and takes a)po\ tou/tou with e)/laqe katakauqe/n. e)pigenome/nou—‘having sprung up after’, see note on ch. 26. 14. e)/laqe katakauqe/n=‘got burnt down accidentally’.

ou(/tw dh/—this sentence extends to e(toima/zwn, line 15. As it stands in the text there is one principal verb, pareskeua/zeto, line 13; the participle katidw/n, in agreement with the subject of this verb, governing the two clauses tou/s te *lakedaimoni/ous...o)/ntas, and th/n te nh=son...ou)=san. The clause u(ponow=n... e)spe/mpein is parenthetical.
plei/ous o(/ntas—‘to be more numerous’ than he had thought.

u(ponow=n pro/teron—this refers to the arrangements for provisioning the island in the truce, ch. 16. e)la/ssosi—for a smaller number than was stated, or than now appeared. Demosthenes had been under the impression that the enemy had overstated their numbers in order to get a store of provisions. u(ponow=n and e)spe/mpein are imperfect.

au)tou=—the invariable MSS reading. Professor Kennedy considers it to be the genitive, referring to to\n si=ton and governed by e)la/ssosi, and translates ‘suspecting that he (Dem.) was sending in the corn for a smaller number than the corn itself’, i.e. smaller than corresponded to the rations imported according to the terms of the armistice. It is true that in ch. 16, lines 9 and 13, the words e)kpe/mpein and e)spe/mpein are used of the Lacedaemonians, which is an argument in favour of their being here also the subject of e)spe/mpein. The Spartans however would not be allowed by Demosthenes to convey the corn into Sphacteria themselves, and so to have constant intercommunication with their men on the island. Whatever the particular arrangements were, the rations would be delivered by the agency of the Athenians, and therefore e)spe/mpein is here used of Demosthenes, who actually ‘sent in’ the corn.

It has also been proposed to take au)tou= with e)spe/mpein as equivalent to au)to/se, but this seems impossible, the occurrence of such words as e)ntau=qa and e)kei= with verbs of motion (e.g. i(/na per m(/rmhnto, ch. 48, 31), being no warrant for such a use of au)tou=, which as an adverb means ‘on the spot’.

au)to/se, au)toi=s, au)tou/s, and au)tou\s pe/mpein have been suggested as emendations. Of these au)tou/s, which is read by Classen, gives the best sense and supplies a subject to e)spe/mpein: though it is open to the objection that its meaning must be gathered from the context, those who sent in the corn not being identical with tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous, line 9. (See Appendix.)

th/n te nh=son—I have adopted the transposition of the clauses thn te nh=son...ou=san and to/te...poiei=sqai, which is approved by Krüger and followed by Classen. It has the advantage of avoiding grammatical difficulty, and greatly improving the sense. The fire disclosed the number of the enemy, and made landing easier. Demosthenes then saw the prospect of effecting a capture, which was in truth worth a struggle, and accordingly prepared for the attempt.

It must however be noted that according to manuscript authority the clause to/te...poiei=sqai follows e)spe/mpein. If this
order be retained, the inf. poiei=sqai depends on u(ponow=n or the sense of thinking implied therein and it is necessary to insert de/ after to/te (Poppo). We thus get the meaning, ‘thinking that the Athenians were now the more eager, as for a prize worthy of their efforts’. Arnold reads to/ te...poiei=sqai dependent on katidw/n, but the arrangement is extremely awkward.
eu)apobatwte/ran—the island was ‘easier to land on’ because the fire had destroyed the cover in which the enemy could have posted themselves.

to/te w(s e)p' a)cio/xrewn—following th\n e)pixei/rhsin pareskeua/zeto, ‘as for a prize worthy of a more earnest effort on the part of the Athenians’, or perhaps ‘a risk which called for’ such an effort. a)cio/xrewn, ‘worthy, adequate’, is here followed by an infinitive clause.
