We have, v. 13, a)cio/xrewn o)/ntwn dra=n, in the sense of ‘competent’: also Hdt. iv. 126.
metape/mpwn—‘sending for’. In this sense the middle would be expected; Thucydides however uses active and middle indifferently: cf. ch. 15, 4, note on bouleu/ein.

prokalou/menoi ei) bou/lointo—‘proposing, if they would, etc.’ sc. that they should agree to these terms: the force of bou/lointo extends to the end of the sentence, which is partly elliptical: cf. ch. 37, 8, e)kh/ruca/n te ei) bouloi/nto.
sfi/si—the Athenians, referring to subject of pe/mpousi, = ‘to us’. sfa=s au)tou/s—i.e. tou\s e)n th=| nh/sw|.

e)f' w(=|...thrh/sontai—‘on condition that they shall be kept’: i. 113, e)f' w(=| tou\s a)/ndras komiou=ntai, ‘on condition that they shall have their men restored’: so i. 103, e)f' w(=| te e)ci/asin. For this use of e)pi/ cf. ch. 16, 24, ai( spondai\ e)pi\ tou/tois e)ge/nonto: it gives the ground or understanding on which the truce was based. For fut. indic. see Goodwin, § 65, especially beginning and note 5.

fulakh=| metri/a|—an order not uncommon in Thuc.; cf. ch. 10, 8, kindu/nou tou= taxi/stou. The definite article here seems to imply a particular kind of imprisonment, which would be called metri/a, the conditions of which were supposed to be known to the Lacedaemonians.

e(/ws a)\n...cumbaqh=|—‘till terms should be arranged concerning the general issue’. tou= ple/onos—the question of the war in general, as opposed to the smaller part of it which concerned Pylos in particular: so ch. 117, 7, cumbh=nai ta\ plei/w, ‘to make general terms’, as opposed to a temporary truce: cf. note on ch. 17, 17, tou= ple/onos. cumbaqh=|—aor. pass. of cumbai/nw (so ch. 23, 8, parabaqh=|): the perf. pass. inf. cumbeba/sqai occurs viii. 98.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXI
div2.p: e)pe/sxon—‘delayed’, often used with the acc. of time: ch. 73, 29, xro/non de\ e)pisxo/ntes: cf. ch. 5, 4, note.
u(sterai/a|—sc. h(me/ra|: ch. 25, 32. The termination -aios is especially used of a day; so i. 61, tritai=oi a)fi/konto, ‘they came on the third day’.

e)p' o)li/gas nau=s—the heavy armed men were landed first, the rest of the force following at daybreak, ch. 32, 6. th=s nh/sou e(kate/rwqen—‘on both sides of the island’, = ab utraque parte. So words like inde are used of the quarter on which a movement is made: cf. line 13, e)k.

w(=de ga\r dieteta/xato—‘the enemy were disposed as follows’: ato, an Ionic form, = nto as seen in e)le/lunto: so v. 6 and vii. 4, e)teta/xato: iii. 13, teta/xatai: ib. e/fqa/ratai i.e. e)/fqar-n-tai. In Plat. Rep. 533 B we have tetra/fatai from tre/pw. These forms are not found in the orators, the substantive verb, as infr. tetagme\noi h)=san, being the usual periphrasis for an unpronounceable third person plural.

me/son de/—the absence of articles in this clause is remarkable. me/son is indeed often used without to/ for ‘the centre’ of an army, and here is similarly used of the centre of the island or of the Lacedaemonian position. On the same principle the definite sense is to be supplied with o(malw/taton and peri\ to\ u)/dwr. There seems to have been only one spring, and that was brackish (a(lmuro/n), ch. 26, 16.

kai\ ga/r ti—‘for indeed there was also, etc.’; this explains why it was less e)pi/maxon. li/qwn—‘made of stones’; i. 93, oi( qeme/lioi pantoi/wn li/qwn u)po/keintai, ‘the lower courses consist of stones of all sorts’. Krüger quotes some other instances. For loga/dhn see note on ch. 4, 7.

ei) katalamba)noi—‘if they should be hard pressed’: for katalamba/nw see note on ch. 20, 4. a)naxw/rhsis biaiote/ra— a retreat unusually hard pressed: v. 73, h( fugh\ kai a)poxw/rhsis ou\ bi/aios ou)de\ makra\ h/=n: so ii. 33, biaio/teron a)nagago/menoi, after the failure of a naval attempt.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXII
div2.p:
e)/n te tai=s eu)nai=s—te couples this clause with its acc. participle to the nominative laqo/ntes th\n a)po/basin, which is in agreement with oi) *)aqhnai=oi. Classen quotes from Tac. Hist.
i. 45, vinciri iussum et maiores poenas daturum affirmans praesenti exitio subtraxit. Demosthenes now repeated the manoeuvre by which he had surprised the Ambraciots the year before; iii. 112, a(/ma o)/|rqrw| e)pipi/ptei...e)/ti e)n tai=s eu)nai=s k.t.l.
laqo/ntes th\n a)po/basin—‘having landed without being seen’, a)po/basin is a determinant accusative, ‘in the landing’: a strange construction. Rutherford inserts poihsa/menoi.
e)s e)/formon—because all the ships lay round the island at night; ch. 23, 14.

e)k me\n new=n e(bdomh/konta—seventy ships were already at Pylos, ch. 23, 18, and Cleon had brought a small number besides. qalami/wn—the oarsmen of the lowest bench, usually called qalami=tai. They were left to look after the ships, probably as being less able-bodied than the qrani=tai and zugi=tai, who had to work longer oars.

According to the calculation on ch. 9, 13, each ship would furnish upwards of 100 men, giving a total of about 8000 sailors. Besides these there were 800 heavy-armed, at least 1600 archers and targeteers, and Messenians and others from the garrison. Demosthenes and Cleon had therefore a force of more than 10,000 men to attack the 420 Lacedaemonians with their attendant Helots.

w(s e)/kastoi e)skeuasme/noi—‘equipped as they severally were’, i.e. as well as could be managed in each case. In this phrase, which is far from uncommon, the participle suggests the verb which is to be supplied with w(s: vi. 17, taxu\ d' a)\n w(s e)/kastoi prosxwroi=en, ‘they would speedily join us severally’, lit. ‘as each (would be inclined to do so)’. toco/tai te—corresponding to e)k me\n new=n: so i. 144, te answers to me/n, where Poppo cites other instances. Krüger writes toco/tai de/. Three divisions of the force are noted, the sailors (me/n), the archers etc. brought by Cleon (te), and besides these (te) the Messenians and others on the spot.

katei=xon—‘were posted’, lit. ‘held (their quarters)’: viii. 28, e)n h(=| *)amo/rghs pole/mios w)\n katei=xe, ‘was maintaining (his position)’: so habito = ‘to live’; and so ‘to keep’ is sometimes used in English.

*dhmosqe/nous de\ ta/cantos—Demosthenes, who appears to have directed the entire attack, brought to bear on the Spartans the same tactics that had overthrown his own army in Aetolia (iii. 98, 99). die/sthsan—‘were divided’; elsewhere used of taking different sides in a quarrel, as ch. 61, 8, kata\ po/leis die/stamen. kata/—distributive, ‘in bodies of two hundred or more’; te and
kai/ have here a disjunctive force, implying that there were bodies answering both descriptions, some of the stated size, some larger.

e)/sti d' h)=|—‘and at some points’: so i. 93, etc.: we have also e)/sgin o)/te, ‘at times’, i. 25, etc.; and various similar expressions with the relative, as e)/stin w)=n, e)/sti par' oi(=s, ei/si\n oi(/, this last phrase being always plural.
ta\ metewro/tata—‘the highest points’.

pro\s o(/ ti a)ntita/cwntai—for subj. see note on kaqormi/swntai, ch. 13, 13. a)ntita/cwntai— so vi. 102, a)nteta/canto pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, ‘faced, drew up against’: cf. ch. 11, 3 e)ta/canto: ch. 35, 10, etc. The aor. middle not having a passive force we must understand ‘themselves’ or ‘their forces’ in all these cases; indeed an object is expressed after a)ntita/casqai in ii. 87 and iii. 56.

a)mfi/boloi—‘exposed on all sides, between two fires’: so ch. 36, 19: ii. 76, e)n a(mfibo/lw|: from ba/llw in the sense of ‘to shoot at, hit with a missile’, as in line 19, and often in this description. tw=| plh/qei—‘from the number’ of their assailants; dat. of instrumental cause.

h(=| xwrh/seian—opt. because of e)/mellon, ‘wherever they went the foe were sure to be in their rear’; it corresponds to h(=| a(\n xwrh/swsin after a present. Classen is perhaps right in taking oi( pole/mioi as nom. to xwrh/seian, as pole/mioi is used in line 16 of the Lacedaemonians. In most editions the comma is placed after xwrh/seian and pole/mioi is nom. to e)/mellon.

yiloi\ kai\ oi( a)porw/tatoi—a)/poros is taken by nearly all commentators as meaning in this passage ‘hard to deal with’, of those against whom a po/ros or ‘means of acting’ can not be found. The sense then is ‘light armed troops and those the most difficult to cope with’. The words kai\ oi) come in very awkwardly with a)porw/tatoi, and kai/ is bracketed by Classen, who takes yiloi\ oi( a)porw/tatoi as subst. before adj. like kindu/nou tou= taxi/stou.

Probably however kai\ oi( a)porw/tatoi means ‘even the worst provided’, being in partial apposition with yiloi/ and closely connected with e)/xontes a)lkh/n. This view avoids any difficulty as to the construction of kai\ oi(, and gives the excellent sense that even the least efficient combatants proved in the circumstances very effective foes.

It is to be noticed that adjectives which, like a)/poros, admit of both an active and a passive meaning, have usually an active sense when used of persons, and a passive sense when
used of things: e.g. Soph. Ant. 79, bi/a| politw=n dra=n e)/fun a)mh/xanos, ‘I am unable to do’, compared with ib. 90, a)mhxa/nwn e)ra=s, ‘you are enamoured of what can not be done’. So a)/poros of persons would naturally be ‘without means’, as i. 9, h)=lqen e)s a)nqrw/pous a)po/rous: Soph. Ant. 360, a)/poros e)p' ou)de\n e)/rxetai. It is however certainly used sometimes of persons in the passive sense, e.g. Plat. Apol. Socr. 18 D: Eur. Bacch. 800.

e)k pollou= e)/xontes a)lkh/n—a)lkh/, ‘prowess, spirit for fighting’: ii. 84, e)s a)lkh\n tre/pesqai opposed to feu/gein: ib. 87, te/xnh a)/neu a)lkh=s ou)de\n w)felei=. The meaning is that the light troops proved valiant and formidable foes with missiles from a distance (e)k pollou=): cf. iii. 30, (qa/lassan) h(=| h)mw=n h\ a)lkh\ tugxa/nei ma/lista ou)=sa = ‘where our main strength lies’. So Aristotle, Eth. Nic. iii. 6 (9). 11, says the a)ndrei=os is brave, e)n oi)=s e)/stin a)lkh/, ‘in circumstances where a man can strike a blow for life and honour’.
oi)=s mhde\ e)pelqei=n—The neg. mh/ implies such that, like qui with the subjunctive.
feu/gonte/s te ga/r—explains oi(=s mhde\ e)pelqei=n. e)kra/toun—‘got the better’, i.e. in speed. a)naxwrou=sin—dat. participle: ii. 79, a)naxwrou=sin e)ne/keinto.
gnw/mh|—‘plan’ or ‘design’ as formed in the mind. to/ te prw=ton. kai/—cf. ch. 103, 15. e)peno/ei—‘planned’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXIII
div2.p: o(/per h)=n plei=ston—‘what was in fact the main portion of the troops’: ii. 4, to\ plei=ston, ‘the main body’: i. 73, to\ ple/on.
e)sxei=ras e)lqei=n—‘to come to close quarters’: so ch. 96, 9: ch. 43, 9, h)=n h( ma/xh e)n xersi\ pa=sa.
e)c e)nanti/as—‘opposite, in face’: ch. 35, 13, etc.: so iii. 92, e)k kainh=s: i. 77, apo\ th=s prw/ths, etc. A fem. noun is supposed in these expressions, but it is not always clear what noun.
th=| sfete/ra| e)mpeiri/a|—‘their special skill’ as heavy armed infantry: ii. 89, dia\ th\n e)n tw=| pezw=| e\mpeiri/an ta\ plei/w katorqou=ntes.

h)=| ma/lista—lit. ‘wherever especially’, i.e. at any particular point where: so ti/ ma/lista; ‘what in particular?’ The Latin use of maxime with tum, cum, etc. corresponds to this. The opt. and imperf. are frequentative.

kai\ oi( u(postre/fontes—‘and those who retired’: for the use of the article cf. ch. 46, 19, tou\s e)lqo/ntas: v. 5, tou/tois e)ntuxw\n toi=s komizome/nois, etc. In the present passage many editions read oi(/ demonstrative, as in ch. 68, 30. (See Jowett's note; and Lidd. and Scott on o( and o(/s.)

a)/nqrwpoi kou/fws te—two reasons are given for the success of the light troops; their equipment enabled them to elude the enemy, and the ground was in their favour. The first reason is expressed by e)skeuasme/noi and prolamba/nontes in agreement with a)/nqrwpoi, the second by the dat. xwri/wn te xalepo/thti k.t.l. It is therefore the te after xwri/wn which corresponds to kou/fws te. It is however possible to take te and lai\ as merely connecting e)skeuasme/noi and prolamba/nontes.

prolamba/nontes th=s fugh=s—‘getting the advantage in their flight’: vii. 80, prou)/labe pollw=|, ‘got far ahead’. fugh=s is explained as a partitive genitive: so ch. 47, 17, e)peta/xunon th=s o(dou=, ‘quickened on their road’: Hdt. iii. 105, prolamba/nein th=s o(dou=.
xwri/wn te xalepo/thti—‘and from difficulty of ground’: xwri/a, various spots where a struggle took place.

kai\ .o)/ntwn—either this means ‘which also were’, or kai\ connects the dative xalepo/thti with a gen. abs. traxe/wn o)/ntwn. In the latter case the construction is confused between xwri/wn te xalepo/thti kai\ traxu/thti and xwri/wn te xalepw=n kai\ traxe/wn o)/ntwn. A somewhat similar irregularity is noticed on ch. 9, 20.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXIV
div2.p: h)kroboli/santo—‘skirmished’: iii. 73, etc. The aor. implies that this skirmishing is now to be considered at an end.
e)pekqei=n—‘to run out against’: used in v. 9 of a sally from Amphipolis. The variety of words used in these chapters for attacking an enemy is worthy of notice.
gno/ntes au)tou/s—a long sentence loosely strung together, consisting chiefly of participial clauses in agreement with oi( yiloi/. The verb does not come till line 12.

tw=| a)mu/nasqai—with bradute/rous, either ‘from defending themselves’, i.e. from keeping up the struggle so long; or, with var. lect. a)mu/nesqai, in defending themselves. The latter view gives the better sense in a similar passage, vii. 43, o(/pws th=| parou/sh| o(rmh=| mh\ bradei=s ge/nwntai.

kai\ au)toi\ ei)lhfo/tes ‘and having themselves derived the greatest confidence’. th=| o)/yei—lit. ‘from their seeing’, i.e. the sight of their overwhelming superiority in numbers: iii. 38, ou( to\ drasqe\n pisto/teron o)/yei labo/ntes, ‘from having seen it’.
cuneiqisme/noi—lit. ‘having become more habituated to the enemy's no longer appearing equally formidable to them’, i.e. having learned by now to dread their enemy less.
a)/cia th=s prosdoki/as—‘corresponding to their expectation’: v. 60, ou)de\n a)/cion th=s paraskeuh=s; so vi. 21, a)/cion th=s dianoi/as.

dedoulwme/noi—‘cowed’, like slaves before their masters (Arnold): ii. 61, douloi= to\ fro/nhma. w(s e)pi\ *lakedaimoni/ous —‘considering that they were going against Lacedaemonians’: cf. note on ch. 2, 1.
a)qro/oi—with e)mboh/santes: ch. 112, 3, strato\n e)mboh/santa a)qro/on: ii. 92, a)po\ e)no\s keleu/smatos e)mboh/santes.
e)xw/rei polu\s a)/nw—‘rose up in clouds’. to\ pro\ au(tou=— ‘what was before one's self’, tini\ or tina\ being implied: ch. 62. 12, th\n au)tou= tina\ swthri/an proi+dei=n.

ferome/nwn—‘pouring on them’: Plat. Rep. 496 D, e)n xeimw=ni koniortou= kai\ za/lhs u)po\ pneu/matos ferome/nou. fe/resqai often = to move, as of the heavenly bodies, ib. 529 D: Cic. Acad. ii. 26. 82, sol tanta incitatione fertur: so h) fora/, motion, Ar. Eth. Nic. x. 3 (4). 3.

to/ te e)/rgon xalepo/n—‘so now the struggle began to go hard with the Lacedaemonians’: cf. ch. 25, 42, xalepw=s a)pexw/rhsan. kaqi/stato—stronger than e)gi/gneto, as implying a more fixed result: cf. ch. 26, 29, kaqesth/kei.

ou)/te—the next te corresponds to this. oi( pi=loi—‘felt cuirasses’, or according to others ‘felt helmets’. e)/stegon— ‘were proof against’; ste/gw in this sense = ‘to keep out’: ii. 94, nh=es ou)de\n ste/gousai, of leaky vessels.
e)napoke/klasto—the broken spears were sticking in their cuirasses and shields, and impeding their movements. ballome/nwn—gen. abs. ‘as they got hit’.

ei)=xo/n te—‘and they could do nothing with themselves’, not knowing which way to turn, or how to act. Subordinate to this sentence and explanatory of it are the three following clauses introduced by me/n, de/, and te.
th=| o)/yei—lit. ‘in respect of seeing’, as in line 6: iii. 112, ou) kaqorwme/nous th=| o)/yei.

paraggello/mena—‘orders’: so ii. 11, etc.: v. 71, parh/ggellen, ‘passed the word’, or gave orders. kindu/nou...periestw=tos—‘being surrounded by danger on every side’: cf. note on periesto/s, ch. 10, 4. kaq' o(/ ti—‘as to how’, with a)munome/nous swqh=nai.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXV
div2.p: te/los de/—‘but at last’, an accusative used adverbially; sometimes in the middle of a sentence: ii. 100, w)/ste te/los h\suxi/an h)=gon: cf. the adverbial use of a)rxh/n, ‘to begin with’. traumatizome/nwn—imp., lit. ‘were being wounded’.

e)n tw=| au)tw=|—‘on the same ground’. a)nastre/fesqai— lit. ‘to move to and fro’: vii. 44, o(pli=tai ou)k o)li/goi e)n stenoxwri/a| a)nestre/fonto: Matt xvii. 22, a)nastrefome/nwn de\ au)tw=n e)n th=| *galilai/a|. The Lacedaemonians suffered more from the missiles because their movements were confined within a small space.

cugklh/|santes—‘closing up’, or locking their shields together’: v. 71, h( pukno/ths th=s cugklh/|sews, ‘locking up closely’. With the act. aor. is to be understood ‘their shields’ or ‘their ranks’: cf. note on ch. 32, 17, a)ntita/cwntai.
e)ne/dosan—‘gave in’ or ‘gave ground’, so ch. 37, 2, etc.: cf. ch. 19, 21. u(poxwrou=ntes e)gkatelamba/nonto—‘were caught in making their retreat,’ or ‘on the field’ (cf. e)gkata/lhyin v. 72 fin.).
meta\ tw=n tau/th|—called me/ros ti ou) polu/, ch. 31, 11. tau/th|—‘at this point’.

peri/odon...ei)=xon—‘could not surround and hem them in from the strength of the position’. au)tw=n—objective gen. with peri/odon and ku/klwsin: so sfw=n, line 19. Words in wsis have an active force; ku/klwsis, ‘encircling’, e)leuqe/rwsis, ‘setting free’, etc.: iii. 78, fobou/menoi th\n periku/klwsin, ‘fearing that the foe would surround them’. ou)x ei)=xon—i.e. had not the power of effecting.
w)/sasqai—cf. ch. 11, 15.

kai\ th=s h(me/ras—‘and in fact for the greatest part of the day’. kai/ not uncommonly thus gives a further definition or explanation, sometimes even a correction, of what has gone before. It may then be translated by some such expression as ‘in fact’, ‘that is to say’, etc.; cf. ch. 33, 2, kai\ o)/per h)=n.
oi( me\n e)cela/sasqai—‘the one to dislodge (the enemy) from the hill, the others to maintain their ground’: vii. 5, e)cela/sasqai e)k th=s xw/ras.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXVI
div2.p: a)pe/ranton—‘when it proved endless’; sc. the struggle (to e)/rgon) or the matter generally.

a)/llws e)/fh ponei=n sfa=s—‘said they were wearying themselves to no purpose’: i. 109, ta\ xrh/mata a)/llws a)nalou=to. ponei=n more commonly means ‘to be in distress’: i. 30, oi( cu/mmaxoi e)po/noun: or ‘to be hard pressed’ in battle: ch. 96, 25, e)po/nei to\ eu)w/numon.

sfa=s—see note on ch. 9, 21. The Messenian said a)/llws ponou=men, which is thus represented in oratio obliqua. As the subject of ponei=n is not identical with the subject of e)/fh, but much more extensive, the former is naturally put in the accusative; and this is no violation of the principle by which a)/llws ponei= becomes in orat. obliq. a)/llws e)/fh (au)to\s) ponei=n: cf. Krüger on iii. 111, nomi/sas kataprodi/dosqai sfa=s, where he cites a large number of similar instances, e.g. vi. 49: vii. 4 and 48: viii. 32. (See however ch. 114, 31.)

dokei=n bia/sasqai—‘he was resolved to force the approach’. dokw= and dokw= moi take an aor. or present inf. in the sense ‘I have a mind to, am determined’: Ar. Av. 671, e)gw\ me
 au)th
 kai\ filh=sai/ moi dokw=, ‘I mean to kiss her’: id. Vesp. 177, to
 o)/non e)ca/gein dokw=: cf. Wayte's note on Plat. Protag. 340 A, dokw= moi parakalei=n. bia/sesqai (Cob.) is tempting.

e)k tou= a)fanou=s—so ch. 96, 24: i. 51, e)pe/pleon e)k tou= a)fanou=s. e)k either means ‘starting from where he could not be seen’, like ii. 19, o(rmh/santes a)p' au)th=s, or is used adverbially with tou= a)fanou=s, meaning ‘so as not to be seen’: so e)k tou= fanerou=, e)k tou= profanou=s, etc.

kata\ to\ a)ei\ parei=kon—the meaning is that he made his way as he could find a passage from place to place along the cliffs. kata/—‘along, by way of’, as in ch. 26, 33. parei=kon— ‘affording an opportunity or chance’ of getting along: iii. 1, o(/ph| parei/koi ‘wherever a chance offered’. a)ei/—‘from time to time’, i.e. from point to point.
prosbai/nwn—‘making his approach’: also in iii. 22: ch. 129, 24, etc. Some manuscripts have probai/nwn, ‘advancing’.

e)pe/rrwsen—‘gave fresh confidence to’: cf. note on r(w/mh, ch. 29. 10: in pass. vii. 17, pollw=| ma=llon e)pe/rrwnto. e)pi/ in comp. implies sequence, as in e)piskeua/zw, to repair, e)pibio/w, to survive, e)pigame/w, to marry a new wife: cf. ch. 38. 9. e)fh|rhme/nou.

cumptw/mati—a (rare) substantive from cumpi/ptw, ‘to fall out, happen’ or ‘to happen together’. It means therefore ‘a chance’ or ‘coincidence of circumstances’. Dem. in Dionys. 1295, a)kou/sion su/mptwma = an unavoidable mischance: Ar. Rhet. i. 9. 32 (where see Cope's note), su/mptwma = ‘an accidental coincidence’: as applied to disease it is our symptom. In ch. 68, 10, we have the verb cune/pese, ‘it fell out at the same time’.

e)kei=noi/ te...ou(=toi/ te—taken by the majority of editors as a parenthetical sentence. In some editions, however, there is no stop after ou(=toi/ te, which is taken as nom. to ou)ke/ti a)ntei=xon. According to this latter view the words oi( *Lakedaimo/nioi k.t.l. are by a change of construction left without a verb.

e)kei=noi—the Lacedaemonians at Thermopylae. th=| a)trapw=|—‘by the path’, known to all Greeks: see Hdt. vii. 213, seq. ou(=toi/ te—sc. diefqa/rhsan, though as a matter of fact they were not all slain but compelled to surrender.
polloi=s te—two reasons for their giving ground, the one expressed by part. maxo/menoi, the other by dat. a)sqenei/a|. dia\ th\n sitodei/an gives the reason for a)sqenei/a|.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXVII
div2.p: gnou(s...o(/ti—followed, after an intervening clause, by the participial construction diafqarhsome/nous, as if o)/ti had not preceded: so v. 46, ei\pei=n te e)ke/leuon o)/ti...h)/dh a)\n pepoih=sqai. See Madvig, § 159 R. 4, for similar irregularities.

o(posonou=n—‘ever so little’, lit. ‘how much soever’: vi. 56, ei/ kai\ o(posoiou=n tolmh/seian, ‘if ever so few should make the venture’: ou)=n added to a rel. pronoun or adverb having the same force as the Latin cumque.

e)piklasqei=en th=| gnw/mh|—‘they might be shaken in their resolution’. Here gnw/mh is the ‘determination’ to resist to the last: in iii. 59 the same phrase is used of a ‘fixed purpose’ to do justice without mercy: in iii. 67 e)piklasqh=nai by itself means ‘to be softened’. ta\ o(/pla paradou=nai—explanatory of what the Athenians hoped for. Classen brackets these words, believing them to have been inserted from the following line.

e)kh/ruca/n te—‘so they made proclamation’: ch. 4, 12. ei) bou/lointo k.t.l.—sc. that they should do so: cf. ch. 30, 18: iii. 52, prope/mpei kh/ruka le/gonta ei\ bou/lontai paradou=nai th\n po/lin: v. 115, e)kh/rucan ei)/ tis bou/letai *)aqhnai/ous lhi/zesqai.

w(/ste bouleu=sai—‘on condition that the Athenians should decide’, lit. ‘so that’: ch. 46, 11, cune/bhsan w/ste, ‘they made terms on condition that’: Xen. Anab. ii. 6. 6, e)co\n r(a|qumei=n, bou/letai ponei=n w(/ste polemei=n, ‘when he might live at ease, he prefers labour provided he may be at war’.

e)kei/nois—the Athenians, though just spoken of, are called e)kei=noi, ‘those yonder’, because in place and in interests alike they are remote from the Lacedaemonians, with whom this part of the sentence deals: iii. 52, paradou=nai th\n po/lin toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois kai\ dikastai=s e)k ei/nois xrh/sasqai: ii. 11, o(/tan e)n th=| gh=| o(rw=sin h(ma=s dh|ou=nta/s te kai\ ta)kei/nwn fqei/rontas, ‘when (the Athenians) once see us in their country ravaging and wasting the possessions of our enemies yonder’, i.e. of the Athenians. So in the orators a person just named is often called e)kei=nos, when not present in the court or immediately concerned in the case: ille is similarly used.

The following are instances of the Thucydidean use of this pronoun: i. 132, paidika/ pote w)\n au)tou= kai\ pisto/tatos e)kei/nw|, where both au/tou= and e)kei/nw| refer to Pausanias (see Shilleto's note for parallels): ii. 7, *lakedaimoni)ois ..toi=s ta)kei/nwn (sc. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn) e(lome/nois: viii. 45, w(s oi( *xi=oi...a)ciou=si...a)/llous u\pe\r th=s e)kei/nwn (sc. tw=n *xi/wn) e)leuqeri/as kinduneu/ein.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXVIII
div2.p: parh=kan—‘dropped’, or ‘lowered’, shewing that they ceased to resist: so Hdt. iii. 128, meth=kan ta\s ai)xma/s, ‘dropped their spears’, or ‘lowered their spear points’, in token of submission. oi( plei=stoi—‘for the most part’; partial apposition; see note on ch. 6, 4.

dhlou=ntes prosi/esqai —dhlw= is commonly followed by a participle, but here by the infin., to avoid the concurrence of two participles: so ch. 47, 8, kata/dhloi o)/ntes...mh\ a)
 bou/lesqai. prosi/esqai—‘to accept, approve of’, with acc.: so ch. 108, 26, a(\ mh\ prosi/entai. The literal meaning is ‘to take, draw to oneself’, hence ‘to admit, adopt’. It is also used with nom. of thing and acc. of person, meaning, ‘to bring over, attract’: Ar. Eq. 359, e)
 d) ou) prosi/etai/ me, ‘one thing pleases me not’: Hdt. i. 48, ou)de
 prosi/eto/ min. ‘With this, and the former signf., may be compared the double idiom, I like it not,—it likes me not’ (Lidd. and Scott).
e)kei/nwn—‘on the part of the Lacedaemonians’.

tou= de\ met) au)to/n—with e)fh|rhme/nou, ‘the officer who had been chosen to succeed after him’. So when the first and second in command had fallen at Olpae the leadership devolved
on Menedaeus (iii. 109). e)fhrh|me/nou is the pluperfect participle, the appointment having been made beforehand in view of a possible future contingency: for e)pi/ in comp. implying sequence, see note on ch. 36, 14. For the position of the words cf. note on ch. 5, 10.

ei)/ ti e)kei=noi pa/sxoien—‘if anything should befall them’ a frequent euphemism, meaning if they should fall = si quid illis accidisset (Suetonius uses evenio in the same way): cf. Ar. Vesp. 385, h)/n ti pa/qw 'gw/: Eur. Iph. T. 753, h)/n ti vau=s pa/qh|: Dem. Lept. 472, e)a/n ti sumbh=| pote/. The opt. with ei) in orat. obliqua in a sentence referring to past time, often represents h)/n with subj. in orat. directa in a sentence referring to present time (Madvig, § 132 a).
diakhrukeu/sasqai—‘to send a message across’: like diapleu/sas, line 17: diebi/bazon, ch. 8, 46. In such words the mid. voice is used of those who employ the herald or get the message sent.

e)kei/nwn me/n—i.e. of the Lacedaemonians; put first in the sentence for emphasis, in construction governed by ou)de/na. a)fe/ntwn—sc. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, ‘the Athenians allowing no Lacedaemonians (to pass over)’.

o( teleutai=os diapleu/sas...a)nh/r—‘the messenger who crossed last’. All the words between the article and the substantive form the epithet of a)nh/r, while teleutai=os especially belongs to and qualifies diapleu/sas: so ch. 8, 49, oi( teleutai=oi (sc. diaba/ntes) kai\ e)gkatalhfqe/ntes.
o(/ti—not uncommonly introduces the actual words: v. 10. le)gei o)/ti, oi( a)/ndres h(ma=s ou) me/nousi. This is a well-known usage in New Testament Greek.

mhde\n ai)sxro\n poiou=ntas—‘provided you do nothing dishonourable’. Possibly implying, as the scholiast says, that death was more noble than surrender: at any rate thrusting all possible responsibility on their unfortunate countrymen.

dieskeua/zonto—this verb is only found here in Thucydides, who elsewhere prefers paraskeua/zomai. The preposition probably denotes the different arrangements of the Athenians for disposing their force or distributing their prisoners, as in the following diedi/dosan.

diekomi/santo—komi/zomai is the word commonly used for recovering or obtaining the restoration of the bodies of the slain: compounded with dia/ it means ‘conveyed across to themselves’ or ‘got conveyed across’: so in i. 89 it is used of the bringing back of the women and children to Athens from Salamis, where they had been placed during the Persian invasion.

tosoi/de—‘the following number’; see note on toia/de, ch. 9, 29. o)ktw\ a)pode/ontes triako/sioi—‘three hundred all but eight’, lit. ‘failing, falling short of eight’. o)ktw/ is genitive: ii. 13, triakosi/wn a)pode/onta mu/ria = 9700.

stadi/a—‘standing, hand to hand’: Hom. Il. xiii. 314, stadi/h u)smi/nh, ‘close fight’: so e)n stadi/h| alone, ib. 514, etc.: cf. vii. 81, ou) custado\n ma/xais e)xrw=nto, ‘they did not fight pitched battles’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XXXIX
div2.p: xro/nos de\ o( cu/mpas—the same order is found i. 1, ki/nhsis ga\r au(/th megi/sth| e)ge/neto, the substantive being put first in such instances in order to shew at once what the sentence is about. e)ge/neto—‘amounted to’: see note on 9, 12.
a)ph=san—‘were away’ a correction of Cobet's for a)ph/|esan ‘went away’, the proper form of writing which is a)ph=|san (Nov. Lect. p. 346): the same correction is made ch. 42, 20.

toi=s e)sple/ousi—neuter, ‘by the provisions thrown in’; ch. 27, 3, si=tos e)splei=. The Athenians had a blockading squadron at Salamis, ii. 93, tou= mh\ e)splei=n *megareu=si mhd' e)kplei=n mhde/n, ‘to prevent imports or exports’.
e)gkatelh/fqh—i.e. were found in the island on its capture: note on ch. 8, 49.
h)\ pro\s th\n e)cousi/an—‘than he might have done’; lit. ‘than (was possible) looking at, having regard to, his ability’.

maniw/dhs—this refers to the mad and reckless manner in which Cleon asserted that he would perform a dangerous military enterprise in a given time. There was nothing insane in the attempt itself. Plutarch (Nic. ch. 7) says that the Athenians were wont to indulge Cleon's koufo/ths and mani/a. He shewed no mani/a in carrying out his undertaking, but succeeded (ib. ch. 8) tu/xh| xrhsa/menos a)gaqh=| kai\ strathgh/sas a)/rista meta\ *dhmosqe/nous.

a)pe/bh—‘was fulfilled, came off’: iii. 26, ou)de
 a)pe/bainen au)toi=s w)
 prosede/xonto, ‘none of their expectations were realized’: iii. 93, para\ do/can au)toi=s a)pe/bh: ch. 104, 11, ou)de
 a)pe/bainen. a)po/ thus used in composition signifies a result corresponding to what goes before; thus a)podi/dwmi often = to give in the proper quarter, e.g. to deliver a letter, to pay due honour, etc.

u(pe/sth—‘undertook’; the lit. meaning of u(fi/stamai in this sense being to place oneself under an engagement: viii. 29, w)/sper u(pe/sth: Hom. Il. iv. 267, w(s u(pe/sthn: also with inf. and with acc.

div2.head: CHAPTER XL
div2.p: h)ci/oun—‘expected’, lit. ‘thought it worthy of them’: i. 136, ou)k a(cioi= feu)gonta timwrei=sqai, ‘he calls on him not to avenge himself on an exile’: iii. 44, ou)k a)ciw= u(ma=s to\ xrh/simon a)pw/sasqai, ‘I would not have you reject’. In such instances the negative is placed as with ou)/ fhmi = I deny or refuse: i. 28, po/lemon de\ ou)k ei)/wn poiei=n, ‘they urged them not to make war’
a)pistou=nte/s te—this nominative has no verb, the construction being altered after the introduction of the clause with gen. abs. tino/s e)rome/nou.

di' a)xqhdo/na—‘for the sake of annoyance’, i.e. in order to insult or mortify. dia/ with acc. usually means ‘in consequence of’; sometimes however it is used, like e(/neka, of the object or purpose; ii. 89, dia\ th
 sfete/ran do/can, ‘for the sake of their honour’: ch. 102, 20, dia\ to\ perie/xein au)th/n, ‘for the sake of enclosing it’: v. 53, dia\ tou= qu/matos th
 e)/spracin, ‘for the sake of exacting payment of the sacrifice’: so Plat. Rep. 524 c, dia\ th
 tou/tou safh/neian, ‘for the sake of making this clear’: Dem. Boeot. 1004, di' e)ph/reian, ‘for spite’: Ar. Eth. Nic. iv. 3 (8), 31, di' u)/brin.

kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/—‘A title’, says Arnold, ‘corresponding, in the union which is expressed of personal qualities with a certain superiority of birth and condition more nearly with our word gentleman than with any other. The Spartans prided themselves on being all kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/; and the question, put probably by a democratical seaman, was intended to sneer at once at the pretension and the name’. The term is only found here and viii. 48 (also as a quotation): see Neil, Ar. Eq. Ap. ii.

a)/traktos—a word meaning some kind of reed, or thorn, and thence applied to anything made thereof. In prose it means a spindle, and is used by the poets for an arrow. Probably the Laconians used the word in the latter sense; though some suppose that the heavy-armed soldier called darts and arrows spindles in contempt.

o( e)ntugxa/nwn—diefqei/reto—Classen takes e)ntugxa/nwn absolutely, ‘he who came in the way, he who chanced’, governing toi=s te li/qois kai\ toceu/masi by diefqei/reto. For this use of e)ntugla/nw cf. ch. 132, 20, toi=s e)ntuxou=sin e)pitre/pein. Here
however the run of the words seems to connect e)ntugxa/nwn with what follows. Thucydides in fact often adopts such an order that the intermediate words may be governed either by what precedes or what follows, or may indeed depend upon both; cf. ch. 17, 10. Note the force of the imperfect tense in e)ntugxa/nwn and diefqei/reto, ‘he who (from time to time) came in the way was slain (on each occasion)’.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLI
div2.p: e)bou/leusan—‘resolved’; see note on ch. 15, 4.
me/xri ou(=—with subjunctive without a)/n: ch. 16, 19.

w(s e)s patri/da tau/thn—lit., ‘as into their native country in this’, = e)s tau/thn w)s (e)s) patri/da. In prose ou(=tos without the article is always predicative in force: e)/xwn tou=to e)pi/gramma ‘having this as an inscription’, not ‘having this inscription’.
e)/sti ga\r h( *pu/los k.t.l.—nearly similar words are used in ch. 3, 15, where we have the reasons for which Demosthenes wished to occupy Pylos.

e)lhi/zonto—Classen reads e)lhi/zonto instead of e)lh/izo/n te, on the ground that the word, which occurs six times in Thucydides, should always be in the middle voice: so iii. 85, e)lhi/zonto tou\s e)n th=| nh/sw| kai\ polla\ e)/blapton.

kai\ fobou/menoi—‘fearing lest they should have some of the institutions in the land still further revolutionized’; fearing, that is, a new insurrection of the Helots, or some other rising against their aristocratic rule: cf. ch. 55, 8, fobou/menoi mh\ sfi/si new/tero/n ti ge/nhtai tw=n peri\ th\n kata/stasin, ‘relating to their constitution’.
e)/ndhloi ei)=nai—sc. ou) r\a|di/ws fe/rontes, ‘to betray their uneasiness’: ii. 64, mh\ e)/ndhloi e)/ste baruno/menoi, ‘do not shew your distress’.
foitw/ntwn—‘though they often came’: for gen. abs. see ch. 3, 8.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLII
div2.p: The Athenians, in the warlike and hopeful temper caused by their success at Pylos, now begin a series of attempts to occupy points on the enemy's coast. The command is taken by Nicias, who was both encouraged to action and incited to rivalry by the glory which Cleon had gained.
eu(qu/s—with meta\ tau=ta: i. 56, meta\ tau=ta d' eu)qu/s.

e)n i(ppagwgoi=s nausi/—‘in horse-transports’; first mentioned by Thuc. in 430, when they were made by the Athenians out of old ships (ii. 56): i)ppagwga\ ploi=a were used by the invading Persians under Xerxes (Hdt. vii. 79). Aristophanes, lauding the services of the cavalry in this expedition to Corinth, says of the horses (Eq. 599), ei)s ta\s i(ppagwgou\s ei)seph/dwn a)ndrikw=s.

ple/ontes—‘in their voyage’, imperf. part., as in ch. 3, 1, referring to the progress of the whole enterprise: the aor. e)/sxon denotes the first operation attempted. a(/ma e(/w| goes with e)/sxon: if it referred to the departure from Athens pleu/santes would be required.

metacu\ *xersonh/sou kai\ *(rei/tou—see the map in Arnold's edition. The Chersonesus, or peninsula, was a promontory formed by a low ridge of mount Oneion, which intercepted the view between Cenchreae and the beach where the Athenians landed. Rheitus, ‘the beck’, was not quite two miles to the south.

to\ pa/lai—at the time of the Dorian conquest of Peloponnesus, known as ‘the return of the Heraclidae’. The legend is that the Dorians under Aletes reduced Corinth by incessant attacks, expelled the Aeolian dynasty of Sisyphus, and became thenceforth the dominant race. i(druqe/ntes—‘having established themselves’, with pro/s: so i. 131, e/s *kolwna\s i(druqei/s.
e)p' au)tou=—note the demonstrative form of the second clause in a relative sentence.
kate/sxon—so katasxo/ntes, ch. 54, 1; 57, 13.
o( de\ *)isqmo\s ei)/kosi—reckoning to the extreme south of the isthmus where Cenchreae stands.

e)k plei/onos—‘from some time back’: ch. 103, 15, e)/praca/n te e)k plei/onos: so v. 82: viii. 88. The order of the sentence will admit of taking e)k plei/onos either with the words which follow it or with those which go before, while in sense either connexion is right. Timely warning enabled the Corinthians to take timely precautions. tw=n e)/cw *)isqmou=—i. e. those on the north towards Megara, who had their own coast to watch. Note the absence of the article with *)isqmou=: cf. ch 18, 11 note.
a)ph=san—a correction for a)ph/|esan: cf. ch. 39, 5. Poppo retains a)ph/|esan e/n as being equivalent to a)ph=lqon kai\ a)ph=san e)n.

nukto\s katapleu/santes—the Athenians made the coast (kata/) while it was still night, and landed at daybreak, line 8. to\ shmei=a—if it was still night these were fire-signals raised by
the watchers on the coast: so ii. 94 and iii. 22, fruktoi\ h(/|ronto pole/mioi: iii. 80, e)fruktwrh/qhsan e)ch/konta nh=es: cf. ch. 111, 4. shmei=a h)/rqh is used i. 49; i. 63; vii. 34, of a signal for battle; and viii. 95 of a signal for embarkation.
*kegxreia=|—sing. as in ch. 44, 16: viii. 10 etc. *keyxreiai/. h(\n a)ra—cf. ch. 8, 24.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLIII
div2.p: h)=lqen e)pi/—‘advance upon’; not in a hostile sense.
toi=s a)/llois—‘with the rest’, sc. under his command: dat. of the force with which the attack was made, a regular and common construction: cf. ch. 42, 3: Madvig, § 42.
cune/ballen—‘was to encounter’ the enemy, or ‘went on to encounter’: the imp. is read by most editors on good manuscript authority; Arnold has cune/bale.

e)/peita de/—‘in the second place’, corresponding to prw=ton me)n. In this connexion Thucydides uses e)/peita either with or without de/, while other Attic writers usually omit de/: cf. ch. 44, 1, xro/non me\n ou)=n polu\n...e)/peita.

e)n xersi\ pa=sa—‘hand to hand throughout’: vi. 70, genome/nhs e)n xersi\ th=s ma/xhs: cf. ch. 33, 6, e)s xei=ras e)lqei=n: cf. ch. 96, 9. e)w/santo—‘repulsed’, lit. ‘drove from themselves’: so ch. 96, 22: in ch. 11, 15, and 35, 13, it is used of assailants forcing their way.
ai(masia/n—a stone wall or fence, the usual meaning of the word. toi=s li/qois—the stones of which the wall was made loga/dhn: cf. note on ch. 4, 7.

tw=| eu)wnu/mw| ke/ra| e(autw=n—the position of e(autw=n is to be observed. It is admissible because of the epithet eu)wnu/mw| standing where it does; otherwise to\ e)autw=n ke/ras is the right order: cf. note on ch. 5, 10.
a)ne/streyan—‘wheeled round’; the only instance of the active used intransitively by Thucydides: in ii. 49 it is trans.: the middle is found in a somewhat different sense, ch. 35, 2, etc.
kata\ to\ eu/w/numon—‘opposed to’: v. 71, kata\ to\ tw=n e)nanti/wi eu\w/numon.
h)/lpizon...peira/sein—‘they expected the enemy would make an attempt towards the village of Solygeia’: cf. note on ch. 25, 48, kata\ to\n lime/na e)pei/rwn.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLIV
div2.p: cummaxo/menoi—pred. ‘by fighting with them’, i.e. their help was of service in the action.

e)/qento ta\ o(/pla—‘halted’, or ‘took up their position’. The literal meaning of the phrase ti/qesqai ta\ o)/pla is to ground, or put down one's arms, the Greeks being accustomed to lay down their shields and spears when they halted for any time, for instance to listen to an address from their commanders. The converse expression is a)nalamba/nein ta\ o(/pla (ch. 130, 19: Hdt. vi. 78: Xen. Hel. ii. 4, 19, etc.). From the idea of taking up a position thus implied, the phrase ti/qesqai ta\ o(/pla is often used, as in the present passage, when the idea of actually putting down the arms would be out of place. Thus the Thebans, after making their way by surprise into Plataeae, established themselves in the public place (qe/menoi e/s th\n a)gora\n ta\ o(/pla), and made proclamation for any one who chose ti/qesqai par' au(tou\s ta\ o)/pla i.e. to join them (ii. 2). So ta\ o(/pla is used for the camp or position occupied by troops i. 111; iii. 1. Such phrases are especially common in the military language of Xenophon; see Shilleto on ii. 2.

oi( plei=stoi...a)pe/qanon—i.e. their chief loss was at this point. oi( plei=stoi must mean the greater part of those who fell, not of their whole force, for we see afterwards that their total loss only amounted to 212: so vii. 30, a)poktei/nousin au(tw=n e/n th=| e)kba/sei tou\s plei/stous, where the total loss was 250 out of 1300. Classen takes the meaning to be that the greater part of the Corinthians on the right wing were slain, their allies escaping better.
kata\ di/wcin pollh/n—‘hard pressed’, with fugh=s genome/nhs.
oi( e)k th=s po/lews presbu/teroi—cf. ch. 8, 1, tw=n e)k th=s *)attikh=s. The presbu/teroi had remained to guard the city.
e)gkate/lipon—‘left on the field’, more commonly used of leaving a garrison etc. in a town, as in ch. 25, 51.

e)pikhrukeusa/menoi...a)nei/lonto—asking leave to remove the dead was an admission of defeat, which is also implied by the use of e)pikhrukeu/esqai. Thus Plutarch (Nic. ch. 6) says that Nicias preferred to sacrifice his victory and his glory rather than leave two Athenian citizens unburied.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLV
div2.p:
*meqw/nhn—‘the place is now called *me/qana, as the name is written by Pausanias and by Strabo, with this remark on
the part of the latter, that in some copies of Thucydides it was written *meqw/nh, like the town so called in Macedonia. As the Macedonian town was the more famous, the reading *meqw/nh probably prevailed more and more, and is now found in every MS. of Thucydides at present in existence’ (Arnold).

a)polabo/ntes—‘cutting off’ from the mainland by a wall and trench. We are told (i. 7) that the maritime Greeks thus established themselves on peninsulas (ta\s i)sqmou\s a)pela/mbanon) for the sake of security and convenience. The peninsula of Methana, which is of considerable size, is connected with the mainland by a very narrow neck.

e)n w(=|—i.e. on the isthmus or neck itself; but perhaps e)n h(=| should be read, in agreement with xersonh/sou: cf. Classen's critical note. Pausanias (ii. 34) applies the term i)sqmo/s to the whole peninsula when he says th=s *troizhni/as gh=s e)sti\n i/sqmo)s e)pi\ polu\ die/xwn e(s qa/lassan, e)n de( au)tw=| po/lisma ou) me/ga e)pi\ qala/ssh| *me/qana.
to\n e)/peita xro/non—till the peace concluded in 421. In v. 18 we find Methone named as one of the places which the Athenians agreed to give up.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLVI
div2.p:
xro/non o(/n—so edited by Poppo and others as being in accordance with other passages, such as iii. 18, kata\ to
 au)to
 xro/non o(
 oi( *lakedaimo/nioi peri) to
 i)sqmo
 h)=san, and as best accounting for the variation of reading here found. Others have kaq' o(/n: while the manuscript authority is in favour of omitting o(/n, and reading tau=ta e)ge/neto, kai/.... In this last case we have kai/ connecting two statements of time, as is very common in New Testament Greek, e.g. Mk. xv. 25, h)=n de\ w)/ra tri/th kai\ e)stau/rwsan au)to/n. So in Thuc. we have, iii. 110, tw=| de\ *dhmosqe/nei a)gge/lletai...kai\ pe/mpei: cf. Soph. Phil. 355, h)=n d' h)=mar deu/teron...kai\ kathgo/mhn. In the present passage o)/n might have been omitted by a copyist from confusion with the last syllable of xro/non and kaq' o)/n subsequently added as an explanatory gloss.

th=s *(istw/nhs—subjective gen., as we say the city of London. Thucydides elsewhere uses the appositional construction, as iii. 85, e)s to\ o)/ros th\n *)istw/nhn: so line 14. to/te, lit. ‘at that time’, refers to the events described in iii. 85, and may be rendered ‘as we have related’: viii. 20, katadiwxqei=sai to/te.
prosbalo/ntes—‘having made their assault’, without a following case. to\ tei/xisma—called tei=xos iii. 85, a fortified position on Istone, held by 600 men.
cune/bhsan w(/ste—cf. ch. 37, 10: infr. line 16.
me/xri ou(=—cf. ch. 41, 3, note. a(/n—for e)a/n, rarely used by Thucydides, though h(/n is common. Possibly w(/st' e)a/n should be read. lelu/sqai—ch. 16, 18.
oi( tou= dh/mou prosta/tai—so iii. 75: cf. ch. 66, 12, of Megara. The term appears to be a general one, sometimes implying a particular office and sometimes not: vid. Arnold on vi. 35.
tou\s e)lqo/ntas—‘those who were sent’. Poppo suggests au)tou\s e)lqo/ntas, certainly a more usual form of expression: see however the note on kai\ oi( u(postre)fontes, ch. 33, 13.

pei/qousi...e(toima/sein—there is a slight irregularity in this sentence. The clause with pei/qousi is lost sight of after the introduction of the participial clause u(pope/myantes fi/lous, and o(/ti kra/tiston ei)/h depends upon le)gein.

tina\s o)li/gous—‘some few’: i. 63, o)li/gous me/n tinas a)pobalw/n. It was stipulated that any attempt at escape ended the treaty. kat' eu)/noian dh/—ch. 23, 8. o(/ti...ei)/h ..e(toima/sein— o(/ti only affects the former clause, the construction changing with the change of subject; so i. 87, ei)=pon o(/ti dokoi=en..., bou/lesqai de/. It is not however quite clear whether au)toi/ refers to the democratic leaders, the subject of pei/qousi, or to fi/loi, the subject of le/gein.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLVII
div2.p: w(s de\ e)/peisan e)lh/fqhsan—the change of subject in this sentence is noticeable: for mhxanhsame/nwn, gen. abs. without subject expressed, see ch. 3, 8. e)le/lunto...parede/donto, for the force of the pluperfect, see Arnold's note quoted on ch. 13, 2: ‘parede/donto must be taken with paralabo/ntes...kaqei=rcan, a few lines below, as if the sentence ran—you are now to suppose the treaty broken, and the prisoners delivered up to the Corcyreans. Upon their having been so delivered, the Corcyreans took them, etc.’

cunela/bonto—parenthetical, ‘helped, contributed to’, with the partitive gen. like cunara/menoi, ch. 10, 1: Hdt. iii. 49, sunela/bonto tou= strateu/matos, ‘took part in’. The subject of this sentence is oi( strathgoi\ kata/dhloi o)/ntes, k.t.l., ‘the obvious fact that the Athenian commanders would not wish’; the predicate having the same force as in ch. 5, 5, o) strato\s e)/ti e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w=n. Thucydides does not assert that the Athenians were in the plot; though it seems plain that they made no effort to save the captives.

a)kribh=—the strict force of this word is ‘exact, complete in its details’. The meaning is that the pro/fasis, ‘ground, or reason’ for escaping, urged on the captives was made fully convincing by the known feelings of the Athenians; so Poppo, Krüger, etc., in agreement with the Scholiast. Arnold however takes pro/fasis as ‘the pretence for killing them’ and a)kribh/s as ‘going to the very letter of the bond’.
mh\ a)\n bou)lesqai—such phrases as dh=lo/s ei)mi usually take a participial construction; and possibly katadhlou=ntes should be read: see however note on ch. 38, 3, dhlou=ntes prosi/esqai.
prospoih=sai—‘to add, attach’: lit. ii. 2, th\n po/lin *qhbai/ois prospoih=sai, ‘to make over the city’: so i. 55. The word is more common in the middle, meaning to win or claim for one's self.
paralabo/ntes—corresponds to parede/donto line 3: paralamba/nw=traditum accipere: cf. v. 95, where it is used of a traditional policy.

kaqei=rcan—so in all MSS. Classen however reads katei=rcan, on the ground that this is the form found elsewhere in Thucydides, aud that he also invariably uses a)pei/grw. Buttmann considered that ei)/rgw meant to shut out, ei)/rgw to shut in. Poppo says the word having here the literal force of ‘shutting in’ is properly written with q. It is to be observed that the other instances of katei/rgw in Thuc. are metaphorical in meaning and in the pres. or imp. tense, e.g. vi. 6, katei=rgon au)tou\s tw=| pole/mw|. For e)s cf. ch. 57, 10, e)s to\ tei=xos kataklh/|esqai: and note on au(to/se ch. 1, 20. Dem. de Cor. 258, has e)n oi)ki/skw| kaqei/rcas.

kata\ ei)/kosin—ch. 10, 19. ei)/pou...i)/doi—frequentative, like ei)/ pou de/oi ch. 4, 9. th=s o(dou=—partitive gen., like th=s fugh=s ch. 33, 15. prosio/ntas—‘coming up’ to receive the blows of the executioners; there is no manuscript authority for the suggested alteration proio/ntas, though such words might easily be confused.

div2.head: CHAPTER XLVIII
div2.p: e)s me\n a)/ndras e(ch/konta—‘to the number of’; these words form the object of e)cagago/ntes: so ch. 80, 18, prokri/nantes e)s disxili/ous: as subject, iii. 20, e)s a)/ndras diakosi/ous kai\ ei)/kosi e)ne/meinan.

metasth/sonta/s poi a)/llose—‘in order to remove them elsewhere’. The fut. participle is a correction for metasth/santas, to retain which necessitates taking poi a)/llose with a)/gein: the enclitic more naturally belongs to the word which it follows, while a)/gein corresponds to the preceding e)cagago/ntes.
sfa=s...au)tou/s—the former of these words is governed by diafqei/rein, of which au)tou/s is the subject; ‘kill us yourselves’, is the appeal which the captives make to the Athenians.

ou(d' e)sie/nai...ou)de/na—the inf. follows perio/yesqai, as in v. 29: i. 35, proslabei=n perio/yesqe. kata\ du/namin—‘to the best of their power’, ou( perio/yesqai being equivalent to ‘will prevent’: so i. 53, ou) perioyo/meqa kapa\ to\ dunato/n.

kata\ me\n ta\s qu/ras—cf. note, ch. 25, 48. ou(d' au)toi/— lit. ‘neither themselves’, i.e. they had no more intention of entering than the prisoners had of letting them in. ou)de/ means ‘also not’, as in this sentence, more commonly than ‘not even.
th\n o)rofh/n—so iii. 68, o)rofai=s e)xrhsanto: but i. 134, to\n o)/rofon. tw=| kera/mw|—‘with the tiling’: so ii. 4, li/qois te kai\ kera/mw| ballontwn.

kai\ a(/ma...die/fqeiron—the rest of the sentence, as far as a)pagxo/menoi, describes the ways in which the captives destroyed themselves. It has two main divisions, oi)stou/s te... kaqie/ntes and kai\...a)pagxo/menoi, the latter being again divided into two clauses of somewhat different construction. The imperfect participles kaqie/ntes and a)pagxo/menoi denote what went on during the night, while the concluding aor. diefqa/rhsan regards the work of death as ended and complete.
e)s ta\s sfaga/s—‘into their throats’. sfagh/ is the spot where the victim is struck for sacrifice: Eur. Or. 291, tekou/shs e)s sfaga\s w)=sai ci/fos.

e)k klinw=n tinw=n...a) pagxo/menoi—they strangled themselves either with bed girths or with strips of their garments. e)k klinw=n goes with toi=s spa/rtois alone, which is governed by a)pagxo/menoi. In the next clause instead of another dative of the instrument we have the active construction parairh/mata poiou=ntes, which must be rendered ‘with strips made’. This use of the act. participle is a common way of varying the construction in the concluding clause of the sentence: Dem. Lept. 496, kai\ toiou/tous tina\s e)ceilegme/noi, ‘and such specimens’: Eur. El. 496, tala/rwn t' e)celw\n tureu/mata, ‘and cheeses taken from their baskets’.

panti/ te tro/pw|—‘and so in every fashion’. te is not found in the MSS. but is inserted by Poppo. We have in this book frequent instances of its use in summing up and concluding an account, e.g. ch. 4, 12. If te be not read, diefqa/rhsan is redundant, being added as if there had been no such main verb as die/fqeiron.
e)pege/neto tw=| paqh/mati—‘closed on the scene’: ch. 25, 9.
formhdo/n—‘like matting’, some lengthways, some across: ii. 75, formhdo\n tiqe/ntes: so Hdt. ii. 96, plinqhdo/n, ‘brickfashion’.

h)ndrapodi/santo—‘enslaved’: the middle, as Classen points out, possibly implying that the Corcyreans kept them in their own service. In all other passages Thuc. uses the active to describe the selling of captives, e.g. v. 32, pai=das de\ kai\ gunai=kas h/ndrapo/disan.

h( sta/sis pollh\ genome/nh—an English writer would have said, ‘this was the end of this great struggle’, but in Greek an accessory idea, as in this case of the height to which faction rose, is not as a rule expressed by an epithet but thrown into a predicative form.

sta/sis—the word used throughout of the Corcyrean revolution: so iii. 76, oi( *kerkurai=oi e)stasi/azon. It is applied to any struggle between men of the same blood, even if rising to the importance of a civil war: thus in ch. 61, 6, to the war in Sicily.

e)teleu/thsen e)s tou=to—so iii. 104, e)teleu/ta e)s ta/de ta\ e)/ph, ‘ended with these verses’: cf. i. 51, h( naumaxi/a e)teleu/ta e)s nu/kta, i.e. lasted till night and then ended: iii. 108, h\ ma/xh e)teleu/ta e(/ws o)ye/. There is a similar use of me/xri in i. 71, me/xri tou=de w(ri/sqw u(mw=n h( braduth/s, ‘let this be the limit of your inaction’.
o(/sa ge kata/—‘so far as relates to’: so viii. 70, o(/sa pro\s tou\s qeou/s: cf. ch. 16, 15, o(/sa mh/. o(/ ti kai\ a)cio/logon—so i. 15, o(/qen tis kai\ du/namis parege/neto.

i)/na per...w(/rmhnto—so ch. 74, 4, i(/na per kai\ to\ prw=ton w(/rmhto, e)kei= and e)ntau=qa are often similarly used with verbs of motion. Thuc. uses the perfect and plup. of o(rma=sqai to denote actual motion, as in these passages, or mental impulse, as in ch. 27, 24.

e)pole/moun—by the use of the imperfect the historian leaves the Athenians engaged in their operations in Sicily and passes to another subject. Nothing further is said of Sicily till the convention at Gela next year (ch. 58).

div2.head: CHAPTER XLIX
div2.p: oi( e)n th=| *naupa/ktw|—for the order of the words cf. note on ch. 24, 1. The Athenians had a regular naval station at Naupactus. The Acarnanians had come to terms with the Ambrakiotes the year before (iii. 114).

e)kpe/myantes—a milder word than e)kbalo/ntes, probably implying the absence of a struggle: so v. 52, e)ce/pemyan, of an unsatisfactory governor: cf. Dem. Lept. 597, *qhbai/ous upospo/ndous a)pepe/myate.

oi)kh/tores a)po\ pa/ntwn—predicate in agreement with the subject, like ch. 14, 31, kai\ a)po\ pa/ntwn h)/dh bebohqhko/tes: some settlers came from every Acarnanian town. au)toi/—‘by themselves’ as opposed to the Athenians.

div2.head: CHAPTER L
div2.p: a)rgurolo/gwn new=n—‘sent to collect arrears, or to exact extraordinary contributions. The regular fo/ros appears to have been paid at Athens, at the great Dionysia’ (Jowett, citing Böckh). The same word is used in (iii. 19) of a squadron of twelve ships despatched in 428. Six ships were also sent in 430 (ii. 69). The absence of the article with *)aqhnai/wn is to be noticed: see note on ch. 18, 11.

para\ basile/ws—from the Persian court. basileu/s, without an article, is commonly used to denote the Persian sovereign: ii. 62, ou)/te basileu\s ou)/te a)/llo ou)de\n e)/qnos=neither the Persians nor any other nation: cf. i. 18 etc.

metagraya/menoi—‘having caused to be transcribed’: we have the act. i. 132, metagra/yai ti, ‘to make some alteration’. e)k tw=n *)assuri/wn gramma/twn—‘i.e. the cuneiform characters, which the Persians employed in their public inscriptions (Hdt. iv. 87), as here in a public document. They were, in various forms, the common alphabet of several langnages’ (Jowett). See also Poppo and Arnold. Here ‘transcription’ no doubt implies a translation.

pollw=n e(lqo/ntwn—at the beginning of the war we find the Lacedaemonians preparing to send envoys to the Persians and other ba/rbaroi (ii. 7); and in 430 a body of Peloponnesian ambassadors on their way to Persia were seized in Thrace and given up to the Athenians (ii. 67).
safe\s le/gein—so in vi. 21 the MSS. reading is a)/cion dra=n, where Arnold inserts ti.
pe/myai—‘they must send’, as if keleu/ein had gone before. A similar construction to that found in treaties etc.: cf. ch. 16, 5.

w(s au)to/n—referring to the primary subject, sc basile/a. When two subjects are expressed or implied, the former is often denoted by the oblique cases of au)to/s, when in Latin we
should expect se. (Caesar frequently uses is in the same way, e.g. B. G. i. 5, Helvetii persuadent Rauracis ut una cum iis (=secum) proficiscantur.) In ii. 65 is a noticeable instance, e/peira=to tou\s *)aqhnai/ous th=s e/p' au)to
 o)rgh=s (=h(
 e)p' au)to
 ei)=xon) paralu/ein: cf. ch. 71, 3. For this idiom see Poppo on I. 17, and the appendix to Buttmann's Meidias ‘do formis au(to/n et au)to/n.’

div2.head: CHAPTER LI
div2.p: periei=lon—for force of peri/ in composition see note on ch. 12, 7, perierru/h. The Chians took down the wall which surrounded their city.
kai\ u(popteusa/ntwn—the second participle gives the cause of the first: cf. note on ch. 97, 9.

e)s au(tou/s—‘against them’ sc. the Athenians, with newteriei=n. Another possible reading is e)s au)tou/s, ‘having formed some suspicion with regard to them’ viz. the Chians. For e)s cf. Ar. Plut. 361, su\ mhde\n ei)s e)/m' u(pono/ei toioutoni/.

poihsa/menoi—‘having effected for themselves’ i.e. stipulated for. The sense is that, before dismantling their works, they obtained the strongest guarantees which they could that the Athenians would do them no injury. pro\s *)aqhnai/ous—‘in regard to the Athenians’, i.e. between the Athenians and themselves. pi/steis kai\ bebaio/thta—‘pledges and security’.
e)k tw=n dunatw=n—‘to the best of their power’: ii. 3, w(s e)k tw=n dunatw=n.

div2.head: CHAPTER LII
div2.p: tou= d' e)pigignome/nou qe/rous—cf. note on ch. 1, 1. eu)qu/s— ‘at its very beginning’.

e)klipe/s ti—apparently a partial eclipse; calculated to have happened on the 21st of March: cf. ii. 28, o( h)/lios e/ce/lipe. This took place noumhni/a| kata\ selh/nhn, ‘at the beginning of a lunar month’, and Thuc. adds that this seems the only possible time.

tou= au)tou= mhno\s i(stame/nou—in the first 10 days of the same month, viz. Elaphebolion, which began in the latter half of March. For the variation and uncertainty of the Greek calendar see Jowett on ii. 1.

e)/seisen—‘there was an earthquake’: cf. u)/ei, bronta=|, and the like, as we say, it rains, etc. o( qeo/s is to be understood: Ar. Ach. 510, *poseidw=n...sei/sas. We have the pass. of sei/w in ii. 8, (*dh=los) pro/teron ou)/pw seisqei=sa. Portents, such as earthquakes and eclipses, were especially frequent at the time of the Peloponnesian war (i. 23).
oi( *mutilhnai/wn fuga/des—the revolt of Mytilene and Lesbos is related in the earlier part of bk. iii.: the final reduction of the island in ch. 50.

oi( polloi/—partial apposition: cf. ch. 6, 4. e)k te—te and kai/ couple *peloponnh/sou and au)to/qen, the two districts supplying the force, te being somewhat out of place, as in ch. 28, 21, e)/k te *ai)/nou.. kai\ a)/lloqen.
e)pikouriko/n—‘an auxiliary force’: viii. 25, ceniko\n e)pikouriko/n: so o(plitiko/n, i(ppiko/n, nautiko/n, etc.
*(roi/teion—cf. viii. 101, e)s *(roi/teion h)/dh tou= *(ellhspo/ntou.

labo/ntes—as ransom for the place. stath=ras—the Phocaean stater was worth somewhat less than the Attic stater, the value of which was about 16 shillings. a)pe/dosan pa/lin ou)de\n a)dikh/santes—‘restored the town uninjured’ (Jowett).
*)aktai/as—so called because they were on the coast (a\kth/) near Lesbos. In iii. 50 we read that the Athenians took possession of the towns on the mainland o)/swn *mutilhnai=oi e)kra/toun.
pa/ntwn ma/lista—this use of the neuter is to be noted. Poppo compares Mark xii. 28, prw/th pa/ntwn e)ntolh/.

kratuna/menoi—construction in accordance with the sense, as if dienoou=nto had preceded instead of h)=n h( dia/noia: cf. ch. 23, 13, note. The middle form of kratu/nw is found ch. 114, 13: also iii. 82, ta\s pi/steis e)kratu/nonto: the active occurs i. 69, etc.

nau=s te ga/r—this parenthetical sentence extends to paraskeuh=|. te and kai/ coupling its two members nau=s and th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=|. Arnold however ends the parenthesis with e)pikeime/nhs, and takes th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=| with the following o(rmw/menoi.
au)to/qen—in sense may be joined with the words before or after it, and is probably connected with both.

th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=|—most probably dat. of the instrument, dependent by a change of construction on the sense derived from kratuna/menoi, sc. th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=| kratu/nesqai eu)/poron h)=n. Poppo proposes to read th\n a)/llhn paraskeuh/n governed by poiei=sqai. It has also been proposed to take the dative as dependent on eu)pori/a, ‘there were facilities for’ etc.,
or to alter the reading to th=s a)/llhs paraskeuh=s, giving the same meaning. Arnold regards the text as a mixture of two constructions, connecting the dat. with what follows, as if the words ran nausi/ te (nau=s ga\r eu)pori/a h)=n poiei=sqai k.t.l.) kai\ th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=|.

Instead of paraskeuh=| the manuscript authority is in favour of skeuh=|, which is accordingly retained by Jowett. skeuh/ however appears used exclusively of dress and personal appointments, e.g. i. 6: vi. 31, tw=n peri\ to\ sw=ma skeuw=n: and though it would apply to fitting out men for an expedition, is not so appropriate to the fortifying of a stronghold: cf. i. 2, ou)/te mege/qei po/lewn i)/sxuon ou)/te th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=|.
o(rmw/menoi—cf. ch. i. 8: constructed like kratuna/menoi above.
kakw/sein. xeirw/sasqai—construction and variation of tense as in ch. 28, 29.
kai\ oi( me/n—cf. note on imp. e)pole/moun, ch. 48, 32: the account of these operations is resumed in ch. 75.

div2.head: CHAPTER LIII
div2.p: kai\ a)gago/ntes—for this use of the participle see note on ch. 48, 18, parairh/mata poiou=ntes.

e)pi/keitai th=| *lakwnikh=|—‘it lies off the coast of Laconia’: ch. 44, 28, e)s ta\s e)pikeime/nas nh/sous: ii. 27, with dat. th=| *peloponnh/sw| e)pi/keitai. kata/—‘opposite to’: i. 46, h( kata\ *ke/rkuran h)/peiros.

*lakedaimo/nioi d' ei)si/—sc. oi( *kuqh/rioi, ‘the people are Lacedaemonians of the class of Perioeci’ (ch. 8, 3): *lakedaimo/nioi is pred. the subject being understood from *ku/qhra: cf. note on ch. 1, 4. For the gen. denoting a class see Madv. § 51 c.

*kuqhrodi/khs a)rxh/—an ‘authority’ or official with this title: so i. 96, *(ellhnotami/ai a)rxh/, a ‘board’ so called: see note on ta\ te/lh, ch. 15, 2. In both passages Cobet proposes to omit a)rxh/ as being an explanatory gloss.
prosbolh/—cf. ch. 1, 7: here it means a port or landing-place. Merchantmen from Egypt are mentioned again in viii. 35: they probably imported corn.

pa=sa ga\r a)ne/xei—sc. either (1) h( *lakwnikh/, meaning that the Laconian coast lay open to attack from the sea on the S.W. and S.E.; or (2) h) nh=sos, meaning that Cythera commanded the coast on both sides, and therefore protected the
country. a)ne/xei—‘juts out, extends’: i. 46, h( a)kra a)ne/xei: so viii. 35, a)/kra th=s *knidi/as prou)/xousa. Grote (vol. iv. ch. 53) renders it, ‘the whole Laconian coast is high projecting cliff where it fronts the Sicilian and Cretan seas’, being therefore only assailable at Malea. This agrees with the fact of the want of harbours on the Laconian coast, but the use of a)ne/xw is against it. For pe/lagos cf. ch. 24, 22.

div2.head: CHAPTER LIV
div2.p: disxili/ois—Classen suspects an error in the number, as so large a Milesian force seems improbable. Possibly *milhsi/wn ought to be omitted. Scandeia seems to have been the chief fortress of the island, and would be attacked by the main body.

*ska/ndeian—Pausanias calls Scandeia the arsenal (e)pi/neion) of Cythera, and says that it is ten stadia from the city of Cythera itself. The latter appears from Thucydides to have consisted of the harbour (h( e)pi\ qala/ssh| po/lis, line 7) and the upper city (h) a)/nw po/lis, line 11).
u(pe/sthsan—‘stood the attack’: ch. 59, 12, kindu/nous u\fi/stasqai: cf. note on ch. 28, 17. cune/bhsan—‘they agreed’, with e)pitre)yai: so ch. 69, 22, cune/bhsan e(/kaston a)poluqh=nai.
h)=san de/ tines kai\ geno/menoi—‘and some communications had actually passed between Nicias and some of the inhabitants’.

e)pithdeio/teron—‘on more favourable terms’: i. 58, ou)de\n eu(/ronto e)pith/deion: i. 144, toi)/s *lakedaimoni/ois e)pithdei/ws, ‘in the interests of’. to/ te parauti/ka k.t.l.—some MSS. read ta\ th=s o)mologi/as, but the best are without ta/. to\ parauti/ka th=s o(mologi/as then means the terms now granted, and to\ e)/peita the arrangements afterwards concluded by the Athenians (ch. 57).
a)ne/sthsan ga\r a)/n—‘for otherwise the Athenians, etc.’ i.e. but for the understanding with Nicias: so i. 102, bi/a| ga\r a)\n ei(=lon to\ xwri/on, ‘else they wonld have stormed the town’.

ou(/tws e)pikeime/nhs—referring to the situation of Cythera described in the previous chapter. This is the only instance in Thuc. of e)pikei=sqai with e/pi/: Hdt. vii. 235, e)p' au(th=| nh=sos e)pikeime/nh.
paralabo/ntes—‘taking into their own hands’: i. 19, nau=s tw=n po/lewn paralabo/ntes. The Athenians occupied Scandeia completely and probably garrisoned other points in the island.
e(/s te—te and kai/ here couple the two clauses of which e)/pleusan aud e/dh/|oun are the verbs.
e)naulizo/menoi...ei)/h—imperfect and opt. of repeated action. tw=n xwri/wn—part. gen. after ou(=, ‘on such spots as were favourable from time to time’. For kairo/s of place, cf. ch. 90, 14.

div2.head: CHAPTER LV
div2.p: a)qro/a|...th=| duna/mei—a prominent position of the predicate, not uncommon where emphasis is desired: cf. iii. 63, ou)k i/shn au)toi=s th\n xa/rin a)ntape/dote.

fobou/menoi...kata/stasin—cf. ch. 41, 11. kata/stasin— the established order of things or ‘constitution’. What the Lacedaemonians chiefly dreaded was revolt on the part of the Helots. The slavery in which they held these was the ‘peculiar institution’ of which they were jealous and apprehensive.

e)xome/nhs—‘was in the enemy's hands’: ch. 108, 1, e)xome)nhs de\ th=s *)amfipo/lews. taxe/os kai\ a)profula/ktou—because it was impossible to guard against the sudden descents of the Athenians on their coasts.
e)s ta\ polemika/—‘for warlike operations’. ei)/per pote/— so ch. 20, 1; here made more emphatic by the superlative ma/lista dh/, ‘in the highest degree’. o)knhro/teroi—‘more backward than ever’.

cunestw=tes—‘being engaged’: so ch. 96, 11, cunesth/kei, of an army in actual battle. para\ th\n u(pa/rxousan i)de/an— the ‘existing form’ of their force consisting almost entirely of heavy-armed infantry.

oi(=s to\ mh\ e)pixeirou/menon—‘with whom whatever they were not actually attempting was so much subtracted from their expectation of success’: cf. i. 70, where the Corinthian envoys at Sparta enlarge on the ambition and activity of the Athenians, a(\ me\n a)\n e/pinoh/santes mh\ e/ce/lqwsin, oi)kei=a ste/resqai h(gou=ntai k.t.l.
ta\ th=s tu/xhs—so to\ th=s tu/xhs, ch. 18, 12.

pa=n a(marth/sesqai—they expected to fail in any active movement they made: for opt. cf. h)=| xwrh/seian, ch. 32, 22. The neuter adj. is a cognate accusative following the verb: so iii. 47, o(/son a)\n kai\ tou=to a(marta/noite.

a)nexe/lluon—lit. ‘affording no guarantee (of success)’. Their gnw/mh, or ‘mental conviction’, had lost its confidence, and they were, as we say, demoralized. Till the capture of Pylos the evils of the war had in no sense been brought home to the Spartans.

div2.head: CHAPTER LVI
div2.p: toi=s d' *)aqhnai/ois—this dat. is dependent on h)su/xasan, or rather is placed at the beginning of the sentence to denote what state of things the Athenians found resulting from the dispirited feeling of the Lacedaemonians: cf. note on ch. 10, 13, u=poxwrh/sasi. to/te—‘now’, at the time mentioned at the end of chapter 54.
th\n paraqala/ssion—so ii. 26, th=s paraqalassi/ou e)/stin a)\ e)dh/wse.

e)n tw=| toiou/tw|—‘under such circumstances, in such a condition’: cf. ii. 36, e/n tw=| toiw=|de, ‘in a case like this’. From h(gou/menoi ei)=nai we have to supply a sense equivalent to o)/ntes: so iii. 69, nh=es xeimasqei=sai kai\ spora/des=spora/des geno/menai: iii. 82, ou(k a)\n e)xo/ntwn pro/fasin ou)d' e(toi/mwn=e(toi/mwn o)/ntwn.

h(/per kai\ h)mu/nato—‘which did make a stand’. kai/ thus used implies an unexpected statement: ch. 11, 18, ei)/ ph| kai\ dokoi/h. peri\ *kotu/rtan kai\ *)afrodisi/an—places on the w. coast of Laconia near Cape Malea.

perie/pleusan—the Ath. now rounded Cape Malea and sailed upwards along the E. coast of Laconia. Epidaurus Limera was a short distance N. from Malea. The name signifies ‘the hungry’ or ‘the harbour-possessing’ according as it comes from li=mo/s or li=mh/n, both derivations being given.

h(/ e)sti me\n th=s—for gen. ‘belonging to’ of. iii. 106, ou)ke/ti *)akarnani/as. *kunosouri/as—the form of the word which has the best authority here and in v. 14 and 41. Another form is *kunouri/a (Hdt. viii. 73 etc.).

nemo/menoi—‘possessing’ or ‘occupying: i. 2, nemo/menoi ta\ au(tw=n e(/kastoi o(/son a)pozh=n. e)kpesou=sin—the expulsion of the Aeginetans was in 431; some settled in Thyrea, some were scattered throughout Greece (ii. 27).
u(po\ to\n seismo/n—the great earthquake and the revolt of the Helots which took place in 464 (i. 101). Thucydides here repeats what he has already said, ii. 27.

*(aqhnai/wn u(pakou/ontes—‘though subject to Athens’. pro\s e(/stasan—cf. vi. 34, pro\s ta\ lego/mena ai\ gnw=mai i(/stantai: so Soph. Ant. 299, (fre/nas) pro\s ai)sxra\ pra/gmat' i(/stasqai. e)kei/nwn—the Lacedaemonians, as locally remote from Athens and Aegina; cf. note on ch. 37, 10.

div2.head: CHAPTER LVII
div2.p: tei=xos—‘fort’: ch. 11, 22, etc.
tw=n peri\ th\n xw/ran—cf. ch. 55, 5.
e)n xersi/—‘in the fight’: ch. 113, 7: cf. ch. 43, 9. agontes a)fi/konto—we should say ‘took with them’; the usual Greek expression is a verb with the partic. of a)/gw.

kataqe/sqai e)s ta\s nh/sous—so iii. 28, katati/qetai e)s *te/nedon: iii. 72, kate/qento e)s *ai)/ginan. The middle voice is always used in this sense of depositing for safety: cf. note on e)/qento, ch. 18, 14.

kai\ tou\s a)/llous...fe/rein—the grammatical subject is changed in this clause, the original construction being resumed in the next clause. In sense the subject is still the Athenians, the meaning being ‘as for the rest to let them inhabit’, etc.

a)ei/ pote—‘of old standing’; commonly used by Thuc. with words implying friendship or enmity: i. 47, a)ei/ pote fi/loi ei)si/n, etc.: so ch. 78, 16: 103, 13: cf. i. 15, e)s to\n pa/lai pote\ geno/menon po/lemon.
para\ tou\s a)/llous—=para\ tou\s a)/llous a)gago/ntes katadh=sai par' au)toi=s, pregnant constr.: so tou\s e)n th=| nh/sw|=those who had been captured in the island.

div2.head: CHAPTER LVIII
div2.p: The history now returns to affairs in Sicily, of which nothing has been recorded since the conclusion of the operations related in ch. 25.

*kamarinai/ois—Camarina, though Dorian, was opposed to Syracuse (iii. 86), while the neighbouring town of Gela, like the other Dorian colonies, took the Syracusan side. prw=ton pro\s a)llh/lous—note the order. The force of the sentence is that the pacification of Sicily began with Camarina and Gela, that the first step was a cessation of hostilities, and that this was first concluded between the two states in question.

pre/sbeis—in apposition to oi( a)/lloi *sikeliw=tai: so ch. 49, 6, oi)kh/tores a)po\ pa/ntwn. e)s lo/gous kate/sthsan—so iii. 8: iii. 70, e)s lo/gous katasta/ntwn: i. 23, e)s to\n po/lemon kate/sthsan, etc.

e)p' a)mfo/tera—ch. 17, 19; here it refers to counterarguments and claims, as is shown by w(s e(/kastoi k.t.l. diaferome/nwn kai\ a)ciou/ntwn—‘(the envoys) disputing and urging their respective claims’; gen. abs. without subject expressed.
e)lassou=sqai—‘to be at a disadvantage’, with cognate accus.: cf. ch. 59, 12.

*(ermokra/ths—the most eminent Syracusan of this time, and a man of singular energy and intelligence. His courage and wisdom undoubtedly saved his country from the Athenian invaders. The speeches which Thucydides puts in his mouth are marked by outspoken frankness and an unusual breadth of view. Their language is also striking in style, close and antithetical, and abounding in rhetorical mannerisms.
o(/sper kai\ e)/peise—this refers to the effect of Hermocrates's counsel, ch. 65.

e)s to\ koino/n—according to Classen ‘for the general interest’, as opposed to the private claims of individual states: so i. 91, e)s to\ koino\n bouleu/esqai: cf. Lat. in medium. Poppo considers to\ koino/n to mean ‘concilium legatorum ab omnibus Siciliensibus missorum’; so Krüger.

toiou/tous dh/—a variation from toia/de, with which speeches are commonly introduced, as in ch. 10 and 16. On the other hand, in vii. 78, toia/de parakeleuo/menos refers to a speech which has just been made.

div2.head: CHAPTER LIX
div2.p: ou(/te po/lews—for the gen. Classen compares Hdt. vii. 101, su\ ei)=s po/lios ou)/t' e)laxi/sths ou)/t' a)sqenesta/ths. The order of the words in this vigorous sentence gives it a force which it would not have if precise grammatical sequence had been observed. po/lews is put early, in contrast with the following e)s koino/n, to show that the speaker is not urging state claims but general interests; while ou)/te e)laxi/sths negatives the idea that fear could be his motive in urging peace, inasmuch as he was the representative of a country which had less to dread than others.

tou\s lo/gous poih/somai—the position of these words is in accordance with the manner of Thuc. who commonly separates two parallel expressions, such as ou)/te e)laxi/sths ..ou)/te ponoume/nhs, by an intermediate word or words belonging to both, e.g. i. 93, sidh/rw| pro\s a)llh/lous ta\ e)/cwqen kai\ molu/bdw| dedeme/noi.
ponoume/nhs—so ii. 51, to\n ponou/menon w)|kti/zonto, of sufferers from the plague.

e)s koino/n—‘for common consideration’ or ‘for the common interest’—cf. ch. 58, 10. belti/sthn—to be connected with th=| *sikeli/a|. a)pofaino/menos—‘declaring’, commonly used with gnw/mhn, etc. of setting forth one's own views: so without acc. Plat. Phaedr. 274 E. etc.
kai\ peri\ me/n—the converse of this me/n is de/ in line 13. Though there is no use in enlarging on the evils of war in general, it may be of service to shew the inexpediency of this particular war.

w(s xalepo/n—‘what a grievous thing it is’. pa=n to\ e)no/n—‘all that it involves’, or ‘all that is possible’, sc. e)kle/gein: so ii. 43. o(/sa e)/nesti. in a somewhat similar clause. e)kle/gwn—‘picking out’, not = e)cagoreu/wn. Only a)nti/, pro/, and e)pi/ are compounded with le/gw in the sense of speaking. Other prepositions are compounded with a)goreu/w or (poetically) au)dw= (R. S.). e)n ei)do/si—cf. ch. 17, 12, note. makrhgorei=n—i. 68: ii. 36.
a)nagka/zetai—‘is constrained’: viii. 41, a)nagka/zetai u(po tw=n *knidi/wn parainou/ntwn. au)to\ dra=n—to engage in war; cf. au)ta\ tau=ta, line 13: ch. 18, 7, e)pa/qomen au)to/.

cumbai/nei—‘the fact is’, connected with toi=s me\n... fai/nesqai so far as construction goes, but in sense applying no less to the second clause with oi) de/: for constr. cf. Plat. Rep. 505 C, sumbai/nei au)toi=s o(mologei=n, ‘the result is they admit’, or ‘they find themselves admitting’. toi=s me\n...oi( de/—these two clauses apply generally to aggressive and defensive warfare. The definite ta\ ke/rdh, tou\s kindu/nous refer to polemei=n, ‘its gains, its dangers’.

e)qe/lousin—‘are ready’,=dare: ii. 71, e)qelhsa/ntwn cuna/rasqai to\n ki/ndunon. pro\ tou= au)ti/ka—‘rather than suffer their rights to be infringed one jot’: cf. ch. 58, 8: i. 77, e)lassou/menoi e)n tai=s di/kais.

ei) mh\ e)n kairw=|—e)n has very slight MSS. authority and is omitted by Arnold. There is however no proof that kairw=| by itself can mean ‘in proper time’. Arnold quotes ii. 40, plou/tw| te e)/rgou ma=llon kairw=| xrw/meqa, which as his own note in loc. shews is in no way a case in point; while Krüger points out that Soph. O. T. 1516, pa/nta ga\r kairw=| kala/, means ‘by being seasonable’. e)n kairw=| occurs v. 61, etc.
tw=|n cunallagw=n—objective gen.: v. 69, th\n parake/leusin th=s mnh/mhs.

o(\ kai\ h(mi=n—o)/ referring to what immediately precedes, is the belief that this is a time for union rather than strife. In constr. it is a cogn. acc. after peiqome/nois and supplies the subj. to a)/cion ge/noito. As Poppo says, ‘pro peiqome/nois etiam pei/qesqai scribi potuit’, the sense being ‘such a conviction on your part would now be invaluable’.

bouleuo/menoi dh/—dh/ lays a sarcastic emphasis on bouleuo/menoi ‘deliberating, forsooth’. There seems therefore no reason for Cobet's suggestion of boulo/menoi, with which indeed dh/ would have no force. For inf. cf. vii. 60, e)bouleu/santo ta\ tei/xh e)klipei=n: Hdt. vi. 100, e)bouleu/onto e)klipei=n th\n po/lin.

qe/sqai—with eu)=: ch. 17, 14. Krüger finds a difficulty in the separation of adverb and verb and proposes to omit qe/sqai as a gloss, taking i)/dia as acc. after bouleuo/menoi, like vi. 23. polla\ eu)= bouleu/sasqai. The omission however, besides having no authority, spoils the rhythm of the sentence.

di' a:ntilogiw=n—‘we are trying to settle our differences by mutual recriminations’. It seems simplest to understand this clause as ironical, implying that the envoys in their selfish eagerness for advantage are defeating their own objects. Otherwise a)ntilogiw=n is simply ‘discussions’. peirw/meqa is taken as subj. by Classen.
h)\n a)/ra—‘if after all’; undoubtedly ironical, as such disappointment was inevitable. proxwrh/sh|—cf. ch. 18, 24, note.
i)/son—‘his just due’, as opposed to e)/lasson or ple/on: v. 31, mh\ i)/son e)/cein.

div2.head: CHAPTER LX
div2.p: kai/toi—the next chapter begins in a similar way. ei) swfronou=men—cf. i. 40, o)/stis mh\ toi=s decame/nois, ei) swfronou=si, po/lemon poih/sei. Such expressions are elliptical, =‘as will be the case if, etc.’
h( cu/nodos—‘our conference’; followed by a double construction, ou) peri\..., a)ll' ei/: cf. v. 88, h( me/ntoi cu/nodos kai\ peri\ swthri/as h)/de pa/resti.
e)pibouleuome/nhn—pass. as in ch. 61, 7, though the active takes the dat. in the sense of plotting against. th\n a)poxw/rhsin e)pebou/leuon, iii. 109, means ‘made arrangements for the withdrawal’.

diallakta/s—‘peacemakers’: also in ch. 64, 21: Dem. de Symm. 189: Eur. Phoen. 468. a)nagkaiote/rous—‘more cogent’. The adj. being here used of a person has an active force=causing a)na/gkh: so v. 105, u(po\ fu/sews a)nagkai/as, where fu/sis is as it were personified. When used of a thing=such as a)na/gkh compels: i. 61, cummaxi/a a)nagkai/a: cf. note on ch. 32, 23.
throu=si—‘are on the look-out for’: ch. 27, 11.

to\ fu/sei pole/mion—‘are speciously ordering what is naturally hostile to them with a view to their own advantage’; i.e. are merely securing their own interests in dealing with those who are naturally enemies, though they may call them allies. According to this view to\ pole/mion nearly equals tou\s polemi/ous: cf. i. 76, ta\s po/leis e)pi\ to\ u(mi=n w)fe/limon katasthsa/menoi: vi. 85, ta)nqa/de pro\s to\ lusitelou=n kaqi/stasqai: cf. ch. 76, 33.

Classen takes to\ fu/sei pole/mion to mean the hostile and ambitious designs which the Athenians concealed under pretence of alliance; but this does not agree with kaqi/stasqai, a word which implies political arrangements.

e)pagome/nwn—ch. 1, 4. e)pistrateu/ousi—with acc.: so ch. 92, 32. Here it scarcely means attacking, but rather sending troops to. In this passage we have a rhetorical effect of sound produced by three consecutive compounds of e)pi/.

te/lesi toi=s oi)kei/ois—‘with our own revenues’: vi. 16, toi=s i)di/ois te/lesi, ‘at one's own expense’. th=s a)rxh=s—partitive gen. with prokopto/ntwn: vii. 56, tou= nautikou= me/ga me/ros proko/yantes. proko/ptein—lit. ‘to pioneer’: Eur. Hip. 23, ta\ polla\ de\ pa/lai proko/yasa. The Siceliots by their quarrels are destroying their resources, and preparing the way for Athenian domination.
tetruxwme/nous—‘worn out’: vii. 28, tw=| pole/mw| tetruxwme/noi. The present truxo/w (=tru/xw) is not found in classical Greek.
pote/—‘some day’: ch. 1, 9.
ta/de pa/nta—‘all we see’, i.e. all Sicily.

peira/sasqai—aor. after ei)ko/s, as is common: see note on ch. 9, 22. Krüger remarks (on ii. 5) that Thuc. differs from other writers in preferring the middle aor. form of peirw=mai. We have peiraqe/ntes in act. sense ii. 5, and 33: peiraqh=|, vi. 92: peiraqei/s, pass. vi. 54.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXI
