div2.p: kai/toi th=| e(autw=n—if we must call in allies, let it be when we gain by it: dat. after e)piktwme/nous ‘gaining in addition to’: i. 144, a(rxh\n e)pikta=sqai.

ta\ e(toi=ma bla/ptontas—‘spoiling what we have’: so kta=sqai/ ti is contrasted with ta\ e(toi=ma bla/yai. i. 70. The compound proslamba/nein here means to take on yourselves: so v. 111: vi. 78, proslabei=n: i. 144, prosti/qesqai. etc.

kata\ po/leis—‘while taking our several cities we are divided’; kata/, distributive, one city takes one side, one the other: cf. i. 15, die/sthsan e)s cummaxi/an e(kate)rwn, = took one side or the other.

paresta/nai de/—sc. xrh/. The subject is changed in point of grammar, though in sense it remains the same, = ‘none of us ought to think’: ch. 95, 4, parasth=| de\ mhdeni/: Dem. Olynth. iii. 28, tau)ta\ pari/statai/ moi gignw/skein.

oi( me\n *dwrih=s h(mw=n—‘those of us who are Dorians’: ch. 126, 17, toi=s *makedosin au)tw=n. to\ de\ *xalkidiko/n—‘the Chalcidian element’,=oi/ *xalkidh=s. th=| *)ia/di cuggenei/a|—‘from their Ionian ties of blood’: so the Leontine allies appealed to Athens, o(/ti *)/iwnes h)=san, iii. 86; cf. vi. 3.

ou) ga\r toi=s e)/qnesi—dat. with di/xa pe/fuke, ‘in respect of its races’. The prominent position of the words however causes them to affect the whole sentence, and gives a sense equivalent to ‘it is not from a quarrel of races, etc.’

pe/fuke—sc. h( *sikeli/a; so Poppo and Classen: cf. Plat. Rep. 503 B, diespasme/nh fu/etai (unless diespasme/na should be read). Krüger and Donaldson take e)/qnesi as governed by e\pi/asi and e)/qnh as subject of pe/fuke, ‘they do not invade our races because their origin is different, through hatred of one of them’.
e)pi/asi—like e)pistrateu/ontai, ch. 60, 13, conveys the idea of armed intervention rather than actual hostility.

paraklh/sei—‘appeal’, with subjective genitive of those by whom it was made. The verb parakalei=n is common in the sense of inviting allies and the like, but the subst. is not used elsewhere by Thuc. with this meaning: in viii. 92 it means advice or exhortation.

au)toi/—‘of themselves’, contrasting the eagerness of the Athenians with the backwardness of their so-called allies. to\ di/kaion—what is justly due, meaning here the aid which they had covenanted to render. th=s cunqh)khs—either with to\ di/kaion, ‘the due requirements of the covenant’, or with ma=llon, ‘more than their covenant required’,=ma=llon h)\ kata/. Note the concluding alliteration, proqu/mws pare/sxonto.
kai\ tou\s me/n—corresponds to o(/soi de/, line 25. pollh\ cuggnw/mh—‘is fully excusable’, with inf. clause: so v. 83, ei/ko\s kai) cuggnw/mh.
e(toimote/rois—‘still more ready’, than toi=s a)/rxein boulome/nois: cf. ch. 18, 4, kuriwteroi: so iii. 63, a)ciw/teroi.

pe/fuke ga/r—for similar statements of the right of the strongest, cf. i. 76: v. 105. In the latter passage the Athenians say that they know that men always rule whatever they can, and they suppose that the deity does the same. dia\ panto/s—‘always’: i. 38, a)festa=si dia\ panto/s: so v. 105.

o)/soi—equivalent to ei)/ tines and therefore followed by mhde) tis=ei)/ tis h)/kei mh\ k.t.l. au)ta/—‘all this’: cf. note on ch. 18, 7. presbu/taton—‘of highest importance’: more commonly in comparative, e.g. Soph. O. T. 1365. Compare the Latin use of antiquior and antiquissimus.
eu)= qe/sqai—cf. note on ch. 17, 14. au)tou—sc. tou= koinw=s foberou=.

eu\prepw=s a)/dikoi—note the antithetical balance of two sets of three words with which the sentence concludes. Each member begins with an adverb compounded with eu)=, eu)prepw=s ‘with fair outside’ corresponding to eu)lo/gws ‘with good actual reason’: a)/dikoi ‘without justice’ corresponds to a)/praktoi ‘without success’; while e)lqo/ntes finds its converse in a)pi/asin. This sentence is a good example of the emphatic usage of adverbs, which is characteristic of Thucydides.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXII
div2.p: to\ me\n pro/s—either determinant accus. ‘as concerns the Athenians’ like the more usual plural (ch. 15, 10: ch. 85, 28, ta\ pro\s *)aqhnai/ous): or, according to Poppo, subject to eu(ri/sketai, ‘the (advantage we gain) in respect of the Athenians is found to be so great an advantage’. eu)= bouleuome/nois—‘if we take good counsel’, dat. commodi, grammatically connected with either a)gaqo/n or eu(ri/sketai. eu(ri/sketai—‘is found’ by due consideration, = ‘proves to be’: so iii. 47, to\ *kle/wnos...ou)x eu)ri/sketai dunato/n.
a)/riston—neut. predicate with ei/rh/nhn: Plat. Rep. 455 E, a)sqene/steron gunh\ a)ndro/s, cf. Madv. § 1 b, R. 4.

h)\ dokei=te—this sentence is irregular in construction. Following dokei=te we have two optatives with a)/n as if o)/ti had gone before, and then the inf. construction e)/xein th\n ei/rh/nhn dependent on dokei=te. This last clause too is worded as if ou( dokei=te had preceded, a sense which must be supplied from ou)x h(suxi/a ma=llon. For similar irregularities cf. i. 3, dokei= de/ moi ou)de\ tou)/noma tou=to cu/mpasa/ pw ei)=xen, a)lla\. ou)d' ei=nai h( e)pi/klhsis au)/th.

ei)/ tw|—i.e. tini/—addressing the individual envoys as representatives of their states. to\ me\n...to\ de/ correspond to ta\ e)nanti/a and a)gaqo/n respectively, the order being inverted by the grammatical figure called chiasmus.
cundiasw/sai—‘would help to preserve throughout’: so vii. 57, cundiasw/sontes, of the allies who helped to maintain the independence of Sicily: ii. 62, diasw/santes.
e)n mh/kei lo/gwn—cf. v. 89, lo)gwn mh=kos a)/piston. w(/sper peri\ tou= polemei=n—referring to what he had already said, ch. 59, 6.

u(peridei=n...proi+dei=n—=despicere, prospicere. We have a similar play on sound in a subsequent speech of Hermocrates, vi. 76, ou)k a)cunetwte/rou, kakocunetwte/rou de/: so i. 33, proepibouleu/ein au)toi=s ma=llon h)\ a)ntepibouleu/ein: ii. 62, mh\ fronh/mati mo/non a)lla\ kai\ katafronh/mati.

bebai/ws—usually connected with oi)/etai, ‘is assured’: cf. i. 132, pisteu/santes bebai/ws: i. 134, bebai/ws ei)do/tes, etc. Krüger however joins the word with pra/cein, quoting ch. 112, 10, bebai/ws e(lei=n: ch. 114, 2, bebai/ws th=s po/lews e)xome/nhs, and many similar instances.

tw=| dikai/w|—‘from the justice of his cause’, dat. of the efficient cause (Madv. § 41). Krüger quotes Soph. O. C. 880, toi=s toi dikai/ois xw) braxu\s nika=| me/gan. For di/kaion contrasted with bi/a, right as opposed to might, cf. i. 77, bia/zesqai oi)=s a)\n e)ch=| dika/zesqai ou)de\n prosde/ontai.
tw=| par' e)lpi/da—‘let him not be grievously disappointed if he fail’: cf. vii. 66, tw=| par' e)lpi/da sfallo/menoi.

xalerw=s=w(s xalero\n o)/n: cf. ch. 20, 14, a)safw=s. rlei/ous h)/dh—‘many men before now’, lit. ‘more (than he)’. plei/ous is subdivided into two classes, kai\ timwri/ais and kai\ e)lpi/santes, the repeated kai/ having a disjunctive force, ‘either...or’, like te and kai/, ch. 32, 14. The subdivision is continued in the clauses with oi/ me\n...toi=s de/.
timwri/ais—dat of the instrument. Krüger cites i. 34, pole/mw| ta\ e)gklh/mata metelqei=n: cf. also ch. 86, 21.

e(/teroi—‘in other cases’, in partial apposition with plei/ous: for a striking example of this construction cf. v. 96, a)/poikoi o)/ntes oi/ polloi\ kai\ a)posta/ntes tine/s, ‘being colonists for the most part and having revolted in some cases’.
ou)x o(/son ou)k— ‘not only failed to avenge their wrongs’: so ii. 97, ou)x o(/ti. We have also mh\ o(/ti, ou)x o(/pws, etc. in a similar sense: see Madv. § 212.
proskatalipei=n—‘to leave behind them besides’, i.e. to lose: in ii. 36 the word is used of those who bequeathed an accession of territory to their descendants.

dikai/ws— ‘in accordance with justice’, i.e. as our ideas of justice would lead us to expect. o(/ti kai\ a)dikei=tai—kai/, ‘also’, connects the two notions of wrong received and just revenge. ‘The antecedent, and not as in English would be more natural the consequent, is emphasized’ (Jowett): so infr. kai\ eu)/elpi: ch. 64, 1, kai\ a)rxo/menos. The nom. to a)dikei=tai is timwri/a personified, sc. the injured man. It is to be noted that the present tense of a)dikw= is used in both active and passive so long as the wrong done is not atoned for: i. 38, diafero/ntws ti a)dikou/menoi, ‘suffering a great wrong’.
w(s e)pi\ plei=ston kratei=—‘prevails to the utmost’: Krüger quotes Soph. O. T. 977, a)/nqrwpos, w(=| ta\ th=s tu/xhs kratei=, pro/noia d' e)sti\n ou)deno\s safh/s.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXIII
div2.p: tou= a)fanou=s—put first for the sake of emphasis and clearness. The two main reasons for union are the uncertainty of the future, and the actual presence of the Athenians. a)te/kmarton—used in Hdt. v 92 (3) of an obscure oracle; from te)kmar, a fixed mark or limit, hence a sure sign.
dia\ to\...paro/ntas—a confusion between dia\ to\...parei=nai and dia\ tou\s...paro/ntas: so v. 7, dia\ to\...kaqhme/nous. In viii. 105 most manuscripts have dia\ to\...diw/kontes.

to\ e)llipe\s th=s gnw/mhs—lit. ‘the coming short of our plans’, i.e. of the schemes of advantage which the several states had formed: cf. ch. 55, 18, e)llipe\s th=s dokh/sews. w(=n—i.e. tou/twn w(=n, dep. on to\ e)llipe\s th=s gnw/mhs. e(/kasto/s ti—this has the best manuscript authority, but e(/kasto/s tis is also a well supported reading and gives a good sense.

ei)rxqh=nai—with to\ e)llipe\s th=s gnw/mhs, lit. ‘was restrained’, i.e was brought about by restraint. We should say, ‘satisfied that the failure in our hopes had an adequate cause in these obstacles’: cf. ch. 98, 22, kateirgo/menon, ‘done under constraint’.

It is also possible to take to\ e)llipe/s as determinant accusative with ei)rxqh=nai, understanding h(mei=s as the subject, ‘in the failure of our plans convinced that we were sufficiently prevented’. In support of this construction Poppo cites Ar. Vesp. 333, ti/s e)sq' o( tau=ta/ d' ei)/rgwn;

e)festw=tas—=instantes: Dem. de Cor. 287, to\n e)festhko/ta ki/ndunon. a)pope/mpwmen—‘dismiss’: so Dem. Androt. 597, *qhbai/ous u(pospo/ndous a)pepe/myate, of compelling an enemy to evacuate a district: cf. ch. 49, 5, e)kpe/myantes.
ma/lista me\n...ei) de\ mh/—of the best and next best alternative: i. 32: ii. 72, etc. e)s a)i/=dion—so ii. 64: cf. ch. 20, 5; where also we have the concurrence of sound a)i/=dion...i)di/an.
e)s au)=qis a)nabalw/meqa—cf. Plat. Symp. 174 E, ei)sau=qis a)nabalou=: id. Euthyphr. 15 E, ei)sau=qis toi/nun. Thuc. has e)s a)ei/, i. 22 and 129: e)s e)/peita, i. 130.
to\ cu/mpan te—adverbial: cf. i. 144, kaq) e(/kasta/ te kai\ to\ cu/mpan.
a)reth=|—referring to eu)= as well as kakw=s drw=nta, ‘like true men’ (Jowett): cf. ch. 19, 18, a)ntapodou=nai a)reth/n. a)munou/meqa—‘requite’: cf. i. 44, toi=s o(moi/ois h(ma=s a)mu/nesqai.

ou) peri\ tou=—sc. o( lo/gos or o( a)gw\n e)/stai, ‘it will be no question of punishing another’: cf. Dem. Androt. 607, ou) peri\ pra/cews ei)sforw=n e)sti/n: id. Tim. 701, peri\ au)tou= tou/tou nu=n u(mi=n e)sti/.
kai\ a)/gan ei) tu/xoimen—‘if we were ever so successful’: iii. 39, tuxo/ntes me\n...sfale/ntes de/: iii. 42, mh\ tuxw/n, opp. to pei/sas: cf. ch. 22, 15.

fi/loi me\n a)/n—the sentences begins as if the principal verb would be in the optative; instead of which by a change of construction a)/n is left without a verb and the second clause concludes with the present indicative gigno/meqa. The sense thus given is ‘we might indeed become friends with our deadly foes, but we are actually becoming at variance with our true friends’; the change of expression being a rhetorical device to arrest the attention.

We have a similar variation in Dem. Lept. 461, para\ d) u(mi=n a)\ a)\n la/bh| tis e)/xein u(ph=rxe to\n gou=n a)/llon xro/non, ‘in your city whatever a man has once received he used at any rate to be allowed to keep’. In this passage, in which the speaker is discussing a change of the laws for rewarding public services, he makes a sudden change of tense, and instead of saying e)/xein u(pa/rxei, throws the sentence into an imperfect form.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXIV
div2.p:
po/lin...parexo/menos—pare/xesqai means to put forward as one's own, or on one's own part. Hence, applied to an envoy, it means either to represent, or to offer the alliance of the city
from which the speaker comes. The former view seems to give the better sense in the present passage and in ch. 85, 24, po/lin a)cio/xrewn parexome/nous: while the latter agrees better with such expressions as iii. 36, e)/stin a(\ parexo/menon, ‘making certain offers’.
e)piw/n tw|—‘more likely to be an assailant than to have to defend myself’; sing. because the speaker identifies himself with the state which he represents.

proeido/menos...au)to/s—a correction adopted by all editors for the manuscript reading proeidome/nous...au)tou/s, ‘e)gw\ me\n...a)ciw= is clearly opposed to tou\s a)/llous dikaiw= tau)to/ moi poih=sai, and distinguishes what Hermocrates thinks should be done by others from what he was prepared to do himself’ (Arnold). The augmented participle proeido/menos is abnormal and open to question; on the other hand there seems to be no authority here for the regular form proi)do/menos. In Dem. fals. leg. 413, proi)do/menos is now read, but in Aesch. Timarch. 23, 71, proeido/menos is still retained: see Veitch's Greek Verbs.

proeido/menos au)tw=n—‘taking thought beforehand for these things’, i.e. for the interests which he has been urging: cf. note on au)to/, ch. 18, 5. The gen. is to be explained like fulassome/nous tw=n new=n, ch. 11, 19: elsewhere we have the accusative construction, with the sense of foreseeing.
mwri/a| filoneikw=n—‘in a foolish spirit of contentiousness’: v. 43, fronh/mati filoneikw=n.
o(/son ei)ko\s h(ssa=sqai—‘to make all reasonable concessions’: cf. ch. 19, 22.

u(f' u(mw=n au)tw=n—the manuscript reading, retained by most editors, to be taken with paqei=n. Arnold however approves of Dobree's correction a)f' u(mw=n, connecting it with poih=sai. tou=to paqei=n—sc. h(ssa=sqai, which implies either to yield to friends or to be worsted by enemies.

to\ de\ cu/mpan—‘while we are all neighbours and joint possessors of one island home’. In this clause the speaker passes from the individual ties of race to the universal bond of a common country. The accusatives correspond to the construction with ou)de\n ai)sxro/n with which the sentence begins. Instead of de/ Krüger reads ge and Classen te, but neither correction is an improvement. This is not the place for a resumptive te, and de/ is required to mark the opposition between the particular and the general obligations to mutual concession.

kai\ perirru/tou—‘and that an island’; a further reason for union. peri/rrutos is rare in prose: Hdt. iv. 42, *libu/h
dhloi= e(wuth\n e)ou=sa peri/rrutos. o)/noma e(/n—cf. ii. 37, o)/noma... dhmokrati/a ke/klhtai: i. 122, to\ e)nanti/on o)/noma a)frosu/nh metwno/mastai.

duoi=n a)gaqoi=n—‘there are two blessings of which we shall not rob Sicily’. ou) sterh/somen is practically equivalent to a single expression: cf. ch. 106, 10: Eur. Or. 1151, e(no\s ga\r ou) sfale/ntes e(/comen kle/os.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXV
div2.p: au)toi\ me/n—opp. to oi( de\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, line 7: cf. ch. 49, 6. The Athenians were not communicated with till the Siceliots had settled their policy.

cunhne/xqhsan—‘agreed, came to terms’: vi. 13, kaq' au(tou\s kai\ cumfe/resqai. gnw/mh|—‘in a resolution’, denoting the views which finally prevailed and the determination which was formed. w(/ste—cf. ch. 37, 10.
e)/xontes—so ch. 118, 15, e)/xontes a)/per nu=n e)/xomen.

*kamarinai/ois *morganti/nhn—Morgantine was situated on the Symaethus between Syracuse and Catana on the east of Sicily, while Camarina was on the south coast. There seems therefore some error in one of the names. Possibly *katanai/ois should be read instead of *kamarinai/ois, unless indeed there was another Morgantine of which we do not know.

oi( de\. cu/mmaxoi—they had of course taken part in the conference. The real opposition is therefore between the Sicilian convention and its effect on the Athenians: cf. note on ch. 24, 1, oi( e)n th=| *sikeli/a| *surako/sioi.
ka)kei/nois—the Athenians: ch. 37, 10. e)painesa/ntwn... e)poiou=nto—the same tenses are used in a similar sentence, ch. 16, 1.
xrh/mata e)pra/canto—=e)zhmi/wsan xrh/masin, ii. 65: cf. vi. 54, ei)kosth\n prasso/menoi, of a tax: pass. viii. 5, pepragme/nos fo/rous.

th=| parou/sh|—the manuscripts are in favour of th=| te parou/sh|: Bekker suggests th=| to/te. h)ci/oun—‘expected’; with two constructions, mhde\n e)nantiou=sqai and katerga/zesqai: in i. 43 we have a converse change of subject, to\ au)to\ a)ciou=men komi/zesqai, kai\ mh\...h(ma=s bla/yai. sc. u(ma=s, subj. to bla/yai.
ai)ti/a d' h)=n—the same construction as in ch. 26, 16. Classen points out that Thuc. elsewhere uses ai)/tion: e.g. i. 11: ai)/tion...h\ o)liganqrwpi/a.

u(potiqei=sa—‘inspiring’: i. 138, e)lpi/da h(
 u(peti/qei: iii. 45, e)lpi\s...th
 eu)pori/an th=s tu/xhs u(potiqei=sa, ‘giving hopes of’. i)sxu
 th=s e)lpi/dos—cf. ii. 62, e)lpi/di...h)=s e)n tw=| a)po/rw| h) i)sxu/s, where hope is contrasted with judgment founded on actual resources (gnw/mh a)po\ tw=n u)parxo/ntwn): so in v. 103, we have the Athenians denouncing the dangers of mere visionary hopes.

The ideas of the Athenians at this period may possibly have been extravagant, but there was certainly good reason for their indignation against Pythodorus, who had handled the fleet badly and lost Messene. We are not told that Eurymedon and Sophocles effected anything to improve the position of affairs; so that, although the generals might not have had it in their power to prevent the Sicilian convention, the displeasure with which they were received is not to be wondered at.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXVI
div2.p: kata\ e)/tos e(/kaston di/s—cf. ii. 31, where we have the first invasion under Pericles in the autumn of 431. Plutarch (Per. ch. 30) records a decree that the strategi should swear to invade Megara twice a year, and speaks of the strong feeling of Pericles against the Megarians. In i. 67 and 139 reference is made to their exclusion from Attic ports and markets. For their starving condition vid. Ar. Ach. 535 and 729—818. This play was exhibited in Feb. 425.

tw=n e)k *phgw=n—Pegae was the Megarian harbour on the gulf of Corinth; ch. 21, 14. We are not told before this of its occupation by the fuga/des. They were possibly the same as those who were allowed to settle for a year or so in Plataeae, iii. 68. As the Athenians commanded Nisaea the hostility of Pegae was a serious evil.

stasiasa/ntwn—cf. ch. 3. 8, a)ntilego/ntwn. e)kpeso/ntes— ‘having been expelled’: e)kpi/ptw is virtually pass. of e)kba/llw, and so constructed with u(po/: cf. i. 131, e)s th\n ei(rkth\n e)spi/ptei u(po\ tw=n e)fo/rwn, ‘is thrown into prison’. The same constr. is common with a)poqnh/skw, plhga\s lamba/nw, kakw=s a)kou/w, etc.
a)mfote/rwqen—by intestine as well as foreign war; or possibly from Pegae as well as Minoa.
to\n qrou=n—‘the general talk’: v. 7 and viii. 79 with ai)sqo/menos: v. 30, ai/sqo/menoi to\n qrou=n kaqestw=ta: v. 59, e)s qrou=n kaqi/stato.

h)ci/oun—‘thought fit’, i.e. felt themselves in a position to urge the question of recalling their friends lo/gou—the proposal for the restoration of the exiles. e)/xesqai—cf. v. 49, tou= au)tou= lo/gou ei)/xonto, ‘held fast to, insisted on’.
oi( tou= dh/mou prosta/tai—cf. ch. 46, 17.

e(ndou=nai—so ch. 76, 15, *xairw/neian e)nedi/dosan: v. 62, e(nedi/dosan ta\ pra/gmata. For other uses of e)ndi/dwmi cf. ch. 35, 17; iii. 37, oi)/ktw| e)n dw=te, ‘concede’: ii. 49, spasmo\n e)ndidou=sa, ‘causing, bringing with it’.
katelqei=n—cf. periplei=n, v. 53.

h)=n de\ stadi/wn—gen. of measure. Xen. Anab. i. 2. 8, to\ eu)=ros ei)/kosi kai\ pe)nte podw=n: Madv. § 54. As regards the length of the walls Thucydides differs from Strabo, according to whom the distance to the port was 18 stades. These walls were constructed and garrisoned by the Athenians in 455, when Megara joined their alliance (i. 103).

th
 *ni/saian to/n—so ch. 46, 14, th
 nh=son th
 *ptuxi/an: ch. 67, 7, tou= *dhmosqe/nous tou=: v. 46, peri\ to
 *cena/rh to
 e)/foron, etc.
bebaio/thtos e(/neka—‘in order to secure’ with object. gen. *mega/rwn. peira=sqai—sc. themselves; change of subject, as in ch. 65, 20.
e)/mellon—sc. oi( *megarh=s.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXVII
div2.p: a)po/ te tw=n—lit. ‘on the side of’, i.e. ‘so far as regards’: cf. ii. 77, a)po\ tw=n paro/ntwn deinw=n, ‘with their present means of offence’: vi. 102, a)po\ th=s parou/shs duna/mews: see also note on a)po/, ch. 18, 8. pareskeu/asto—so i. 46, e)peidh\ au)toi=s pareskeu/asto, ‘when their arrangements were complete’.

th\n *megare/wn nh=son—so iii. 51, e)pi( *minw/an th\n nh=son h(\ kei=tai pro\ *mega/rwn. The definite article is used because the situation of the island was well known, or because it has been mentioned before. Minoa was occupied by the Athenians in 427, as a convenient station for maintaining the blockade against Megara (iii. 51).

o(/qen e)pli/nqeuon—‘from which they got bricks for the walls’, i.e. clay to make them: so Hom. Od. xviii. 359. ai(masi/as le/gwn. ‘picking (stones for) walls’. For e)pli/nqeuon Classen suggests e)pli/nqeusan: the imperfect however gives a good sense, as repairs and additions were probably made from time to time.

kai\ a)pei=xen—sc. from the walls: it was plainly on the main land. We should say ‘and which was distant’, and possibly o(/ is to be understood from o(/qen. In Greek however the second clause in a relative construction is commonly thrown into a demonstrative form; cf. ii. 4, oi)/khma, o(\ h)=n tou= tei/xous, kai\ ai\ qu/rai a)new|gme/nai e)/tuxon au)tou=: Plat. Gorg. 452 D, ti/ e/sti tou=to o(\ fh\|s su\ me/giston a)gaqo\n ei)=nai, kai\ se\ dhmiourgo\n ei)=nai au)tou=. This seems also the simplest explanation of such sentences as the present, which are of common occurrence; e.g. i. 106, w)=| e)/tuxen o)/rugma me/ga periei=rgon kai\ ou)k h)=n e)/codos.

*plataih=s—of those who escaped to Athens, iii. 24. kai\ e(/teroi peri/poloi—‘and besides them certain of the frontier guard’. The Athenians on attaining eighteen years of age were enrolled among the e)/fhboi, and after some preliminary training, served till the age of twenty in the peri/poloi or national guard. It seems probable that their first term of service was in Athens itself, while during the second year they formed a moveable force, employed in garrisoning fortified places in Attica, and in the defence of any point which might be threatened. They were armed with the hoplite's spear and shield. On the present occasion they seem to have been employed on service beyond the frontier of Attica, or to have been stationed at Minoa. Some authorities therefore doubt if peri/poloi is to be understood here in its usual sense: see Arnold's and Poppo's notes.

e)s to\ *)enua/lion—so Poppo, Krüger, etc. for the manuscript reading e)s to/n. The neuter o(/ which follows makes the correction imperative, otherwise to/n might possibly be retained on the analogy of iii. 3, e)s to\n *malo/enta e)ch=lqon, ‘to the temple of (Apollo) Maloeis’: Ar. Av. 619, ei)s *)/ammwn' e)lqo/ntes. In both these passages however there is an idea of worshipping or consulting the deity beyond the mere notion of locality, as is natural when the name of the god is used to designate his temple; vid. Arnold: cf. however ch. 118, 21, para\ tou= *ni/sou. The form *)enua/lion is neut. adj. sc. i(ero/n.
e)/lasson a)/poqen—nearer (than the brick pit) to the walls.

w(s lh|stai/—in iii. 51 we find that the Athenians hoped by occupying Nisaea to suffer less from lh|stw=n e)kpompai/ on the part of the Megarians. e)k pollou=—‘for some time back’, connected with both teqerapeuko/tes and ei)w/qesan, and opposed to kai\ to/te, line 22: cf. ch. 103, 15. teqerapeuko/tes—‘having managed, secured’: v. 11, cummaxi/an qerapeu/ontes: vi. 61, qerapeu/ontes (to\) mh\ qorubei=n. tw=n pulw=n—at the end of the long walls. These gates, like Nisaea itself, were held by the Peloponnesian garrison.
dia\ th=s ta/froi—this seems to have been a dry trench outside the walls of Nisaea, extending from the long walls to the sea. Rutherford rejects the words, kata\ th/n being Attic.

e)s to\ tei=xos—sc. within the long walls: so ch. 68, 2: 69, 9. o(/pws...a)fanh/s—i.e. that the Athenian garrison might not know what they had to look out against. For a)fanh/s in the sense of uncertain and doubtful, cf. ii. 42, opp. to to\ o(rw/menon: viii. 92, opp. to a settled arrangement. dh/ implies pretence: cf. ch. 23, 8.
kai\ to/te—‘so now’, resuming the account of the actual attempt.

cugklh|sqh=nai—Bekker and Arnold have cugklh|qh=nai, but the aor. pass. seems always to have s: vid. Poppo, and Veitch's Greek Verbs. All editors have cugklh|sqe/n, v. 72, and kateklh/|sqhsan, i. 117.

kw/luma...prosqei=nai—‘a hindrance to shutting’; vid. Goodwin § 92, note 2. In i. 16 we have kwlu/mata mh\ au)chqh=nai. Similarly kwlu/w and other verbs of kindred meaning take an inf. with or without mh/. prosqei=nai—cf. Hdt. iii. 78, prosqei=nai ta\s qu/ras: in Ar. Vesp. 201 th=| dokw=| prosqei/s possibly means ‘shutting (the door) by means of the bar’.

kai\ au)toi=s—from its position virtually dat. commodi, though it may be connected grammatically with cumpra/ssontes: iii. 36, oi( au)toi=s tw=n *)aqhnai/wn cumpra/ssontes. kata\ ta\s pu/las—there is good authority for the article, which however is omitted by many editors: cf. note on me/son, ch. 31, 9.

ou)= nu=n to\ tropai=on—so v. 10, h)=|per nu=n tropai=on e)/sthke. Jowett points out that although the Megarians recovered the walls and destroyed them (ch. 109), yet the trophy was not molested. h)/|sqonto ga/r—explains maxo/menoi: notwithstanding the surprise the Athenians did not win the gates without fighting (Arnold).
o(pli/tais—the troops under Hippocrates, supr. line 4.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXVIII
div2.p: o( a)ei\ e)nto\s gigno/menos—as each got in: iii. 77, ta\s a)ei\ plhroume/nas (nau=s) e)ce/pempon, sent out their ships as fast as they could man them.

to\ me\n prw=ton—this finds its corresponding clause in a)/ma d' e)/w|, line 16, or perhaps in oi( d' w(s, line 13. The latter however seems rather to belong to the loosely-worded parenthetical sentences which describe the general panic.

a)ntisxo)ntes—‘held out, made a stand’: vi. 22, o)/pws pro\s to\ i(ppiko\n a)nte/xwsi: ii. 49, with dat., of the body holding out against disease: i. 65, abs. of supplies holding out. o)li/goi— partial apposition: ch. 6, 4: 62, 17.

e)s fugh\n kate/sthsan—so ch. 100, 22, and often. prospeptwko/twn kai\ nomi/santes—two different constructions giving the reasons of the panic; the second clause having a subordinate parenthesis tw=n prodido/ntwn a)ntimaxome/nwn. sfa=s— the Peloponnesians, gov. by prodedwke/nai.

cune/pese—see note on cu/mptwma, ch. 36, 16: Hdt. viii. 15, sune/pipte de\ w)/ste gi/gnesqai, of two coincident events. a)f' e(autou= gnw/mhs—‘of his own idea’, an unusual expression, of which Poppo cites instances from Dio. Cass.: in iii. 92 we have a)po\ toia=sde gnw/mhs, ‘with this idea’: cf. Dem. de Cor. 281, a)po\ th=s e/mautou= gnw/mhs, ‘from my own judgment’.

qhso/menon ta\ o(/pla—to be taken with i)e/nai, the inf. depending on khru=cai: so ch. 105, 12: cf. ii. 2, a)nei=pen o) kh/ruc, ei)/ tis bou/letai cummaxei=n, ti/qesqai par' au(tou\s ta\ o)/pla. The phrase of course is not to be taken literally, but simply means ‘to join the Athenians’; see note on ch. 44, 6.
polemei=sqai—pers. ‘that they were attacked’: so i. 37, au(toi\ ou(k ei)ko/tws polemou=ntai: or perhaps impers. like ch. 23, 12, ta\ peri\ *pu/lon e)polemei=to.

oi( pro\s ..pra/cantes—‘those who had conducted the intrigue with the Athenians’: i. 131, pra/sswn pro\s tou\s barba/rous. Instead of a)/lloi Krüger and Classen read a)/llo in agreement with plh=qos. The main body of the democratical party is denoted, the arrangement having been made by their prosta/tai (ch. 66).
cune/keito—see note on ch. 23, 4: for inf. cf. viii. 52, cugkei=sqai kratei=n basile/a.
dia/dhloi—‘distinguished from the others’, dia/ denoting disjunction, as in dialu/w, diagignw/skw, etc.

li/pa—so i. 6, li/pa h)lei/yanto. li/pa is regarded as either (1) a dat. (=li/pai or li/pa|) from an old noun li/pa, or (2) an adv. or cogn. accus. from a supposed nom. li/y. See Lidd. and Scott, and notes on Hom. Il. x. 577, a)leiyame/nw li/p' e)lai/w|: Od. iii. 466, e)/xrisen li/p' e)lai/w|. It only occurs once in Homer without e)lai/w|, Od. vi. 227.
a)lei/yesqai is constructed in accordance with the sense as if ‘they agreed’ had preceded. a)dikw=ntai—harmed by their friends (the Athenians): the word implies unfair or wrongful injury.

a)sfa/leia—‘they could open the gates with more safety’, because the main Athenian army was now at hand. Classen suspects that this sentence, as far as parh=san, is out of place, and ought to follow e)pecie/nai e)s ma/xhn, line 20. It certainly seems clear that by tou\s *)aqhnai/ous (line 21) is denoted the force which came from Eleusis, and not the troops in possession of the long walls.

oi( a)po/—the def. article is explained by kata\ to\ cugkei/menon, though the arrangement has not been mentioned before. oi( th\n nu/kta poreuo/menoi—‘those troops, that is, which were marching (or were to march) during the night’, as opposed to those already in ambush at Megara. If the def. article be retained it is used to give a further definition, as in ch. 1, 19, a)/llai ai( plhrou/menai. Most editors however reject oi(, which is absent from several manuscripts, and may have got into the text from the last syllable of e(cako/sioi.
kai\ oi(/—cf. note on ch. 33, 13. Here the demonstrative form seems required by the sense.
tis—a common usage in threats and warnings: cf. ch. 13, 21, h)\n e)sple/h| tis: iii. 2, ei) mh/ tis prokatalh/yetai. au)tou=...e)/sesqai—sc. they threatened to fight it out on the spot.
i)sxuri/zonto—‘insisted’: ch. 23, 6.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXIX
div2.p: e)nanti/wma—only here in Thuc.: Dem. de Cor. 328, para\ th=s tu/xhs ti sumbe/bhken e)nanti/wma. perietei/xizon—imp., =began the circumvallation.
si/dhros—according to the scholiast the same as sidhria liqourga/, ch. 4, 6.

a)rca/menoi d'—the construction of this sentence is loose and irregular; the chief difficulty being with what verb a)rca/menoi and the following participles are to be connected. Krüger and Arnold refer them to the preceding perietei/xizon: but the de/ with a)rca/menoi is against this view, and marks the beginning of a new sentence. Accordingly Poppo connects all the participles with a)pestau/roun in line 14. This verb however does not contain the main idea of the sentence, but only describes a small part of the siege operations. There remains therefore the explanation suggested in Classen's critical note, that some general word such as perietei/xizon was
intended to follow a)rca/menoi, and must be understood with i\p' e/kei/nou...*nisai/as and what follows. A similar view is taken by Jowett.

a)po\ tou= tei/xous—the long walls and the space enclosed, which had been taken at daybreak (ch. 66). For sing. tei/xous cf. ch. 67, 19: also ii. 13, where tou= makrou= means the double wall to the Piraeus. dioikodomh/santes—‘walling off’, by a cross work, to prevent interruption from the city: cf. viii. 90, diw|kodo/mhsan stoa/n: so in iii. 34 and vii. 60 diatei/xisma means a separate space walled off, a separate fortified work.

a)p' e)kei/nou e(kate/rwqen—the Athenians extended their works on both sides, so as to enclose Nisaea from sea to sea. e)s qa/lassan—sc. perietei/xizon, note on line 9. *nisai/as— dep. on e(kate/rwqen: ch. 31, 5, th=s nh/sou e(kate/rwqen.

ta/fron...dielome/nh—the sentence, which began with oi( strathgoi/, has now expanded its subject, and applies to the whole Athenian force, with which the collective stratia/ stands in apposition. For dielome/nh see note on ch. 11, 11: so v. 75, dielo/menoi th\n po/lin perietei/xizon.

proastei/ou—‘an open space like the parks in London. partly planted with trees, and containing public walks, colonnades, temples, and the houses of some of the principal citizens. It was used as a ground for reviews of the army, and for public games’ (Arnold).

kai\ ko/ptontes—most editors take this as a fresh sentence. Probably however as no finite verb has yet been expressed, though intended, the main sentence closes with a)pestau/roun, although in sense this verb applies to the final clause alone. The clue has in fact been dropped in a maze of participles and parentheses. According to this view the kai/ which precedes ko/ptontes corresponds to the te which follows e)k in the previous line; otherwise dielome/nh and xrw/menoi are connected by (ta/fron) te...(e)/k) te.

ta) de/ndra—esp. the fruit trees, which would be found in the proa/steion, mainly olives and figs: see Arnold on ii. 75. u(/lhn—‘brushwood’, for fascines and to interlace with the palisades. See the account of the siege of Plataeae, ii. 75, 76; where we find that cu/la is the word used for timber from forest trees, as in ch. 13, 3 and 52, 16: cf. Xen. Anab. i. 5, 1, ei) de/ ti kai\ a)/llo e)nh=n u(/lhs h)\ kala/mou (shrub or plant)...de/ndron d' ou)de\n e)nh=n.

ei)/ ph| de/oito/ ti—‘if at any point any part needed it’; ti being the subject of the verb; so Poppo. Krüger proposes to read de/oi, as in ch. 4, 9, ei)/ pou de/oi. Classen and Jowett
take de/oito=de/oi, citing Soph. O. C. 570, w)/ste braxe/a moi dei=sqai fra/sai: Dem. de Cor. 276, ou)de\n...ei)sh/geto w)=n e)dei=t' au)tw=|. Veitch gives Plat. Meno 79 c, and Hdt. iv. 11, as instances in which dei=sqai and deo/menon ‘may be thought to have rather an appearance of impersonality’. All these passages however can be explained without depriving de/omai of its usual meaning.

e)pa/lceis lamba/nousai—‘with the addition of battlements’: ch. 115, 3, a)p' oi)kiw=n e)pa/lceis e)xousw=n. In the same ch., line 14, we have labo\n mei=zon a)/xqos: cf. Hdt. ix. 7, to\ tei=xos ...h)/dh e)pa/lceis e)la/mbane. au)tai\ u(ph=rxon—‘of themselves’, cf. ch. 4, 15.
o(/son ou)k—‘all but’: i. 36, o(/son ou( paro/nta po/lemon: ch. 125, 11, o(/son ou)/pw. si/tou te—the first reason for their surrender; two others are then given with nomi/zontes and h)gou/menoi.

e(/kaston...parado/ntas—acc. because the subject of a)poluqh=nai is not identical with the subject of cune/bhsan, but corresponds to e(/kaston put collectively. The convention was made by the Lacedaemonian officers on behalf of the whole force. ‘The a)/rxwn here spoken of was the Spartan commander of the Peloponnesian garrison, like Tantalus at Thyrea, ch. 57; Pasitelidas at Torone, v. 3; Menedaeus and his colleagues in Acarnania, iii. 100’ (Arnold).

xrh=sqai—so ii. 4, cune/bhsan paradou=nai sfa=s au)tou\s... xrh/sasqai o(/ ti a)\n bou/lwntai. a)porrh/cantes—by destroying a portion of the walls; thus securing their occupation of Nisaea, and the rest of the walls.
paralabo/ntes—ch. 54, 21.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXX
div2.p: *brasi/das o( *te/llidos—Brasidas was spoken of in chapter 11 without any description; while here we have his country and father named, as in ii. 25. So Cleon is twice described in similar words, ch. 21, 10 note.

stratei/an—so Poppo, etc. for stratia/n, cf. ch. 74, 10. The two words are frequently confused in the manuscripts; see Krüger on i. 3, and Poppo and Classen on i. 9. Aristophanes undoubtedly uses stratia/ for an expedition, e.g. Vesp. 354, but the usage is very doubtful in prose. In vii. 17 and viii. 108 stratia\n e)pagge/llein is ‘to require a military force’.
e)/s te tou/s—corresponds to kai\ au)to/s, line 10, showing what Brasidas and the Boeotians were to do respectively. te is slightly out of place: cf. ch. 52, 6.
o)/noma tou=to—see note on ou(=tos, ch. 41, 7.

e)celqw/n—‘having marched out’, sc. to relieve Megara: v. 8, kaqaro
 e)ch=lqe, of Cleon's expedition: v. 54, e)celqo/ntes: Classen however takes it to mean coming out from the mountain pass. e(/tuxe ga/r—showing why he could act without discovery. pri
 e)/kpustos gene/sqai—so iii. 30, pri
 e)kpu/stous gene/sqai.

tw=| lo/gw|—his professed object was the recovery of Nisaea, and he might possibly really attempt it, but his main purpose was to enter the city and secure Megara itself against the democratical party. The definite article with lo/gw| shows that this motive was actually put forward, while it is absent with the merely hypothetical e)/rgw|. to\ me/giston is a frequent appositional construction: ii. 65, to\ de\ me/giston po/lemon a/nt' ei)rh/nhs e)/xontes.

sfa=s—himself and his men: ch. 9, 21. e)n e)lpi/di ei)=nai—so vii. 25, e/n e)lpi)sin ei)si/n. The aor. inf. follows in accordance with the general construction of such phrases; in vii. 46 however we have e)n e)lpi/di ei)=nai...ai(rh/sein, denoting a result not immediately looked for.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXI
div2.p: oi( me\n...oi( de/—‘the one party...the other’, in apposition with sta/seis: iii. 105, oi( *)akarna=nes oi( me\n...oi( de/. sfi/sin— dat. incommodi with e)sagagw/n. au)tou/s—‘themselves’=sfa=s: ch. 50, 13 note.
e)pi/qhtai—ch. 1, 17.
e)fedreuo/ntwn—‘waiting to attack them’; viii. 92, e)fedreuo/ntwn tw=n polemi/wn: Eur. Or. 1627, cifh/rhs th=|d' e)fedreu/eis ko/rh|.

h(suxa/sasi—‘to stop their quarrel and await the issue’: note the force of the aorist participle. perii+dei=n, which in the act. usually means ‘to overlook’, here means ‘to look round for’, i.e. await: this is the meaning of the mid. present, as in ch. 73, 6, periorwme/nous: in vi. 93 and vii. 33, periorw/menoi means ‘standing aloof, waiting the event’: cf. ch. 124, 29.

a)sfaleste/rws—so ch. 39, 11, e)ndeeste/rws: i. 130, meizo/nws. oi)=s=o(pote/rois: so ch. 128, 1, o(/n, meaning one of two. ei)/h—see Goodwin § 74, for the use of the optative in compound sentences. krath/sasi—‘when they had won the day’.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXII
div2.p: parh=san—arrived at Tripodiscus. The rest of the sentence as far as a)ph=lqon pa/lin is parenthetical, and relates to what passed before this: cf. iii. 2, boulhqe/ntes me\n kai\ pro\ tou= pole/mou, k.t.l. dianenohme/noi me/n—the construction is slightly irregular, as the corresponding clause with de/ has a finite verb e)rrw/sqhsan, line 6; the participial and subordinate character of the parenthesis is in fact lost sight of.
ou)k a)llotri/ou—cf. note on ch. 6, 5, oi)kei=on.

e)rrw/sqhsan—‘were ardent’: ii. 8, e)/rrwnto e)s to\n po/lemon: ib. e)/rrwto pa=s with inf.: viii. 78, e)/rrwnto ma=llon. a)postei/lantes—they despatched at once a large force to cooperate with Brasidas: the rest of their army was no longer required. This explains who were oi( *boiwtoi/, line 1.

ou)k e)/lasson—so vi. 95, e)pra/qh tala/ntwn ou)k e)/lasson pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi. ‘When a magnitude expressed in numbers is increased by ple/on (plei=on, plei=n), or diminished by e)/latton (mei=on), these words, with or without h)/, are attached to the denomination of the magnitude without influencing its case’ (Madv. § 92). So in Latin with plus, minus, etc., e.g. Liv. xlii. 7, pugnatum est amplius tres horas.
e)n ga/r—explanatory of a)prosdokh/tois. e)n tw=| pro\ tou=—so i. 32 with pw: cf. ch. 12, 18, e)n tw=| to/te.

a)ntepecela/santes—a compound like a)ntepanago/menoi, ch. 25, 4: cf. ch. 131, 1, a)ntepecelqo/ntes: viii. 104, a)ntepech=gon. oi( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn—sc. i(pph=s, understood from line 14 and implied by a(ntepecela/santes. e)pi\ polu/—of time, as in v. 16, xrh=sai ta/de e)pi\ polu/. The phrase more commonly denotes extent of space rather than of time, while in such passages as the following its meaning is doubtful; i. 6, e)pi\ polu\ au(/th h) skeuh\ kate/sxe: i. 7, dia\ th\n lhstei/an e)pi\ polu\ a)ntisxou=san.
a)ciou=sin e(ka/teroi—‘both sides claim the victory’: i. 105, e)no/misan au(toi\ e(ka/teroi ou)k e)/lasson e)/xein: cf. i. 54, e(ka/teroi nika=n h)ci/oun.

prosela/santas—a conjecture of Portus for prosela/santes, so Classen. The latter shows that the word is used of cavalry ‘riding up’ or ‘pushing on’; vi. 63, i(pph=s proselau/nontes pro\s to\ stra/teuma: vi. 65, oi( i(pph=s prosela/santes e)s th\n *kata/nhn. It therefore applies exactly to the Boeotians, who pushed their advance as far as the walls of Nisaea. One manuscript has prosela/santa, which might possibly be retained in agreement with i(/pparxon. The only objection to reading prosela/santas is
the awkwardness of the following kai/, which must be taken in the sense of ‘both’, connecting a)poktei/nantes e)sku/leusan with kai\ tw=n te...e)/sthsan, instead of simply joining two participles of the same construction.

Poppo retains prosela/santes, which he considers may mean that the Athenians retired on Nisaea, so as to draw the enemy in that direction. Arnold, followed by Krüger, reads pro\s au\th=| th=| *nisai/a|, ‘under the walls of Nisaea’, and explains prosela/santes of the Athenians ‘charging the enemy’.

ou) me/ntoi—the general action however had no decisive result. e)n tw=| panti\ e)/rgw| is opposed to the success of the Athenians at a single point. bebai/ws—with teleuth/santes, ‘certum pugnae eventum adepti’, Poppo. If the text be right we must adopt this explanation. Classen takes teleuth/santes adverbially, ‘in the end’; but I believe that the present participle only can be thus used. Krüger and others suspect an error in teleuth/santes.

a)pekri/qhsan—‘separated’; so diekri/qhsan, ch. 14, 24, etc. Lid. and Scott give no other instance of apokri/nomai thus used. In ii. 49 e)s tou=to pa/nta a(pekri/qh means ‘all diseases ended in this alone’. a)ll' oi( me/n—sc. a)pekri/qhsan, neither side got the victory, but they retired to their respective camps. The disjunction is awkward, and the whole sentence somewhat unsatisfactory. It would seem as if a)pekri/qhsan ought to follow a)lla/, some finite verb being lost in the first clause.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXIII
div2.p: periorwme/nous—cf. ch. 71, 8, perii+dei=n.

a)mfo/tera—explained by the clauses with a(/ma me/n and e)n tw=| au(tw=| de/ line 12: cf. iii. 11, a(/ma me
 ga/r...e)n tw=| au)tw=| de\ kai/ k.t.l. e)pixeirei=n prote/rous—both words used of taking the initiative in attack: ch. 29, 21, e)p' e)kei/nois ga a)
 ei)=nai th
 e)pixei/rhsin: i. 123, oi( pro/teroi e)pio/ntes.

e)peidh/ ge—having shown that they were ready to defend themselves, there was no need to begin the attack. For nom. e/toi=moi o)/ntes cf. v. 72, e)/deican perigeno/menoi: i. 21, o( po/lemos dhlw/sei mei/zwn gegenhme/nos: Soph. Ant. 20, dhloi=s ti kalxai/nous' e)/pos: see Goodwin, § 113.

kai\ au)toi=s—‘and so the victory might be justly put down to them as it were without a struggle’. This is a parenthetical clause dependent on e)no/mizon. For au)toi=s cf. ch. 50, 13: so infr. line 18. a)koniti/—Dem. de Cor. 295, tau=ta proei=to a)koniti/: cf. Hor. Ep. i. 1, 51, condicio dulcis sine pulnere palinae.

ti/qesqai—pass. in the sense of attributing or reckoning. Krüger and Classen regard this use of ti/qesqai with suspicion, no instance of such a phrase as tiqe/nai tini\ ni/khn being found. Krüger therefore reads a)nati/qesqai for a)\n ti/qesqai: cf. Dem. de Cor. 230, ta\ pepragme/na e(autw=| a)natiqei\s e)moi/, etc. Classen considers that in sense also the whole clause is out of place. It seems, he thinks, like an explanatory gloss of a)maxei\ w)=n e(/neka h)=lqon, line 18, or a second clause in connexion with those words.

e)n tw=| au)tw=| de/—‘and moreover as regards the Megareans things turned out well’. o)rqw=s cumbai/nein is a repetition of kalw=s e)/xein, line 7, and in construction depends on e)no/mizon. Had strict regularity been observed the two clauses would run thus, kalw=s e)no/mizon a)mfo/tera e)/xein, a(/ma me\n to\ mh\ e)pixeirei=n k.t.l., e)n tw=| au)tw=| de\ to\ pro\s *megare/as.

ou)k a)\n e)n tu/xh|—i.e. they would not have had even a chance; ‘non fuisse futurum ut res in aleam daretur’, Poppo. e)n tu/xh| gi/gnesqai, sc. ta\ pra/gmata, is a very unusual phrase: it may be illustrated by such expressions as i. 137, e)n tw=| a)sfalei= me\n e)moi/ (e)gi/gneto), ‘I was in safety’: vi. 60, ou)k e)n pau/lh| e)fai/neto, ‘there was no sign of stopping’. Poppo explains in the same way iii. 33, ou)ke/ti e)n katalh/yei e)fai/neto, ‘there seemed no hope of catching (the foe)’: here however *)alki/das, who has been mentioned before, may be the subject of the verb.

w(/sper h(sshqe/ntwn—gen. abs. sc. sfw=n: cf. v. 33, e)s *parrasi/ous...e)pikalesame/nwn sfa=s, sc. tw=n *parrasi/wn: vi. 7, oi *)argei=oi...e)celqo/ntwn, sc. tw=n *)argei/wn. In all these passages we might have expected a nom. or acc. participle. Possibly the subject of h(sshqe/ntwn, ‘after a defeat’, is to be considered as not absolutely identical and co-extensive with the subject of e)no/mizon and sterhqh=nai, though referring to the same side, and the other passages may be similarly explained.

ka)\n tuxei=n...boulhqe/ntas—for tugxa/nw with particip. cf. ch. 115, 5, e)/tuxon kaqeu/dontes: and see Goodwin § 112, 2. The aorist boulhqe/ntas can not be equivalent to boulo/menoi, but must give the sense ‘it might even be the case that the Athenians had shrunk from an engagement’, i.e. had been dismayed when they saw the Lacedaemonians advance towards Megara. Note the absence of the article with au)tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, a construction only admissible with proper names: cf. ch. 80, 25, au)to\n *brasi/dan: so Plat. Menex. 241 D, au)to\s *basilei/s, of the Persian king.
perigene/sqai—of the accruing of advantage: cf. vi. 8, h)/n ti perige/nhtai au)toi=s.

oi( ga\r *megarh=s—the subject of the main sentence. It is followed by a long parenthesis as far as line 32, and it is repeated in the words oi( tw=n feugo/ntwn fi/loi *megarh=s. mh) e)pio/ntwn—sc. tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn. kai\ oi( e)kei/nwn strathgoi/— partial apposition: cf. note on ch. 6, 4.

a)nti/palon—lit. ‘equally matched’: the Athenians reflected that they would risk more in a battle than their adversaries. e)peidh\ kai/—cf. e)peidh/ k.t.l. line 9. ta\ plei/w— the capture of Nisaea and the long walls.
a)/rcasi—sc. sfi/si, ‘to begin’ or ‘if they began’. pro\s plei/onas—the enemy had 6000 heavy-armed men, the Athenians 4600 (ch. 68, 4: 72, 25) besides the light-armed Plataeans and peri/poloi.

h(\ labei=n...h)\...blafqh=nai—these alternative clauses are explanatory of to\n ki/ndunon. tw=| belti/stw|—to be taken with blafqh=nai, the dat. denoting the part in or with which the loss would be incurred. This construction is not elsewhere found with bla/ptw, with which ‘poetae, cum in vim privandi transeat, genitivo utuntur’ (Poppo); but it may be defended on the analogy of such passages as ii. 65, sfale/ntes...paraskeuh=|: vi. 10, sfale/ntwn a)cio/xrew| duna/mei: ib. metew/rw| po/lei kinduneu/ein. Possibly in the present passage the construction may be somewhat affected by sfale)ntas.
For the 1st aor. form blafqh=nai cf. ch. 87, 29: blabh=nai occurs i. 141. There is good authority for both aorists, but the second is the more common: see Veitch's Irregular Greek Verbs.

toi=s de/—eth. dative, the construction of the sentence depending on logizo/menoi: ‘while on the side of the enemy each part of their whole force and of the troops on the field was naturally ready to dare to risk a battle’. This is Poppo's translation, and it gives a fairly satisfactory sense. The Peloponnesian army was composed of contingents from different states: each contingent was only a portion of the whole available military force (cumpa/shs th=s duna/mews) and of the army now under Brasidas (tw=n paro/ntwn). Therefore a defeat would not cripple the Peloponnesian confederacy as a whole, while the several contingents might be willing to risk a battle with the chance of their neighbours suffering more than themselves. On the other hand any loss sustained by the Athenians would fall on the flower of their national troops.

me/ros e(/kaston, according to this view, is the subject of e)qe)lein, and kinduneu/ein depends on tolma=n. The redundancy of infinitives is certainly awkward: cf. however iii. 56, e)qe/lontes de\ tolma=n meta\ kindu/nwn: v. 9, to\ e)qe/lein kai\ ai)dxu/nesqai kai\ toi=s a)/rxousi pei/qesqai: i. 71, boulome/nwn proqu/mwn ei)=nai.

It has been proposed to take me/ros as the object of kinduneu/ein and e(/kaston as masc., ‘each (commander) was naturally willing to hazard a portion’, etc. But this use of kinduneu/ein is doubtful, being only supported by such phrases as vi. 57, pa/nta e)kindu/neuon, and the improvement in sense is not great.

For kai\ tw=n paro/ntwn Donaldson adopts the conjecture o)li/gwn paro/ntwn gen. abs., which gives a good sense and construction, but does not seem necessary. Classen follows Göller in altering e(/kaston into e)ka/stwn in agreement with paro/ntwn, giving the sense ‘a portion of the several powers present on the field’, i.e. represented by their contingents. We have then to supply a subject to e)qe/lein from the general sense, sc. the enemy, or else toi=s de/ must be changed into tou\s de/.
xro/non de\...kai\ w(s—‘after they had waited some time, and since there was no sign of movement on either side’. For a)f' e(kate/rwn we should have expected ou)dete/rwn or ou)d' a)f' e(te/rwn.

ou(/tw dh/—‘upon this, then at last’; ‘introducing the apodosis after a long protasis’ (Lid. and Scott); so ch. 75, 13. The subject of the sentence is again defined in the words oi( tw=n feugo/ntwn fi/loi *megarh=s, see line 19.

In viii. 99 there is a very similar sentence, where oi( *peloponnh/sioi is the original subject, and after a series of clauses introduced by w)s, which take up more than half the chapter, we have ou(/tw dh\ o) *mi/ndaros...e)/plei.
tw=| me\n *brasi/da|—there is no corresponding clause with de/: some mention of receiving back the exiles was probably intended to follow.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXIV
div2.p: dialuqe/ntwn—Classen points out that in all the fourteen instances in which this word is used of the separation of a confederate force the aor. pass. is the tense employed. kata/ is distributive, ‘to their several cities’.
i(/na per—cf. ch. 48, 31.

o)/soi me\n...oi( de\ a)/lloi—two coordinate divisions of oi( e)n th=| po/lei *megarh=s: cf. i. 89, oi)ki)ai ai( me\n pollai\...o)li)gai de/. pragma/twn—‘dealings, intrigues’. an unusual sense of the substantive, though common with the verb: cf. ch. 73, 38, tw=n
pro\s tou\s' *aqhnai/ous praca/ntwn: also ch. 76, 6. For pro\s tou/s we might expect tw=n pro/s, but in such constructions the article is sometimes omitted before a preposition, and pro/s may also be regarded as belonging to the whole clause rather than to pragma/twn alone.

u(pech=lqon—cf. vi. 51, of a defeated party, oi( ta\ tw=n *surakosi/wn fronou=ntes eu)qu\s u\pech=lqon: in iii. 34 it takes the acc. u(pecelqo/ntes tou/tous: cf. constr. ch. 28, 14. We find 120 of these Megarians serving in the Athenian expedition to Sicily, vi. 43.
kata/gousi—the regular word for restoring an exile: Aesch. Sept. 647, kata/cw d' a)/ndra to/nde: cf. Ar. Ran. 1165, feu/gwn d' anh\r h(/kei te kai\ kate/rxetai.
o(rkw/santes—in viii. 75 we have cogn. acc. w(/rkwsan pa/ntas tou\s stratiw/tas tou\s megi/stous o)/rkous, h)= mh\n o)monoh/sein.

e)ce/tasin o(/plwn—an inspection or review: vi. 96, e)ce/tasin o(/plwn e)poiou=nto. This would give an opportunity of selecting and securing the disaffected, especially if, as Arnold supposes, the men had laid down their arms in order to listen to an address from their commanders. Hippias in a similar way seized his enemies, who appeared without their arms, oi)o/menoi/ ti e)rei=n au)to/n (vi. 58). diasth/santes tou\s lo/xous —the several divisions were apparently reviewed in different parts of the town.

yh=fon dienegkei=n—=diayhfi/sasqai, dia/ implying a vote on this or that side: Eur. Or. 49. dioi/sei yh=fon *)argei/wn po/lis: in Hdt. iv. 138, oi( diafe/rontes th\n yh=fon seems to mean those who differed in their vote. fanera/n—opp. kru/fa, ch. 88, 2.

kategnw/sqhsan—passive, though the active takes a genitive of the person. Lysias, de caede Erat. 94, has the act. with acc. tou=ton katagignw/skein fo/non. Lid. and Scott give Dion H. xi. 22, katagnwsqei\s deili/an, ‘found guilty of cowardice’: and Hdt. vi. 2, katagnwsqei\s prh/ssein, ‘thought to be doing’. So too Andocides, de Myst. 2, has para\ tw=n kathgoroume/nwn, ‘from the accused’. In fact verbs which govern the genitive or dative are not uncommonly personally constructed in the passive, Greek being more elastic than Latin in this point.

plei=ston dh/—so ch. 55, 15, ma/lista dh/: i. 1, ki/nhsis ga\r au(/th megi/sth dh\ e)ge/neto. au(/th...meta/stasis—‘this was a change which’, lit. ‘this, though a change’ or ‘as a change’, not ‘this change’, which would require the article: so in the passage cited above ki/nhsis is the predicate.

u(p' e)laxi/stwn—‘a few daring men effected the revolution, tacitly countenanced probably by the aristocratic party in general, who thought the worst oligarchy better than the ascendancy of the popular party. What Thucydides notices is the long duration of a government which owed its existence to a violent revolution effected by a very small number of active instruments’ (Arnold).

e)k sta/sews meta/stasis—a play on the sound of words: Classen compares ii. 62, mh\ fronh/mati mo)non a)lla( katafronhmati: iii. 39, e)pane/sthsan ma=llon h)\ a)pe/sthsan. meta/stasis is used of a political revolution in vi. 20 and viii. 86. For cune/meinen cf. viii. 73, h( a)rxh\ cune/meinen: also i. 18, of the lasting of an alliance.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXV
div2.p: w(/sper dienoou=nto—‘as (we saw) was their intention’: see ch. 52. For the impf. cf. ch. 2, 8, w)/sper pareskeua/zonto. kataskeua/zw and kataskeuh/ are used especially of permanent appliances, such as walls, dockyards and arsenals, in the case of a fortress: so in vi. 17 of the plant and stock of farmers and settlers: in vi. 31 of the fittings of a ship: see Arnold on i. 10.
a)rgurolo/gwn—either agreeing with *)aqhnai/wn or with new=n understood. nau=s is understood with i(ppagwgo/s in vi. 43; with penthko/ntoros ib.: so with triako/ntoros ch. 9, 9.
deino\n mh/—‘reason to dread that’: cf. iii. 102, deino\n ga(r h)=n mh\...ou)k a)nti/sxwsin.

ta\ *)/anaia—iii. 32, and viii. 19: *)anaiitw=n, iii. 19. The Athenians feared that Antandros would be a standing menace to Lesbos as Anaea was to Samos. For e)pi\ th=| *sa/mw| cf. ch. 14, 32, e)pi\ th=| *pu/lw|.
katasta/ntes—‘established themselves’: iii. 86, katasta/ntes e)s *(rh/gion. e)s ta\ nautika/—‘for their fleets’, or ‘in naval matters’, connected with both w)fe/loun and kubernh/tas pe/mpontes.
tou\s e)cio/ntas e)de/xonto—so i. 40, tou\s e\te/rwn a)fistame/nous de/xesqai, of receiving disaffected allies.

ou) polu\ u(/steron—with a(po/llusi, for Lamachus had already entered the Pontus, line 6. *(hraklew/tidi—the district of Heraclea on the coast of Bithynia; founded in the sixth century by colonists from Megara and Tanagra. o(rmh/sas. fr. o)rme/w, ‘having come to an anchor’, is the better supported
reading, and though o)rmei=n is constructed with e)n when it means lying at anchor (i. 52 etc.), the aorist might certainly take e)s with a pregnant idea of motion. The aor. form itself is however considered extremely doubtful by Classen, who (with Krüger) reads o(rmi/sas, sc. ta\s nau=s.

u(/datos a)/nwqen—according to Poppo=u(/dwr e)c ou)ranou=, ii. 77: Xen. Mem. Socr. iv. 3. 14, kerauno\s a)/nwqen a)fi/etai. Arnold however believes the words to mean ‘rain having fallen in the interior, in the upper country’, quoting Hdt. viii. 12, e)ge/neto d' u(/dwr a)/pleton dia\ pa/shs th=s nukto/s, to show that the addition of e)c ou)ranou= is not required to denote rain. May not the meaning be ‘floods having come down from the upper country’? ‘The river Calex, or Cales, is hardly more than a mountain torrent; or at least has its source in the mountains at so short a distance from the sea that its floods must be exceedingly sudden and violent; and, like the fiumare in Sicily, they would come down with such a body of water, sweeping trees and rocks along with them in their course, that vessels drawn up on the shore, just at the mouth of the river, might very easily have been swamped or dashed to pieces’ (Arnold).

pe/ran—from an European point of view. th\n *megare/wn a)poiki/an—‘that (well-known) colony’. Chalcedon, opposite Byzantium, was said to have been founded by the blind, ‘quod priores illuc advecti, praevisa locorum utilitate, peiora legissent’ (Tac. Ann. xii. 63): cf. Hdt. iv. 144.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXVI
div2.p: pra/gmata—‘public affairs, interests’; the whole phrase means that a plot was going on to betray Boeotia. pra/ssein is perpetually used of political intrigues; it is constructed with the dative, as in ch. 106, 12; ch. 110, 10: with pro/s, as in i. 128, pro\s basile/a pra/gmata pra/ssein: and even with e)s, as in i. 132, e)s tou\s *ei(/lwtas pra/ssein ti.

a)po/—‘on the part of’: i. 17, e(pra/xqh a)p' au)tw=n ou)de\n e)/rgon. As distinguished from u\po/, a)po/ denotes the ‘personal origin’ of anything, not the agent. It is found especially with passive verbs of doing and saying (see Shilleto on i. 17); and in later Greek becomes more and more common with the passive generally.

to\n ko/smon—cf. viii. 48, e)k tou= paro/ntos ko/smou th\n po/lin metasth/sas: viii. 67, e)k tou= au)tou= ko/smou. w(/sper oi( *)aqhnai=oi—sc. dhmokratou=ntai: or perhaps referring to mete/sthsan or e)/treyan.

e)shgoume/nou—‘being the prime mover’: with acc. iii. 20, e)shghsame/nou th\n pei=ran: cf. vi. 90, peri\ w(n e)moi\ e)shghte/on: so generally of bringing forward proposals and the like, as in vii. 73. au)toi=s—either=pro)s au(tou/s ‘with them’, sc. the Athenians, or ethical dat. referring to both sides, ‘these were their schemes’. I have adopted Classen's punctuation, as ta/de refers to what follows; otherwise we should have tau=ta as in line 22.
*si/fas me/n—the three points selected would command three several sides of Boeotia; Siphae was on the south coast, Chaeronea on the north-west frontier, and Delium on the eastern coast.

*minu/eion—Hom. Il. ii. 511, oi(\ d' *)asplhdo/n' e)/naion i)d' *)orxomeno\n *minu/eion: Theocr. xvi. 104. (*xa/rites) *minu/eion *)orxomeno\n file/oisai: cf. Pind. Ol. xiv. 4. It was the capital of the ancient clan of the Minyae; see Class. Dict. There was another Orchomenos in Arcadia. cuntelei=—‘belongs to, is dependent on’. ‘The Boeotian confederacy consisted of a number of free and sovereign states, each of which elected its Boeotarch, or member of the supreme executive government of Boeotia. The sovereign states had each a number of smaller states subject to their authority; as Chaeronea was dependent on Orchomenos; Leuctra and Siphae on Thespiae; Acraephia, Glisas, Therapne, and others, on Thebes. These smaller states were called cu/mmoroi, or cuntelei=s, to the larger ones; and were obliged to furnish troops and money, to make up the contingent of the state to which they belonged, to the general confederacy of Boeotia’ (Arnold).
e)nedi/dosan—‘were to give up’; the imperfect denoting what was intended by the conspirators: cf. ch. 7, 5, prodidome/nhn: for e)ndi/dwmi see ch. 66, 17 note.

e)/sxaton—for neut. cf. i. 10, *mukh=nai mikro\n h)=n: i. 63, (*)/olunqos) e)sti\ katafane/s: i. 138, e)do/kei (*la/myakos) poluoino/taton tw=n to/te ei)=nai. pro\s *fano/tidi—‘hard by the district of Phanoteus’, see ch. 89, 12: the city was twenty stades from Chaeronea. metei=xon—‘were in the plot’.

e)/dei—‘the Athenians were to’, sc. according to arrangement: ch. 89, 4: ii. 84, nh=es a(\s e)/dei tau/tais cummi/cai. *dh/lion— cf. Liv. xxxv. 51, templum est Apollinis Delium imminens mari: quinque milia passuum ab Tanagra abest. Minus quatuor milium inde in proxima Euboeae est mari traiectus. For katalabei=n see note on ch. 1, 4.
cumbohqh/swsin—of joint action. The simple verb is to be understood in the following clause with e(/kastoi: cf. ii. 81, ou)/te cuneboh/qoun, e)fu/lasso/n te ta\ au(tw=n e(/kastoi.

r(a|di/ws—this word affects the whole sentence generally, implying that the conspirators anticipated no difficulty in carrying out their plans; it belongs however more particularly to katasth/sein, line 33.

newteri/zoito—the reading adopted by almost all editors for newteri/zoi, which is found in most manuscripts. Arnold thinks that h( pei=ra might be the nominative to newteri/zoi ‘would effect a change’, or else that the verb might be neuter in sense. It is however invariably transitive in Thuc. For the pass. cf. ch. 41, 14.

e(ka/stois—the disaffected in different places, who would find a refuge at hand (dia\ braxe/os) when the three points were occupied by the Athenians. For a)postrofh=s cf. viii. 75, a)postrofh\ swthri/as. The Athenians intended to carry out the system of establishing fortified positions in the enemy's territory, which had already proved so successful in annoying the Lacedaemonians. kata\ xw/ran—cf. ch. 14, 32.
prosio/ntwn—‘joining’: cf. ch. 85, 22, e)moi\ pro/seisi. e)s to\ e)pithdeion—cf. ch. 54, 15, e)pithdeio/teron: ch. 60, 10, e)s to\ cumfe/ron kaqi)stantai.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXVII
div2.p: o(po/te kairo\s ei)/h—opt. because of the past tense e)/melle =o(/tan kairo\s h)=| with present: see note on ei)/ ti pa/sxoien, ch. 38, 11. e)s tou\s *boiwtou/s=into Boeotia; cf. ch. 78, 42: i. 108, e)stra/teusan e)s *boiwtou/s: Hdt. iv. 28, e)pelau/nousin e)s tou\s *sindou/s. In v. 49, fa/skontes sfa=s e)pi\ *fu/rkon o)/pla e)penegkei=n probably ought to be e)s sfa=s (R. S.).

proape/steile—‘had sent in advance’; see the beginning of ch. 76: tai=s tessara/konta nausi/n are the ships there mentioned. e)c e)kei/nwn tw=n xwri/wn—Acarnania and its neighbourhood, where Demosthenes was well known since his campaign in 426 (iii. 94 etc.).
ei)/rhto—the usual word for instructions and arrangements: i. 129, ta/ te a)/lla e)poi/hsen, w)/sper ei)/rhto. For e)/dei and tau=ta cf. ch. 76, 20 and 22.

o( me\n *dhmosqe(nhs—the corresponding particle to me/n is de/ at the beginning of the next chapter. *oi)nia/das de/—there is an awkwardness about this de/ (one manuscript has te); possibly it may be explained, like polemi/an de\ ou<*>san, ch. 7, 3, as denoting what was not looked for; for Oeniadae stood apart from the other Acarnanian towns in opposition to Athens, ii.
102; iii. 94. It was situated at the mouth of the Achelous and was surrounded by water in winter.

u(po/ te...kai\ au)to/s—the connecting particles show what was effected by the Acarnanians and Demosthenes respectively, te being out of place: cf. 28, 21, e)/k te *ai)/nou...kai/: ch. 70, 7, e)/s te tou\s...kai/. Such an irregularity of construction is especially common when the juxtaposition of de/ and te is thereby avoided; e.g. ch. 95, 2: i. 16, e)pege/neto de\ a)/llois te kwlu/mata kai\ *)/iwsi *ku=ros e)pestra/teuse.

kathnagkasme/nous e)s—‘forced into’; masc. because the city is designated by the name of the inhabitants: so ii. 102: cf. vi. 3, met' au)tou/s, of the town of Leontini: see Poppo on i. 111, e)s *oi)nia/das.

a)nasth/sas—‘having called to his standard’, of summoning troops for an expedition: so ch. 90, 1: cf. ii. 68, au)toi/ te kai\ tw=n barba/rwn pollou\s a)nasthsa/ntes, etc. In ch. 93, 3, it is used of setting an army in motion.

*salu)nqion kai\ *)agrai/ous—mentioned in iii. 106 and 111 as neighbours of the Acarnanians but friendly to the Peloponnesian interests. prospoihsa/menos—‘having reduced’ or ‘brought over’: i. 8, prosepoiou=nto u(phko/ous, etc. For the act. see ch. 47, 10. a)panthso/menos—with e)pi/, of appearing at a given place: cf. ch. 89, 6: so ch. 70, 8. An analogous use denotes appearing at a trial, presenting one's self in court, see Lid. and Scott. The middle form of the future is classical; a)panth/sw is later, Polyb. Plut. etc.
The historian now passes to another point, concluding with an imperfect construction, as in ch. 48.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXVIII
div2.p: From this point the fortunes of the war begin to turn against the Athenians, who seem to have been entirely unprepared for Brasidas' bold enterprise against their Thracian allies.

*brasi/das de/—in sense this sentence is descriptive enough. Brasidas begins his march—reaches Heraclea—is joined by friends whom he had previously sent to—continues his march. The wording however is awkward and involved. There are two subordinate clauses, e)peidh\ e)ge/neto, and kai\ (e)peidh\)...h)=lqon k.t.l., the latter clause being complicated by a parenthetical explanation with gen. abs., prope/myantos...stratia/n: the whole concludes with the main verb to/te dh\ e)poreu/eto.
poreuo/menos—‘beginning his expedition’; he was last seen at Corinth, ch. 74, 3: the construction with e)peidh\ e)ge/neto somewhat resembles w(s e)ge/nonto ple/ontes, k.t.l. ch. 3, 1.

e)n *)hraklei/a|—in 426 the Lacedaemonians established a colony and place of arms at Heraclea near Trachis, and began the construction of docks at Thermopylae, 40 stades distant (iii. 93, 94). Cf. Liv. xxxvi. 22, sita est Heraclea in radicibus Oetae montis: ipsa in campo arcem imminentem loco alto et undique praecipiti habet. The town or district of Trachis gives the name to the Trachiniae of Sophocles, and the whole neighbourhood was associated with the memory of Heracles.

prope/myantos—parenthetical; Brasidas had already sent his messenger in advance. We find in ii. 22 that Pharsalus (ā) and Larissa like the other Thessalian towns were in alliance with Athens; oi( e)pith/deioi were therefore an oligarchical faction.
*)axai/as—Achaea Pthiotis, north of the Malian gulf. For the limits of the district see Arnold's note.

a)/llws te—i.e. under any circumstances, much less with an armed force in the face of an unfriendly people. kai\ meta\ o(/plwn ge dh/—either (1) to be taken with the following u)/popton kaq...diie/nai, kai\ strengthening pa=si: or (2) to be regarded as completing the sentence, sc. ou)k eu)/poron h)=n diie/nai. The majority of editors are in favour of the latter view, and put a stop after dh/. The sense of (1) seems however the better; and the passing from the particular *qessali/an to the general toi=s pa=si is thoroughly Thucydidean. No doubt there is an awkwardness in the repetition ge dh/...pa=si/ ge; but this is not more objectionable than the harsh and abrupt ending involved by (2).
kaqesth/kei—cf. ch. 26, 29. a)ei/ po/te—ch. 57, 26.

dunastei/a|—a narrow oligarchy or poluke/falos turanni/s: iii. 62, e)gguta/tw de\ tura/nnou dunastei/a a)ndrw=n o)li/gwn: so Aristotle Pol. iv. 5, 2 speaks of a dunastei/a as the counterpart of a tyranny, o(/tan a)rxh=| mh\ o( no/mos a)ll' oi( a)/rxontes. It is opposed to a politei/a or constitutional government: cf. Tac. Ann. vi. 42, paucorum dominatio regiae libidini propior, ‘borders on arbitrary monarchy’. The government in Thessaly was held by ‘a class of rich proprietors distributed through the principal cities possessing most of the soil, and constituting separate oligarchies loosely hanging together’: the rest of the inhabitants were in a condition somewhat resembling that of the Laconians and Helots; see Grote, vol. ii. ch. 3, on the state of Thessaly. Some at any rate of the dominant families were naturally not ill disposed to the oligarchy of Sparta.

i)sonomi/a|—cf. iii. 82, where i)sonomi/a politikh/ is an euphemism for dhmokrati/a: in iii. 62 we have o)ligarxi/a i)so/nomos, i.e. constitutional. to\ e)gxw/rion—adverbial: so ch. 3, 22, to\ a)rxai=on.
boulome/nwn—so ii. 79, tw=n ou) tau=ta boulome/nwn, of political feeling. e)pi\ tw=| *)enipei=—at his entrance into Thessaly proper; see Arnold's note on the line of march probably taken by Brasidas.

a)/neu—without the consent or authority of: i. 128, a)/neu *lakedaimoni/wn etc.: Soph. O.T. 1464, a)/neu tou=d' a)ndro/s. to\ pa/ntwn koino/n is the general confederacy of Thessaly. It had little cohesion, and though strong if united, seldom was.
au)toi=s—the people themselves. ou)...a)ci/oun=‘he called on them not to stop him’: cf. the instances given on ch. 40, 5.

to\ kwlu=son—when the future participle is used to denote purpose or intention the article is usually prefixed. iii. 83, ou) ga\r h)=n o( dialu/swn ou)/te lo/gos ou)/te o(/rkos=o)/stis dia lu/sei: cf. Plat. Menex. 235 D, a)gaqou= a)/n r(h/toros de/oi tou= pei/. sontos: Soph. Ant. 260, ou(d' o( kwlu/swn parh=n.

a)fw/rmhsen—only here in Thucydides in the active, though the uncompounded verb is common: mid. vii. 74 etc. Soph and Eur. have the active in intr. sense. e)te/lese—‘accomplished (his march)’: ii. 97, e)c *)abdh/rwn e)s *)/istron telei=. Lid and Scott compare the use of a)nu/w, which like telw= is a trans. verb: e.g. Soph. Trach. 657, pro\s po/lin a)nu/seie.

Brasidas seems to have marched northwards down the valley of the Enipeus as far as Pharsalus, and a little beyond, to its junction with the valley of the Apidanus. His troops probably did not enter Pharsalus. He then marched down the valley of the Apidanus, in a north-westerly direction as far as Phacium, which was at its lower extremity, where it joins the valley of the Peneus (Arnold).

e)s *peraibi/an—between the Peneus and the Cambunian mountains. Brasidas seems to have marched across this district leaving Tempe on his right and bearing towards Dium. a)po) tou/tou—‘from this point’.

kate/sthsan e)s—‘brought him to’, or ‘set him down at’: so ch. 103, 19. *di=on—on the Thermaic gulf: there was another place so called in Chalcidice, ch. 109. *makedoni/as— ‘in, or belonging to Macedonia’. pro\s *qessalou/s—‘looking towards Thessaly’, i.e. on the frontier.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXIX
div2.p: w(s *perdi/kkan—Perdiccas is first mentioned in 432 as trying to get up a league against Athens, cu/mmaxos pro/teron kai\ fi/los w)/n (i. 57). He was alternately the nominal friend and the enemy of Athens. Some account of the rise and extent of the Macedonian kingdom is given in ii. 99.
oi(...a)festw=tes *)aqhnai/wn—Chalcidians and Bottiaeans who joined in the revolt of Potidaea in 432 (i. 58).

e)ch/gagon—‘promoted the expedition’: Arnold points out that e)ca/gw ‘is applied with great propriety in the present case, for the getting the Peloponnesians to move out of Peloponnesus was the great difficulty’. For the force of the active see note on cunepago/ntwn, ch. 1, 14: so infr. cuneph=gon.
plhsio/xwroi—apparently governs au)tw=n, for the position of which word see note on ch. 5, 10: Ar. Vesp. 393, to\n sautou= plhsio/xwron.
dia/fora—with gen.: so iii. 54, ta\ *qhbai/wn dia/fora.

*lugkhstw=n—cf. ii. 99, where we find that the kingdom of the Lyncestae was subordinate to Macedonia. Arrhibaeus seems to have defied his suzerain Perdiccas. parasth/sasqai— ‘to reduce, bring to terms’: so parasth=nai means to yield or surrender: Dem. Androt. 597, tw=| pole/mw| pare/sthsan.
cune/bh—‘opportune cecidit’: in construction this sentence resembles ch. 47, 4, cunela/bonto de\...w(/ste k.t.l.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXX
div2.p: e)gkeime/nwn—by the occupation of Pylos and Cythera; see ch. 55. For a)postre/yai some manuscripts have a)potre/yai, the two words being easily confused: see ch. 97, 9. There is also some slight authority for a)potre/yein: the aor. construction however is quite regular.

ei) a)ntiparalupoi=en—this compound, which only occurs here, implies ‘parallel (i.e. simultaneous) counter-annoyance’: for paralupw= cf. ii. 51, a)/llo parelu/pei ou)de/n, i.e. nothing besides the plague. Classen gives a list of upwards of 40 compounds with a)nti/ which Thuc. only uses once; and concludes that this prefix was connected at pleasure with any following verb: cf. Plat. Gorg. 521 E, a)nt' eu)= poiei=n...a)nt' eu)= pei/setai.
e(toi/mwn o)/ntwn—sc. twn cumma/xwn: cf. note on gen. abs. ch. 73, 15. tre/fein te—the usual irregularity or ‘trajection’ of te.

tw=n *ei(lw/twn—partitive gen. with e)kpe/myai: i. 30, th=s gh=s e)/temon: Xen. Hel. ii. 3, 14, tw=n frou/rwn cumpe/mpontos. boulome/nois h)=n—cf. iii. 2, tw=| plh/qei ou) boulome/nw| h)=n: so ch. 28, 27, a)sme/nois e)gi/gneto: see Madvig 38 d. So in Latin we have volenti, volentibus esse, Liv. Tac. etc.

e)pi\ profa/sei—‘on a (good) pretext’: like paraskeuh=|, ch. 27, 30. pro\s ta\ paro/nta—lit. ‘looking to’, i.e. in the present circumstances and in consequence of them; like pro\s tau=ta, ‘therefore’, one of the many phases of meaning with pro/s expressing relation between two things.

e)pei/—often thus used in elliptical expressions, where the context supplies the meaning; here the sense is ‘it is plain that they always dreaded the Helots, for’, etc.; cf. a similar use in ch. 78, 19, e)pei\ kai\ to/te.

to/de e)/pracan—probably ‘they once did, or had done’ at some time not stated, so Thirlwall. ‘That this atrocity should have been committed at the very time when the Spartans were sending out a body of Helots on a foreign expedition is improbable in itself, and is contradicted by the words kai\ to/te k.t.l. (line 22), which clearly imply that Thucydides is led by association to speak of what had occurred on some former occasion. Shortly after the expedition of Brasidas the Spartans changed their policy towards the Helots, and emancipated those of them who had served with him, v. 34. They had previously given promises of emancipation which were believed, and therefore probably fulfilled, to Helots conveying food into Sphacteria, ch. 26’ (Jowett). Grote however (vol. iv. ch. 53) considers that the massacre took place immediately after the capture of Sphacteria, which was in July or August of the previous year, and that there was an interval of several months before the government formed the idea of employing the Helots on foreign service, an interval ‘quite sufficient to give a full and distinct meaning to the expression kai\ to/te’.

neo/thta—either abstract, ‘their youth (and vigour)’, as in vi. 17, h( e)mh\ neo/ths: ib. 18, contrasted with gh=ras: or with a concrete meaning (iuventus=iuvenes), as in ii. 8, pollh\ neo/ths: so ii. 21. In the latter case plh=qos means the general number, or the two words give a ‘hendiadys’=to\ plh=qos tw=n ne/wn.

Instead of neo/thta some manuscripts have skaio/thta, which is adopted among other editors by Classen. He understands it to mean the rash stupidity and wrong-headedness (stoliditas, importunitas), which would make bondsmen rise in
insurrection, even with little prospect of success: cf. Soph. Ant. 1028, au)qadi/a toi skaio/tht' o)fliska/nei: Hdt. vii. 9, u(po\ a\gnwmosu/nhs kai\ skaio/thtos.

a)ei\ ga/r—the predicate of this sentence is th=s fulakh=s pe/ri, the sense being that ‘most of the relations between the Lacedaemonians and the Helots always were of an eminently precautionary character’: not that ‘most of the Lacedaemonian institutions were intended mainly to guard against the Helots’. This latter statement, besides not being true, would require a different wording: cf. Shilleto on i. 17, pro\s perioi/kous toi=s au(tw=n e(ka/stois, ‘between each state and its neighbours’: so i. 127, diabolh\n au)tw=| pro\s th\n po/lin, ‘prejudice between him and the city’: cf. ch. 54, 14. Dem. Lept. § 68 fin. is a parallel.
Arnold compares the situation of the Spartans to that of an army of occupation in a conquered country, perpetually on its guard to prevent the inhabitants from breaking out into insurrection.

e)n toi=s polemi/ois—probably masc., the preposition denoting the sphere of operation of the adjective=‘on the persons of, in dealing with’ etc.; Verg. Aen. ii. 540, talis in hoste fuit: Soph. Aj. 1092, e)n toi=s qanou=sin u(bristh/s: ib. 1315, e)n e)moi\ qrasu/s: Ar. Eth. iv. 3, 26, e)n e)kei/nois semnu/nesqai, ‘to give one's self airs at their expense’. Classen takes e)n toi=s polemi/ois to be neuter. ‘in matters of war’; citing ch. 126, 9: so i. 18, and vi. 80. These however are all instances of the acc. of reference; we should therefore expect the same construction here, or else e)n tw=| pole/mw|.
kri/nesqai—‘should be selected’, a common meaning of kri/nw in Homer: so Hdt. vi. 129, kri/noi e)k pa/ntwn.

u(po\ fronh/matos—‘from their high spirit’; u)po/ expresses the cause, as in i. 49, u(po\ plh/qous kai\ o)/xlou tw=n new=n: so possibly in v. 31, periorw/menoi u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn, ‘looking about them (i.e. refusing to commit themselves) from Lacedaemonian influence’ (R. S.); unless indeed ta\ a)po\ should be read. For fro/nhma cf. ii. 43, a)ndri/ ge fro/nhma e)/xonti; v. 40, e)n fronh/mati o)/ntes, ‘proudly aspiring’.

kai\ h)ci/wsan...kai\ e)piqe/sqai—a good instance of kai/ with both clauses. prw=tos e(/kastos—resolved sing. in apposition with plur.: Plato Gorg. 503 E, ble/pontes pro\s to\ au)tw=n e)/rgon e(/kastos: so quisque.

kai\ prokri/nantes...oi( me
...oi( de/—there is no difficulty in understanding this sentence; and an exact parallel to it occurs in iii. 34, o( de\ (Paches) prokalesa/menos e)s lo/gous *(ippi/an...o( me
 (Hippias) e)ch=lqe par/ au)to/n, o( de\ (Paches) e)kei=non e)n
fulakh=| ei=xen. Poppo compares Dem. in Callip. 1244, ou\(tws e)rrwme/nos e)sti
 w)/ste pe/rusi/ moi laxw
 th
 di/khn...e)gw\ me
...ou)=tos de\ k.t.l.: so Xen. Cyr. iv. 6. 3, etc. In all these sentences the ‘anacoluthon’ arises from stating in a primary clause with me/n a fact which is really accessory to the main subject of the sentence. Thus in the passage before us the sense is ‘they chose out some 2000 Helots, and while they decked themselves with garlands on the strength of being set free, the Lacedaemonians etc.’ This is an extension of the ordinary idiom of expressing the contrast between two things by coordinate clauses with me)n and de/, the clause with me/n being in sense subordinate to that with de/ (e)gw\ me
...su\ de/, ‘although I ...yet you’, etc.); see Madv. § 189.
e)s disxili/ois—cf. ch. 48, 2.

ou)dei\s h)/|sqeto—Diodorus (1st cent. B.C.) says that the chief Spartans were commissioned to put them to death at their own homes, a mere guess. ‘The government had now made the selection which it desired; presently every one among these newly enfranchised Helots was made away with— no one knew how. A stratagem at once so perfidious in the contrivance, so murderous in the purpose, and so complete in the execution, stands without parallel in Greek history—we might almost say without a parallel in any history. The Ephors must have employed numerous instruments, apart from each other, for the performance of this bloody deed. Yet it appears that no certain knowledge could be obtained of the details—a striking proof of the mysterious efficiency of this Council of Five, surpassing even that of the Council of Ten at Venice—as well as of the utter absence of public inquiry or discussion’ (Grote iv. ch. 53).
kai\ to/te—‘so now’, resuming the account from line 9. tou\s d' a)/llous—1000 in number, ch. 78, 2. misqw=| pei/qein is the regular term for engaging mercenaries, as in i. 31: ii. 96.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXI
div2.p: prou)qumh/qhsan de/—sc. that Brasidas should be sent; a clause parenthetically inserted and not affecting the construction: proqume/omai takes an acc. of the object, as v. 17, prou)qumh/qh th\n cu/mbasin (so freq. neut. ti, tou=to, etc.); but this constr. does not extend to persons. Arnold compares vii. 86, tou\s a)/ndras prou)qumh/qh...w)/ste a)feqh=nai, ‘he was anxious with regard to the men...that they should be set free’.
dokou=nta—‘held, accounted’, imperf. part. drasth/rion—‘a man of energy and enterprise’: ii. 63, to\ drasth/rion.
to/ te ga/r—corresponding to this te we have e)/s te, line 11, these particles connecting the two main divisions of the sentence.

cnmbai/nein te boulome/nois—‘this answers to kai\ tou= pole/mou k.t.l. When they wanted to come to terms they had places to offer in exchange, and as long as they continued the war it did not press so heavily upon Peloponnesus’ (Jowett).

o(/per e)poi/hsan—sc. cune/bhsan ‘made peace’, in 421 (v. 17). Krüger suggests e)po/qhsan, but o)/per, ‘which in fact’, agrees better with the reading of the text. a)ntapo/dosin kai\ a)podoxh/n=exchange.
