ta\ e)k *sikeli/as—so iii. 102. meta\ ta\ e)k th=s *ai)twli/as: viii. 2, th\n e)k *sikeli/as kakopragi/an: all these passages refer to a disastrous withdrawal. a)reth/—probably generosity and humanity, as in ch. 19, 15, rather than valour.

prw=tos—to be taken with e)celqw/n, as both rhythm and sense clearly show. Brasidas was ‘the first of a series of Lacedaemonian generals who, in accordance with a new policy, were regularly sent to the dependencies of Athens either that they might raise revolt or that they might govern a town already revolted (ch. 132, 21). prw=tos contrasts Brasidas not with Pausanias, Salaethus, etc. but with Astyochus, and the Harmosts, who were afterwards so notorious’ (Jowett). Classen takes prw=tos with e)gkate/lipe, ‘he was the first who left behind him an assured hope’. But what were the grounds of the ‘assured hope’ if other generals had come before Brasidas and not proved equally good?
do/cas—‘having won the name, proved himself’. e)gkate)lipe—in the minds of the allies, or in the districts which he visited.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXII
div2.p: to/te d' ou)/n—d' ou)=n like ceterum, is perpetually used to resume the narrative after a digression, frequently after a very short one: i. 3, oi( d' ou)=n w(s e)/kastoi *)/ellhnes.
poiou=ntai—i. 28, fi/lous poiei=sfai: so cumma/xous etc.

paro/dou—the same word is used ch. 108, 5: so in iii. 92 the situation of Heraclea was considered th=s e)pi\ *qra/|khs paro/dou xrhsi/mws e(/cein. Part of the route at any rate was a ‘passage along’ the coast.
fulakh(n ple/ona—‘a closer watch’; they do not appear to have despatched any fresh troops as yet; see ch. 108, 37.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXIII
div2.p: th=| e)sbolh=| th=s *lu/gkou—for gen. cf. ch. 1, 7. For the description of the ‘pass into Lyncus’ see Arnold. The pass crossed a chain of mountains, and descended by a gorge and stream: cf. ch. 127, 17.
lo/gois—with poih=sai, line 11. kai\ ga/r ti kai/—we have a somewhat similar order infr. line 16: so ch. 5, 4: 54, 13. For the force of e)pekhrukeu/eto see note on ch. 27, 14.

me/sw| dikasth=| e)pitre/pein—‘to entrust the matter to the mediation of Brasidas’. me/sos dikasth/s is an arbitrator, me/sos implying interposition as well as impartiality; see Arnold. e\pitre/pw is regularly used without an object expressed of referring a question to arbitration: i. 28, h)/qelon tw=| e)n *delfoi=s mantei/w| e)pitre/pein: so Dem. passim.

mh\ u(pecelei=n—‘not to remove from (lit. for) Perdiccas his grounds of apprehension’; i.e. not to make his position too secure. u(pecairw= means to remove secretly or gradually, or to remove to begin with (ch. 4, 15, note); hence to clear from one's path: Plat. Rep. 519 B, u(pecairei=n tou/tous dei= to\n tu/rannon ei) me/llei a)/rcein.

koinh=| ma=llon—(1) ‘in a more impartial spirit’ (Poppo, Classen, etc.). The adjective is not unusual with this meaning, e.g. iii. 53, mh\ ou) koinoi\ a)pobh=te, ‘lest you should not prove impartial judges’. No instance is however given of this sense of the adverb. Arnold and Krüger therefore take it to mean (2) that Brasidas claimed ‘a joint voice’ in dealing with Arrhibaeus; whereas Perdiccas insisted that he was merely engaged to act as his auxiliary.

h)ci/ou—‘felt himself entitled’. ‘Perdiccas had promised to make his neighbours allies of the Lacedaemonians. This gave Brasidas a right to interfere. For, he would argue, you are not making an ally but an enemy of Arrhibaeus’ (Jowett).
ou)/te—with te line 23. kaqaire/thn—‘to overthrow’; a common sense of kaqairw=. The subst. is not found elsewhere in Attic Greek: it is used by Dio Cassius.

e)k diafora=s—probably ‘after a quarrel’, as in ch. 125, 6: v. 42, e)k diafora=s peri\ au)tou=. Arnold however considers this to be one of the many adverbial expressions with e)k, equivalent to ‘in decided opposition to Perdiccas’.

a)dikei=sqai—note the use of the present, lit. ‘to be the victim of a wrong’: the pres. of a)dikw= ‘to be a wrong doer’ is used in the same way as nikw=, ‘to be victorious’, feu/gw, ‘to be in exile’, etc.
The short account here given shows the broad and generous spirit of Brasidas, as well as the arrogance and fickleness of Perdiccas, who was always ready to quarrel with his allies.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXIV
div2.p: *)/akanqon—Acanthus was situated on the Strymonian gulf, a short distance to the north of the point where the canal of Xerxes cut the peninsula of Athos. th\n *)andri/wn a)poiki/an —founded in the middle of the seventh century. The def. article probably means ‘the (well-known) colony’, as in ch. 67, 4, or it may be used to distinguish the town from others of the same name. Same, Stageirus, and Argilus were Andrian colonies in the same district. Andros itself had been colonized from Eretria.

trugh/tou—‘vintage’; it was now late in the summer. tou= karpou=, line 7, therefore means the grapes, though by itself it more naturally denotes corn: cf. iii. 15, e)n karpou= cugkomidh=|. Note in these passages the collective use of karpo/s, like ke/ramos ch. 48, 13.
tou= karpou= to\ de/os—a very uncommon construction for peri/ tou=, see ch. 88, 5: de/os, like fo/bos, usually takes gen. of the thing feared.

a)kou/santas bouleu/sasqai—‘to hear him before deciding’: for plur. cf. 7, 34, o( pezo\s...bebohqhko/tes, etc.: we should expect a)kou/santes, but the acc. may be explained as referring to both parties and not only to the plh=qos: cf. ch. 69, 24.
katasta\s e)pi\ to\ plh=qos—‘presenting himself before the popular assembly’: cf. ch. 97, 10.

ou(de\ a)du/natos—‘not a bad speaker either’, besides his other merits; ou(de/ ‘also not’ as in ch. 48, 11. w(s *lakedaimo/nios—‘for a Lacedaemonian’; i.e. taking that into account. This is (a) a limiting use of w(s, showing that the main statement is modified by reference to the condition which w(s introduces: Soph. O. C. 20, makro\n ga\r w(s ge/ronti prou)sta/lhs o(do/n, ‘you have come a long way (not absolutely, but) for an old man’: so vi. 20, w(s e)n mia=| nh/sw|. Hdt. uses w(s ei(=nai and w(s
a)/n ei)=nai in the same way, see Lidd. and Scott. So in Lat., Cic. de Sen. 4. 12, multae, ut in homine Romano, literae: Liv. xxxii. 33, vir, ut inter Aetolos, facundus.

This usage must not be confused with its converse (b) w(s in the sense of ‘as being’, which introduces a general statement in accordance with a particular fact stated; Eur. Ion, 1190, o( de\, w(s e)n i(erw=| trafei/s: so Cic. Tusc. i. 8. 15, Epicharmi, acuti nec insulsi hominis, ut Siculi; intelligence and wit being characteristic of the Sicilian Greeks.

Both (a) and (b) come under a general head, the comparison of a particular statement with a general one introduced by w(s or ut. In most instances the context shows to which division a passage should be assigned, but there is at times a doubt: thus Soph. O. T. 1078, fronei= ga\r w(s gunh\ me/ga, probably belongs to (b), ‘she is proud, like a woman’; but possibly to (a), ‘her thoughts are lofty for a woman’: ib. 1118, pisto\s w(s nomeu/s, probably comes under (a), ‘loyal, for a herdsman’, i.e. in such things as a herdsman is capable of: see also ch. 14, 5.

Rhetorical speaking was not cultivated at Sparta, but rather a terse and pregnant form of expression; see note on ch. 17, 6: cf. i. 84, and Plat. Protag. 342 E. The speech here attributed to Brasidas is both forcible and politic: as Grote observes, it is especially interesting as a manifesto of the principles professed by Sparta.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXV
div2.p: h( me\n e)/kpemyis—cf. i. 73, h( me\n pre/sbeusis...e)ge/neto. me/n finds its apodosis in line 6, or possibly in line 12, ei) de\ xro/nw| k.t.l. in the latter case being parenthetical.

th
 ai)ti/an—cf. Shilleto on i. 23, ai( e)s to\ fanero
 lego/menai ai	i/ai, which he renders ‘the openly alleged recriminatory charges’, ai	i/a being not merely a cause, but a ground of complaint put forward as a cause: cf. ch. 86, 21, e)gklh/masi. e\palhqeu/ousa—so viii. 52, to
 lo/gon e)phlh/qeusen.
proei/pomen—ii. 8 (of the Lacedaemonians), proeipo/ntwn o(/ti th\n *(/ellada e)leuqerou=sin.
e)ph/lqomen—‘came to’, not necessarily in a hostile sense: cf. e)pi/w, line 22.
a)po/—‘arising from, grounded on’. h(=|—‘in accordance with which, by which’.
mhdei\s memfqg=|—for the mood and tense used in prohibitions, see Goodwin, § 86.
o(/te pare/sxen—impers. ‘when a chance offered’: i. 120, eu)= parasxo/n, neut. partcp. used abs.: so v. 14, kalw=s parasxo/n: vi. 86, parasxh/sein a)mu/nasqai.

th=| a)poklh/|sei—‘I wonder at’, dat. with qauma/zw expressing the ground or cause, a very rare construction: in vii. 63, there is a dat. with the passive e)qauma/zesqe, ‘you were admired by reason of’, but it is not an analogous instance, though so cited by editors. We have a better illustration in iii. 97, th=| tu/xh| e)lpi/sas. The gen. mou corresponds to the acc. with the verb=‘the exclusion of me from your gates’: cf. vi. 101, au)tou\s a)poklh/|sasqai th=s diaba/sews.

oi)o/menoi/ te—the sentence presents two irregularities of construction with te. The first te and kai/ couple para\ cumma/xous h)/cein and boulome/nois e)/sesqai, ‘we thought that you were our allies in feeling, and would welcome us when we came’. The second te connects ki/ndunon a)nerri/yamen with pa=n to\ pro/qumon, the sense being ‘we ran the risk of marching into Thrace, and are now showing all zeal on your behalf’. dia\ th=s a)llotri/as i)o/ntes is explanatory of ki/ndunon: after this the participial construction is continued and parexo/menoi written instead of parexo/meqa. This explanation gives the most forcible sense, but it is of course a possible view that te and kai/ simply connect the two participles. te is bracketed by Poppo and Krüger and omitted by Classen.
th=| gou=n gnw/mh|—‘at least in feeling’ with cumma/xous. boulome/nois e)/sesqai—sc. our coming: for dat. cf. ch. 28, 27.

a)nerri/yamen—ch. 95, 6: in v. 103 without an acc. toi=s e)s a(/pan to\ u(pa/rxon a)narriptou=si, ‘those who stake their all on the cast’: this is a metaphor from dice. In iii. 38, au)th\ tou\s kindu/nous a)nafe/rei, is ‘takes on herself the risks’: and this may be the meaning of Aesch. Sept. 1028, ka)na\ ki/ndunon balw=. For pres. form r(ipte/w see Lid. and Scott.
parexo/menoi—‘showing’, on our part: see note on ch. 64, 2: cf. infr. line 24.
e)n nw=| e)/xete—‘purpose, intend’: ch. 8, 24. deino\n a)\n ei)/h—less direct than the ind.; the speaker hopes for better things.

ou) mo/non o(/ti—so Plat. Symp. 179 B, ou) mo/non o(/ti a)/ndres a)lla\ kai\ gunai=kes: in ii. 97 we have ou)x o)/ti...a)ll' ou)de/. ou)x o(/pws...a)lla/ is far more common. e)pi/w does not here imply hostile approach, and we might expect the accusative rather than the dative: cf. v. 110, o)/sous mh\ *brasi/das e)ph=lqen, ‘if Brasidas failed to visit any’.

dusxere\s poiou/menoi—‘taking it ill’, i.e. refusing to listen to us: cf. dusxerai/nw: neither the adj. nor the verb is used elsewhere by Thucydides. In the next clause with ei), Brasidas quotes the objection which would be urged, ‘that you refused to receive me’: cf. ch. 122, 21.
parexome/nous—see ch. 64, 2.

th\n ai)ti/an—probably used with the same force as in line 3, the sense being ‘I shall not be able to satisfy men that I am come, as I profess, to deliver them from Athens’. Others take it ‘I shall not be able to give a credible reason for your rejection of me’. pisth/n is of course pred. ‘so as to gain belief’. a)ll' h)/—either (1) ‘but (I shall be thought) either etc.’, where we must supply the sense from the context, or perhaps take ai)ti/an e)/cw again in a different connexion and meaning=‘I shall incur the imputation’: or (2) after neg. a)ll' h)/ taken together=‘except’, explaining ai)ti/an, i.e. this will seem the only possible reason. This latter view necessitates taking ai)ti/an in the second and less forcible of the two senses given above, and also does away with the parallelism h)\ e)pife/rein, h)\...a)fi=xqai. I therefore incline to (1).

a)/dikon—‘no true freedom’; this point is discussed in the following chapter. e)pife/rein—lit. to bring to or upon, more than to proffer: so ch. 87, 10: iii. 56, in a bad sense, doulei/an e)pe/feren o( ba/rbaros.
ta\ pro\s *)aqhnai/ous—acc. of ref. as in ch. 108, 7.
kai/toi—Brasidas first rebuts the imputation of weakness. The Athenians had already refused to encounter him at Nisaea, and they could only send an inferior force now.

stratia=| ge th=|d'—Poppo observes on the absence of the article with th=|de that it gives the pronoun an adverbial force, =‘I have here an army which the Athenians refused to face’: so ii. 74, e)pi\ gh=n th/nde h)/lqomen, e)n h(=|, ‘we now invade a land in which’, etc. This statement, as well as the words ple/ones o)/ntes, is untrue. Besides his own troops Brasidas had a large force of allies before Nisaea, and was superior in numbers to the Athenians; see note on ch. 73, 24.

w(/ste ou)k ei)ko/s—instead of saying that the Athenians would certainly not attack Brasidas with an inferior force such as they could send by sea, the speaker says that such a force would not be equal to the army at Nisaea, leaving the hearers to draw the conclusion.

nhi+/th|—adj. ii. 24, h)\n nhi+/th| stratw=| e)piple/wsi. Here one manuscript has stratw=| before au)tou/s, which would give an identical construction, dat. of the force employed. If we do not adopt the transposition, stratw=| or the like must be understood from what follows. Arnold proposes to omit the words tw=| e)n *nisai/a|. So Rutherford, who reads nhi/thn...strato\n i)sopalh=.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXVI
div2.p: katalabw/n—i. 9, o(/rkois kateilhmme/nous: cf. ch. 19, 13. ‘Not because Brasidas himself distrusted the Lacedaemonian magistrates as Grote supposes (vol. iv. ch. 52 fin.), but as a security to which he could appeal when addressing the allies’ (Jowett). For ta\ te/lh see ch. 15, 3.

prosaga/gwmai—‘bring over, win to my side’: ii. 30, proshga/gonto a)/neu ma/xhs: vi. 94, prosagago/menoi o(mologi/a|; sometimes implying force ‘reduce’, i. 99, prosa/gesqai tou\s a)fistame/nous: so iii. 91. In these words Brasidas seems to hint at the Athenian practice of treating their so-called allies as subjects.
cummaxh/sontes—instead of cummaxh/swn, the plural being used after the intervening i(/n' e)/xwmen.

ou)/t' au)to/s—‘Brasidas opposes one aspect of himself, i.e. his personal honesty, to another aspect not equally personal, his ability to help the Acanthians. My personal character ought not to be suspected by you, nor my power to assist you undervalued’ (Jowett). Note the force of the aor. in qarsh/santas, ‘you must take courage’.

kai\ ei)/ tis—a third point, Brasidas is not a partizan. For ara cf. ch. 8, 24. mh/ tisi prosqw=—‘to this or that faction’; the people might not unnaturally fear that Brasidas would establish an oligarchy in the interests of Sparta. prosti/qhmi, ‘to make over’: iii. 92, *)aqhnai/ois prosqei=nai sfa=s au)tou/s, ‘to join, surrender’.

a)safh=...ei)—‘doubtful, (as it would be) if’ etc.; the freedom would be a)safh/s on the supposition which ei) introduces. ‘I am not minded to offer you a dim and doubtful liberty by making the many the slaves of the few, or the few of the many’ (Arnold).

Analogous instances are not uncommon, e.g. iii. 11, martu- ri/w| e)xrw=nto mh\ a)
 tou/s ge i)soyhfous a)/kontas, ei/ mh/ ti h)di/koun oi(=s e)ph/|esan custrateu/ein: Dem. Con. 1266, ou)de/pot' a)
 ta\ yeudh= marturei=n h)qe/lhsan, ei) mh\ tau=q' e(wrwn. There is there
fore no need to adopt the conjecture ou)d' a)
 safh=, or Classen's ou)d' a)spasth/n, ‘welcome’.
nomi/zw—according to Arnold=nomi/zw xrh=nai, but there is no need for this view here; ‘nor do I think the freedom I proffer you a vague one’ gives an excellent sense.

to\ pa/trion parei/s—‘disregarding (your) hereditary usage’ or ‘institutions’; not ‘our usage’, a statement which would be not only untrue, but incredible. pari/hmi is not uncommon in the sense of passing over or omitting: if Soph. O. T. 688, tou)mo\n pariei/s, is rightly rendered ‘setting aside all consideration for me’, it gives an exact parallel: cf. Dem. Meid. 548, mhdamh=| pareqh=nai, ‘to be let go, left in peace’.
to\ ple/on—lit. ‘the more numerous element’, collective neuter. The ‘many’ and the ‘few’ have of course a political meaning.
xalepwte/ra—sc. such an e)leuqerla: Krüger reads xalepw/tera, sc. such a state of things: for neut. plur. cf. 1, 7, plwimwte/rwn o)/ntwn: so ch. 108, 10.
a)nti\...a)nti/—in two different senses ‘in return for’... ‘instead of’, both derived from the original notion of setting one thing over against another.
oi(=s e)gklh/masi—‘the charges with which’, i.e. on the ground of which; see the beginning of the speech.

u(podei/cas—the compound probably means starting with a display of virtue (ch. 4, 15 note), i.e. proclaiming a high-minded and generous policy. This the Lacedaemonians did; cf. i. 69, where the Corinthians say that of Sparta, th\n a)ci/wsin th=s a)reth=s w\s e)leuqerwn th\n *(ella/da fe/retai. On the other hand the Athenians professed a cynical contempt for all principles but the right of the strongest; see i. 76.
kataktw/menoi—corresponds alliteratively to katapolemou=men: the sense is, this is all that we should secure for ourselves.
to\ me\n ga/r—the neuters denote the two principles. dikaiw/sei—‘plea, justification’. e)pe/rxetai—‘makes its attack’, or encroachment; a common meaning of e)pi/ in composition.
periwph/n—‘circumspection’: elsewhere used in a literal sense, chiefly in Homer, e.g. Od. x. 146, a)nh/ion e)s periwph/n, ‘I went up to (a place commanding) a view round’.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXVII
div2.p: h)/ oi(=s—‘than you get from men whose deeds looked at in the light of their words necessitate a conviction that their interests really correspond to their professions’. oi(=s is eth. dat.=‘from those in whose case’. a)naqrw=—a rare word, Eur. Hec. 808, and Plat. For do/khsin cf. ii. 84, do/khsin pare/xontes, with fut. inf. ‘causing an expectation’: also ch. 55, 19.

proi+sxome/nou—‘putting forward’ (mid.=on one's own part): so i. 26, cugge/neian proi+sxo/menoi. It therefore seems strictly to denote ‘professions’ rather than ‘offers’, which would be expressed by parexome/nou. One meaning would however naturally pass into the other.
diwqei=sqai—‘to reject’: so ch. 108, 27: lit. ii. 84, toi=s kontoi=s diwqou=nto, of keeping ships from collision.

u(mi=n—the best manuscripts here read h(mi=n, but it is not possible to explain it satisfactorily, either as referring to the Lacedaemonians or as a mixture of direct and indirect expression. The two pronouns are often confused by copyists.

fai/nesqai—dependent on fh/sete, or the general sense of the passage. kai\ dunato/n...kai\ e)pife/rein—so ch. 80, 17. prosanagka/zein—‘to force into’ acceptance of such freedom: iii. 61, e)peidh proshnagka/zonto: v. 42, tous mh\ dexome/nous ta\s sponda\s prosanagka/sein.

ma/rturas—cf. ii. 74, where Archidamus solemnly appeals to the gods and heroes of Plataeae, when he is about to attack the city: also ii. 71, where Arnold has an interesting note on the local and particular powers and sympathies which the Greeks attributed to gods and heroes.
e)/ti—‘after this’; when a fair appeal has been rejected, force is no longer (ou)k e)/ti) a violation of justice.

prosei=nai de/—pro/seimi=‘to be added’: not only is Brasidas not acting unjustly, but also he is obliged to act as he does. ti, ‘in a measure’, may be considered either as determinant acc. (Classen) or as a predicate in agreement with to\ eu)/logon. In either case it is a ‘litotes’ which really strengthens the sense, so me/ros ti, ma=llo/n ti, etc.

kata\ du/o a)na/gkas—‘for two cogent reasons’: the first reason is the good of Sparta, expressed by gen. tw=n me\n *lakedaimoni/wn, dependent on a)na/gkh, ‘the necessity of (i.e. imposed by the Lacedaemonians’: the second reason is the general interest expressed by a change of construction oi( de\ *(/ellhnes i(/na k.t.l.
tw=| u(mete/rw| eu)/nw|—somewhat ironical in sense: in constr. dat. of the instiument or cause; vi. 16, tw=| e)mw=| diaprepei=. toi=s xrh/masi is a second dat. of the nearer instrument or cause.

ferome/nois—Classen and Poppo explain the position of the partcp. in accordance with the principle noted on ch. 5, 10. Surely however the words ferome/nois par' *)aqhnai/ous have a most forcible predicative sense; ‘that the Lacedaemonians may not be injured by Athens receiving your revenues’, lit. ‘by your revenues being paid to the Athenians’: cf. iii. 20, tw=| si/tw| e)pilipo/nti e/pie/zonto, they suffered from failure of the corn. fe/rw is the regular word for payment of tribute to a ruling state.

ou) ga\r dh\ ei)ko/tws—Arnold has an excellent note on the connexion of thought in this passage. Brasidas urges that his second motive—the deliverance of Greece—is what actuates him most of all. And it is this, and no selfish ambition of Sparta, which justifies him in refusing to tolerate the neutrality of Acanthus.

The natural meaning of ta/de is ‘what we are now doing’: Classen therefore follows Dobree in writing e)pra/ssomen for pra/ssoimen, giving the sense ‘otherwise we should not be now acting with good reason’ (but we are). This would be an instance of unfulfilled condition, see Goodwin, § 49. 2.

The optative however presents no difficulty if we give ta/de a more general sense, sc. ‘our coercion of neutrals (in any supposed case) would not be right’: this agrees with the general character (tou\s mh\ boulome/nous) of the rest of the sentence, and is better than to take tade as=to dh|ou=n th)n gh=n, or to\ e)a=n kwlu/esqai tou\s *)/ellhnas k.t.l.
perii+/doimen—sc. so to oppose it. pro\s tau=ta—cf. i. 71, pro\s ta/de bouleu/esqe eu)= k.t.l. the concluding words of the speech made by the Corinthians at Sparta.

a)/rcai prw=toi—so ii. 36, a)/rcomai prw=ton: ii. 68, h)/rcato prw=ton: v. 71, h(gei=tai th=s ai)ti/as, ‘begins the cause’. kataqe/sqai—‘to secure’, lit. ‘to lay up for yourselves’: ch. 20, 9. For the jingle a)i/dion...i)/dia see ch. 20, 5.

kai\ au)toi/—this corresponds to toi=s te *(/ellhsin. to\ ka/lliston o)/noma, as Jowett suggests, possibly means the title of free; otherwise how does the sense differ from a)i\dion do/cai kataqe/sqai? For constr. cf. vi. 89, e)moi\ de\ a)timi/an perie/qete,

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXVIII
div2.p: e)p' a)mfo/tera—ch. 58, 7. kru/fa—by ballot, kru/bdhn is more common in this sense. For the force of the compound diayhfi/sasqai see note on ch. 74, 17, yh=fon fanera\n dienegkei=n. At Acanthus secret voting permitted freedom of choice.
e)pagwga/—v. 85, e)pagwga\ kai\ a)nelegkta/: vi. 8, e)pagwga\ kai\ ou)k a)lhqh=. oi( plei/ous—partial apposition; we may render ‘by a majority’.

pistw/santes—Lid. and Scott give no other instance of the active. The middle occurs Soph. O. C. 650, u(f' o(/rkou sepistw/somai, ‘I will bind you to myself’: more usually in a reflexive sense, as Hom. Il. vi. 233, pistw/santo, they exchanged mutual pledges. The pass.=‘to be pledged’, Hom. Od. xv. 436, o)/rkw| pistwqh=nai: Eur. Iph. A. 66, e)pei\ d' e)pistw/qhsan.

ta\ te/lh—see note on ch. 15, 2: o)mo/santa agrees with ta\ te/lh and not with au)to/n, as seems plain from ch. 86, 3; the position of au)to/n however is awkward. ou(/tw—‘on these terms’, or ‘after this’; iii. 96, ta)/lla katastreya/menos ou)/tws...strateu=sai.

Grote points out (vol. iv. ch. 53) that it is clear that the Acanthians had no great reason to complain of the rule of Athens. They did not welcome Brasidas as a deliverer, but only joined him under compulsion. So in the other towns of Thrace, while a party was in favour of Sparta, the main bulk of the people seem to have been well satisfied to be subject allies of Athens. It follows that the empire of the Athenians could not have been so harsh and burdensome as it was often represented.

With regard to the surrender of Acanthus, Grote remarks that ‘Grecian political reason and morality’ appear to unusual advantage in the free discussion, the care to protect individual independence of judgment, and the established respect to the vote of the majority, which the citizens observed. It would be more difficult to praise the reason and morality of the decision itself, which is rather an instance of the political untrustworthiness of a democracy, and its readiness to adopt any change however momentous. The Acanthians revolted from Athens, not because they were dissatisfied or oppressed, but ‘because Brasidas said what was attractive, and from fear for their fruit’.

div2.head: CHAPTER LXXXIX
div2.p: The account of the Boeotian plot is now resumed from chs. 76 and 77; many of the words and phrases there used being repeated in this chapter.
e)nedi/doto—‘was to be given up’, according to arrangement: cf. ch. 76. 15, e)nedi/dosan. For the meaning and construction of a)panth=sai cf. ch. 77, 16.

diamarti/as tw=n h(merw=n—this might easily arise as each state had its own calendar: cf. ch. 119, 3. e)s a(/s—the prep. denotes an appointment made for some future day: Plat. Hip. ma. 286 B. me/llw e)pideiknu/nai ei)s tri/thn h(me/ran: Cic. Ep. Att. xvi. 16, admonuit ut pecuniam ad diem solverent.
parelu/pei—of harassing by a simultaneous attack; as we say ‘effecting a diversion’: cf. ch. 80, 4, ei/ a)ntiparalupoi=en. prokatalamba/nontai—‘is secured, or occupied beforehand’: ch. 1, 4.

div2.head: CHAPTER XC
div2.p: tou\s metoi/kous—the me/toikoi are mentioned as serving on board the Athenian fleets, i. 143; iii. 16, etc. Some of them too were heavy-armed men, ii. 13, kai\ metoi/kwn o(/soi o(pli=tai h)=san. It appears from i. 121 and 143 that the navy was partly manned by hired ce/noi: but Classen observes that no other instance is recorded of impressing ‘all the foreigners in Athens’ into military service.
u(/steros—not simply the converse of pro/teron, ch. 89, 8, but implying that Hippocrates came too late to help, as the plot was discovered.

to\ i(ero\n tou= *)apo/llwnos—with regard to these words, which have somewhat the appearance of an explanatory note which has crept into the text, Poppo points out that Thuc. often repeats a description which he has already given (ch. 76, 22), and often separates an appositional construction by intervening words, e.g. ii. 12, *melh/sippon prw=ton a)poste/llei e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas to\n *diakri/tou.

to\ i\ero
 kai\ to
 new/n—so v. 18, to\ d' i(ero
 kai\ to
 new
 to
 e)n *delfoi=s: cf Hdt. vi. 19. When the words are thus distinguished, new/s denotes the actual temple or shrine; while i(ero/n is a more general term, which might be applied for example to all the precincts and surroundings of a convent, or of the colleges in Oxford and Cambridge.

a)ne/ballon...parakataph/gnuntes—‘a rampart was made, consisting chiefly of the earth thrown up from the ditch, with a palisade set along it; but they threw in besides other materials, such as brushwood obtained from the vines which grew round the temple, and stones and bricks procured by pulling down the adjacent houses. That the vines were used in building the wall appears from ch. 100, 16, and their use appears to have been to form a sort of wattling to keep the earth together; as at Plataeae the clay for the besiegers' mound was rammed into flat cases or frames of reeds (e)n tarsoi=s kala/mou e)nei/llontes), and as the earth was enclosed besides in a wooden frame, o(/pws mh\ diaxe/oito e)pi\ polu\ to\ xw=ma, ii. 75, 76’ (Arnold).

a)ne/ballon—rare in this lit. sense: Xen. An. v. 2, 5, ta/fros h)=n eu)rei=a a)nabeblhme/nh kai\ sko/lopes e)pi\ th=s a)nabolh=s. Comparing ii. 76 we see that xou=s is the material of which a xw=ma or mound was made: cf. Hdt. vii. 23, paredi/dosan to\n a)ei\ e)corusso/menon xou=n.
a)/mpelon—generic sing. like pli/nqon infr.; so ch. 48, 13, tw=| kera/mw|.

ko/ptontes...kaqairou=ntes—imperfect, corresponding to the verbs: cf. ch. 48, 18, where we have the same tense and the same participial use. We should say ‘they threw in vine-wood cut down from the precincts of the temple, and stones taken from the houses around’. oi)ko/peda—‘home-steads’; the word means either the site of a house, or the site with its buildings.
h(=| kairo\s h)=n—ch. 54, 25, ou(= kairo\s ei)/h. u(ph=rxen—ch. 4, 15. stoa/—a cloister or colonnade.
tri/th| w(s—=e)c ou(=, Lat. ut. Poppo compares i. 6, ou) polu\s xro/nos e)peidh/: i. 13, e)/th triako/sia...o(/te.

to\ me\n strato/pedon—cor. to *)ippokra/ths de/. In the morning of the fifth day the works were nearly finished. The main body of the Athenians accordingly started for Attica, and while the heavy armed men took up a position near Delium, the light troops mostly (oi( plei=stoi) continued their march. Hippocrates himself had not yet left the fortress. The imperfects h(su/xazon and kaqi/stato leave the narrative at this point, and the writer turns to the movements of the Boeotians.
ta\ peri/—‘what belonged to’. The protei/xisma or ‘outwork’ is apparently the rampart and ditch before described.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCI
div2.p: cunele/gonto—the imperfect refers to the whole time that the Athenians had been in Boeotia. We must render ‘had been gathering together’.

oi(/ ei)sin e(/ndeka—if these words are not a gloss, Thucydides must mean that the total number of Boeotarchs in his days was eleven, otherwise we should have h)=san (R. S.). The number varied at different times; see Arnold. cunepainou/ntwn—of joint approval; Dem. de Cor. 288, sunepainesa/ntwn de\ pa/ntwn.

ma/lista—‘about’, here of approximate situation, more commonly of number or time: the lit. meaning is that a thing is ‘most nearly’ as stated. th=s *)wrwpi/as—the district of Oropus, a frequent ground of dispute, was at this time subject to Athens: ii. 23, ne/montai *)wrw/pioi *)aqhnai/wn u(ph/kooi.

kai\ h(gemoni/as ou)/shs au)tou=—the position of these words is awkward, and their connexion open to doubt. Most editors take them with what follows, ‘both wishing to fight while he was in command, and thinking it better to risk a battle’. It is however quite possible that the kai/ may merely join the gen. absolute, ‘and he being in command’, to the preceding boiwtarxw=n: see ch. 29, 1. It would appear that the Boeotarchs, or possibly only the two Theban Boeotarchs, held the command in turn, but we do not know any facts.
th\n ma/xhn poih=sai—to bring on, or order: ii. 86, strathgoi\ boulo/menoi th\n ma/xhn poih=sai: ‘activum de ducibus ponitur, qui auctores sunt ut pugna fiat’ (Poppo).

o(/pws mh\ a)qro/oi—Arnold points out that this illustrates the practice of the Greek soldiers attending the speeches of their general without their arms; see notes on ch. 44, 6 and 74, 13. In iii. 1 etc., ta\ o(/pla means the camp or place of arms, and this may possibly be the meaning here.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCII
div2.p: Speech of Pagondas. It is right as a general principle to attack an invader at once, wherever we encounter him.

mhd' e)s e)pi/noian—‘none of us ought even to have conceived the idea’; tina\ h(mw=n is the subject of e)lqei=n: cf. iii. 46, o/pws mhd' e)s e)pi/noian tou/tou i)/wsi. dia\ ma/xhs e)lqei=n—ii. 11, e)lqei=n h(mi=n dia\ ma/xhs.

e)noikodomhsa/menoi—the Athenians had ‘built for themselves’ a stronghold in Boeotia: so iii. 85: this is probably the meaning of vi. 90, ta\s de\ (tw=n po/lewn) e)nteixisa/menoi, ‘reducing some of the states by establishing strongholds in the country’.

e)n w)=| te a)
...e)/drasan—‘in whatever place they may have been caught and wherever they came from to attack us’. The latter clause might have been o(/qen a)
 e)pe/lqwsi w)/ste ta\ pole/mia dra=sai, but the construction is changed to the indicative because e)/drasan denotes definite acts of hostility undoubtedly committed. Cob. e)n o(/tw| a)
...o)/qen, omitting te and kai/.

ei)/ tw|—see note on ch. 68, 34, ei) mh/ tis. As this clause is in opposition to the opening words xrh=n me/n k t.l., kai/ seems to emphasize a)sfale/steron e)/doce, not simply a)sfale/steron. ‘if any one did think it safer’. a)sfale/steron—sc. to\ mh\ dia\ ma/xhs e)lqei=n.

ou) ga\r to\ promhqe/s—‘for forethought, in the case of such as are invaded by foes, does not admit of calculation, when their own land is in danger, in the same way as when a man is in possession of his own but chooses to attack another from desire of more’. Prudence itself teaches men to repel an invader at once without reflection, though it may be prudent to reflect before invading another country.

to\ promhqe/s—prudence and forethought, in a good sense: iii. 82, me/llhsis promhqh/s opposed to to/lma a)lo/gistos. With oi(=s a)/n and o(/stis are to be supplied tou/tois, tou/tw|, eth. dat. ‘for, in the case of’.
peri\ th=s sfete/ras—sc. gh=s: the pron. refers to what is in sense the subject of the sentence, viz. those who have been invaded by others.

e)nde/xetai logismo/n—so ch. 10, 7. kai\ o(/stis—with o)moi/ws, ‘as in the case of one who’. The constr. passes to the indic. as in line 9: here too it may be meant to denote the actual conduct of the Athenians; o(/stis, the rel. of a class, often referring to a definite antecedent as possessing the characteristics of that class. There is a similar change of construction in ii. 44, to\ de\ eu)tuxe/s, oi(\ a)\n th=s eu)prepesta/ths la/xwsi, kai\ oi(=s...cunemetrh/qh: cf. ch. 18, 13.
*)aqhnai/ous de/—the speaker now passes to the particular need of repelling an Athenian invasion. a)mu/nesqai is to be supplied with dei=.

pro/s te ga/r—‘in the relations of neighbours freedom is always (pa=si) ensured by a manful spirit of resistance’. The subject is to\ a)nti/palon, ‘being a match for’ one's adversary, i.e. being able and determined to resist him: kai\ e)leu/qeron is the predicate.

oi(\ kai\ mh/—Poppo, with Haack, seems right in taking mh/ for mh\ o(/ti, ‘ne dicam’; the sense required being ‘not only’, or ‘not to say only’: no other instance however is given of mh/ thus standing alone. The restless and aggressive spirit of the Athenians is often spoken of; cf. ch. 55, 17.
e)pi\ to\ e)/sxaton a)gw=nos—in illustration of this gen Classen cites i. 49, e)s tou=to a)na/gkhs: i. 118, e)pi\ me/ga duna/mews, etc.

para/deigma de/—so iii. 39, of a warning example, para/deigma d' au)toi=s...e)ge/nonto k.t.l.: vi. 77, e)/xontes paradei/gmata tw=n *)ellh/nwn, w)s e)doulw/qhsan. a)ntipe/ras—‘across the water’, Euboea being right opposite the Boeotian coast, and in full view. The island was entirely subdued by Pericles in 445 (i. 114).

w(s au)toi=s dia/keitai—‘in what relations it stands to them’, i.e. regards them with hostility, and is always in danger from their ambition. This rendering gives a more satisfactory sense than ‘how it is disposed towards them’, and does no violence to the meaning of dia/keimai, which denotes ‘being in a certain condition’, of mind, body, or circumstances. It has also been proposed to render the words ‘how it has been treated, to what condition it is reduced, by them’: or to take dia/keitai impersonally and au)toi=s to refer to the Euboeans and Greeks, ‘how things stand as regards them’. In support of this last view Krüger cites Xen. Anab. vii. 3. 17, a)/meinon u)mi=n diakei/setai.

Other instances of dia/keimai in Thuc. are vii. 77, w)s dia/keimai u(po\ th=s vo/sou, ‘to what state I am reduced’: i. 75, toi=s *(/ellhsin e)pifqo/nws diakei=sqai, ‘to be regarded with jealousy by’: viii. 68, u)po/ptws tw=| plh/qei diakei/menos.

e)s pa=san—‘extending to and including our whole country’: the following are somewhat similar uses of e)s: iii. 82, e)s to\ h\donh\n e)/xon o)ri/zontes, ‘making their pleasure the limit’; v. 103, e)s a)/pan to\ u(pa/rxon a)narriptou=si, ‘throwing the die so as to include their all in the risk’. ou)k a)nti/lektos—‘not to be gainsaid’; there will be no more boundary disputes.

e(te/rwn—i.e. h)\ th\n e(te/rwn: see Madvig, § 90. paroi/khsin—elsewhere only found in the Septuagint, according to Lidd. and Scott. paroikw= occurs i. 71, etc. The proverb *)attiko\s pa/roikos, of a restless and dangerous neighbour, is cited by Ar. Rhet. ii. 21. 12.

ei)w/qasi/ te—a warlike spirit is the best security against aggression, and has always proved so. i)sxu/os qra/sei—Soph. Phil. 104, ou(/tws e)/xei ti deino\n i)sxu/os qra/sos: cf. ch. 86, 25,
i)sxu/os dikaiw/sei. proapantw=nta—i. 69, pro/teron h)\ proapanth=sai, in the same sense, of anticipating an invader.

kate/xein—probably ‘to hold down’, i.e. oppress, overbear; as in i. 103, pole/mw| katei=xon. Several editors give the meaning ‘to withstand’, sustinere; but the sense is not satisfactory, as a notion of aggression is required, nor is it plain that kate/xw will bear this meaning. The present and imp. are by no means identical in use with the aorist; though the tenses are hopelessly mixed in dictionaries and commentaries.
au)tou=—‘of this’; see note on ch. 18, 7, e)pa/qomen au)to/. e)s tou/sde—for instances of the use of e)s see note on ch. 28, 2.

e)n *korwnei/a|—in 447 (i. 113). The Athenians had been dominant in Boeotia for eight or nine years, but after the battle of Coronea they entirely evacuated the country (e)ce/lipon pa=san), cf. iii. 62 fin. For e)n=‘at’ see note on ch. 5, 5.
kate/sxon—‘over-ran’, or ‘got the mastery’: vii. 66, tw=| nautikw=| w(=|per pa/nta kate/sxon.
h(ma=s—in apposition with this we have two clauses, tou/s te...tou/s te.
o(moiwqh=nai—to come up to, not to degenerate from. Persons are here compared with things: in i. 71 we have the opposite, a)rxaio/tropa u)mw=n ta\ e)pithdeu/mata pro\s au)tou/s e)stin.

ta\s proshkou/sas a)reta/s—proshkou/sas denotes the virtues which are as it were the heirloom or belongings of the race or family: cf. iii. 64, a(/ pote xrhstoi\ e)ge/nesqe, ou) prosh/konta nu=n e)pedei/cate, ‘the good service you once did you now shew was not natural to you’, but due to accident: so iii. 67, referring to the palaiai\ a)retai/ of the Plataeans, ou)k e)k proshko/ntwn a(marta/nousi, i.e. we have a right to expect different conduct: cf. Cope on Ar. Rhet. i. 9. 31, o(/sa kata\ to\ prosh=kon, oi)=on ei) a)/cia tw=n progo/nwn kai\ tw=n prou+phrgme/nwn, ‘worthy of a man's ancestors and his own previous acquisitions or possessions—a stock of previous good, noble, great deeds’.
pro\s h(mw=n e)/sesqai—explanatory of pisteu/santas tw=| qew=|: for pro/s, ‘on our side’, cf. ii. 86, pro\s e)kei/nwn, ‘in their favour’. ne/montai—‘occupy’: so e)noikei=n. ch. 97, 9.

qusame/nois...fai/netai—the aor. participle denotes a sacrifice performed and complete, though possibly only just completed; the pres. fai/netai gives the still remaining result: we found, when we sacrificed, that the omens are in our favour. Sacrifices were always offered before a battle. The mid. qu/esqai
is used of the army, or commander: the act. of the priest who actually slew the victim. kala/—of favourable omens; only here in Thuc.: Xen. Anab. iv. 3, etc.

o(mo/se xwrh=sai—ch. 10, 5. dei=cai o(/ti...kta/sqwsan— not a case of o(/ti with orat. direct. like ch. 38, 19, but rather a rhetorical change of construction—‘let them win’ instead of ‘they may win’—which gives force and abruptness to the speaker's words. gennai=on—according to the Schol.=pa/trion kai\ a)po\ ge/nous: so Hom. Il. v. 253, ou) ga/r moi gennai=on a)luska/zonti ma/xesqai, the only passage in which the word occurs in Homer. Paley there takes the meaning to be ‘consistent with honour, worthy of one well born’; and such a sense is quite applicable to the present passage, in which Pagondas is extolling the noble spirit of the Boeotians.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCIII
div2.p: a)nasth/sas—ch. 77, 13.
prose/micen—of a near approach: so viii. 71, w(s de\ prose/mice/ te e)ggu/s. In ch. 33, 9 and 96, 7 the word is used of coming to close quarters with the enemy: cf. v. 72, fqa/sai th=| prosmi/cei.
kaqi/sas—sc. to\n strato/n, line 3; to be supplied also with e)/tasse.

tw=| de\ *(ippokra/tei...w(s au)tw=|—the redundancy is probably to be explained as a confusion of construction, au)tw=| being added as if o( de\ *(ippokra/ths had gone before. Hippocrates had remained behind at Delium, ch. 90 fin.
e)pige/nointo—as a reserve force, e)pi/ implying sequence: see notes on ch. 26, 14 and 36, 14. tou\s a)munoume/nous—for the use of the article cf. note on ch. 78, 33.
w(/sper e)/mellon—sc. ta/ssesqai: the contingents were already in the order which they intended to keep in the battle.

decio
 me
 ke/ras—the article is omitted, as noted on ch. 18, 11. oi( cu/mmoroi au)toi=s—see note on cuntelei=, ch. 76, 15. th
 li/mnhn—Copais.

e)p' a)spi/das pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi—twenty-five deep: v. 68, e)pi\ de\ ba/qos e)ta/canto...e)pi\ o)ktw/: viii. 79, ou)k e)p' o)li/gwn a)spi/dwn. The depth and weight of the Boeotian column is to be noticed. At Leuctra the Theban phalanx was drawn up 50 deep.
dia/kosmos—a word only found elsewhere in later Greek.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCIV
div2.p: *)aqhnai=oi de\ oi( me/n—the varieties of appositional construction throughout this chapter are to be noticed. pa=n to\ strato/pedon—in apposition with oi( o)pli=tai.
e)k paraskeuh=s w(plisme/noi—‘regularly armed’ as light infantry. e)k paraskeuh=s denotes the result of set purpose: so v. 56, ma/xh ou)demi/a e)ge/neto e)k paraskeuh=s.
a)/oploi—of hastily and imperfectly armed troops, as in ch. 9, 13. polloi/—partial apposition; possibly oi( polloi/, ‘for the most part’, should be read.
panstratia=s—elsewhere in classical Greek only found in the adverbial dative, as in ch. 66, 4. ou) parege/nonto—‘did not appear’ or ‘fall in’.

e)pipariw/n—‘passing along’, secundum ordines exercitus procedens (Poppo): vi. 67, kata\ e)/qnh e)pipariw\n e)/kasta: so vii. 76. In v. 10 with dat. e)pipariw\n tw=| deciw=| means ‘passing along to attack the right wing’: see also ch. 108, 19.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCV
div2.p: di' o)li/gou—of time: i. 76, di' o)li/gou h(ghsa/menoi: ii. 85, opposed to e)k pollou=: iii. 43, di' o)li/gou skopou/ntwn, ‘taking a hasty view’, opposed to peraite/rw pronoou=ntas.

to\ i)/son...du/natai—a short speech is as good as a long one when addressed (pro/s te) to brave men and consisting of (kai\ e(/xei) admonition rather than exhortation. te and kai/ connect the two ideas of the quality of the men and the character of the speech; the finite verb e)/xei being brought in, like prosh/gagon in ch. 100, 8, instead of a subordinate construction, or te being simply out of place as noted on ch. 77, 11. Krüger and Classen follow Reiske in reading pro/s ge tou/s instead of pro/s te, but the alteration does not seem required.
u(po/mnhsin...e)/xei—sc. h( parai/nesis. Note the use of similar words in the speech of Brasidas, ch. 126.
parasth=|—cf. ch. 61, 11. ou) prosh=kon—acc. abs.: iii. 40, u)mei=s a)\n ou) xrew\n a)/rxoite, ‘you must be wrong in holding your empire’.

For a)narriptou=men cf. ch. 85, 16. e)n th=| pou/twn— Hippocrates seems to speak generally as the leader of an invasion; for the present position of the Athenians was admitted by the Boeotians to be beyond their border, ch. 91. 6; 99, 7.

ou) mh/ pote...e)sba/lwsin—this and v. 49 are the only instances of this construction in Thucydides. e)kei/nhn—‘yon land of ours’, cf. note on ch. 37, 10. Note the graphic use of the present tense in this sentence.

xwrh/sate e)s au)tou/s—a curious phrase to denote an attack: so Xen. Anab. iii. 2. 16, e)tolmh/sate i(e/nai ei)s au)tou/s. The use of strateu/ein e)s, ch. 77, 2, is not analogous (see note). Note the separation of the words by the position of a)ci/ws: cf. note on ch. 90, 7.

e)/xwn...a)ga/lletai—a participial construction, which is common with other verbs expressing joy or grief: in ii. 63 we have the dative. w(=|per a)ga/llesqe: in iii. 82 a preposition, e)pi\ de\ tw=| a)ga/llontai.

kratou=ntes—‘being victorious over’; the pres. and imperf. of nikw=, a)dikw=, feu/gw (to be in exile), etc. are used in the same way; e.g. i. 14, *karxhdoni/ous e)ni/kwn naumaxou=ntes. The victory of Oenophyta (456) gave the Athenians the mastery of Boeotia for some years (i. 108); see note on ch. 92, 35.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCVI
div2.p: to\ de\ ple/on—either determinant acc. or governed by e)pelqei=n or e)pelqo/ntos, which must be supplied with fqa/santos.
w(s dia\ taxe/wn—as well as the short time allowed: so ch. 125, 26. kai\ e)ntau=qa—besides the harangue at Tanagra, ch. 92.
ta\ e)/sxata—‘the ends’. r(u/akes—ravines or torrents; iii. 116, o( r)u/ac tou= puro/s, of the eruption of Aetna.

to\ de\ a)/llo...cunesth/kei—cetera vero acies consistebat acriter pugnans et clipeis se (mutuo) propellens (Poppo). For to\ a(/llo cf. i. 48, where it is opposed to to\ decio\n ke/ras: see also note on ch. 19, 22. The w)qismo\s a)spi/dwn is a common feature of the closely-fought battles described by Livy and Tacitus. me/xri me/sou—‘as far as the centre of the line’, to be connected with the article before eu)w/numon.
au)toi=s—ethical dative; as in iii. 98, o( h(gemw\n au)toi=s e)tu/gxane teqnhkw/s: cf. ch. 10, 13. kuklwqe/ntwn—sc. the Thespians; ‘those posted near them’ were the men of Tanagra and Orchomenos.
kata\ braxu/—‘gradually’ or ‘little by little’; in vii. 79 kata\ braxu\ treya/menoi seems to mean defeating small sections of the enemy one after another. e)k tou= a)fanou=s—ch. 36, 7.
pararrhgnu/ntwn—‘breaking their ranks’; because one man was forced from his position beside another: v. 73, parerrh/gnunto h)/dh. fugh\ kaqeisth/kei = a decided rout began.
e)pilabou/shs to\ e)/rgon—cf. ch. 27, 5; and for e)/rgon ch. 25, 9. to\ plh=qos—‘the bulk’, so ch. 100, 25.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCVII
div2.p: e)pi\ tou\s nekrou/s—‘for the dead’, i.e. to ask permission to remove them. apostre/yas kai\ ei)pw/n—the second participle gives the reason for turning the Athenian herald back; we have a similar order in ch. 51, 2: so i. 1, a)rca/menos...kai\ e)lpi/sas: so i. 109, chra/nas th\n diw/ruxa kai\ paratre/yas a)/llh| to\ u)/dwr. katasta\s e)pi/—so ch. 84, 10.

pa=si ga\r ei)=nai—the construction changes to the infinitive with the change of subject: cf. ch. 46, 22, o(/ti...ei)/h...me/llein ga\r dh/. kaqesthko/s—‘an established custom’: i. 98, para\ to\ kaqesthko/s.

e)noikei=n—‘were living in it’ like an ordinary town: ii. 17, dia\ th\n para/nomon e)noi/khsin. bebh/lw|—a tragic word: other words in this chapter, such as a)/yaustos and xe/rniy, are poetical, and possibly characteristic of Boeotian speech.
o(\ h)=n a)/yauston sfi/si = ‘which we forbore to touch’. xe/rnibi xrh=sqai—the inf. construction is explanatory of pro\s ta\ i(era/.
tou\s o(mwxe/tas dai/monas—cf. iii. 59, qeou\s tou\s o(mobwmi/ous e)pibow/menoi.

div2.head: CHAPTER XCVIII
div2.p: tou= me\n i(erou=—‘as regards the temple’; the first point in the Athenian reply; the second and third are to\n de\ no/mon, line 8, and u)/dwr te, line 18. In construction tou= i(erou= depends on ou)de/n.

a)dikh=sai...bla/yein—‘wrong...harm’. Poppo considers that the contrast is rather between the force of the tenses than the meaning of the words: there seems however this distinction, that a)dikw= implies damage which could be justly complained of; cf. ch. 68, 23.

tou= loipou=—‘for the future’; partitive gen.: ch. 1, 1. ou)de\ ga/r—‘neither had they to begin with entered it with this object’; ou)de/ = ‘also not’, its more common meaning. th\n a)rxh/n, a well-known adverbial accusative, occurs ii. 74 and vi. 56. It is only used in negative sentences.
ma=llon—i. e. if there was any wrong-doing in the case it was on the other side.

braxute/ras—Thucydides often uses braxu/s in the general sense of small: e.g. i. 14, braxe/a (nautika\) e)ke/kthnto, opp. to a)cio/loga: i. 130, e)/rgois braxe/si, ‘by small actions’, opp. to meizo/nws.

tro/pois qerapeuo/mena...du/nwntai—the sense is clear, that the victorious invader satisfies the demands of Grecian law if he maintains to the best of his power the usual religious observances of the temple which he has seized. There seems however a difficulty in the words pro\s toi=s ei)wqo/si. pro/s means ‘in addition to’, and we should rather expect some expression implying shortcoming or variation, such as para\ ta\ ei)wqo/ta. pro\ tou= ei)wqo/si, ‘hitherto usual’, Stahl.

kai\ du/nwntai—Poppo and Classen take i(era/ as nom. to du/nwntai, sc. qerapeu/esqai, and Classen adds that the plural verb, implying different occasions, is rightly used with i(era/ after the words a)ei/ gi/gnesqai. Such a phrase however as i(ero\n du/natai qerapeu/esqai is decidedly strange; and a nom. to du/nwntai (qerapeu/ein) is easily supplied from tou/twn in line 10.

kai\ ga\r *boiwtou/s—cf. i. 12, ‘sixty years after the taking of Troy the present Boeotians settled in the country which is now called Boeotia but was formerly called the Cadmean land’. oi)kei=a—pred., ‘as their own’.

ei)...dunhqh=nai— = ei) e)dunh/qhsan: cf. i. 91, o(/sa...bouleu/esqai: ii. 102, o(/te dh\ a(la=sqai au)to/n. With ei) this construction is a peculiarity of Herodotus; see Madvig, § 169 b: Goodwin, § 92. 2. tou=t' a)\n e)/xein—lit. ‘this they would (now) be holding’.
e(ko/ntes ei)=nai—a much stronger expression than e(ko/ntes: e(kw\n ei)=nai, lit. ‘so far as will goes’, i. e. (not) if I can avoid it.

h(\n...prosqe/sqai—‘which they had not brought on themselves by insolent pride’: cf. i. 78, mh\ a)llotri/ais gnw/mais kai\ e/gklh/masi peisqe/ntes oi)kei=on po/non prosqh=sqe: i. 144, kindunous au)qaire/tous prosti/qesqai. In the following clause bia/zesqai is passive, and the accusatives are governed by a)muno/menoi. e)pi th\n sfete/ran—Delium is meant, as in line 32, e)n h)| dori\ e/kth/santo.

pa=n kateirgo/menon—‘everything (i. e. anything) when (if) done under stress of the war may reasonably claim some indulgence even from the god’. For this predicative use of the participle cf. Plat. Phaedr. 328 B, lexqe\n...pa=n...safe/steron, ‘every proposition is clearer when stated’; and for the meaning ‘done under constraint’ cf. ch. 63, 7, ei)rxqh=nai. There seems
no need for the alteration pa=n to\ pole/mw|, nor for the reading adopted by Classen, tw=|...kateirgome/nw| (masc.).

cu/ggnwmon—‘admitting of excuse or indulgence’: iii. 40, cu/ggnwmon d' e)sti\ to\ a)kou/sion. This passive meaning of the neuter is in accordance with the principle noted on ch. 32, 22. When applied to a person cuggnw/mwn has the active force of ‘regarding with indulgence, making allowance’ etc.
kai\ pro\s tou= qeou=—Apollo, whose temple Delium was. For pro(s cf. i. 71, a)/dikon ou)de\n ou)/te pro\s qew=n ou)/te pro\s a)nqrw/pwn, ‘regarded as unjust by’.
paranomi/an o)nomasqh=nai—‘lawlessness is a term applied’ etc.
tou/s te nekrou/s—‘as regards the dead’, grammatically dependent on a)podido/nai: cf. line 3. The form meizo/nws occurs ch. 19, 19 and i. 130.

i(eroi=s...komi/zesqai—‘to get back by the medium of sacred things what it is not seemly (so to recover)’; to barter a temple for corpses was profanation and gross impiety. In construction i(eroi=s is the instrumental dative.

safw=s te—to be taken with ei)pei=n; the Athenians demand a plain proffer of what was just and usual, viz. that they might remove their dead not ‘on condition of evacuating Boeotian territory’, but under the usual terms of truce. In construction mh/ goes with ei)pei=n and a)piou=sin and spe/ndousin are in agreement with sfi/sin.
e)n th=| e)kei/nwn—see note on ch. 37. 10.
dori\ e)kth/santo—so i. 128, dori\ e(lw/n, in a letter from Pausanias to the Persian king.

spe/ndousin—if the reading is right the active of spe/ndw seems here used in the sense of ‘making a truce’, for which the middle is elsewhere used. Poppo suggests speu/dousin, which however has little or no meaning. Others explain spe/ndousin as used in its proper meaning of ‘making libations’, i.e. doing their part in the joint act which would be denoted by spe/ndesqai (see B. and C. and Rutherford).

div2.head: CHAPTER XCIX
div2.p:
e)k th=s e(autw=n—the pronouns in this chapter are used with a freedom which is scarcely reducible to any rule; the meaning however is clear from the context. The words which refer to the primary subject oi( *boiwtoi/ are the following: e)k th=s e(autw=n...nomi/zontes...bi/a| sfw=n...e)k th=s e(autw=n: the following refer to the secondary subject a)pio/ntas (sc. the Athenians):
ta\ sfe/tera...e)n th=| e)kei/nwn...au)tou\s gignw/skein...ou)k a(\n au)tou/s...u)pe\r th=s e)kei/nwn.
au)tou\s gignw/skein—‘they must judge for themselves’; the infinitives in this chapter follow a)pekri/nanto, as a)nairei=sqai follows ei)pei=n in ch. 98, 33.

nomi/zontes th\n me/n—the corresponding ‘apodosis’ is to\ de/ line 10; kai\ ou)k a)/n being an additional clause with nomi/zontes, and ou)d' au)= e)spe/ndonto being parenthetical in construction. The original idea of the sentence seems to have been ‘the Boeotians thought that the dead were really lying on Athenian ground, but that still they might plausibly refuse to let the Athenians remove them till they evacuated Delium’.

kata\ to\ u(ph/koon—‘as being subject to them’: i. 95, kata\ to\ cuggene/s. kai\ ou)k a)/n—‘and (yet) they could not’: kai/ has a somewhat similar adversative force in ii. 90, a)/kwn kai\ kata\ spoudh/n: et is at times similarly used, especially in late Latin.

ou)d' au)= e)spe/ndonto—‘nor again would they make a truce’: for this use of the imp. cf. ch. 4, 11, h)pei/gonto: ch. 76, 15, e)nedi/dosan. dh=qen, like dh/, gives the alleged reason; it sometimes stands before the words which it particularly affects; e.g. i. 127, tou=to to\ a)/gos e)lau/nein e)ke/leuon dh=qen tw=| qew=| prw=ton timwrou=ntes.

to\ de/—‘but (considering) that the reply, Let them evacuate our land and then take back what they ask for, was a plausible answer to give’. ‘They considered it a fair diplomatic way of meeting the alternative raised by the Athenian herald’ (Grote). The substantive of to/ is formed by the quoted words. The harsh break in the citation is intended to emphasize the phrase e)k th=s e(autw=n as the main point in the answer, to which the term eu)prepe/s especially belongs. We have a somewhat similar order in the concluding sentence of ch. 98.

The Boeotian answer was in fact a second demand for the evacuation of Delium couched in different terms. Comparing line 3 with ch. 97 line 21 we see that e)k th=s e(autw=n is simply substituted for e)k tou= i(erou=. Originally they had called on the Athenians to leave the temple which they profaned; now they bid them leave the territory of Boeotia. The demand seems at first to refer to the district of Oropus, where the dead were lying; but no Athenians were left there (ch. 96 fin.) nor could there be any reason for the Athenians insisting on its occupation. Delium, on the other hand, they claimed to be their own by right of conquest; and the Boeotians, who held
Oropia, turn against them their own unlucky argument of de facto possession. Greek feeling, as Grote points out, was violated by the Boeotians in thus refusing to restore the dead, nor is it likely that they could have persisted in their refusal. On the other hand they might reasonably complain of the occupation of a temple as an advanced hostile post; which was a very different thing from conquering a country and taking over the temples as well.
eu)prepe/s—to be taken with a)pokri/nasqai. kai\ a)polabei=n—‘let them also take back’, i.e. then, on that condition.
o( de\ kh=ruc—‘so the herald’ etc.: ch. 71, 12.

div2.head: CHAPTER C
div2.p: e)/k te—te and kai/ connect the two sets of auxiliary forces, the light-armed troops from the Melian gulf and the heavy-armed men from Corinth and Nisaea: cf. ch. 28, 21, e)/k te *ai)/nou k.t.l.
kai\ bebohqhko/twn au)toi=s—‘and having been reinforced by’ etc.: for the change of participial construction cf. the beginning of ch. 29.
*korinqi/wn—possibly a portion of the force which marched with Brasidas to Megara, ch. 70, 11. tw=n e)k *nisai/as —ch. 69, 23.

prose/balon—the manuscript reading; Classen alters it to prose/ballon, the ‘preliminary’ imperfect, which is followed by the details of the attack. Note the irregularity of the finite verb prosh/gagon in the following line.
h(/per ei)=len au)to/—‘which in fact took the place’; Classen cites ii. 77, ai( mhxanai\ ou)de\n w)fe/loun, to shew that Krüger's correction, h(=|per ei)=lon, is not necessary.
kerai/an—a beam or spar: ii. 76: vii. 41. a)kribw=s— ‘exactly, nicely’. e)p' a(/kran—adj. agreeing with kerai/an.

a)krofu/sion—‘a nozzle’, from a)/kros and fu=sa. e)s au)to\n neu=on—either to be taken separately, ‘curving into the cauldron’ or with kaqei=to, ‘was bent down in a curve into the cauldron’: for kaqei=to, demissum erat, cf. ch. 103, 21.
e(pi\ me/ga—‘a large part of the wood as well’: cf. note on ch. 3, 13, e/pi\ polu/. The use of a)/llos where we should say ‘besides’ is well known.
e)k pollou=—of distance. h(=|...w)|kodo/mhto—see ch. 90; the definite articles point to the materials there described.
o(po/te ei)h—the frequentative optative shews that more than one attempt was made. steganw=s—through the closed pipe.
h)=ye tou= tei/xous—‘set fire to the wall’, a good illustration of the partitive genitive.

div2.head: CHAPTER CI
div2.p: e(ptakaideka/th|—the same form occurs vii. 28; elsewhere pe/mptos kai\ de/katos (11. 2), etc.

polu\s a)riqmo/s—possibly including stragglers who were cut off by the cavalry, cf. ch. 94, 10. We learn from Plato that Socrates fought among the hoplites at Delium, and preserved his life by his steadiness in the retreat. Alcibiades also was with the cavalry. The defeat of the Athenians was great and decisive, and the material and moral loss seems to have crippled the power of the city.
to/te—ch. 89, 8, *dhmosqe/nhs...a)/praktos gi/gnetai.
tetrakosi/ous o(pli/tas—Arnold considers that these were the marines of the forty ships under Demosthenes (ch. 76, 2): cf. note on ch. 9, 13.

a)pe/qane...*sita)lkhs—the most obvious meaning is that Sitalces was slain in the expedition. There is however an intimation in a letter of Philip that he fell by the hand of an assassin. This may have taken place when he returned after his defeat. The dominions and power of Sitalces are described at length in ii. 95—101.
toi=s e)pi\ *dhli/w|—neut.: we have the same construction ch. 129, 6. *triballou/s—mentioned in ii. 96, as an independent nation, on the north-west of the Odrysian Thracians.
*seu/qhs—we learn from ii. 101 that Seuthes married the daughter of Perdiccas king of Macedonia. e)basi/leusen— ‘became king’: i. 14, *persw=n e)basi/leuse.
h(=sper kai/—i. 14, ai(=sper kai\ e)nauma/xhsan: i. 74, w)/sper kai\ a)/lloi.

div2.head: CHAPTER CII
div2.p: The disastrous defeat of Delium is now followed by the still more serious loss of Amphipolis on the Strymon, the key of the Thracian dependencies.
*)aristago/ras—his attempt and failure to establish himself in ‘the Edonian Myrcinus’ are related by Herodotus v. 11 and 124—6. The date is 497, or according to Krüger 499: see Jowett on i. 103.

e)cekrou/sqh—so ch. 7, 7. e)/peita...oi( *)aqhnai=oi—in 465 or 467: cf. i. 100, pe/myantes muri/ous oi)kh/toras au)tw=n kai\ tw=n cumma/xwn, which words shew how the slightly irregular clause with te and kai/ is to be understood here.
e)n *drabh/skw|—between the Strymon and Philippi: see Poppo on i. 100.
au)=qis—in 437 or 439. oi)kistou=—predicate. After the death of Brasidas the Amphipolitans made him their ‘oekist’ instead of Hagnon, and thus honoured him as their tutelary hero (v. 11).
o(/per...e)kalou=nto—cf. i. 10, *mukh=nai mikro\n h)=n. h(\n au)toi\ ei)=xon—since 467; note on ch. 7, 2.

*)amfi/polin w)no/masen o(/ti—Amphipolis means a surrounded city, or a city looking both ways or all round. Poppo notes that, regarding the order of the words, the reason for the name is given in the final clause perifanh=...w)/|kisen, ‘because its position was conspicuous seawards and landwards’. The similarity of sound however in *)amfi/polis and e)p' a)mfo/tera must be intended to bear upon the name. In fact the whole sentence deals with it. The town was called Amphipolis because it was virtually surrounded by the river, and was an insulated fortress visible on all sides.

e)p' a)mfo/tera perir)r(e/ontos—the city stands on a hill round which the river sweeps in a semicircle towards the west, forming a peninsula. ep' a)mfotera therefore means, both above and below the city.

dia\ to\ perie/xein au)th/n—most editors take this to mean ‘for the sake of enclosing it’, i.e. in order to do so; a sense which dia/ with the acc. sometimes has, at any rate with substantives, as noted on ch. 40, 9. Classen however brackets the words, believing them to be a mere explanatory note, ‘because it surrounds it’, identical in meaning with the words which immediately precede, and doubting if dia\ to/ with inf. can mean ‘in order to’.

a)polabw/n—ch. 45, 9. e)k potamou= e)s potamo/n—from a point in the river's course above the city to a point below; the wall, to take Classen's illustration, being thus like a string to the bow represented by the river.
perifanh=—predicate. For the word cf. the Homeric use of perifaino/menos. The topography of Amphipolis causes some difficulty: see the Appendix to Arnold's second volume.

div2.head: CHAPTER CIII
div2.p: e)c *)arnw=n—unknown. ‘Bromiscus is the traditional scene of the death of Euripides. The Arethusa convallis et statio, in qua visitur Euripidis sepulcrum, of Ammianus Marcellinus is evidently the Aulon and Bromiscus of Thucydides; the very name Aulon being descriptive of the place, a valley through which the lake Bolbe discharges itself into the sea (Arnold).
e)ci/hsin—trans. ‘discharges’ sc. its waters: so ii. 102, e)s qa/lassan e)ciei/s: in i. 46 e)/ceisi is the better supported reading, though some manuscripts have e)ci/hsi.

xeimw/n—stormy weather, as in ch. 6, 7. h(=| kai\ ma=llon —cf. ch. 1, 17. u(pe/neifen—cf. iii. 23, h( nu\c u(poneifome/nh. In both passages Classen, on Cobet's authority, reads u(ponif. though u(poneif. is the reading of the best manuscripts.
*)argi/lioi—Argilus was a short way S. E. of Amphipolis. peiqo/menoi—‘instigated by’ (Jowett).
a)ei/ pote—ch. 57, 26. u(/poptoi with dat. implies a footing of mutual suspicion, as in ch. 104, 5.

e)peidh\...h)=lqen—it is possible to understand these words of the arrival of Brasidas in Thrace, but I think that they rather refer to his actual appearance near Amphipolis, and are closely connected with the following kai\ to/te deca/menoi. The next clause e)/praca/n te is then parenthetical in sense, ‘as they had from the first intrigued...so now’: cf. ch. 32, 27, to/ te prw=ton...e)peno/ei kai\ e)n tw=| e)/rgw| e)/tacen: so vii. 55, ta/ te pro\ au)tw=n h)po/roun kai\ e)peidh/ ge k.t.l.
In all these sentences the clause with te refers to a time before that with which the main part of the sentence deals. We have a somewhat similar construction with me/n at the beginning of ch. 7, 2.
e)k plei/onos—‘for some (longer) time back’ (ch. 42, 17), i e. since the first arrival of Brasidas in Thrace. e)mpoliteu/ontas—ch. 106, 3.
th=| po/lei—in (lit. with) their city; dative of the instrument: vi. 44, ou) dexome/nwn au)tou\s a)gora=| ou)de\ a)/stei, u(/dati de\ kai\ o(/rmw|. Poppo compares the Latin recipere urbe, tecto, etc.
kate/sthsan—ch. 78, 40. pro/sw—‘far on its way’. Bekker and Classen read pro\ e(/w, but on very slight authority.

a)pe/xei...ple/on—probably ‘is some distance from the crossing’, ple/on being a general comparison like e)k plei/onos in line 15, and diaba/sews being governed by a)pe/xei. Arnold however makes it depend on ple/on, ‘the city is further off than the crossing’, i.e. when you had crossed the river you had not yet reached the city.
ou) kaqei=to tei/xh—‘there were no walls extending down’ to connect the bridge with the city. For braxei=a see note on ch. 98, 9.

a)prosdo/khtos—passive; as in viii. 23, a)prosdo/khtoi katasxo/ntes. Possibly a)prosdokh/tois should be read in both passages, since the word is more commonly active when used of a person, as in ch. 72, 14. ta\ e)/cw—cf. ii. 5, e)pebou/leuon toi=s e)/cw th=s po/lews tw=n *plataiw=n. xwri/on here means the district belonging to the city, as opposed to the po/lisma or po/lis itself.

div2.head: CHAPTER CIV
div2.p: au)tou=—seemingly subjective gen.; ‘his crossing’; or can it refer to potamou=? Note the force of the imperfect participles in the following clause.
dokei=n a)\n e)lei=n—dependent on le/getai, *brasi/dan being the subject to dokei=n, which is imperfect, ‘they say that it was thought that he might have taken it’ (ei) h)qe/lhse...ei(=len a)/n).
i(dru/sas— = kaqi/sas: Hdt. iv. 124, i(/druse th\n stratih\n e)pi\ potamw=| *)oa/rw|. Thucydides elsewhere uses only the passive i(dru/esqai. a)pe/bainen—ch. 39, 13.
tw=| plh/qei—dative of the instrument, ‘by reason of’.
meta\ *eu)kle/ous—‘in concert with, with the consent of’: v. 44, ou met' *(aqhnai/wn praxqei=san cummaxi/an. We have the converse in ch. 78, 22, a)/neu tou= koinou=.

tw=n e)pi\ *qra/|khs—there is some authority for to/n, but tw=n gives the better sense. Both commanders were probably jointly responsible for ‘the Thraceward regions’. For the responsibility of Thucydides for the loss of Amphipolis see Appendix.

h(mi/seus h(me/ras—the better supported reading: cf. ch. 83, 23: Hdt. iv. 15, kata\ me/son h(me/rhs. Bekker and Classen read h(misei/as, which Poppo calls ‘grammaticorum manifestam correctionem’. Such a construction is no doubt more usual.

ma/lista me\n ou)=n...ei) de\ mh/—so iii. 101, prw=ton me\n ou)=n...e)/peita. For the alternative expression cf. ch. 63, 9. The addition of ou)=n is very unusual. pri/n ti e)ndou=nai: so ii. 12, ei)/ ti ma=llon e)ndoi=en. prokatalabw/n (ch. 89, 16) is to be taken with fqa/sai.

div2.head: CHAPTER CV
div2.p: dediw\s kai\ th/n—either kai/ is to be considered as out of place, or there is an irregularity in the next clause caused by the introduction of a second participle punqano/menos: cf. iii. 67, a)mu/nate ou)=n kai\ tw=| no/mw|...kai\ h(mi=n a)ntapo/dote xa/rin, where Poppo cites other instances.
kth=sin...e)rgasi/as—‘a right of working’: the gen. defines what the kth=sis or ‘property’ consisted of.

a)p' au)tou=—‘from this’. e)n toi=s prw/tois—masc.: so ch. 132, 13: cf. 108, 41. The influence and connexions of Thucydides in the Thraceward district probably caused him to be chosen for the command.
cummaxiko/n—‘an allied force’ (ch. 77, 13), in construction governed by a)gei/ranta. e)k qala/sshs—from Thasos and the neighbouring islands.
peripoih/sein—‘save’: iii. 102, periepoi/hsan to\ xwri/on (cf. ch. 27, 10, perigenh/sesqai): the middle means to win, acquire.

e)poiei=to—‘offered’, the imperfect implying the terms which ‘he was ready’ to make. to/de—predicate, ‘to the following effect’. For the construction following cf. ch. 68, 11. th=s i)/shs kai\ o(moi/as—cf. Poppo's note on i. 27, e)pi\ th=| i)/sh| kai\ o(moi/a|, and on i. 15, a)po\ th=s i)/shs. Whatever substantive be regarded as understood the meaning is ‘fair and equal terms’, = v. 79, e)pi\ toi=s i)/sois kai\ o(moi/ois. For other instances of feminine adjectives see note on ch. 33, 6.
pe/nte h(merw=n—‘within five days’.

div2.head: CHAPTER CVI
div2.p: a)lloio/teroi—‘more changed’ or ‘somewhat changed’: cf. ii. 59, h)lloi/wnto ta\s gnw/mas. In the following clause the subject oi( polloi/ is divided by partial apposition into two sections braxu\ me\n...to\ de\ plei=on: for neut. cf. ch. 61, 12, to\ *xalkidiko/n.
pro\s to\n fo/bon—‘in their fear’, lit. ‘looking at’, or ‘measuring it by’: cf. ch. 39, 9, pro\s th\n e)cousi/an.

e)la/mbanon—the better supported reading, for which some manuscripts have u(pela/mbanon. There are sufficient instances in which lamba/nw means ‘to take’ in the sense of regarding (accipere in aliquam partem); e.g. ii. 42, poqeinote/ran labo/ntes: iii. 38, pisto/teron labo/ntes: vi. 53, pa/nta u(po/ptws e/la/mbanon. Here however the reading is more doubtful, because of the infinitive construction, which is not found elsewhere with the uncompounded verb.

ou)k e)n o(moi/w|—this seems an instance of mei/wsis (ch. 13, 22), the sense being that the Athenians thought that they were in greater danger than the rest of the inhabitants: so vi. 11, mh\ e)n tw=| o(moi/w| kai\ pri\n e)pixeirh=sai, ‘in a worse position than before the attempt’. Classen takes the meaning to be that the Athenians thought that they would incur less danger by accepting the terms which Brasidas offered; but this does not agree so well with the context, especially considering the emphatic position of sfi/si and the statement that the Athenians ‘would be glad to depart’.

e)n tw=| i)/sw|—Poppo ‘aeque atque antea’; others ‘on equal terms’. Classen however seems right in taking the phrase as connecting the two following participial clauses, ‘at the same time’ they both retained (ou) sterisko/menoi) their rights as citizens and were freed from danger. The present (or imperfect) participles denote what was sure to be secured by the capitulation. For ou) sterisko/menoi ‘undeprived of’ cf. ch. 64, 22.

diadikaiou/ntwn—‘advocating’, not found elsewhere before Dio Cassius. au)ta/, in the general sense of ‘this’, denotes the claims of Brasidas, or the acceptance of his terms: cf. note on ch. 18, 7. prosede/canto—sc. Brasidas, or his terms.

kate/pleon—the use of the imperfect is to be remarked. Even as the ships ‘were sailing in’ Brasidas was in possession of Amphipolis and preparing an attack on Eion. Note the promptitude and energy with which this really great soldier followed up his success.

para\ nu/kta—‘he came within a night of taking Eion’: cf. viii. 76, par) e)la/xiston h)=lqe...a)fele/sqai, ‘came within a very little of taking away’: viii. 34, para\ tosou=ton e)ge/neto au)tw=| mh\ peripesei=n toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, ‘such a narrow escape had he of encountering the Athenians’: ii. 89, h(sshqe)ntas para\ polu/. Hence we get the phrase para\ tosou=ton e)lqei=n kindu/nou of a narrow escape from danger (iii. 49 and vii. 2).
a(/ma e(/w| a)\n ei)/xeto—‘it would have been in his hands at daybreak’: so e)xume/nhs at the beginning of ch. 108.

div2.head: CHAPTER CVII
div2.p: to\ au)ti/ka...to\ e)/peita—probably adverbial, Eion or ta\ e)n th=| *)hio/ni being the subject of e(/cei: cf. however ch. 54, 16. a)/nwqen—from Amphipolis, which was inland and up the river.

kata\ to\n potamo/n—‘by the river’, as opposed to kata\ gh=n: cf. ch. 25, 32. The words themselves may doubtless mean ‘secundo flumine’, as in Hdt. iii. 13, but this is sufficiently expressed by katapleu/sas.
a)po\ tou= tei/xous—to be taken with prou)/xousan: Poppo compares vii. 70, e)kra/toun tw=n tetagme/nwn new=n pro\s au)tw=|: cf. note on ch. 5, 10.

a/popeira/sas—‘having made an attempt’: cf. ch. 43, 24, e)pi\ th\n *solu/geian peira/sein. e)chrtu/eto—of material appliances generally: i. 13, nautika\ e)chrtu/eto: so act. ii. 3, ta)=lla e)ch/rtuon.
*goa/cios—Ionic gen.: so i. 64, *)afu/tios: v. 55, *kni/dios. Nothing more is known of the event here mentioned.
*perdi/kkas—in spite of his difference with Brasidas (ch. 83), Perdiccas came at once to share in his success, and to look after his own interests.

div2.head: CHAPTER CVIII
div2.p: This important chapter, a typical example of the writer's style, deals with the political situation after the capture of Amphipolis.

kai\ o)/ti...gegenh=sqai—the cause of Athenian alarm was that the capture of Amphipolis had removed the obstacles which had hitherto prevented the advance of the Spartans beyond the Strymon. This is stated in the final clause, to/te de/, k.t.l., the preceding part of the sentence being subordinate in sense though co-ordinate in form: cf. note on ch. 80, 18.

It is to be noticed that there are two clauses with de), th=s de\ gefu/ras line 7, and to/te de/ line 10. The sense is equivalent to pro/teron me/n (me/xri me/n...th=s de/)...to/te de/. The repeated me/n would however have been stiff and clumsy and is therefore avoided. For other instances of me/n followed by de/...de/, see Shilleto on i. 142.

me/xri me\n...proselqei=n—these words refer to the state of things before Amphipolis was taken. In themselves they are a good illustration of co-ordinate construction with me/n and de/:
‘though (hitherto) the Lacedaemonians might have got as far as the Strymon, yet they could have advanced no further without the command of the bridge’.
pa/rodos—ch. 82, 4. *qessalw=n diago/ntwn—‘if the Thessalians guided them’ or ‘gave them a passage’: cf. ch. 77, 6 and 12.

mh\ kratou/ntwn—‘but if they were not masters of the bridge, seeing that above the town the river formed a great lake, while on the side toward Eion they were watched by the enemy's triremes, they could not have pushed their advance’. The gen. abs. kratou/ntwn and throume/nwn refer to the Lacedaemonians, and supply the subject to du/nasqai. proselqei=n—the reading of the best manuscripts, ‘to get at’ the city or the allies. Most editors have proelqei=n, ‘to advance’. The words are perpetually confused.
e)pi\ polu/—‘extending far’. tou= potamou=—formed by the river. This lake is called in v. 7 to\ limnw=des tou= *strumo/nos. ta\ de\ pro/s—so ch. 23, 15.
ou)k a)\n du/nasqai—the original construction with o(/ti is now lost sight of, the inf. depending on the idea which is implied of what the Athenians said or thought.

to/te de/—now that Amphipolis was lost. The reading r(a/|dia is undoubtedly to be preferred to r(a|di/a (sc. h( pa/rodos), for the pa/rodos had been open all along. For the neut. plural cf. viii. 55, eu)fulakto/tera e)gi/gneto: iii. 16, a)/pora nomi/zontes. For e)nomi/zeto Classen reads e)no/mizon with some manuscript authority: several MSS. have e)no/mize.

a(\ pare/xetai—‘the terms (or advantages) which (Brasidas) offers’: see note on ch. 64, 1. There is some awkwardness in making Brasidas the subject of pare/xetai, which however is lessened by the fact that a)/lwsin is an active word = ‘his taking’. For the use of the following e)kei/nou cf. note on ch. 37, 10.

e)pekhrukeu/onto—‘made overtures’: ch. 27, 14. e)piparie/nai—lit. ‘to pass along to’. For keleu/ontes following po/leis cf. ch. 2, 15. For the order au)toi\ e)/kastoi cf. i. 105, e)no/misan au)toi\ e(ka/teroi ou)k e)/lasson e)/xein.

e)yeusme/nois—lit. ‘being deceived in (their estimate of) the Athenian power to as great an extent as that power proved great on trial’. The meaning is that they grossly underrated the power which Athens proved to possess; but this is expressed in a confused way, o(/sh being written (instead of o(/son mei/zwn h)\ w)/|onto or the like) as if ou) tosau/thn nomi/zousi had gone before. diefa/nh—‘proved on trial’; i. 18, tau=ta me/gista diefa/nh: vi. 17, diefa/nhsan tosou=toi o)/ntes.
kri/nontes—the construction is changed to the nom., as in ch. 52, 15: cf. ch. 23, 13. Note the alliteration in a)safei=...a)sfalei=.

ei)wqo/tes oi( a)/nqrwpoi—‘men being accustomed’; lit. ‘being accustomed, that is to say, men (being accustomed)’: the subject of the sentence, viz. the Athenian allies, is by expanded apposition extended to human beings in general. It is the exact converse of a partial apposition like dedio/tes oi\ strathgai/, i. 49.

ou(= me\n e)piqumou=sin—‘to commit what they desire to unreflecting hope, but to reject what they do not like by arbitrary reasoning’. e)lpi/di dido/nai, sc. tou=to, may be compared with ii. 42, e)lpi/di to\ a)fane\s e)pitre/yantes: the scholiast however understands e\autou/s.
o(\ de\ mh/—mh/ implies ‘such as’: ch. 32, 25. For prosi/entai cf. ch. 38, 3: and for diwqei=sqai, ch. 87, 7.

e)n toi=s *boiwtoi=s—‘in Boeotia’: as e)s tou\s *boiwtou/s (ch. 77, 4) means into Boeotia. peplhgme/nwn—of a defeat: so viii. 38: iii. 18, plhge/ntes u)po/: the aor. and perf. passive only are thus used.
e)folka/—in act. sense ‘attractive’, like e)pagwga/, ch. 88, 4: so Plat. Rep. 521 D, o(lko/s ‘tending to draw’. In Ar. Vesp. 268 e)folko/s has the middle or passive sense of ‘lagging behind’.

w(s au)tw=|...cumbalei=n—this sentence corresponds closely to the words of Brasidas in his speech at Acanthus, ch. 85, fin. The construction however is not so clear, and seems to require the addition of bohqh/santi. As the sentence stands, au)tw=| is governed directly by cumbalei=n, and e)pi\ *ni/saian might be connected with h)qe/lhsan cumbalei=n in the sense of attacking or approaching Nisaea. There is however the objection that it was Brasidas, not the Athenians, who approached Nisaea (ch. 69— 73); and though this difficulty would be removed by adopting the correction e)pi\ *nisai/a|, the words th=|...stratia=|, dat. of ‘the force which’ Brasidas had with him, stand most awkwardly without a participle.
e)pi\ sfa=s bohqh=sai—sc. to reduce them to obedience; cf. ch. 25, 35.

dia\ to\ h(donh\n e)/xon— = ‘because of the pleasure involved at the moment’: for e)/xw = ‘to cause, bring’, cf. note on ch. 1, 7. The use of neuter participles to express abstract ideas is characteristic of Thucydides: see the instances cited by commentators on i. 36, to\ me\n dedio\s...to\ de\ qarsou=n. to\ prw=ton—
‘for the first time’. Classen takes the phrase as meaning quam primum; but the stress of the sentence falls on o)rgw/ntwn, ‘with their hearts in it’; i.e. the allies were elated because now for the first time they felt that Sparta was taking up their cause with energy: cf. viii. 2, 2, o)rgw=ntes kri/nein ta\ pra/gmata, i.e. with excitement or enthusiasm: so ii. 85, o)rgh=| a)pe/stellon.
w(s—ch. 96, 4. e/c o/li/gou—‘at short notice’; also used of space.

e)fie/menos—either (1) ‘sending instructions’ or despatches; a rendering which gives good sense, but is open to the objection that ‘to enjoin’ is a meaning of e)fi/emai which appears confined to poetry: or (2) ‘eagerly desiring’ i.e. urgently. In the latter case e)s th\n *lakedai/mona must be taken with e(ke/leue.
stratia/n te...kai\ au)to/s—cf. ch. 77, 11, u(po/ te...kai\ au)to/s.
ta\ me\n...ta\ de/—i. 18, ta\ me\n polemou=ntes ta\ de\ spendo/menoi. fqo/nw| a)po/—‘from jealousy on the part of the leading men’. tou\s a)/ndras...komi/s asqai—cf. ch. 41, fin.

div2.head: CHAPTER CIX
div2.p: *megarh=s te ta/—the manuscripts have ta/ te, but as the particles connect the respective operations of the Megarians and of Brasidas, Krüger and others adopt the transposition suggested by Haacke; see note on ch. 77, 11.
a(\ sfw=n—the pronoun is placed in the relative clause: so ii. 45, paisi/, o(/soi tw=nde pa/reste, where Poppo cites several instances. For the Athenian occupation of the walls, see ch. 69.
e)s e)/dafos—so iii. 68, kaqelo/ntes e)s e)/dafos e)k tw=n qemeli/wn.

*)akth/n—(a)kth/, properly a headland or peninsula; see Liddell and Scott) the most easterly peninsula of Chalcidice. It is about 40 miles in length, and averages 4 in width: it is mountainous and rugged, especially towards Mount Athos. The latter name was often applied to the whole peninsula, which is joined to the mainland near Acanthus by a low and narrow isthmus. The following is the description given by Herodotus (vii. 22), o( ga\r *)/aqws e)sti\ o)/ros me/ga te kai\ ou)nomasto\n e)s qa/lassan kath=kon oi)khme/non u(po\ a)nqrw/pwn. th=| de\ teleuta=| e)s th\n h)/peiron to\ o)/ros, xersonhsoeide/s te/ e)sti kai\ i)sqmo\s w)s dw/deka stadi/wn: pedi/on de\ tou=to.

tou= basile/ws dioru/gmatos—the canal made by Xerxes; cf. Hdt. vii. 22 etc. Distinct traces of it remain. e)/sw prou)/xousa must mean ‘jutting out inwards’, i.e. into the sea; or according to Haack ‘intra Chersonesum’. Herodotus calls the towns of the peninsula ai( e)nto\s *sa/nhs. Krüger suggests e)/cw.

*)/aqws au)th=s...teleuta=|—au)th=s is either geographical gen. ‘situated in, belonging to it’; or is governed by teleuta/|, as in iii. 104, e)teleu/ta tou= e)pai/nou e)s ta/de ta\ e)/ph, ‘he ended his panegyric with these verses’. Mount Athos ‘forms the extremity of’ the peninsula, rising abruptly from the sea to a height of more than 6000 feet. The phrase teleuta=n e)s occurs ch. 48, 27.
e)s to\ pro\s *eu)/boian—Sane is on the isthmus and looks south: see Hdt. vii. 22, where the same list of six towns is given, Sane being distinguished as po/lis *(ella/s.
