diglw/sswn—speaking Greek besides their own tongue: viii. 85, *ka=ra di/glwsson.

*pelasgiko/n—See Grote Vol. ii., ch. 2 and 22; and the authorities cited by Poppo and Classen. *lh=mnon kai\ *)aqh/nas—see the account in Hdt. vii. 137—140. For the position of oi)khsa/ntwn cf. note on ch. 5, 10.

div2.head: CHAPTER CX
div2.p: *torw/nhn—the chief city in Sithonia, the middle Chalcidic peninsula; it was near its southern extremity.
peri\ o)/rqron—at the first glimmering of dawn: so iii. 112, a(/ma o)/rqrw| followed by nukto\s e)/ti ou)/shs: cf. Plat. Protag. init.

kai\ proselqo/ntes—‘and some few of them having indeed gone over to him’, i.e. to arrange terms, etc., a parenthetical statement of what had been done before: cf. ch. 72, 1. There is also good authority for proelqo/ntes ‘having advanced to meet him’. If this reading be adopted the comma may be removed after o)li/goi, and the order taken kai\...e)th/roun...kai\ e)skomi/zousi. tine\s o)li/goi—partial apposition.
tosou=toi mo/noi—so iii. 52, h)rw/twn tosou=ton mo/non. diadu/ntes—possibly where the wall had fallen (ch. 112). laqontes—‘without discovery’.

tou\s...frourou/s—governed by die/fqeiran. a)nw/tata— this is the only passage in which Thucydides has the superlative of a)/nw, ka/tw or pro/sw. a)nw/tata etc. are found in Herodotus, though not invariably, and in the tragedians: in later
Attic prose a)nwta/tw etc. (Krüger). Thucydides has e)ggu/tata v. 74, e)gguta/tw iii. 38. fulakthri/ou—‘a guard-post’: ch. 31, 7.
pro\s lo/fon—‘against (on the slope of) a hill’.

kata\ *kanastrai=on—‘over against Canastraeum’, the extreme point of the (western) peninsula of Pallene: Hdt. vii. 103. Note the difference of tense in die/fqeiran and dih/|roun, the assailants cut down the guard and then ‘set to work to force’ the postern. diairw=, ‘to break through’, is used of forcing an entrance through a puli/s in vi. 51: cf. ch. 48, 12: when used of a wall it means to make a breach, as in ii. 75 (with partitive gen.).

div2.head: CHAPTER CXI
div2.p: o(po/te...a)noixqei=en—this corresponds to o(po/tan a)noixqw=si with present tense; so ch. 32, 22, h(=| xwrh/seian, to\ shmei=on— cf. ch. 42, 23. cune/keito=pass. of cunti/qesqai, as in ch. 23, 4. Krüger quotes Ar. Eccles. 6, o(/rma flogo\s shmei=a ta\ cugkei/mena.

e)ggignome/nou—so i. 113, xro/nou e)ggenome/nou. The gen. absolute is connected by kai/ with a nom. participle, as in i. 65: cf. ch. 29, 1, etc. The tenses are to be noticed; the imperfect participle giving the ‘side-view’ (Clyde) of what went on for some time, the aorists the ‘end-view’ of the concluded fact that ‘little by little they had got close up to the city’.
oi( tw=n *torwnai/wn k.t.l.—we have a similar order in i. 126, oi( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn e)pitetramme/noi th\n fulakh/n: so iii. 22 etc. paraskeua/zontes=oi( pra/ssontes ch. 110.

au)toi=s—usually taken as ‘by them’, sc. toi=s ei)selhluqo/si. From its position however it seems rather the ethical dative, ‘when they (the conspirators) saw the postern forced’, or ‘when they (the forlorn hope) had got the postern open’.

ai( kata\ th
 a)gora/n—from what follows we see that ‘the market-gate’ was on the land side, opposite the ‘postern’. tou= moxlou=—the wooden bar which went across the gates on the inside; it was secured by inserting a pin (ba/lanos): cf. ii. 4; and comm. on Ar. Vesp. 200, th
 ba/lanon e)/mballe pa/lin e)s to
 moxlo/n.
periagago/ntes—outside the walls; e)seko/misan—going with kata\ th\n puli/da.
a)ne/sxon—so iii. 22, parani=sxon fruktou/s. Classen reads a)ni=sxon in the present passage, but here the aorist gives the better sense, referring to lighting one particular beacon.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXII
div2.p: to\ cu/nqhma—the signal agreed upon,=to\ cugkei/menon: so Hdt. viii. 7: often a watchword, as in vii. 44. e)/qei dro/mw|— so ch. 67, 25.

e)mboh/santa—=o)\s e)nebo/hse: Jowett compares ii. 68, *)/argos thn a)/llhn e)/ktise...*)/argos o)noma/sas: cf. Poppo on i. 18. a)qro/on is in agreement with strato/n: cf. ch. 34, 11: the word is generally used by Thucydides as a predicative adjective. Krüger points out that such constructions as a)qro/on e)mboh/santes (Heliodorus), which are found in later Greek, may have come from misunderstanding the Thucydidean construction.

e)se/pipton—so ch. 68, 21, of an enemy rushing in: Hdt. v. 15, e)spi/ptousi e)s ta\s po/lias. kata\ dokou\s tetragw/nous —‘i.e. planks, which formed an inclined plane from the ground to the top of the broken wall, for the purpose of drawing up stones. Thus queen Nitocris laid cu/la tetra/gwna, or planks across the piers of her bridge at Babylon (Hdt. i. 186), ep' w)=n th\n diabasin e)poieu=nto oi( *babulw/nioi’ (Arnold).
a)nolkh/n—not found elsewhere in classical Greek. proskei/menai—‘put against’,=perf. pass. of prosti/qhmi.
kai\ to\ plh=qos—‘with the bulk of his troops’ (ch. 100, 25), the construction of participle and verb referring to Brasidas alone. e)pi\ ta\ mete/wra—so iii. 72: cf. ch. 32, 15.

kat' a)/kras—‘from top to bottom’, i.e. utterly: Hdt. vi. 18, ai(re/ousi kat' a)/krhs: Hom. etc., see Lid. and Scott. ‘An expression borrowed from the seizure of the citadel, always situated in ancient towns in the highest part of the city, and the consequent easy reduction of the whole place’ (Arnold). Thucydides uses the phrase in this passage only, where the literal and metaphorical meanings are both applicable.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXIII
div2.p: oi)=s tau=ta h)/reske—Classen reads tau(ta/, on the ground that there is nothing sufficiently definite for tau=ta to refer to. In line 5 he alters kaqeu/dontes into e)kkaqeu/dontes, ‘sleeping out of their quarters’, i.e. stationed as a watch; a word which is found only in Xen. Hel. ii. 4. 24.

au)tw=n—with oi( me/n tines: there is a similar order in i. 21, ta\ polla\ u)po\ xro/nou au)tw=n, k.t.l. ai(\ e)frou/roun du/o— the numeral is put predicatively in the relative clause; so vii. 43, ta\ strato/peda a)\ h)=n e)pi\ tw=n *)epipolw=n tri/a: cf. the construction of sfw=n in ch. 109. 2: o(/sai h)=san tw=n teqnew/twn, i. 8.
e)s th\n *lh/kuqon to\ frou/rion—similar instances of the article are noted on ch. 66, 21. au)toi/—emphatic, as in ch. 66, 23, e)n h(=| au)toi\ mo/noi e)frou/roun.

katalabo/ntes—probably to be taken with ei)=xon, ‘which they had occupied and held’: a)/kron is then in apposition with *lh/kuqon. In Poppo's edition there is a comma after au)toi/, and a)/kron is governed directly by katalabo/ntes.

a)/kron—a promontory or ‘end’ of the city. e)s th\n qa/lassan a/peilhmme/non—‘projecting into the sea and cut off by a narrow isthmus’: for a)polamba/nw cf. ch. 45, 9. e)n seems to designate the physical point at or in which the cutting off from the mainland was effected: cf. ch. 120, 18.

e)s au)tou/s—here ‘to join them’: the preposition is in fact used of approach in any form: see note on ch. 95, 11. sfi/si refers to the main subject of the sentence, the Athenians; so vii. 70, pantaxo/qen sfi/si...e)piferome/nwn, where the pronoun refers to the subject of the sentence before.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXIV
div2.p: meta\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn...katapefeugo/si—‘who had taken refuge with’: cf. ch. 16, 8. The position of the participle is in accordance with examples noted on ch. 5, 10.
spei/sasqai—spe/ndomai here takes dat. of the person and acc. of the thing granted: cf. iii. 109, a)naxw/rhsin ou)k e)spe/ndonto a(/pasin: so iii. 114.
e)kratu/nato—ch. 52, 15: the aor. implies the completion of his works. ta\ sfe/tera—their position.
cu/llogon poih/sas—the usual phrase for convening an assembly: i. 67: ii. 59. Classen notes on i. 71 that e)/lece as used by Thucydides implies a set speech.

toi=s e)n th=| *)aka/nqw|—sc. lexqei=si: cf. ch. 85—88. Here too Brasidas disclaims all partizanship, and declares that the Spartans only desire the general good of Greece: cf. ch. 108, 14, pantaxou= e)dh/lou w(s e)leuqerw/swn th\n *)ella/da e)kpemfqei/h.
pra/cantas...th\n lh=yin—so iii. 75, cu/mbasin e)/prasse: cf. ch. 76, 6. The word has its usual meaning of political arrangements or intrigue. xei/rous—iii. 9, xei/rous h(gou=ntai.

ou)de\ ga...ou)de/—not to be confused with ou)/te. ou)/te, neither...nor, particles which connect two corresponding
negative expressions, as in the main divisions of the present sentence. There is no mutual co-relation in ou)de)...ou)de/, any more than in de/...de/. Here the first ou)de/ (=also not) connects what follows with what has gone before, the second is the usual conjunction in a negative sentence, and should be rendered or. The sense is ‘for neither did they do it (i.e. moreover they did not do it) from a wish to enslave their country or because they had been bribed’: i. 76, ou)d' h)mei=s qaumasto
 ou)de
 pepoih/kamen ou)de\ a)po\ tou= a)nqrwpei/ou tro/pou, ‘neither have we (any more than you) done anything strange or out of the way of men’: cf. i. 142, kai\ mh
 ou)d' h( e)pitei/xisis ou)de\ to\ nautiko
 au)tw=n a)/cion fobhqh=nai, ‘nor yet again is there need to fear their hostile occupation or their naval power’.
e)pi\ doulei/a|—‘to enslave their country’: ii. 71, e)pi\ doulei/a| th=| h\mete/ra| h)/kete. metasxo/ntas—so ch. 76, metei=xon, without an object expressed.

ou)d' a)/n—=‘nor when you have made trial of us Lacedaemonians do I think you will be less friendly to us’. a)/n belongs to gene/sqai and is repeated later on: see note on ch. 18, 18. au)tou/s is the subject of dokei=n. The whole sentence is somewhat awkward, the order being complicated by the insertion of the semi-parenthetical words a)lla\ pollw=|...pra/ssousin.

tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn—so i. 144, sfi/si toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois: Hdt i. 4, sfe/as tou\s e)k th=s *)asi/hs, etc. The construction is used to emphasize the contrast between two sets of people. Sometimes indeed, as in viii. 46, such appositional words look like a marginal note which has got into the text. But this cannot be the case when we have them in oratio directa, as in ii. 72, h\mi=n toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois.
tou/s te pa/ntas—‘so now he called upon the whole body’, whatever their individual sympathies might have been hitherto. te sums up and concludes.

to\ a/po\ tou=de—‘henceforward’; so ii. 46. h(/dh emphasizes the speaker's significant warning, ‘from this moment you will be held responsible for any misconduct’. For ai)ti/an e)/xein cf. i. 83, to\ ple/on th=s ai)ti/as e(/comen.
sfei=s—not sfa=s, as in ch. 36, 3, because Brasidas represents the Lacedaemonian nation: cf. v. 55: viii. 76.
cuggiw/mhn ei)=nai—so viii. 50 with inf.: in nom. without e)sti/, i. 32, cuggnw/mh ei): v. 88, with inf.: cf. ch. 61, 21.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXV
div2.p: ta\s prosbola\s e)poiei=to—‘began his assault’. The aorists which follow give an ‘end-view’ of the result of the first day's action.

h)mu/nanto/ te—either te connects the following substantives and is out of place, as ch. 9, 7; or it joins h)mu/nanto with a)pekrou/santo, the latter word being originally intended to end the sentence.

prosa/cesqai—pass.: so Aesch. Ag. 1632, a)/cei (2nd. sing.): Plat. Rep. 458 D, a)/contai. In chapter 87, 17 we have prosaxqh/sesqe. Neither future is common, as will be seen by referring to Veitch's Greek Verbs.

a)po\ tw=n e)nanti/wn—‘on the part of, from the side of the enemy’: cf. ch 76, 6 note. e)nh/sein—fut. as in ch. 121, 5. Krüger on i. 27, e)deh/qhsan...cumprope/myein, gives several instances of similar construction.
parafra/gmata—‘a breastwork’, only used in plural: vii. 25, of a ship, pu/rgous te culi/nous e(/xousa kai( parafra/gmata: Plat. Rep. 514 B, of a screen for a puppet-show.
h(=|...ma/lista—cf. ch. 9, 19: and for e)pi/maxos ch. 4, 13.
labo/n—ch. 69, 16.

e)lu/phse—vexed or annoyed. Classen points out that Grote's statement, ‘some of these men were hurt’, does not agree with the context. dia\ plei/stou—‘furthest off’: ch. 14, 5, dia\ braxe/os: ii. 29, dia\ tosou/tou, ‘such a (short) distance off’.
tau/th|—‘at this point’; cf. line 9, h(=| w)/|onto k.t.l.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXVI
div2.p: w(s h)/|sqeto...o(rw=n—o(rw=n=w(s e(w/ra: cf. notes on i. 1, tekmairo/menos o)/ti a)kma/zonte/s te h)=san...kai\ o(rw=n=o)/ti e(w/ra. te and kai/ connect the two actual things with which the sentence deals: cf. ch. 28, 21.
e)pifero/menos—iii. 23, au)toi=s e)pefe/ronto.
toi/s ploi/ois—the merchant vessels in the harbour.

prosba/llein—so Poppo, Krüger, etc. Most manuscripts have ba/llein, which may possibly mean ‘to throw (fire)’, from the machine spoken of in ch. 115, 6. prw/tw| is joined with a participle, like teleutai=os, ch. 38, 17.
a)pe/dwken—‘paid’, as being due: see note on this force of a)po/ in composition, ch. 39, 15. e)s to\ i(ero/n—in usum fani (Poppo).

a)naskeua/sas—the converse of kataskeua/sas. After dismantling (kaqelw/n) the fortifications, Brasidas cleared away the remains of the military and secular occupation of the place. Göller understands it of removing the furniture of the houses. In i. 18, a)naskeuasa/menoi is used of the Athenians who dismantled their abodes when invaded by the Persians.

te/menos a)nh=ken—‘dedicated it all as sacred ground’. a(ni/hmi, to leave untilled, give up as sacred: Isocr. Plat. 302 th\n xw/ran a/nei=nai mhlo/boton, of the soil of Plataeae: Hdt. ii. 65, a)nei=tai ta\ i(ra/. Note a(/pan in agreement with te/menos.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXVII
div2.p: A truce is now concluded for one year. The serious losses of the Athenians in Boeotia and Thrace disposed them to listen to terms; while the Lacedaemonians were more anxious to recover their men than to encourage Brasidas to attempt further conquests.

nomi/santes *)aqhnai=oi me/n—cf. ch. 1, 5, e)/pracan de\ oi( me\n...oi\ de/ k.t.l. ou)k a)\n e)/ti prosaposth=sai—‘could win over no more (pro/s) of their possessions after this’; in other words, they thought that a truce would give them time to secure the rest of their dependencies. a)fi/sthmi, in the sense of ‘causing to revolt’, occurs i. 81: the intransitive tenses are much more common.
pri\n paraskeua/sainto—the regular construction after a negative with a past tense; Goodwin, § 67. 1.

kai\ cumbh=nai—the sense required is ‘thinking that they might make peace’, or ‘wishing or designing to make peace’. It seems possible that the original participle nomi(santes is lost sight of, while the infinitive is governed by the idea of wishing or intending supplied from what has gone before. According to Poppo however cumbh=nai depends directly on nomi/santes, which in this second clause is to be understood in a different sense, nomi/zw sometimes being equivalent to cogito, in animo habeo: see note on ch. 86, 16: and for the whole construction cf. ch. 3, 21. Krüger proposes ka)\n cumbh=nai.
ta\ plei/w—cognate accusative, ‘to make a more general peace’: cf. ch. 30, 23.
tau=ta a(/per e)/deisan—i.e. the loss of more towns, which would revolt to Brasidas, if the Athenians had not time for due preparation; see line 5.

a/nakwxh=s—a Thucydidean word, which has this form on the invariable authority of the manuscripts; though according to analogy and derivation it should be a)nokwxh/: see Lid. and Scott, and Poppo on i. 40.

peirasame/nous—after they had once tasted the blessings of peace. e)s to\n plei/w xro/non—so v. 15, peri\ tou= plei/onos xro/nou, contrasted with a year's armistice. The comparative is to be explained as noted on ch. 17, 17: it ‘means the period of several years, generally stipulated in a treaty of peace, as opposed to the brief interval of a mere truce’ (Arnold).

tou\s ga\r dh\ a)/ndras...krath/sein—in the following notes it is at first assumed that this sentence is descriptive of the actual feelings of the Lacedaemonians: a different view is noticed afterwards.

peri\ plei/onos—if the reading w(s e)/ti is right, the meaning seems to be, ‘they were more anxious to recover their men, as (because) Brasidas was still successful’, i.e. they now saw a chance of concluding negotiations with Athens, and this increased their anxiety to get the men back. So we read in v. 16, that the party desirous of peace ‘became much more eager’ (pollw=| dh\ ma=llon proequmou=nto), when they saw a prospect of it. This view agrees with what is said in v. 15, that the Spartans increased their efforts to obtain terms, as soon as the Athenians had been defeated at Delium.

Some editors regard w(s e)/ti as equivalent to dum, a very questionable interpretation, cf. ch. 76, 6: others read e(/ws, in accordance with the scholiast on Ar. Pax, 475, where the passage is cited with e(/ws o(/te. In either case peri\ plei/ouos is explained by what follows, the sense being that the Lacedaemonians attached greater importance to the immediate recovery of the captives while Brasidas was still successful, than to the possibility of future conquests with the risk of losing their men; cf. ch. 108, 42, ta\ de\ kai\ boulo/menoi ma=llon k.t.l. For the phrase peri\ plei/onos poiei=sqai, ‘to esteem of greater value’, cf. ii. 89, peri\ plei/stou h(gei=sqe: Hdt. i. 73, peri\ pollou= poieo/menos au(tou/s.

kai\ e)/mellon—‘and they were likely, if he carried his successes further, and placed the contending parties on equal terms, to lose their citizens who had been taken at Sphacteria, though they might be finally victorious in the struggle with Athens’. See the following notes for discussion of details.

e)pi\ mei=zon—cf. i. 17, e)pi\ plei=ston e)xw/rhsan duna/mews: i. 118, e)pi\ me/ga e)xw/rhsan duna/mews. a)nti/pala katasth/santos—lit. ‘if he made things equally balanced’: cf. vii. 13, e)peidh\ e)s a)nti/pala kaqesth/kamen: neut. plur. as in ch. 108. It would seem that the Lacedaemonians did not consider that Brasidas was yet on terms of equality with the enemy in Thrace notwithstanding his great successes. Possibly they did not appreciate the importance of his conquests; at any rate we have already seen that their leading men were not desirous of forwarding his enterprise (ch. 108 fin.). Grote supposes the words to mean ‘if he should put himself and his newly-acquired gains in battle-front against the enemy’, i.e. if he should risk losing his conquests by attempting more: but though the sense may be good it is not to be found in the Greek. Moreover, though any further success on the part of Brasidas would put the Spartans in a better position to dictate terms in general, it would certainly interfere with the immediate recovery of the captives, which was the thing they now had most at heart.

tw=n me\n ste/resqai—either ‘to remain deprived of them’ for an indefinite time (Jowett); or ‘to be deprived of them’ by their being put to death. The Athenians had determined to kill the captives in case of any invasion of Attica (ch. 41, 5); and there was therefore reason to fear that they might kill them in exasperation at their losses in Thrace.

toi=s de/—either (1) to be taken as instrumental dative with a)muno/menoi, ‘defending themselves, keeping up the struggle, with the others’, i.e. with the rest of their forces as opposed to the captives: so i. 69, th=| duna/mei a)muno/menoi: vi. 82, du/namin h)=| a)munou/meqa: or (2) ‘as for the Athenians’, i.e. in the contest against them; an ethical dative like ch. 10, 13, u(poxwrh/sasi: ch. 56, 1, toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: ch. 73, 27, toi=s de/. In (1) two parts of the Spartan forces are contrasted with me/n and de/: while (2) contrasts their captured friends with their enemies.

kinduneu/ein kai\ krath/sein—As these words stand they must mean ‘to have a chance of future victory’; lit. ‘to be likely also to prove victorious’. This force of kinduneu/w however, which is common in Plato and Xenophon, is not found elsewhere in Thucydides, except perhaps in vi. 87, mh\ a)deei=s ei)=nai kinduneu/ein. In other passages the meaning with the inf. is ‘to be in danger of’, e.g. vii. 40, tou= panto\s kinduneu=sai diafqarh=nai. The rendering ‘to be in danger of losing final victory’ is good in sense, but does not lie in the words. kai/ ‘also’ emphasizes krath/sein,=actually, eventually. For the future cf. ch. 126, 34, e)kfobh(sein.

It will be seen that it is possible to give a fairly satisfactory sense to the words as they stand in the text. There is however
a difficulty in the final clauses tw=n me
...toi=s de/. The sense required is clearly, ‘though they might be finally victorious, they were certain to lose their men’. We should therefore expect toi=s me
...krath/sein tw=n de\ ste/resqai, the clause with me/n being subordinate in sense to that with de/. Here however the order is reversed. Jowett compares ii. 42, tou\s me
 timwrei=sqai tw=n d' e/fi/esqai. ‘The emphasis’, he says, ‘is on tw=n me
 ste/resqai: the antithetical form has got the better of the logical point of the sentence’. In ch. 121, 19 we have a somewhat similar inversion.

To obviate the difficulty arising from the order of me/n and de/, as well as from the doubtful meaning which the text obliges us to attach to kinduneu/ein, it has been proposed to read mh\ krath/sein or krath/sesqai (passive) instead of krath/sein. We thus get the sense ‘they were sure to lose their men, and would be in danger of final defeat besides’.

It remains to notice the view of the whole passage which was suggested by Herbst, and is adopted by Classen. It is that Thucydides is giving in his own words the ideas, not of the Lacedaemonians, but of the Athenians; in fact explaining the words a)/per e)/deisan in line 8. The Athenians thought that the Lacedaemonians were now likely to offer acceptable terms, and they were not unwilling to listen to their offers; for if Brasidas pursued his victorious career, the opportunity would be lost, and the chance was that the Lacedaemonians, though they lost their captives, might prove victorious in the end.

Herbst and Classen attach particular force to w(s e)/ti *brasi/das eu)tu/xei, to which they give the meaning ‘with his present limit of success’, i.e. before his conquests gave the Spartans an overwhelming advantage. At present they valued the recovery of the men more highly (peri\ plei)onos) than might be the case hereafter, when they could insist on terms. (See Appendix.)

div2.head: CHAPTER CXVIII
div2.p: Terms of the truce for one year. It appears to have been drawn up and agreed to at Sparta, and then sent to Athens for ratification there: see Arnold's note. The main provisions of the treaty concern (1) the temple at Delphi: (2) the retaining by both sides of possessions and conquests: (3) rights at sea: (4) arrangements for further negotiation, arbitration, etc.

peri\ me\n tou= i(erou=—‘a concession to Athens, as the Delphians were always so strongly attached to Lacedaemon, that the Athenians would find it difficult during the war to have access to the temple at all’ (Arnold).
dokei= h(mi=n—i.e. this is what we are ready to agree to, and offer for your acceptance.
xrh=sqai—so i. 126, without case, xrwme/nw| e)n *delfoi=s, ‘consulting the oracle’: here the word contains also the idea of access in general.
e)s du/namin—so viii. 27, in a negative sentence.

peri\ de\ tw=n xrhma/twn—editors agree that this is a general provision, not referring to any particular misuse of the sacred treasures that had lately taken place. In 432 we find the Corinthian envoys proposing to borrow the money at Delphi and Olympia for war purposes (i. 121); and this article may be directed against such appropriation, though if so it is very vaguely expressed.

peri\ me
 ou)=n tou/twn—these words plainly refer to what has gone before, while ta/de refers to what follows. The reading in the text is that which is approved by Poppo and adopted by Arnold and Classen. In the great majority of manuscripts the words e)a
 sponda/s k.t.l. follow immediately after cumma/xois in line 13, a whole line being omitted, as might easily happen from the recurrence of the same form of words. It has indeed been proposed to take the manuscript reading thus: ‘this is agreed to by the Lacedaemonians, on condition that the Athenians stipulate (e)a
 sponda\s poiw=ntai k.t.l.) that each side remain in possession etc.’ But it is much more likely that the several articles of the treaty should follow separately, dependent on e)/doce expressed or implied.
e)a\n sponda/s—i.e. if the Athenians shall agree. Krüger suggests e)/st' a)/n, till a more general treaty be made.

e)/xontas a(/per—so i. 140, ei/rhme/non e)/xein e)kate/rous a)/ e)/xomen. *korufasi/w|—the Spartan name for Pylos, ch. 3, 16. These clauses refer to the positions in Peloponnesus which were occupied by Athenian garrisons.
e)nto\s th=s *boufra/dos k.t.l.—apparently points on the coast: nothing certain seems known of them.

e)n *kuqh/rois—ch. 54. mh\ e)pimisgome/nous—‘should hold no intercourse with any part of the territory of the Peloponnesian confederacy’ (Arnold): i. 13, par' a)llh/lous e)pimisgo/ntwn: so ii. 1, e)pimi/gnunto par' a)llh/lous: i. 2, e)pimi/gnuntes a)llh/lois. h( cummaxi/a—either the allies or their territory: so v. 33.

e)n *nisai/a|—ch. 69. para\ tou= *ni/sou—i.e. from the temple or statue of Nisus: cf. note on ch. 67, 9. a)po\ tou= *nisai/ou (neut.) is also read. Dobree suggests para\ to\ *ni/sou,
‘by the temple of Nisus’, comparing Ar. Lys. 835, para\ to\ th=s *xlo/hs. For Nisus, a mythical king of Megara, see Class. Dict.

eu)qu\s e)pi\ th\n ge/furan—‘straight to the bridge’. This bridge crossed the shallow lagoon (te/nagos) which separated Minoa from the main land, cf. iii. 51. By th\n nh=son is meant Minoa, which the Athenians had taken in 427.

ta\ e)n *troich=ni—sc. e)/xontas, referring to the Athenian occupation of Methone, ch. 45. It was ‘in the neighbourhood or district of’ Troezen: for which use of e)n cf. ch. 5, 5, e)n tai=s *)aqh/nais w)/n. The subject of cune/qento is apparently the people of Troezen, and we must suppose that they had made some arrangement with the Athenian garrison. Arnold originally considered that e(kate/rous e)/xein should be understood after ta\ e)n *troizh=ni, and that oi(=a cune/qento refers to the Lacedaemonians, and denotes the terms of the thirty years peace of 445, by which they recovered possession of Troezen (i. 115). The meaning would then be that the Athenians should keep the peninsula of Methone, and the Peloponnesians the rest of the district.

th=| qala/ssh| xrwme/nous—to be connected with what follows, ‘as for access to the sea, the Lacedaemonians may sail’ etc. o(/sa a)/n—with subj. implied, ‘so far as they may (sail)’. Krüger omits a)/n, comparing ch. 48, 28; but in a limiting clause like this, referring to future time, it seems decidedly in place.

a)/llw| de\ kwph/rei ploi/w|—a)/llw| ‘other’ than a nau=s makra/. A further restriction is enacted, that only rowing vessels be allowed, and the size of these is strictly limited. Arnold considers that the intention of the Athenians was not only to secure their naval supremacy, but also ‘to stop the commerce of Peloponnesus, and particularly their trading voyages eastward to Egypt and Phoenicia, which could only be performed in o(lka/des worked by sails’.

e)s pentako/sia—‘up to (i.e. not exceeding) five hundred talents burden’. ‘As to the amount of tonnage, the word me/tra would seem to shew that it was calculated according to the form and dimensions of the vessel, as with us. If mere weight were meant, five hundred talents would be about twelve tons’ (Arnold). We have a ship's burden expressed in similar terms Hdt. ii. 96, a)/gei e)/nia polla\s xilia/das tala/ntwn: id. i. 194, ta\ me/gista pentakisxili/wn tala/ntwn go/mon e)/xei. In vii. 25 a nau=s muriofo/ros is mentioned, meaning probably one of 10,000 talents burden. In Latin the burden was calculated in amphorae.
presbei/a|—so i. 72, e)/tuxe presbei/a parou=sa. sponda/s =‘safe-conduct’.
di/kas dido/nai—‘to submit to judgment or arbitration’: i. 28, di/kas h)/qelon dou=nai: i. 85 etc. ta\ a)mfi/loga—so v. 79: cf. i. 78, ta\ dia/fora di/kh| lu/esqai.
a)posth/sontai—‘will hang back from’, i.e. decline, refuse; more usually of giving up or renouncing.

te/los e)/xontes—‘with full powers’; te/los here is the power of concluding terms: in v. 41 te/los e)/xein means to be finally arranged. From these and the following words it appears that communications had already passed between Athens and Lacedaemon: probably commissioners from Athens had been present in Sparta, and had taken part in drawing up the treaty, though they were not authorized to complete the settlement.

e)/doce tw=| dh/mw|—the formal resolution of the dh=mos in the e)kklhsi/a, preceded by the names of the prutaneu/ousa fulh/, the clerk, and the president of the day. So in the preamble of a law cited by Andocides de Myst. 13 (48), e)/doce th=| boulh=| kai\ tw=| dh/mw|. Ai/anti\s e)pruta/neue, *kleoge/nhs e)gramma/teue, *bohqo\s e)pesta/tei: see Class. Dict.

ei)=pe—‘moved’, with inf., the usual phrase. tu/xh| a)gaqh=|—the usual form of invoking good fortune, see Lid. and Scott: cf. Cic. Div. i. 45. 102, maiores...omnibus rebus agendis quod bonum faustum felix fortunatumque esset praefabantur.

a)/rxein de/—lit. ‘that this day begin it’: so v. 19, a)/rxei tw=n spondw=n a)/rxwn *)alkai=os, ‘the truce dates from the archonship of Alcaeus’: cf. Dem. Timocr. 713, ei) (no/mw|) prosge/graptai xro/nos o(/ntina dei= a)/rxein, where, as Arnold rightly observes, o(/ntina refers to xronos: so Ar. Pac. 436, th\n nu=n h(me/ran...a)/rcai.
tou\s lo/gous—poiei=sqai lo/gous=‘to confer, negotiate, make proposals’; the definite article implies conducting the stipulated or necessary negotiations for concluding peace.

tou\s strathgou/s—they had the right to call (poiei=n) extraordinary meetings of the assembly: so ii. 59, of Pericles, cu/llogon poih/sas, e)/ti d) e)strath/gei: cf. the decree cited Dem. de Cor. 249, e)kklhsi/a su/gklhtos u(po\ strathgw=n: where also the strategi and prytanes are named together as conducting public business.

In construction this clause seems defective, no verb following: cf. ch. 40, 6, a)pistou=nte/s te k.t.l. Classen however considers that tou\s *(aqhnai/ous stands in apposition to tou\s strathgou\s kai\ tou\s pruta/neis, as in ch. 108, 25.

kaq' o(/ ti a)
 e)si/h|—as the reading stands, I believe that it can only mean ‘in whatever way the embassy may be introduced’: cf. leg. ap. Dem. Timocr. 715, kaq' o(/ ti a)
 dokh=|, ‘in whatever way shall seem fit’. bouleu/sasqai then stands absolutely, and the sense is that the final decision (about the treaty) shall rest with the public assembly, whether the envoys be brought before that assembly or whatever arrangements be made. As however kaq' o(/ ti is perpetually used in the language of decrees for making provision ‘as to how’ something is to be done, we should expect that here too it would introduce a relative clause dependent on bouleu/sasqai ‘the Athenians to decide in what way’ etc. According to the regular and common construction it would then be followed by the future indicative, as in line 56. Poppo suggests the deliberative e)si/h| without a)/n, or e)si/oi a)/n, which would be nearly equivalent to a future indicative. He points out however that a)/n is at times added to o(/pws in similar sentences (e.g. Plat. Protag. 326 A, e)pimelou=ntai o(/pws a)
 mhde
 kakourgw=si), and retains ‘verba omnium membranarum consensu stabilita’.

spei/sasqai—‘do hereby agree’: the aor. denotes the arrangement as concluded at once, as is further expressed by au)ti/ka ma/la. e)mmenei=n e)n—Krüger proposes to omit e)n, as e)mme/nw in the sense of ‘abiding by’ an agreement takes the simple dative elsewhere in Thucydides. We have however, Plat. Legg. 844 C, e)mme/nwn e)n th=| ta/cei, ‘abiding by the arrangement’, and, according to Poppo, the preposition is added in inscriptions and in later Greek. In ii. 23 we have e)mmei/nantes e)n th=| *)attikh=|.
to\n e)niauto)n—for the stipulated year, even if no further peace were made.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXIX
div2.p: kai\ w)/mosan—if the order is right the meaning is ‘and the allies also swore to it’. Some manuscripts however have kai\ w)/mosan *lakedaimo/nioi. Krüger reads tau=ta cune)qento *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ oi\ cu/mmaxoi...kai\ w)/mosan *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ oi\ cu/mmaxoi. w(molo/ghsan is also read instead of w)/mosan.

mhno\s...dwdeka/th|—‘it appears that this truce was signed two days later in the month at Athens than at Lacedaemon; and the peace concluded two years afterwards was signed two days later at Lacedaemon than at Athens (v. 19). Further the Spartan month Gerastius here corresponds with the Attic month Elaphebolion, but there we find that Elaphebolion corresponds with the Spartan Artemisius’. This is
from Arnold's note. He considers that owing to the system of intercalation, the details of which varied in different places, the same months at Athens and Sparta might no longer correspond with each other after an interval of two years. Grote supposes, with Poppo, that the fourteenth of Elaphebolion and the twelfth of Gerastius designate the same day. In any case e)n *lakedai/moni is to be joined with umno\s *gerasti/ou.

cuneti/qento de/—the imperfect, as in v. 19, w)/mnuon de\ kai\ e)spe/ndonto, gives the details of executing the treaty, as opposed to the concluded fact designated by the aorist in lines 1 and 14. The treaty was signed on the one hand by representatives of Sparta, Corinth, Sicyon, Megara and Epidaurus; on the other hand by three of the Athenian strategi.

*tau=ros *)exetimi/da—Krüger points out that in public documents the article never precedes the genitive: Dem. de. Cor. 235, *dhmosqe)nhs *dhmosqe)nous *paianeu\s ei)=pen: but *kle/wn o( *kleaine)tou, *brasi/das o( *te/llidos, in historical description. Note the Doric gen. of the first declension in a=ou.

*)erucidai+/da—‘corrige *)erucilai+/da pro absurdo nomine’ (Cobet). *ai)ne/as—the same form occurs in the Acts of the Apostles, ix. 33: in Xen. Anab. iv. 7. 13, *ai)nei/as is read; and the scholiast on Ar. Eq. 791, citing the present passage, so spells the name. According to Poppo both forms are right.
au(/th—predicate, ‘on the aforesaid terms: iii. 28, h( cu/mbasis au(/th e)ge/neto.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXX
div2.p: ai)=s e)ph/rxonto—‘were going to and fro, communicating with each other’. Cobet regards these words as part of an ‘insulsa annotatiuncula’ incorporated with the text, (the remaining words of) the scholiast's note being ei/s a)llh/lous e(ka/teroi. The imperfect of e)/rxomai and its compounds is rarely, if ever, found in Attic Greek, and is considered quite inadmissible in prose by many critics. Some editors accordingly would substitute e)ph=|san. Herbst suggests that e)ph/rxonto comes from e)pa/rxomai and means ‘making offerings in ratification of the treaty’, e)pi/ implying ‘one after the other’. This view is adopted by Classen. A similar difficulty occurs in ch. 121, 9. The article on e)/rxomai in Veitch's Greek Verbs should be carefully studied.
*pellhnh=s—Pellene was the most easterly city in Achaia, not far from Sicyon. The *pellhnh=s are mentioned in ii. 9 as allies of Sparta: cf. v. 58.

katenexqh=nai—ch. 3, 9. tw=| xeimw=ni—cf. vi. 2, *fwke/wn tine\s tw=n a)po\ *troi/as xeimw=ni...e)s *sikeli/an katenexqe/ntes. The storm which shattered and dispersed the victorious Grecian armament is an essential part of the tale of Troy. e)xrh/santo —cf. Dem. de Cor. 293, xeimw=ni xrhsa/menon. *)axaioi/ is one of the Homeric terms for the Greeks generally: i. 3, *danaou\s kai\ *)argei/ous kai\ *)axaiou\s a(nakalei=: so vi. 2, *trw/wn tine\s diafugo/ntes *)axaiou/s.
oi)kh=sai—the aorist=‘settled, took up their abode’.
trih/rei—dative ‘of accompaniment’, like a)/ras stratw=|. Brasidas seems to have crossed from Torone. a)poqen—’at some distance’: many manuscripts have a)/pwqen, the older form (see Lid. and Scott).

a)mu)nh|—the subj. is the best-supported reading: so vii. 4, o(/pws oi( *)aqhnai=oi, ei) mh\ du/nainto kwlu=sai, mhke/ti oi(=oi/ te w)=sin a)poteixi/sai: cf. note on ch. 1, 13. au)tw=| means the ke/lhs, but the pronoun is doubtful, and ought perhaps to be omitted. Most manuscripts have au)th=|, which is plainly wrong; nor is the proposed au)th/ ‘of itself’ or ’by its mere appearance’ much more satisfactory.

a)ntipa/lou—‘of equal strength’. Note the change of construction in the latter part of the sentence. After the gen. abs., instead of a clause corresponding to o)/pws a)mu/nh|, the participle nomi/zwn is introduced, in a somewhat similar way to o(rw=n, ch. 116, 3: the subject of tre/yesqai is to be supplied from the gen. abs.: while the original subject, Brasidas, is the subject of diasw/sein.

fa/skwn—this participle comes in awkwardly, corresponding to a(/ te in the previous clause: the awkwardness is however lessened by the fact that e)/lege is not simply ‘said’, but ‘began a set speech’: ch. 114, 14.
e)n tw=| i)sqmw=|—for this use of e)n see note on ch. 113, 12. ou)de\n a)/llo h)/—ch. 14, 20.
prosgene/sqai—here ‘to be applied, brought to bear’, not ‘to be added’. Compare the language of Brasidas at Acanthus, ch. 87.

ei) teqh/setai—if their political wishes can be carried out: cf. eu)= ti/qesqai etc. Krüger and Classen read ei)/ te teqh/setai, connecting this clause with what follows. For kata\ nou=n=ex sententia, cf. Soph. O. C. 1768; kata\ no/on is not uncommon in Herodotus: cf. Dem. Ol. i. 14, kata\ gnw/mhn.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXI
div2.p: proqu/mws oi)/sein—‘to bear cheerfully, take part in with alacrity’: Hdt. ix. 18, proqu/mws fe/rete to\n po/lemon tou=ton: ib. 40, proqu/mws e)/feron to\n po/lemon. For the future cf. ch. 115, 8.

xrusw=| stefa/nw|—the special reward of public services: Dem. Androt. 617, ste/fanoi me/n ei)sin a)reth=s shmei=on...kai\ ste/fanos me
 a)/pas, ka)
 mikro\s h)=|, th
 i)shn filotimi/an e)/xei tw=| mega/lw|. a)ne/dhsan—v. 50, a)ne/dhse to
 h(ni/oxon.
e)taini/oun—bound his head with a taini/a or fillet, as an emblem of victory: Plat. Symp. 212 E, e)stefanwme/non...kai\ taini/as e)/xonta e)pi\ th=s kefalh=s.

prosh/rxonto—see note on ch. 120, 1, e)ph/rxonto. If this word comes from prose/rxomai, it means ‘came up to’, i. e. greeted and congratulated. We should however expect prosh=|san, which Cobet would restore to the text. Herbst and Classen take it from prosa/rxomai, ‘to offer’, meaning that they decked Brasidas with flowers and chaplets: cf. Plat. Theaet. 168C, proshrca/mhn...smikra\ a)po\ smikrw=n.

w(/sper a)qlhth=|—Grote observes that ‘the achievements, the self-relying march, the straightforward politics, and probity of this illustrious man inspired a personal emotion towards him such as rarely found its way into Grecian political life. The sympathy and admiration felt in Greece towards a victorious athlete was not merely an intense sentiment in the Grecian mind, but was perhaps, of all others, the most widespread and Panhellenic. ... Thucydides cannot convey a more lively idea of the enthusiasm and unanimity with which Brasidas was welcomed at Scione than by using this simile’.
The whole passage is imitated by Plutarch, Peric. 28, katabai/nonta de\ au)to\n...e)deciou=nto kai\ stefa/nois a)ne/doun kai\ tainiais w)/sper a)qlhth\n nikhforon.
e)perai/wse—here ‘took across’: so Plut. and Polyb.: in classical Greek usually ‘to cross’, as in ii. 67, to\n *(ellh/sponton peraiw/sein. Compare the twofold use of traicio.
a)popeira=sai—ch. 135, 1: mid. ch. 24, 8.
w(s e)s nh=son—the Athenians were especially jealous of their sovereign rights over the islanders, and regarded revolt on their part as inexcusable: cf. Cleon's speech iii. 39.

kai/ ti au)tw=|...e)s—‘and some negotiations were actually going on between him and these cities’: for construction with the dative and pro/s see note on ch. 80, 11: and for the constructions used with pra/ssw, ch. 76, 6.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXII
div2.p: e)gxeirh/sein—e)gxeirw= is used by Xenophon with the dat. in the sense of attacking, but not elsewhere in Thucydides: Krüger proposes e)pixeirh/sein, as in vi. 90.
periagge/llontes—‘carrying round notice of the armistice’.

h( me\n stratia/—Brasidas at once sent back the army (ch. 121, 11) to Torone, while he himself remained in the city with the Lacedaemonian garrison. The next clause implies that he accepted an official notice of the armistice.

a)nh/ggellon—a)nagge/llw is properly to ‘take back word’; Classen therefore takes its meaning to be that the envoys who had already announced the truce to Brasidas, came again to report the general acceptance of the arrangement (th\n cunqh/khn). The words of the text scarcely warrant this view; and it is not necessary to press the meaning of a)nagge/llw. There is however a slight awkwardness in the arrangement of the clauses.

toi=s me\n a)/llois kath/|nei—katainw= is nowhere else found with a simple dat., though it is sometimes used as in Soph. O.C. 432, tou=t' e)moi\ kath/|nesen. Here toi=s a)/llois seems to be the ethical dative, ‘in the case of the others he agreed’, i.e. agreed to accept them as allies of Sparta.
w(s pro/teron—sc. a)festh/koien. a)fi/ei—so viii. 41: ii. 49 h)fi/ei, where see Krüger: cf. Veitch. peri\ au)tw=n—neut.: ch. 18, 6, note.

a)ntepoiou=nto—‘claimed’, as against the Athenians. di/kh| kri/nesqai—of persons, ‘to have their claims legally decided’, i.e. to submit to arbitration: cf. i. 28, ei) de/ ti a)ntipoiou=ntai, di/kas h)/qelon dou=nai.
o)rgh\n poiou/menoi—Hdt. iii. 25, o)rgh\n poihsa/menos. For ei)=‘that’ cf. ch. 85, 23: here of course it gives the actual reason, but less positively and directly than o(/ti: see Lid. and Scott.

h)/dh—to be taken with a)ciou=si. The word stands out of place for the sake of emphasis, the idea being that there is indeed cause for indignation if the spirit of revolt has now reached even the islanders. Possibly however o)/ntes ought to be omitted.
a)nwfelei=—predicate,=a)nwfelei= ou)/sh|, ‘useless as it was’.
ei)=xe—with adv. of manner h)=|. e)dikai/oun—‘maintained’, ‘claimed’: v. 26, ei)/ tis mh\ a)ciw/sei...ou)k o)rqw=s dikaiw/sei.

*kle/wnos gnw/mh| peisqe/ntes—peisqe)ntes is absent from one manuscript, and possibly ought to be omitted, *qemistokle/ous gnw/mh| (i. 90)=‘on the motion of Themistocles’, being the usual form of expression. In i. 78 however we have a)llotri/ais gnw/mais kai\ e)gklhmasi peisqe/ntes.
e)celei=n—‘to take’: ch. 69, 6.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXIII
div2.p: o(/ti—‘in that’, to be taken with adikei=n. The sense is excellently given by Jowett: ‘Brasidas felt justified in receiving the Mendeans, although when they came to him the peace had unmistakably been declared, because there were certain points in which he too charged the Athenians with violating the treaty’. e)/sti ga\r a(/—cognate or determinant acc. with parabai/nein: cf. ch. 16, 18.

th/n te—corresponding to this is the gen. abs. construction kai\ a(/ma k.t.l. tekmairo/menoi—‘drawing their conclusion also from the fact that he would not give up Scione’. This is subordinate to o)rw=ntes and partly explanatory of it: so in i. 1, tekmairo/menos is subordinate to e)lpi/sas. For a)po/ cf. Ar. Vesp. 76, a)f' au(tou= th\n no/son tekmai/retai.

kai\ a(/ma k.t.l.—four genitives absolute follow, co-ordinate in construction, but scarcely so in meaning. The sense is equivalent to ‘and moreover the conspirators, who were few in number, did not relinquish their design, but in their fear of detection constrained the wishes of their countrymen’. See Poppo, who cites other instances of co-ordinate clauses thus strung together.
sfi/sin—‘on their part’, among them. w(s to/te e)me/llhsan—‘when they had once formed the intention’: i. 134, e)me/llhsan me\n...e)/peita, ‘they had intended’. to/te=as related, see ch. 121, fin.

a)ne/ntwn—‘giving up the design’: vi. 86, ou)k a)nia=si: i. 129, a)nei=nai pra/ssein. Classen may possibly be right in taking a)lla\ with kai\ katabiasame/nwn, and foboume/nwn as subordinate and explanatory ‘in their fear’; but the rhythm of the sentence is in favour of the view that the grammatical construction is co-ordinate throughout.
para\ gnw/mhn—‘contrary to their wishes’, or ‘their judgment’; see 128, 25.
u(pekkomi/zei—used in the middle by Hdt. and Xen. of bestowing one's own property in safe hiding; cf. i. 137, a(\ u(pece/keito: viii. 31, o)/sa u(pece/keito.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXIV
div2.p: to\ deu/teron—cf. ch. 83. *makedo/nwn—‘the Macedonians are here plainly distinguished from the Greeks, as in ch. 126, 17, they are even classed among barbarians. The royal family were of Hellenian and Dorian blood, but not the people’ (Arnold). The *)/ellhnes here spoken of may have been the inhabitants of maritime towns such as Therma and Pydna.

pro\s toi=s au)tou=—Brasidas had originally 1700 Peloponnesian men at arms (ch. 78). He had despatched 500 to Mende and Scione, and others were probably in garrison elsewhere; while some may have been lost in the course of the campaign. au)tou=—‘on the spot’, i.e. with him.
tw=n a)/llwn—sc. o(pli/tas (h)=gen). e(ka/stwn is not governed by du/namin, but agrees with tw=n a)/llwn.
cu/mpan de/—note the appositional construction of this clause and the next, which may be compared with the beginning of ch. 94.
o)li/gou—‘nearly’, sc. de/ontes: viii. 35, o)li/gou ei)=lon, ‘they all but took’; Ar. Ach. 381, o)li/gou a:pwlo/mhn. Here the manuscript reading is o)li/gw|, but all editors adopt o)li/gou.

tw=n pezw=n—the opposing infantry forces. The infantry on each side is o( pezo/s (ch. 25, 49); the plural designates more bodies than one. So nautika/ is ‘fleets’, not ‘a fleet’: and in Ar. Eth. Nic. iii. 7 (10). 9, ta\ politika/ means ‘national forces’ in general, not ‘a national force’.
pedi/ou—predicate: Krüger quotes Dem. Cal. 1274, to\ me/son o(do/s e)stin: Xen. Hell. vi. 4. 10, pedi/ou tou= metacu) o)/ntos. a)mfote)rwn—‘on both sides’, governed by i)pph=s.
e)/tuxon...me/llontes—cf. ch. 132, 7. For misqou= h(/cein cf. Xen. Mem. ii. 8. 2, misqou= e)rga/zesqai.
kaqh=sqai—so v. 7, e)n tw=| au)tw=| kaqhme/nous, of Cleon's army. periorw/menos—here=‘anxious about’, with gen., like fulassome/nous tw=n new=n, ch. 11, 19.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXV
div2.p: met' *)arribai/ou gege/nhntai—so Xen. Hell. iv. 8. 16, meta\ *lakedaimoni/wn gene/sqai: cf. ch. 113, 4, meta\ tw=n...h)=san w/ste refers to the whole following sentence, and is grammatically connected with e)xw/roun, line 12.

kurwqe\n d' ou)de/n—a noticeable instance of the acc. absolute personally constructed (=ou)deno\s kurwqe/ntos) without w(s: see Madvig § 182, R. 2: Goodwin § 110, 2: cf. Hdt. ii. 66, tau=ta de\ gigno/mena, pe/nqea mega/la tou\s *ai)gupti)ous katalamba/nei: Ar. Plut. 277, laxo\n to\ gra/mma: Plat. Phaedr. 265 D o)\ e)/stin, o(risqe/n. Here possibly the construction is assimilated to the preceding dokou=n, which itself is very rare, though analogous to e)co/n, prosh=kon, etc.
e)k th=s diafora=s—‘in consequence of the quarrel’.

o(/per filei=...e)kplh/gnusqai—instead of poiei=n, which might be expected, as in ii. 65, o(/per filei= o(/milos poiei=n, an infinitive is added explanatory of o(/per: so vi. 33, o(/per kai\ *)aqhnai=oi...hu)ch/qhsan: cf. Dem. Androt. 593, o(/per *eu)kth/mwn...o)/etai dei=n. The sense in these cases is given by rendering o(/per ‘just as’. In vii. 80, in a description of a similar panic, we have oi)=on filei=...fo/boi e)ggi/gnesqai. a)safw=s—‘without visible cause’. e)kplh/gnusqai is an exceptional form for e)kplhssesqai.
o)/son ou)/pw—so vi. 34: viii. 96, o(/son ou)k h)/dh e)no/mizon au)tou\s parei=nai.
e)kdro/mous—predicate, ‘to sally out’: so Xen. Hel. iv. 5. 16: see ch. 127, 6, e)kdromai/: ch. 34, 3, o)ce/ws e)pekqei=n.
teleutai=os—connected with u(poxwrw=n, as prw/tois is with proskeisome/nois: cf. ch. 38, 17. w(s dia\ taxe/wn—ch. 96, 4.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXVI
div2.p: tw=| te—dat. of the efficient cause, answered by a clause with o)/ti. memonw=sqai—cf. ii. 80, memonwme/nwn ei) krath/seian: also with gen. ‘deserted by’, ‘bereft of’.
e)/kplhcin e)/xein—this particular phrase is not used elsewhere: e)/xw in the sense of entertaining a feeling is not uncommon with such words as e)lpi/da, mi=sos, etc.

o(moi/ws—‘in the same way’ that I now do: ‘I should think only of encouraging and not of instructing you’ (Jowett). th=|—‘my’, the article implying that an encouraging speech was regular and expected: cf. the opening sentence of the speech in ch. 95: see also ii. 88, a chapter which in many expressions resembles the present one.
pro/s—‘looking at’: ‘now that we are left alone in the face of numerous enemies’ (Jowett). The first point is introduced by me/n, which is answered by barba/rous de/, line 15.
a)po/leiyin—‘defection’, with gen. of the subject: in vii. 75 with objective gen. tou= stratope/dou.
a)gaqoi=s...prosh/kei—‘valour in war is to be expected from you’: cf. note on ch. 92, 41, ta\s proshkou/sas a)reta/s. mhde\n plh=qos pefobh=sqai—cf. ii. 88, mhde/na o)/xlon u(poxwrei=n.
oi(/ ge mhde/—‘for also you do not come’, etc. o(/s ge =quippe qui; like o(/stis it is followed by mh/: viii. 76, oi(/ ge mh/te k.t.l.

e)n ai(=s ou) polloi/—the general sense is plain, but there is great awkwardness in the mode of expression. It has therefore been suggested to omit ou) or the preceding mhde/: or else to read e)n oi)=s=a)ll' e)n u(mi=n. Words of denying however are commonly followed by a redundant and untranslatable negative, and possibly this sentence comes under the same head. The speaker forgets that he has already cast his statement in a negative form; he passes on to the character of the constitutions which he has in his mind, and in the clause with ou) insists on the denial which has been already made. Arnold compares ii. 62, where ma=llon h)\ ou) follows a negative and is equivalent to ‘rather than’. See the Appendix to Buttmann's Meidias ‘de abundantia negationis’.

Krüger and others connect the negative force of mhde/ solely with toiou/twn, and refer the latter to what has gone before, ‘not such’ as those in which men fear a multitude. So Jowett, ‘you come from cities of another kind, and in those cities etc.’ This explanation, as Poppo points out, is not without harshness, ‘cum toiou/twn ai(=s inter se cohaerere nemo non suspicari debeat’. In vi. 68 we have ou)k e)n patri/di, e)c h)=s k.t.l. which may be explained as=e)n tg=| mh\ patri/di, or a)lla\ e)n tau/th| may be understood before e)c h(=s, as indeed, a)lla\ e)k tou/twn might be supplied in the present passage. Classen cites other instances in which a negative is put before a preposition, e.g. ii. 67, mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn.
barba/rous—note the emphatic position of the word, and the absence of the article; ‘as for barbarians, etc.’

e)c w(=n te—‘from the struggle you have already had with those of them who are Macedonians’. The Lyncestae are meant, who had just been easily defeated. For the construction of au)tw=n cf. ch. 61, 11. kai\ a)f' w(=n—Donaldson points out that the difference between a)po/ and e/c, signifying respectively motion from the surface of an object and motion from within an object, is illustrated by this passage, ‘where e)c denotes the experience, and a)po/ the testimonies, which are more external’.

ei)ka/zw—the manuscripts are in favour of ei)ka/zwn, but a word implying mere conjecture can not well be connected with e)pi/stamai, but stands in contrast to it: cf. vi. 92, ta\ me\n...oi(/da, ta\ de\...h)/|kazon: see other instances in Poppo's critical note, a)koh=| on the other hand is not uncommonly joined with words of knowing: i. 4, w(=n a)koh=| i)/smen: vi. 65, ei)dw\s a)koh=| a)kribe)steron. (e)pi/stamai is used by Hdt. of mere belief.)

o(/sa me/n...oi(=s de/—here, as in ch. 117, 16, there seems an inversion of the usual order of clauses with me/n and de/. The sense is ‘true information about a really weak enemy emboldens the assailant; though, no doubt, one might attack a really strong foe more boldly if in ignorance of his strength’. There is a somewhat similar inversion in line 37, and again the last sentence of this chapter.
o(/sa...tw=n polemi/wn—nearly equivalent to o(/soi pole/mioi, but less definite. The next clause is constructed as if o(/sa were equivalent to ei)/ tina: cf. Poppo on i. 22.
do/khsin—‘impression’, aestimatio. e)/xei is therefore to be understood in the sense noted on ch. 1, 7: cf. ch. 87, 4, do/khsin pare/xetai.
th\n me/llhsin—what they are going to do, or threaten to do: i. 69, ou) th=| duna/mei a)lla\ th=| mellh/sei a)muno/menoi.
plh/qei o)/yews—lit. ‘from magnitude of appearance’, i.e. from the imposing effect of their numbers.
dia\ kenh=s—adverbial=‘empty’: Eur. Troad. 753, dia\ kenh=s e)ce/qreye: Ar. Vesp. 929, dia\ kenh=s a)/llws. For fem. adj. see note on ch. 33, 6, e)c e)nanti/as.
au)ta/—‘all this’: ch. 18, 7, note on au)to/.

ou)/te ga/r—‘they have not that feeling of military honour which comes from regular order’. For similar sentences see Krüger on i. 12, w(/ste mh\ h(suxa/sasan au)chqh=nai, ‘so that it could not settle down and grow’: so i. 84, ou)de\n ma=llon a)xqesqe/nte a)nepei/sqhmen.

xw/ran—of a soldier's post: ii. 87, xw/ran mh\ prols pontes: cf. Tac. Germ. 6, cedere loco, dummodo rursus instes consilii quam formidinis arbitrantur. See other passages cited by Poppo from Tacitus and Caesar, descriptive of the irregular warfare of barbarians.
a)nece/legkton—used in i. 21, of mythical stories, the truth of which ‘can not be tested’. au)tokra/twr—here ‘independent’: cf. ch. 108, 27. prepo/ntws—‘creditably’, without dishonour.
to\ e)kfobh/sein—see Goodwin § 27, on the fut. infinitive. The sense is ‘the chance of frightening, the attempt to frighten’. e)kei/nw| ga\r a)/n—‘for otherwise’ etc.: cf. ch. 54, 17.

to\ prou+pa/rxon deino/n—i.e. numbers, threatening demonstrations etc., as explained before; deino/n being generally that which there is reason to dread. With the construction with a)po/ may be compared vi. 86, th\n u(pa/rxousan a)p' a)llh/lwn a)mfote/rois (swthri/an): cf. metus ab, spes ab, etc.
e)/rgw| me\n...o)/yei de/—see above, line 19, note.

kataspe/rxon—cf. Ar. Ach. 1188, kataspe/rxwn dori/, where the word is said on the authority of Hesychius to be equivalent to kataplh/sswn. It is very rare: cf. ch. 12, 2, e)pe/sperxe. The Homeric spe/rxw is only used intransitively.

e)pifero/menon—predicate, answered by o(/tan kairo\s h)=|: Brasidas calls on his men to withstand the first onslaught, and make good their retreat when the enemy draws off. u(pagago/ntes—‘retreating’: v. 10, u(pa/gein e)pi\ th=s *)hio/nos: transitive in the first line of ch. 127.
mellh/sei—cf. line 24: the dat. is constructed, like a)peilai=s, with e)pikompou=si, and is added for additional emphasis: cf. ch. 87, 17.

oi(\ d' a)\n ei)/cwsin—‘though, when men have once given way’. kata\ po/das—of following closely: v. 64, i)e/nai kata\ po/das au(tw=n: cf. iii. 98. Here kata\ po(das is contrasted with a)/poqen, and the remaining words are antithetically balanced against the corresponding clause.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXVII
div2.p: diafqei/rein—possibly diafqerei=n should be read; otherwise nomi/santes is to be supplied in a different sense: see note on ch. 117, 7.
au)toi=s—grammatically dependent on a)ph/ntwn, but in sense connected with all the following clauses as far as line 10, =‘when they found themselves met’ etc.

e)kdromai/—cf. ch. 125, 21, e)kdro/mous e)/tace. Here the abstract substantive denotes either the sallies made by these soldiers, or the actual bodies of e)/kdromoi,=oi) tetagme/noi pro\s to\ e)ktre/xein. Arnold compares ch. 128, 6: also viii. 102, tw=| filiw| e)pi/plw|, ‘the fleet of their friends who were e)piple/ontes’.

e)pikeime/nous—sc. au)tou/s, ‘when they pressed on him’: Hdt. v. 81, e)pikeime/nwn *boiwtoi=si: cf. e)/gkeimai and pro/skeimai, which are common in Thucydides. This chapter is rich in words of attack and defence.
para\ gnw/mhn—contrary to what the barbarians expected. a)nte/sthsan—sc. Brasidas and his picked men.
prosba/llein—inf. to be explained as in ch. 36, 5.

e)s th\n *)arribai/ou—part of the main description is thrown into the relative clause: cf. note on ch. 113, 8, ai)= e)frou/roun du/o. Brasidas apparently had to ascend a narrow gorge, which the barbarians occupied in advance by moving along the sides; see Arnold, and note on ch. 83, 7. to\ a)/poron—probably a part where the pass narrowed, and possibly ascended steeply.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXVIII
div2.p: o(\n...tw=n lo/fwn—the lo/foi are the sides of the pass; one of which was more accessible than the other. The subject of e(lei=n is of course Brasidas. pro\s au)to/n—answers to the relative, as in ch. 126, 21.

e)po/ntas—the manuscript reading is e)pio/ntas, which may be explained as meaning either ‘advancing to occupy the height’, or ‘advancing to attack the Lacedaemonians’. But e)po/ntas agrees better with the context, especially with e)kkrou=sai and the subsequent words e)kra/thsan tw=n e(pi\ tou= lo/fou: see ch. 131, 6, where the same question arises.
pri\n prosmi=cai—i.e. before the whole barbarian force could come up to hem them in. sfw=n is governed by the active word ku/klwsin: cf. ch. 35, 12 and 131, 4.
pro\s au)to/n—sc. to\n lo/fon. The Greeks having now cleared one side of the pass would easily gain the head, which may have been level and open.
au)toi=s—‘finding their men dislodged on this point from the height’ (Arnold): for dat. cf. ch. 10, 13 etc.
a)ntela/beto—lit. ‘laid hold of’, i.e. gained or reached: iii. 22, with tou= a)sfalou=s: vii. 77, with fili/as xw/ras.
*)/arnissan—mentioned by Ptolemy (2nd cent. A.D.), but otherwise unknown. prw=ton is adverbial, and does not govern th=s a)rxh=s: cf. ch. 78, 41.
au)toi/—‘of themselves’, without any orders. zeu/gesi boeikoi=s—carts with oxen: Xen. Anab. vii. 5. 2. skeu/ei refers to baggage generally. fobera=|—hurried, in a panic.
oi)kei/wsin e)poiou=nto—‘appropriated’: Classen notes the semi-comic effect of this unusual periphrasis. oi)keiou=sqai is less uncommon in the same sense.

th=| me\n gnw/mh—‘not congenial to his judgment’. gnw/mh here is the ‘mind or judgment’, or else the ‘opinion’ of what was expedient, which had hitherto determined Perdiccas. The meaning is further explained by di' *)aqhnai/ous. It was fear of Athens which had made it his ‘habitual principle’ to court the Spartan alliance; but now his injuries made him forget his interests. The opposition with me/n and de/ is between the dictates of political conviction and of personal feeling.

tw=n de\ a)nagkai/wn—‘departing from his urgent (necessary) interests’. The compound dianasta/s, as Classen notes, expresses very well the idea of a new and divergent policy. It is not found elsewhere in Attic Greek: dii/stasqai is more common.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXIX
div2.p: u(po\ ga/r—explanatory of katalamba/nei *)aqhnai/ous k.t l. For the force of the imperf. pareskeua/zonto cf. note on ch. 2, 7: see ch. 123, 15.

sxo/ntes kata/—‘landing at, or over against’: so i. 110: vi. 97: more commonly with e)s or the dat. as noted on ch. 3, 6. Posidonium, or Posideum, seems to have been a point facing south-west, not far from Mende, which was situated about half way along the western side of the isthmus of Pallene.
cu/mpantes—‘in all’; de/ is added somewhat unusually. e)cestratopedeume/noi—outside the city: some manuscripts have e)stratopedeume/noi. The compound is rare, but occurs Xen. Cyr. vi. 3. 1.
traumatizo/menos—i.e. his troops received wounds: so i. 63, ballo/menos kai\ xalepw=s. Had Nicias himself been meant, we should have traumatisqei/s.
e)k plei/onos—of space, ‘from further off’, i.e. by a longer way.
e)s o)li/gon—‘within a little’, with inf., an unusual phrase: cf. ch. 106, 20.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXX
div2.p: periplei/santes—the Athenians had hitherto made their attack from the side towards Potidaea. They now sailed round the headland of Posidonium and landed between it and the extreme point of Pallene. Scione was just round this point. For pro\s *skiw/nhs cf. ch. 31, 6.

h)=n ti kai/—so ch. 28, 26, ti kai\ ge/lwtos. stasiasmou=— viii. 94, pro\s to\n paro/nta stasiasmo/n: a rare word. We have seen (ch. 123) that the revolutionary party in Mende was small. The Scioneans probably departed to defend their own territory.
a(/ma—this word seems intended to connect the operations of the two commanders: Krüger however takes it simply with proi+w/n, ‘as he advanced he laid waste the land’.

ta\s a)/nw pu/las—inland and northwards. e)/tuxe...kei/mena—‘during a siege the arms of the citizens were kept constantly piled in one or more of the open spaces within the walls, that on any sudden alarm they might assemble there, and at once arm themselves, and be marshalled in their proper divisions. In fact the city for the time became a camp, and therefore, like a camp, had a place where the arms were regularly piled, and which served all the purposes of a parade. Compare viii. 69, and Xen. Anab. ii. 2. 20: iii. 1. 3’ (Arnold) The phrase ti/qesqai ta\ o(/pla has been discussed on ch. 44, 6. kei=mai is equivalent to the perfect passive of ti/qhmi.
kata\ to\ stasiwtiko/n—either generally ‘in the spirit of party’, or particularly referring to the sta/sis prevailing in the town.

ou\de\ de/oito polemei=n—‘and that he (the speaker) did not wish for war’. There is no necessity to take de/oito here as impersonal: see note on ch. 69, 14. Poppo says ‘malis de/oi’, and Krüger suggests de/ointo, making the speaker say ou)de\n deo/meqa: cf. Xen. Hel. ii. 4. 35, le/gontes o(/ti ou)de\n de/ontai toi=s e)n tw=| *peiraiei= polemei=n. The optative joined with the indicative is one of innumerable instances. Here, the indicative refers to a particular point of time, while the optative is more general; but though such an explanation may often be found, this is by no means always the case, and the variation seems merely due to the Greek dislike of rigid uniformity.
e)pispasqe/ntos—the commander seized the man, to drag him away or drag him on to the gate. qorubhqe/ntos implies rough handling, not mere interruption: cf. ch. 129, 28.
fobhqe/ntwn—sc. au)tw=n: irregular gen. absolute, as in ch. 73, 15. a)po\ proeirhme/nou—‘from previous arrangement’: so ch. 67, 24, a)po\ cunqh/matos: i. 133, a)po\ paraskeuh=s.
au)toi/—cf. ch. 113, 10.

e)s th\n *me/ndhn po/lin—the manuscript reading. Dobree and others omit *me/ndhn as being a marginal note which has got into the text. The order of words is like kata\ to\n *)akesi/nhn potamo/n ch. 25, 33. Classen omits e)s, and connects the accusative with the words which follow, comparing ch. 68, 21 etc., where e)spi/ptein alone means to force an entrance. e(spi/ptein e(s however is quite common, as in ii. 4.
a(/te ou)k—the usual construction, as a(/te states a fact.

e)pikaqi/stanto—I have adopted the emendation which Poppo and Krüger approve, two inferior manuscripts having e)pekaqi/stanto. Most manuscripts however have e)pekaqi/santo, aor. mid. in transitive sense, ‘established for themselves’. The word is unusual, and the form suspicious, as Thucydides elsewhere writes not e)ka/qisa but kaqi=sa, as in vi. 66.

In Dem. Apatur. 897, parekaqi/sato is read; but apart from this instance e)ka/qisa and e)kaqisa/mhn have scarcely any authority, as may be seen from Veitch's Greek Verbs. e)kaqezo/mhn and e)kaqh/mhn on the other hand are quite common.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXXI
div2.p: ou)k e)gi/gneto—‘they could not be walled round’: cf. ch. 9, 26. The clause represents what the men of Scione thought (h)\n mh\ e(/lwsi...ou) gi/gnetai h)mw=n k.t.l.). For sfw=n cf. ch. 128, 7 etc.
e)po/ntas—so one MS., the rest have e)pio/ntas: cf. ch. 128.
oi( e)k—such uses of the preposition are common enough; here however the additional poliorkou/menoi is noticeable.
para\ qa/lassan—Classen follows the scholiast in connecting this with a)fiknou=ntai. Jowett however seems right in translating ‘forcing their way out by the sea-shore’.
diafugo/ntes—ch. 19, 8: with acc. ii. 90, mh\ diafu/goien to\n e)pi/ploun. to\ e)pi\ th=| *skiw/nh|—the blockading force: cf. ch. 14, 32, e(pi\ th=| *pu/lw|.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXXII
div2.p: dia\ th\n e)/xqran—see ch. 128, 24. The original quarrel, described in ch. 83, can not be meant, as some commentators hold. For then there was no retreat e)k th=s *au/gkou, as Brasidas did not enter the country: besides, Thucydides expressly says a)po\ tou/tou prw=ton k.t.l. in ch. 128.

kai\ e)tugxane ga\r...o( de/—Arnold seems right in regarding this as a case of de/ ‘in apodosis’ resuming the narration after a parenthesis, ‘so Perdiccas’ etc. the main verb being diekw/luse: see i. 11; vii. 33, etc. Krüger follows Dobree in omitting de/: cf. iii. 70, kai\, h)=n ga)r *peiqi/as..., u/pa/gousin au)to/n k.t.l.
poreu/sein—the act. is rare in prose: Plat. Phaed. 107 E, tou\s e)nqe/nde e)kei=se poreu=sai.

e)/ndhlo/n ti poiei=n—to give some proof of his friendship. The fickle character of Perdiccas naturally made Nicias wish to commit him to the Athenian side by some overt act. paraskeua/sas—iii. 36, paraskeua/sas tou\s e)n te/lei. xrw/menos—see ch. 78, 11, for the influence of Perdiccas with the Thessalian chiefs.

au)tw=n—partitive gen. dependent on h(bw/ntwn which in its turn depends on a)/ndras, ‘certain men’. parano/mws—‘contrary to (Spartan) usage’ (cf. no/mw|), which was to send men of mature age on political missions. The h(bw=ntes, as Grote points out, were probably men of military age. This is the first germ of the institution of Harmosts; see Arnold's note. The word a(rmosth/s is used for the first time in viii. 5 (B.C. 413).

toi=s e)ntuxou=sin—‘to any that came in their way’: Dem. Meid. 543 and 573, of ‘coming in one's way, crossing one's path’: cf. also note on ch. 40, 13. oi( tuxo/ntes is the more usual Attic expression for ‘such as chance, any casual or ordinary person’.
*pasiteli/dan—the manuscripts have *)epiteli/dan, but Pasitelidas is mentioned three times in v. 3 as governor of Torone.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXXIII
div2.p:
tei=xos periei=lon—ch. 51, 1. e)pikale/santes—v. 59, ei)/ ti e)pikalou=sin *)argei/ois: so i. 139. boulo/menoi...paresthko/s— imperf. part., ‘they had been desirous all along’, connected with acc. absolute. paresthko/s requires the sense of an opportunity ‘presenting itself’; and several editors propose paresxhko/s, comparing ch. 85, 10: i. 120, eu)= parasxo/n. However in
Hdt. i. 23 we have tw=| dh\ le/gousi qwu=ma me/giston parasth=nai, and the sound of paresxhko/s is certainly not in its favour. For the general use of pari/stasqai in Thucydides cf. ch. 61, 11.
e)n th=|...ma/xh|—see ch. 96, 14, where we find that the Thespians bore the brunt of the Athenian attack.

o(/ ti h)=n—Cobet would read o(/ ti/ per as the proper form: so Plat. Rep. 492 E, o(/ ti/ per a)\n swqh=|. a)/nqos is not found elsewhere in this sense in Attic prose: Aesch. Prom. 420, *)arabi/as a)/reion a)/nqos: Pers. 59 etc.: cf. flos, which is common.

e)n *)/argei—the temple was between Argos and the ruins of Mycenae, and nearer to the latter; so that e)n is used of the neighbourhood, as noted on ch. 5, 5, or *)/argos is to be understood of the district generally.

e)pe/laben—‘attained to’; lit. ‘caught up’. e)k me/sou —‘midway’: for this adverbial use of e)k cf. v. 20, e)c h)misei/as, ‘in halves’. The Argives reckoned by the priestess's year of office; and we find that at the beginning of the war Chrysis had held office forty-eight years (ii. 2).
*skiw/nh...perietetei/xisto—Scione held out till the summer of 421. Its fate is related in v. 32.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXXIV
div2.p: ta\ me/n...h(su/xaze—cf. ch. 23, 11, ta\ peri\ *pu/lon e)polemei=to.

th=s *)oresqi/dos—‘in the territory of *)ore/sqeion’: v. 64, e)xw/roun de\ e)s *)ore/sqeion th=s *mainali/as. Pausanias says that the town of Oresthasium, which is probably the same place, was on the way leading from Megalopolis to Pallantium and Tegea. The battle seems to have been fought in the valley of the Alpheus, near where Megalopolis was afterwards built; see Arnold.
ni/kh—Poppo suggests h( ni/kh. a)mfidh/ritos is used by Polybius, but only here in classical Greek.

ke/ras to\ kaq' au(tou/s—apparently each army routed the adversary's allies. a)gxwma/lou—vii. 71, a)gxw/mala e)nauma/xoun: iii. 49, e)ge/nonto e)n th=| xeirotoni/a| a)gxw/maloi. a)felome/nhs—‘broke off, stopped’: Aesch. Pers. 428, nukto\s o)/mm' a)fei/leto.
e)phuli/santo—as being masters of the field: iii. 5, ou)/te e)phuli/santo ou)/te e)pi/steusan sfi/sin au)toi=s.

div2.head: CHAPTER CXXXV
div2.p: o( *brasi/das—the singular order of the words in this sentence seems due to a wish to bring in the subject of the verb. The concluding sentence of iii. 90 is very similar.
pro\s e)/ar—v. 56, teleutw=ntos tou= xeimw=nos pro\s e)/ar h)/dh: v. 17, pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh.
me/xri me\n tou/tou—sc. tou= kli/maka prosqei=nai. Krüger suggests me/xri me/n tou, ‘to a certain point’, citing Dem. i. Olynth. 11 etc.

kw/dwnos—here the bell was passed by each sentry in turn to the next in order. Another practice was for an officer to go on his rounds with a bell, as noted in Ar. Av. 842, kwdwnoforw=n peri/trexe. to\ dia/kenon is explained by pri\n e)panelqei=n, i.e. before the sentry who was then carrying the bell on could return to his regular post.

ai)sqome/nwn—gen. abs. as in ch. 3, 8. prosbh=nai implies not merely approach, but ‘getting at’ or ‘getting on’ the ramparts: so iii. 22, e(/pws prosbai/noien, of the Plataean attempt to force the enemy's lines.
